在陈列室里摆放鲜花而不是汽车的汽车经销商。 有关实用性的问题只会将他推向新的极端。 “我看不出为什么你需要每三个月在办公室花超过六分钟的时间，”他告诉欧洲之星伦敦-巴黎火车服务的负责人。 “上那条铁路。”

car dealer who put flowers rather than automobiles in his showroom. Questions about practicalities only push him to new extremes. "I see no reason why you need to spend more than six minutes every three months in your office," he tells the head of the Eurostar London-Paris train service. "Get on that railroad."

骆驼因素

The Llama Factor

彼得斯非凡的声望对他的职业来说是喜忧参半。 许多人只需要阅读他的一篇专栏文章或观看他的一场电视表演，就会加倍对管理理论的偏见。 一个 50 多岁的男人怎么能这样炫耀？ 一个有自尊的专栏作家怎么能滔滔不绝地谈论他对健步走的嗜好或他妻子的禅宗呢？ 一个人怎么能通过希望一群高级管理人员“吵闹和搞砸”来结束一天呢？ 仿佛是为了嘲讽他的批评者，彼得斯在他的一本书《汤姆·彼得斯研讨会：疯狂时代呼唤疯狂组织》（1994 年）的封面上画了一张他穿着平角短裤的照片。 他还将这本书献给他的母亲，“一个说话的人养了一个说话的人”。 彼得斯的书中充斥着诸如“哇”之类的短语， “哎呀”和“哼哼”。 “从字面上看，他不是爱德华·吉本，”正如他自己所说的那样。

Peters's extraordinary prominence is a mixed blessing for his profession. Many people only have to read one of his columns or watch one of his television performances to have their prejudices about management theory redoubled. How can a man in his 50s parade around like that? How can a self-respecting columnist run on about his penchant for power-walking or his wife's Zen Buddhism? How can somebody finish a day by wishing a group of senior managers "loud times and lots of screw-ups"? As if to taunt his critics, Peters illustrated the cover of one of his books, The Tom Peters Seminar: Crazy Times Call for Crazy Organizations (1994), with a picture of himself in his boxer shorts. He also dedicated the book to his mother, "a talker who raised a talker." Peters's books are littered with phrases like "wow," "yikes," and "ho-hum." "Prosewise, he is no Edward Gibbon," as he himself might put it.

然而，除了他的怪癖之外，彼得斯还有很多其他的东西。 诚然，他在过去十年里自相矛盾，但这部分是因为企业界在过去十年里发生了翻天覆地的变化。 诚然，他喜欢匆匆忙忙地撰写相当脆弱的报纸专栏（还有谁会利用《金融时报》的客座位置来教读者呼吸放松练习呢？）； 然而他也写了一个令人钦佩的默默无闻的博士学位。 论文，并继续为《加州管理评论》等重量级（且无偿）学术期刊撰写文章。 他愿意咆哮和狂欢来表达他的观点； 但他说服了更多的经理人比几乎所有在世的人都更仔细地思考他们正在做的事情。

There is, however, a lot more to Peters than his peculiarities. Admittedly, he has contradicted himself spectacularly over the past decade, but that is partly because the corporate world has changed spectacularly over the past decade. True, he has a penchant for dashing off fairly flimsy newspaper columns (who else would use a guest spot in the Financial Times to teach readers breathing-relaxation exercises?); yet he also wrote an admirably obscure Ph.D. thesis and continues to churn out articles for heavyweight (and unremunera-tive) academic periodicals like the California Management Review. He is willing to rant and rave to get his point across; but he has persuaded more managers to think a little bit more carefully about what they are doing than almost anyone else alive.

即使是对彼得斯最严厉的批评者，也应该愿意承认两件对他有利的事情。 首先，他具有非凡的才能，可以让管理这样枯燥的话题变得有趣起来。 他的所有书名——《解放管理》、《追求卓越的激情》、《在混乱中求胜》——的引人注目之处在于，它们传达了他对

Even Peters's harshest critics should be willing to concede two things in his favor. First, he has a remarkable talent for making a dull subject like management sound interesting. What is noticeable about all the titles of his books— Liberation Management, A Passion for Excellence, Thriving on Chaos —is that they convey his fascination with

汤姆彼得斯

Tom Peters

他的主题。 其次，他对企业生活有着深入的了解，不仅在美国，而且在欧洲和环太平洋地区； 不仅在董事会，而且在营销部门和机械车间； 不仅在像索尼和 IBM 这样的巨头中，而且在无数其他人似乎无法追踪的小公司中也是如此。 如果没有找到一个有趣的管理角度，他就无法预订酒店、乘坐飞机或停车。 Crazy Times 中最好的故事之一是关于 Valerio's，这是他在新西兰偶然发现的一家古怪的意大利餐厅，该餐厅拒绝在外面张贴菜单，并陷害失望的顾客的投诉。

his subject. Second, he has an intimate knowledge of corporate life, not just in the United States but also in Europe and around the Pacific rim; not just in the boardroom, but also in the marketing department and in the machine shop; not just in the giants like Sony and IBM, but also in countless small companies that nobody else seems able to track down. He cannot book into a hotel, fly in an aircraft, or park his car without finding an interesting management angle. One of the best stories in Crazy Times is about Valerio's, an eccentric Italian restaurant he stumbled across in New Zealand that refuses to post menus outside and frames complaints from disappointed customers.

在成为管理大师之前，彼得斯设法在越南作战，并在五角大楼和华盛顿特区的管理与预算办公室工作。他还获得了斯坦福商学院的 MBA 学位。 但他接受的培训中最重要的两个部分是他的工程学本科学位，以及他在麦肯锡担任顾问的时间。 Peters 始终保持着顾问的能力，他可以设法进入数百家公司，并且具有工程师对事物实际运作方式的好奇心。

Before becoming a management guru, Peters managed to fight in Vietnam and work for both the Pentagon and the Office of Management and Budget in Washington D.C. He also picked up an MBA from Stanford Business School. But the two most important parts of his training were his undergraduate degree in engineering and then the time he spent as a consultant with McKinsey. Peters has always retained a consultant's ability to inveigle his way into hundreds of companies and an engineer's curiosity about how things actually work.

换句话说，彼得斯比他最初看起来要复杂得多，也更有成就。 尽管如此，如果在他的佛蒙特州农场周围漫游的通常和平的骆驼群变得令人讨厌并将他们的主人踩死，彼得斯会有一个令人不安的墓志铭：他所做的 - 发起，领导和定义当前的大师热潮-比他实际所说的更重要，其中大部分后来被证明是错误的或被彼得斯本人反驳。 该判断包含对彼得斯的相当严厉的批评，我们将在本章后面尝试证实这一点。 但它也包含补语。 彼得斯崇拜的商业英雄中很少有人像彼得斯那样改变了他们的行业。 就目前的管理理论热潮有一个开始日期而言， 它与《追求卓越》一起出版； 就它的主持天才而言，他让争论不断进行，让伪装者不断涌现，那就是汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters)。

In other words, Peters is a much more complicated and accomplished man than he first seems. All the same, if the normally peaceful herd of llamas that roam around his Vermont farm were to turn nasty and trample their owner to death, Peters would have an uncomfortable epitaph: that what he did—launching, leading, and defining the current guru boom—was more significant than what he actually said, much of which was subsequently either proved wrong or contradicted by Peters himself. That judgment contains a fairly damning criticism of Peters, which we will try to substantiate later in this chapter. But it also contains a complement. Few of the business heroes Peters worships have changed their industry in the same way that Peters has his. Insofar as the current management theory boom has a starting date, it is with the publication of In Search of Excellence; and insofar as it has a presiding genius who keeps the arguments rolling and the pretenders coming, it is Tom Peters.

一个美好的开始

An Excellent Beginning

在 20 世纪 70 年代后期，麦肯锡决定投入大量资金开展一项关于“优秀公司”的研究项目。 彼得斯和另一位顾问吉姆贝内特被选中审查

In the late 1970s McKinsey decided to pour a substantial amount of money into a research project on the "excellent company." Peters and another consultant, Jim Bennett, were chosen to review the

先知和布道者

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST

关于“组织效能”的现有文献。 他们得出结论，理论家传统上对战略和结构的重视已经超出了收益递减的范围，而其他更软的因素，如管理风格和“文化”，对成功也至关重要。 这是相对有争议的事情，因为大多数麦肯锡人都沉浸在战略和结构的知识中。 年轻研究人员的项目只有在另外三个人加入后才开始：罗伯特·沃特曼，一位更有经验的麦肯锡人，以及两位商学院教授，​​安东尼·阿托斯，企业文化专家，以及理查德·帕斯卡尔，他们多年来一直在进行比较研究美国和日本公司。 彼得斯和沃特曼决定将这个项目写成一本书。

existing literature on "organizational effectiveness." The emphasis that theorists had traditionally placed on strategy and structure, they concluded, had gone beyond the point of diminishing returns, and other, softer factors, such as management style and "culture," were also crucial to success. This was relatively controversial stuff since most McKinsey men were steeped in the lore of strategy and structure. The young researchers' project only took off when three other people joined: Robert Waterman, a more experienced McKinseyite, and two business school professors, Anthony Athos, a specialist on corporate culture, and Richard Pascale, who had for years been conducting comparative research on American and Japanese companies. Peters and Waterman decided to write up the project as a book.

为什么 In Search of Excellence 做得这么好？ 一方面，它基于大量证据，至少远非严格的管理科学标准。 但它也展示了可能被称为“彼得斯现象”的四个主要成分：不可思议的时间感、表达当下情绪的非凡能力、提出听起来很实用的建议的技巧，以及惊人的营销天赋 正如彼得斯欣然承认的那样，时机“纯属运气”。 2 该书出版于 1982 年 10 月，当月美国失业率达到 10%，自大萧条以来首次突破两位数。 在大量介绍日本管理奇迹的书籍出现后，《追求卓越》也问世了。

Why did In Search of Excellence do so well? For one thing, it was based on a formidable amount of evidence, at least by the far from exacting standards of management science. But it also acted as a showcase for the four main ingredients of what might be called the "Peters phenomenon": an uncanny sense of timing, an extraordinary ability to articulate the mood of the moment, the skill to dispense advice that sounds practical, and a breathtaking talent for marketing. As Peters readily admits, the timing was "pure luck." 2 The book appeared in October 1982, the month that American unemployment hit 10 percent and the first time it had broken the double-digit barrier since the Great Depression. In Search of Excellence also came out after a glut of books on the wonders of Japanese management.

事实上，这本书似乎完美地吸引了一个担心其竞争力下降但又厌倦了被告知日本奇迹的美国。 与许多其他权威人士一样，彼得斯和沃特曼一致认为，美国经理人对他们国家的困境负有大部分责任，这要归功于他们对短期的痴迷以及对质量和服务的漠不关心。 3 然而，他们认为，美国人不必千方百计地向日本学习如何经营优秀公司和重振国家竞争力的模式。 他们指出，美国拥有许多生产新产品、开拓新工艺并加班加点以满足其所有选民——客户、员工、股东和广大公众的公司。 4 彼得斯和沃特曼因此吹响了“

Indeed, the book seemed perfectly designed to appeal to an America that was worried about its declining competitiveness but tired of being told about the Japanese miracle. Like many other pundits, Peters and Waterman agreed that American managers bore much of the blame for their country's plight, thanks to their obsession with the short term and their indifference to quality and service. 3 However, they argued that Americans did not have to look all the way to Japan for models of how to run excellent companies and revive national competitiveness. America, they pointed out, possessed a host of companies that were producing new products, pioneering new processes, and working overtime to satisfy all their constituents—customers, employees, shareholders, and the public at large. 4 Peters and Waterman thus sounded the "morning in America" theme two years before Ronald Reagan used it to seal his reelection. And like "the great communicator," they trumpeted the

汤姆彼得斯

Tom Peters

美国人的能力，靠自己的毅力和头脑，解决任何问题。

abilities of Americans, relying on their own grit and brains, to solve any problem.

优秀公司的调查结果是一个乐观的信息。 美国传来好消息。 今天的良好管理实践并不仅仅存在于日本。 但是，更重要的是，好消息来自于体面地对待人们并要求他们发光，以及来自于生产出有用的东西。 规模效率让位于员工热情的小单位。 旨在大爆炸产品的精确计划的研发工作被专门拥护者的军队所取代。 对成本的麻木关注让位于对质量的高度关注。 等级制度和三件套让位于名字、衬衫袖子、喧嚣和基于项目的灵活性。 根据厚厚的规则书工作被每个人的贡献所取代。 5个

The findings from the excellent companies amount to an upbeat message. There is good news from America. Good management practice today is not resident only in Japan. But, more important, the good news comes from treating people decently and asking them to shine, and from producing things that work. Scale efficiencies give way to small units with turned-on people. Precisely planned R&D efforts aimed at big bang products are replaced by armies of dedicated champions. A numbing focus on cost gives way to an enhancing focus on quality. Hierarchy and three-piece suits give way to first names, shirtsleeves, hoopla, and project-based flexibility. Working according to fat rule books is replaced by everyone's contributing. 5

这本书还有另一个优点：简单。 尽管进行了所有研究，但《追求卓越》有时读起来就像一本流行的操作指南书。 例如，Peters 和 Waterman 列出了优秀公司的八个易于识别（并且令人难忘）的特征，例如“坚持编织”（即专注于公司最擅长的事情并将其他一切外包给其他专家），同时创造松紧控制系统（即集中核心价值但分散实现核心价值的方式），并贴近客户。 正如彼得·德鲁克 (Peter Drucker) 所说，《追求卓越》让管理听起来“非常简单。你所要做的就是把那本书放在枕头下，它就会完成。” 6个

The book had another virtue: simplicity. For all the research that went into it, In Search of Excellence sometimes reads like a popular how-to book. For example, Peters and Waterman list eight easily identifiable (and memorably expressed) characteristics of excellent companies, such as "sticking to the knitting" (i.e., concentrating on what the firm does best and contracting out everything else to other specialists), creating simultaneous loose-tight control systems (i.e., centralizing core values but decentralizing the way they are achieved), and staying close to the customer. As Peter Drucker has put it, In Search of Excellence made management sound "incredibly easy. All you had to do was put that book under your pillow and it will get done." 6

彼得斯和沃特曼使管理理论民主化，将其从首席执行官及其董事会的垄断转变为初级经理需要掌握的东西。 对于一本商业书籍而言，意义重大的是，示例来自大公司的各个级别以及几家小公司。 正如德鲁克承认的那样：“当玛丽阿姨必须给她的侄子一份高中毕业礼物，并送给他追求卓越时，你就会知道管理已经成为一般文化的一部分。” 7

Peters and Waterman democratized management theory, turning it from a monopoly of chief executives and their boards into something that junior managers needed to master. Significantly for a business book, examples were plucked from all levels of big companies and from several small ones as well. As Drucker conceded: "When Aunt Mary has to give that nephew of hers a high school graduation present and she gives him In Search of Excellence, you know that management has become part of the general culture." 7

这本书传到这个世界的玛丽阿姨手中，不仅是因为它传播了一个简单、相关的信息，而且很大程度上是因为彼得斯的营销敏锐度。 他以一种近乎传教士的热情宣传了这本书（当然，他的速度比他更悠闲的合作者，

The book reached the Aunt Marys of this world not just because it was preaching a simple, relevant message, but largely because of Pe-ters's marketing acumen. He publicized the book with an almost missionary zeal (certainly at a pace that his more laid-back collaborator,

先知和布道者

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST

罗伯特·沃特曼 (Robert Waterman) 发现很难理解）。 没有任何会议未被解决，没有任何文章未被撰写，没有任何脱口秀节目未被谈论。 三年后，彼得斯可以吹嘘说，有 100,000 到 200,000 人参加了他的“卓越”研讨会。 即使在大师的队伍中，他非凡耐力的来源仍在争论中。 朋友亨利·明茨伯格 (Henry Mintzberg) 认为，彼得斯如此热烈地欢迎这种宣传，是因为他相信这种繁荣不会持续——彼得斯承认这可能是真的。

Robert Waterman, has found difficult to follow). No conference was left unaddressed, no article unwritten, no talk show untalked. Three years later Peters could boast that between 100,000 and 200,000 people had been through his "excellence" seminars. The source of his extraordinary stamina is still being debated even within the ranks of the gurus. Henry Mintzberg, a friend, thinks that Peters welcomed the publicity so vigorously because he was convinced that the boom would not last—something that Peters admits was probably true.

不管是什么解释，彼得斯为这个行业带来了新的福音派优势。 他把“卓越”当作一场十字军东征。 最忠实的信徒是“臭鼬”——在公司边缘工作的创新局外人（这个名字来自洛克希德公司一个著名的发明部门，称为臭鼬工厂）。 1984 年 9 月，彼得斯举办了他的第一个一年一度的臭鼬营：“40 个勇敢的人在加利福尼亚相遇，他们一直在走自己的路他们的人民成为赢家。” 拥有忠实信徒的核心是至关重要的，因为正如彼得斯首先承认的那样，《追求卓越》的购买多于阅读。 出版三年后， 彼得斯计算出有 500 万人购买了这本书； 200万到300万打开它； 大约 500,000 人阅读了五章； 100,000 人全部阅读； 5,000 人做了详细的记录。 正如他所说，“页面弯曲和下划线很重的数量少得令人沮丧。” 8个

Whatever the explanation, Peters brought a new evangelical edge to the profession. He treated "excellence" as a crusade. The truest believers were "skunks"—innovative outsiders who worked on the fringes of companies (the name came from a well-known inventive part of Lockheed, called the Skunk Works). In September 1984 Peters held his first annual Skunk Camp: "40 brave souls who have been going their own way met in California and swapped tales about the battles fought, the scars accumulated, and the personal and soul-satisfying experiences that have come from watching their people become winners." It was vital to have this hard core of true believers because, as Peters is the first to admit, In Search of Excellence was more bought than read. Three years after its publication, Peters calculated that 5 million people had bought the book; 2 million to 3 million opened it; around 500,000 read five chapters; 100,000 read it all; and 5,000 made detailed notes. As he put it, "The number with bent pages and heavy underlining is dispiritingly low." 8

彼得斯与一位新合作者南希·奥斯汀完成了他的下一本书《追求卓越的激情》。 从营销的角度来看，这相当于品牌强化。 他从一开始就宣称，这是关于臭鼬和它们的战斗的。 信息被扩展了（彼得斯现在强调领导力），但也被简化了。 八个“优秀”特征被归结为美德三角。 三角形的三个边代表对客户、创新和人的关怀。 处于中心位置的是领导力，主要通过彼得斯所说的“四处走动管理”(MBWA) 来行使——可以说是他伟大的滑稽口号中的第一个。 这本书又一次充满了有趣的例子。 为了强调“质量不是技术”这一点，彼得斯和奥斯汀引用了一个价值 250,000 美元的工业“

Peters completed his next book, A Passion for Excellence, with a new collaborator, Nancy Austin. From a marketing point of view, it amounted to brand reinforcement. It was, he declared from the outset, about the skunks and their battles. The message was expanded (Peters now stressed leadership), but it was also simplified. The eight "excellent" characteristics were boiled down to a triangle of virtues. The three sides of the triangle represented care for customers, innovation, and people. At the center was leadership, exercised largely by what Peters calls "management by walking around" (MBWA)—arguably the first of his great zany slogans. Once again, the book was peppered with intriguing examples. To emphasize the point that "quality is not a technique," Peters and Austin cited a $250,000 industrial "blow dryer" bought by Frank Perdue because the chicken seller reckoned that "the most obnoxious thing in the world is the eight hairs that stick up on a typical wing when it is barbecued." The

汤姆彼得斯

Tom Peters

新的吹风机吹松了毛发，并在鸡去商店之前将大部分毛发烧掉了。 “这项新技术，”彼得斯和奥斯汀钦佩地告诉我们，“平均将八根头发减少到两根。弗兰克认为这还不够。” 9

new blow dryer fluffed up the hairs and burnt most of them off before the chicken went to the stores. "The new technique," Peters and Austin tell us admiringly, "on average reduces the eight hairs to two. Frank doesn't think it is enough." 9

在硅谷蓬勃发展

Thriving on Silicon Valley

在流行音乐方面，A Passion for Excellence 是经典的第二张专辑：它听起来像是首张大片，但它更简洁、更专业。 在第三本书《Thirving on Chaos》（1987 年）中，这位明星觉得有必要重塑自己。 现在穿着他的“疯狂的人的疯狂时代”的衣服，彼得斯宣布：“没有优秀的公司。” 这对臭鼬来说一定是一种震撼，就像鲍勃迪伦 (Bob Dylan) 转向电子音乐对民谣音乐迷来说一样。 时机再次出奇地完美。 在 1987 年股市崩盘威胁要对西方经济体造成混乱的同一周，《混乱中的繁荣》出现了。

In pop music terms, A Passion for Excellence was the classic second album: it sounded like the debut blockbuster, but it was a neater, more professional product. With the third book, Thriving on Chaos (1987), the star felt the need to reinvent himself. Now clad in his "crazy times for crazy people" clothes, Peters announced: "There are no excellent companies." This must have been as much a shock for the skunks as Bob Dylan turning electric was for folk music fans. Once again the timing was eerily perfect. Thriving on Chaos appeared in the same week that the stock market crash of 1987 threatened to unleash chaos on the Western economies.

在书中，彼得斯表达了一种普遍的感觉，即世界正处于一场失控的革命之中，如果企业想要生存下去，就需要进行彻底的变革。 他认为，传统公司与东欧经济体非常相似：受到中央的严密控制； 人满为患，而且痴迷于财务规划。 现代信息技术允许公司绕过中层管理人员（他们在生活中的主要作用是收集和控制信息），将决策权交给组装机器或上架的人。 创新的步伐和消费者口味的变化无常使得长期规划变得多余。

In the book, Peters articulated a widespread feeling that the world was in the grip of a revolution running out of control, and that businesses needed to introduce drastic changes if they were to have any chance of surviving. Traditional companies, he argued, were ter-rifyingly like East European economies: tightly controlled from the center; grotesquely overmanned and obsessed with financial planning. Modern information technology was allowing companies to bypass middle managers (whose main role in life was to collect and control information) and hand over decision making to the people who assembled the machines or stocked the shelves. The pace of innovation and the fickleness of consumer tastes were making long-range planning redundant. And increased competition from poorer countries was forcing companies in the rich countries to slash their labor costs, either by replacing men with machines or by inventing cleverer production processes.

再一次，彼得斯非常确定该做什么：缩小你的公司，解雇你的中层管理人员，并将权力下放到尽可能低的级别。 最重要的是，不断改变。 彼得斯警告老板说：“如果你不重组，相当大的重组，每 6 到 12 个月一次，你可能已经与时俱进了。” 彼得斯再次明确表示，即使是最谦逊的员工也必须接受这种态度。 采取的想法

Once again, Peters was attractively certain about what to do: shrink your company, get rid of your middle managers, and devolve power to the lowest possible level. And above all, keep on changing. "If you aren't reorganizing, pretty substantially, once every six to twelve months," Peters warned bosses, "you're probably out of step with the times." Again, Peters made it clear that this was an attitude even the humblest workers had to embrace. Taking the idea of the

先知和布道者

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST

为了得出合乎逻辑的结论，他建议人们在每天结束时问问自己，“在我的工作区域中，与我早上上班时所做的方式完全、准确、明确地做了哪些不同的事情。 “

permanent revolution to its logical conclusion, he advised people to ask themselves at the end of each day, "What exactly and precisely and explicitly is being done in my work area differently from the way it was done when I came to work in the morning."

《Thriving on Chaos》在《纽约时报》畅销书排行榜上停留了 60 周，是《追求卓越》的一半，但比它的任何后续作品都要长。 彼得斯最近的著作，如《解放管理》和《追求惊喜》，重复了“在混乱中繁荣”的反理性信息，以与“追求卓越的热情”强化“追求卓越”的方式相同的方式强化了品牌。 总的来说，论点变得更加疯狂，散文更加辛辣。 现在需要铲除的管理层级似乎包括了首席执行官和信使之间的一切。 Peters 列出的管理者必须做的事情现在长达几页（仅在 Thriving for Chaos 中就有 45 条针对各级管理者的戒律）。 解放管理包括一系列现代管理格言，建议：“被解雇”、“脱掉你的鞋子”和“与牦牛赛跑”。 10 他总结了 Crazg Times 的九个“超越”，其中，“超越改变：走向放弃一切”和“超越 TQM：走向哇！” 彼得斯现在鼓吹“适度组织无政府状态的崇高乐趣”。

Thriving on Chaos spent 60 weeks on the New York Times bestseller list, which was half as long as In Search of Excellence, but longer than any of its successors. Peters's more recent books, such as Liberation Management and the Pursuit of Wow, have repeated the antira-tionalist message of Thriving on Chaos, reinforcing the brand in the same way that A Passion for Excellence reinforced In Search of Excellence. In general, the arguments get zanier and the prose more high-octane. The layers of management that need to be eradicated now seem to include everything between the chief executive and the messenger boy. Peters's lists of things managers have to do now stretch for pages (there were 45 precepts for managers of all levels in Thriving for Chaos alonej. Liberation Management includes a list of maxims for modern management that advises: "get fired," "take off your shoes," and "race yaks." 10 He concludes Crazg Times with nine "be-yonds," among them, "beyond change: towards the abandonment of everything" and "beyond TQM: toward wow!" Peters now preaches "the sublime pleasures of modestly organized anarchy."

彼得斯后来的作品（用“成熟”来形容可能有点牵强）可以被解读为对他的第二故乡加利福尼亚硅谷的长篇赞歌。 加州的计算机行业产生了一种极具企业家精神、随心所欲、打破常规的管理风格。 该地区每年有 300 多家企业成立。 每当科学家和企业家有了一个好主意，他们就会成立一家公司在市场上对其进行测试，然后继续前进，要么是因为这个想法失败了，要么是因为技术发生了变化； 因此，人员和资本可以快速有效地循环利用，以利用时尚的变化或技术的突破。 11 破产是荣誉的象征。 正如彼得斯自己所说：“

Peters's later writing (it might be stretching a point to describe it as "mature") can be read as a long hymn of praise to his adopted home, California's Silicon Valley. California's computer industry has generated an extraordinarily entrepreneurial, free-wheeling, convention-busting management style. The area sees more than 300 businesses founded every year. Each time scientists and entrepreneurs get a bright idea, they form a company to test it on the market and then move on, either because the idea has flopped or because the technology has changed; as a result, people and capital are recycled quickly and efficiently to take advantage of changes in fashion or breakthroughs in technology. 11 Bankruptcy is a badge of honor. As Peters puts it himself: "Through luck I ended up in Santa Clara county—a big godawful mess populated by failures." 12

硅谷的居民穿运动鞋和牛仔裤比穿西装打领带更快乐，并且对人们终生为同一个组织工作的想法感到震惊。 他们愉快地从一个工作跳到另一个工作，相信他们的价值在于他们想法的质量，而不是他们忠诚度的记录。 这样的人喜欢

The inhabitants of Silicon Valley are happier in sneakers and jeans than suits and ties, and appalled at the idea of people spending their entire lives working for the same organization. They happily hop from job to job, confident that their value lies in the quality of their ideas rather than their track record of loyalty. Such people like

汤姆彼得斯

Tom Peters

在围绕项目构建的公司工作，并尽可能摆脱官僚主义。 即使是相当大的公司，如英特尔，也是一个自由流动的“芯片团队”集合——一系列不断变化的团队，致力于不同代的微处理器。 硅谷人不仅从一个工作跳到另一个工作，而且从一个职业跳到另一个职业，科学家成为企业家，企业家成为管理者，管理者成为风险投资家。 换句话说，他们在混乱中茁壮成长。

to work in companies that are structured around projects and are as free from bureaucracy as possible. Even a fairly large company, such as Intel, is a free-flowing collection of "chip squads"—a series of ever-changing teams working on different generations of microprocessors. Valley people hop not just from job to job but also from career to career, with scientists becoming entrepreneurs, entrepreneurs becoming managers, and managers becoming venture capitalists. In other words, they thrive on chaos.

彼得斯的观点

The Point of Peters

这一切都解释了为什么彼得斯是一个千万富翁。 但他有什么好处吗？ 尽管他对公司了解很多，但他的工作有两个潜在的致命缺陷：首先，他经常犯错（1982 年被选为优秀的公司中有三分之二现在已经失宠）； 其次，他比一般政客自相矛盾的次数更多。 将它们加在一起，彼得斯作品的经典看起来令人担忧地虚幻和短暂——因此人们怀疑他所做的比他所说的更有趣。

All this explains why Peters is a multimillionaire. But is he any good? Even if he knows a huge amount about companies, two potentially fatal flaws mar his work: first, he has got it wrong too often (two-thirds of the companies singled out as excellent in 1982 have now fallen from grace); and, second, he has contradicted himself even more often than the average politician. Add them together and the canon of Peters's work looks worryingly insubstantial and ephemeral—hence the suspicion that what he has done is more interesting than what he has said.

可以通过说彼得斯为现实世界写书，供人们使用，并且现实世界变化相当快来部分回答这一指控。 尽管他并没有完全屈服于写一夜暴富的书，但他一直明确表示，他的书远非学术分析练习，而是旨在帮助人们繁荣，或者至少帮助人们生存。 在混乱中蓬勃发展的副标题是管理革命手册。 从这个角度来看——从该领域的经理（人们很想说是臭鼬）的角度来看，对商业趋势的敏锐嗅觉是彼得斯的优势之一，而不是他的弱点，即使这些趋势往往不会持续很长时间。

This charge can partly be answered by saying that Peters writes his books for the real world, for people to use, and that the real world changes fairly quickly. Although he has not quite stooped to writing get-rich-quick books, he has always made it clear that, far from being exercises in academic analysis, his books are intended to help people prosper, or at least survive. Thriving on Chaos is subtitled Handbook for a Management Revolution. From this perspective—from the perspective of the manager (one is tempted to say the skunk) in the field, an unfailing nose for business trends is one of Peters's strengths rather than his weaknesses, even if those trends often do not last long.

彼得斯的作案手法是感知企业界的发展方向，通常是正确的，然后在屋顶大声疾呼。 Liberation Management 是最新管理时尚的有力指南，每一个都通过案例研究进行了充分说明，例如灵活的组织（CNN 在每个新闻日开始时实际上都在重塑自己）、学习型组织（Quad/Graphics 坚持认为它的员工不断自我教育），以及对顾客的不懈关注（英国的 Joshua Tetley 酒吧连锁店为能够背诵 100 位顾客的名字和饮酒习惯的酒吧员工提供奖品）。

Peters's modus operandi is to sense where the corporate world is heading, usually correctly, and then shout it from the rooftops. Liberation Management is, among other things, a feisty guide to the latest management fads, each amply illustrated with case studies, such as flexible organizations (CNN virtually reinvents itself at the start of every news day), learning organizations (Quad/Graphics insists that its employees keep on educating themselves), and a relentless focus on customers (Britain's Joshua Tetley pub chain offers prizes to bar staff who can recite the names and drinking habits of 100 customers).

先知和布道者

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST

该列表可以持续数页。 Liberation Management 和彼得斯后来的一些著作的缺点之一就是它确实如此。

The list could go on for pages. One of the faults of Liberation Management and some of Peters's later books, is that it does.

换句话说，批评彼得斯给出的建议只适用于，比如说，五年，没有抓住要点。 彼得的读者需要他们现在可以使用的建议。 彼得斯在 1982 年选出的许多公司在当时确实如此； 他们的衰落不能归咎于他。 在 1982 年，从读者的角度来看，重要的是“我现在能学到什么？” 在最近的一篇报纸文章中，彼得斯后悔解雇了两位更加非传统的作家，斯蒂芬柯维（高效能人士的七个习惯）和肯布兰查德（一分钟经理人）不够严谨。 13 然而，彼得斯认为，科维和布兰查德的书“给普通人（像我一样）今天下午要做的实际事情，让工作世界变得更好一些。”

In other words, criticizing Peters for giving out advice that was only relevant for, say, five years, misses the point. Peter's readers need advice that they can use now. Many of the companies that Peters selected as excellent in 1982 were indeed so at the time; their decline cannot be blamed on him. What mattered from the reader's point of view back in 1982 was "What can I learn now?" In a recent newspaper article, Peters regretted having dismissed two even more unconventional writers, Stephen Covey (The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People) and Ken Blanchard (The One Minute Manager) for not being rigorous enough. 13 Yet the books by Covey and Blanchard, argues Peters, "give ordinary people (like me) practical things to do this afternoon to make the world of work a little better." Surely some part of Peters was writing about himself.

这一切都可能让彼得斯摆脱被事件推翻的困境。 然而，即使按照一分钟经理的标准，也存在一些相当大的矛盾。 请记住，正是这个人在 1982 年发起了“卓越运动”，并愿意在 1987 年宣称“卓越不是”。尽管如此，对他的指控往往被夸大了。 最常提出的反对意见之一是，彼得斯在开始他的职业生涯时曾在大公司面前屈膝，现在却鼓吹小即是美。 尽管“追求卓越”致力于大公司——顺便说一句，它们是唯一能够支付麦肯锡高昂费用的公司——仔细阅读后，它对巨人主义的弊病和保持小规模的优势非常敏感：

All this may get Peters off the hook for being disproved by events. Even by the standards of one-minute managers, however, there have been some fairly substantial contradictions. Remember that this was the man who, having launched the "excellence movement" in 1982, was willing to claim "Excellence isn't" in 1987. All the same, the charges against him are often exaggerated. One of the most frequently voiced objections is that, having started his career genuflecting before big companies, Peters now preaches that small is beautiful. Though In Search of Excellence is devoted to giant companies— which, incidentally, were the only companies that could afford to pay McKinsey's exorbitant fees—it is, on closer reading, remarkably sensitive to the ills of gigantism and the advantages of staying small:

我们审查的优秀公司的信息总是相同的。 3M 的小型、独立的新创团队（以百人为单位）； 强生公司的小部门（一家价值 50 亿美元的公司有 150 多个部门）； TI 的 90 个 PCC； IBM 产品冠军领导的团队； 通用电气的“盗版”团队； Digital 不断变化的小型细分市场； Bloomingdale's 每月新开精品店。 . . . 小就是美。 14

The message from the excellent companies we reviewed was invariably the same. Small, independent new venture teams at 3M (by the hundred); small divisions at Johnson & Johnson (over 150 in a $5 billion firm); ninety PCCs at TI; the product champion-led teams at IBM; "bootlegging" teams at GE; small, ever-shifting segments at Digital; new boutiques monthly at Bloomingdale's. . . . Small is beautiful. 14

这种权力下放减少了对层层中层管理人员的需求。 它还确保公司致力于创新，并确保他们专注于客户。 15

Such decentralization cut down on the need for layer upon layer of middle managers. It also ensured that companies were committed to innovation and that they focused on their customers. 15

这么多年过去了，Tom Peters 仍然很疯狂

Tom Peters Still Crazy after All These Years

然而，彼得的工作有更深层次的一致性。 他所写的一切，从追求卓越到他最近的疯狂时代漫谈，都可以被解读为对科学管理的扩展批判。 关于创造“愚蠢的技术”，他最具特色的一句话来自他的第一本书。 16 彼得斯是管理界的米歇尔·福柯：理性主义传统的祸害和混乱和疯狂的创造性必要性的颂扬者。

However, there is a deeper consistency to Peter's work. Everything he has written, from In Search of Excellence to his latest Crazy Times ramblings, can be read as an extended critique of scientific management. One of his most characteristic phrases, about creating a "technology of foolishness," came from his first book. 16 Peters is the Michel Foucault of the management world: a scourge of the rationalist tradition and a celebrant of the creative necessity of chaos and craziness.

当彼得斯上商学院时，管理仍然受数字支配：“我们中的许多人认为‘真实数据’的唯一事实是我们可以用数字表示的数据。” 17 管理教育推崇定量分析、嗤之以鼻的“软脑袋人文主义”和不科学的直觉，并为所有决策寻求超然的、分析性的理由。 18 简而言之，这该死的确保“技术运动员”负责。

When Peters went to business school, management was still dominated by numbers: "The only facts that many of us considered 'real data' were the ones we could put numbers on." 17 Management education celebrated the virtues of quantitative analysis, pooh-poohed "soft-headed humanism" and unscientific intuition, and sought detached, analytical justifications for all decisions. 18 In short, it made damn sure that the "technical jocks" were in charge.

理性主义模型在“神童”中找到了其最有影响力的代表，一群战略分析师帮助策划了美国在第二次世界大战中的胜利，然后继续重塑福特汽车公司。 19 对彼得斯和他那一代人来说，这种管理方法的可怕弱点不仅体现在美国境况不佳的行业，也体现在其无望的外交政策上：他们中最聪明的孩子罗伯特·麦克纳马拉 (Robert McNamara) 离开了福特的董事长职位，成为了财政部长国防，他试图通过升级敌人的杀戮来赢得越南战争。 1982 年，彼得斯和沃特曼沉思道，理性主义模型“正确到足以犯下危险的错误”，“而且可以说它已经让我们严重误入歧途。”

The rationalist model found its most influential exponents in "the whiz kids," a group of strategic analysts who helped mastermind America's victory in the Second World War and then went on to reshape the Ford Motor Company. 19 For Peters and his generation, the horrific weaknesses of this approach to management were demonstrated not just in America's ailing industries but in its hopeless foreign policy: the brightest whiz kid of them all, Robert McNamara, left the chairmanship of Ford to become secretary of state for defense, where he tried to win the Vietnam War by escalating enemy kills. The rationalist model "is right enough to be dangerously wrong," Peters and Waterman mused in 1982, "and it has arguably led us seriously astray."

追求卓越提出了反对理性主义模型的三个论点。 首先，该模型过分强调财务分析，而过分强调激励员工或满足客户。 对成本的痴迷促使公司低估质量和价值，修补旧产品而不是发明新产品，将工人视为生产成本而不是价值来源。 作者引用他们的同事安东尼·阿索斯 (Anthony Athos) 赞许的话：“优秀的管理者不仅能为人创造意义，还能为金钱创造意义。”

In Search of Excellence advances three arguments against the rationalist model. First, the model puts too much emphasis on financial analysis and too little on motivating workers or satisfying customers. The obsession with cost persuades firms to undervalue quality and value, to patch up old products rather than invent new ones, to treat workers as costs of production rather than sources of value. The authors quote their colleague Anthony Athos approvingly: "Good managers make meanings for people, as well as money."

其次，理性主义模式以牺牲企业创新为代价鼓励官僚主义的从众。 理性主义的管理者认为大是最好的，因为它带来了规模经济；

Second, the rationalist model encouraged bureaucratic conformity at the expense of entrepreneurial innovation. Rationalist managers believe that big is best, because it brings economies of scale;

先知和布道者

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST

混乱是灾难性的，因为它意味着浪费和混乱； 规划是必不可少的，因为它允许公司控制未来。 对于彼得斯和沃特曼来说，最好的公司，例如办公用品巨头 3M，几乎恰恰相反：它们是实验的温床，对非理性和混乱感到满意。 20

that messiness is disastrous, because it means waste and confusion; and that planning is essential, because it allows firms to control the future. For Peters and Waterman, the best firms, such as 3M, an office-products giant, were almost exactly the opposite: they were hotbeds of experimentation, happy with irrationality and chaos. 20

第三，理性主义模式建立在对人性的误解之上。 “关于组织人的理性主义观点的核心问题是，人不是很理性，”作者认为。 “为了适应泰勒的旧模型或今天的组织结构图，人的设计简直是错误的。” 21 科学管理者高估了经济回报在激励员工方面的重要性：人们对无形的事物更感兴趣，比如赢得同事的称赞或为他们钦佩的组织工作。 “我们采访过的所有公司，”作者指出，“从波音到麦当劳，都是由轶事、神话和童话组成的丰富多彩的挂毯。” 22

Third, the rationalist model rests on a misunderstanding of human nature. "The central problem with the rationalist view of organizing people is that people are not very rational," the authors argue. "To fit Taylor's old model, or today's organizational charts, man is simply designed wrong." 21 Scientific managers overestimate the importance of financial rewards in motivating workers: people are much more interested in intangible things, like winning the praise of colleagues or working for an organization they admire. "All the companies we interviewed," the authors note, "from Boeing to McDonald's, were quite simply rich tapestries of anecdote, myth, and fairytale." 22

彼得斯和沃特曼并不是第一个（也不是最后一个）提请注意理性主义管理模式局限性的人。 正如已经指出的那样，抨击科学管理的传统由来已久，可以追溯到管理理论家的人际关系学派，他们致力于证明人是一种社会动物，而不仅仅是一台理性的计算机器。 在 1960 年出版的《企业的人性方面》中，道格拉斯·麦格雷戈 (Douglas McGregor) 认为，管理理论过于关注“X 理论”，认为员工懒惰，需要经济激励来驱动，而对“Y 理论”的关注不够， 》认为，相反，工人是有创造力的，需要被赋予责任。 商业媒体也并非对商业思维的软性无动于衷：

Peters and Waterman were hardly the first people (and hardly the last) to draw attention to the limitations of the rationalist model of management. As already noted, there is a long tradition of bashing scientific management stretching back to the human-relations school of management theorists who devoted themselves to demonstrating that man is a social animal, not just a rational calculating machine. In The Human Side of Enterprise, published in 1960, Douglas McGregor argued that management theory paid too much attention to "theory X," which holds that workers are lazy and need to be driven by financial incentives, and not enough to "theory Y," which holds that, on the contrary, workers are creative and need to be given responsibility. The business press was not indifferent to the softer side of business thinking either: Business Week even ran a cover story on corporate culture in the late summer of 1980. 23

尽管如此，彼得斯还是把他的反理性主义立场推向了他的前任们做梦也想不到的极端。 世界已经变得疯狂了，他咆哮道，为了应对它，经理们也必须变得疯狂。 对他们来说，仅仅关注工作中的直觉和理性方面已经不够了。 他们必须发疯：扔掉他们的计算尺，忘记攀登职业阶梯，把自己变成滑稽的企业家。 公司精简总部和精简中层管理队伍已经不够了。

Even so, Peters has taken his antirationalist stand to extremes hardly dreamed of by his predecessors. The world has gone bonkers, he rants, and to cope with it managers must go bonkers too. It is no longer enough for them to pay attention to the intuitive as well as the rational side of their jobs. They must go mad: throw away their slide rules, forget about climbing the career ladder, and turn themselves into zany entrepreneurs. It is no longer enough for companies to slim their headquarters and thin the ranks of middle management.

汤姆彼得斯

Tom Peters

公司应该利用内部市场将他们的员工变成微型企业家，并利用外部市场来确保他们不会浪费时间做烹饪和计算等事情，这些事情在其他地方可以做得更好。 对于彼得斯来说，“疯狂”的组织比他们理智的竞争对手更有效率，也更有趣。

Firms should use internal markets to turn their employees into mini-entrepreneurs, and external markets to make sure that they are not wasting their time doing things like cooking and computing, which could be done better elsewhere. For Peters, "crazy" organizations are more efficient as well as more fun than their sane rivals.

但这真的是真的吗？ 要问汤姆彼得斯的关键问题不是他是否始终如一，而是他极端和无情的反理性主义是否有意义。 彼得斯对稳定性和连续性等单调美德的重要性视而不见。 例如，在彼得斯的混乱世界中，没有时间安排或中层管理人员的余地； 在现实世界中，中层管理人员通常是将组织团结在一起的人，而时间表是大多数“不疯狂”的人赖以度过每一天的框架。 事实上，彼得斯致命地低估了即使是最疯狂的组织也需要一些稳定才能蓬勃发展。

But is this really true? The critical question to ask about Tom Peters is not whether he is consistent but whether his extreme and relentless antirationalism makes sense. Peters is blind to the importance of such humdrum virtues as stability and continuity. For instance, in Peters's chaotic world there is no room for schedules or middle managers; in the real world, middle managers are often the people who hold organizations together, and schedules are the framework around which most "uncrazy" people build their days. Indeed, Peters fatally underestimates the need in even the craziest organizations for some stability if they are to thrive.

就连彼得斯钟爱的硅谷也有幸拥有斯坦福大学和惠普这两个稳定的岛屿，它们都培养了企业家并为他们提供了人脉网络。 至于该地区其他组织的不懈重组，这并非没有代价。 在 The Breakthrough Illusion (1990) 中，Richard Florida 和 Martin Kenney 指出，“过度机动性”会导致浪费，因为研究会被打乱，有创造力的人会筋疲力尽，在 40 岁之前结束他们的职业生涯。在他关于公司的书中伙计，安东尼·桑普森 (Anthony Sampson) 引用了苹果公司发言人弗兰克·奥马奥尼 (Frank O'Mahoney) 的话，哀叹公司的健忘症：

Even Peters's beloved Silicon Valley is fortunate to possess two islands of stability in Stanford University and Hewlett-Packard, both of which have trained entrepreneurs and provided them with a network of contacts. As for the relentless reconfiguration of other organizations in the area, this has not come without costs. In The Breakthrough Illusion (1990), Richard Florida and Martin Kenney pointed out that "hypermobility" can lead to waste, as research studies are disrupted and creative individuals burn themselves out, ending their careers before they are 40. In his book on the company man, Anthony Sampson quotes Frank O'Mahoney, a spokesman for Apple, lamenting the company's amnesia:

Apple 没有多少机构记忆。 当我们庆祝 Macintosh 十周年时，很难找到还记得它的人。 我们想要一个 Apple 博物馆，但没有足够的早期产品保存下来。 顾问们似乎比我们更了解 Apple 的历史。 24

There's not much institutional memory at Apple. When we celebrated the tenth anniversary of the Macintosh it was hard to find people who remembered it. We wanted to have an Apple museum but not enough early products had been kept. The consultants seem to know more about the history of Apple than we do. 24

事实上，Apple 过去十年的历史可能被解读为一场布道会，说明为什么追逐一个疯狂的梦想是不够的。 无政府状态是一个挑衅的想法； 这不是商业战略。 说了这么多，不承认挑衅者彼得斯在做某事是无礼的，即使先知彼得斯没有。

Indeed, the history of Apple over the past decade might be read as a sermon on why following a crazy dream is not enough. Anarchy is a provocative idea; it is not a business strategy. Having said all this, it would be churlish not to concede that Peters-the-provocateur is on to something, even if Peters-the-prophet is not.

先知和传道者足够有趣

PROPHET AND EVANGELIST Far Enough Out to Be Interesting

世界可能永远不会像彼得斯预测的那样“疯狂”； 但随着产品周期时间的缩短、命令和控制系统的崩溃以及创新步伐的加快，它肯定在朝着他的方向发展。 像苹果这样的公司可能会灭亡，但硅谷将幸存下来，因为它的商业文化更加流动，而且它的公司比那些管理系统僵化的公司更具企业家精神。 中层管理人员可能会被重塑为“教练”等，但他们永远不会成为旧时官僚主义的推笔人。

The world may never go as "crazy" as Peters predicts; but it is definitely moving in his direction, as product cycle times collapse, command-and-control systems buckle, and the pace of innovation increases. Companies such as Apple may perish, but Silicon Valley will survive precisely because its business culture is more fluid and its companies more entrepreneurial than those with inflexible systems of management. Middle managers may be reinvented as "coaches" and so on, but they will never be the bureaucratic pen pushers of old.

彼得斯承认，他推崇的公司可能比常态稍微领先了一点。 追求卓越谈到了惠普、强生和 3M 等公司。 在后来的著作中，他还对ABB、联合太平洋等知名企业进行了案例研究。 但除了这些强壮的野兽之外，还有更奇特的生物，包括 Verifone、Oticon 和 3.00（是的，这是一家公司的名称）等“虚拟”公司。 彼得斯的雄心是成为变革的推动者：“足够远才能有趣，足够接近才能合理。” 25

Peters concedes that the firms he celebrates may have got a little ahead of the norm. In Search of Excellence talked about the likes of Hewlett-Packard, Johnson & Johnson, and 3M. In later works, he also has case studies on well-known firms such as ABB and Union Pacific. But alongside these sturdy beasts are more exotic creatures, including "virtual" firms such as Verifone, Oticon, and 3.00 (yes, this is a company's name). Peters's ambition is to be an agent of change: "far enough out to be interesting, close enough in to be plausible." 25

他能通过这个测试吗？ 在汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters) 研讨会的午休时间，有人私下询问两位英国商人——一位从事宠物食品，另一位从事酿造——是否像 Verifone 这样的信用卡授权公司没有总部，并且禁止使用纸，确实与他们相当稳定的行业相关。 两位经理都承认，他们主要将彼得斯视为挑衅者。 但他们坚持认为他的想法确实有帮助。 正如宠物食品经理所解释的那样，主要影响是心理上的：“这是我看待世界的方式……我待人的方式。” 啤酒商看起来很困惑； 然后他说：“我们即将赋予我们的车夫权力——让他们与他们送货的酒吧谈判。这是我们三年前从彼得斯研讨会上得到的想法。” 在“纳秒九十年代”，三年听起来很长。 世界正朝着彼得斯的方向发展。 它只是没有像他希望的那样快速移动。

Does he pass this test? At the lunch-break of a Tom Peters seminar, two British businessmen—one in petfoods, the other in brewing—are asked privately whether the likes of Verifone, a credit-card authorization firm that has no head office and that bans the use of paper, are really relevant to their fairly stable industries. The two managers both admit that they see Peters primarily as a provocateur. But they insist that his ideas do help. As the petfood manager explains, the main effect is psychological: "It's in the way I look at the world ... the way I treat people." The brewer looks stumped; then he says: "We're just about to empower our draymen—to let them negotiate with the pubs to which they deliver. That was an idea that we got from a Peters seminar three years ago." Three years sounds like quite a long time in the "nanosecond nineties." The world is going in Peters's direction. It is just not moving as quickly as he would like.

第三部分

PART THREE

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

第 5 章

CHAPTER 5

# & 3^

# & 3^

小号

S

位于伦敦市中心泰晤士河南岸的壳牌中心是一座引人注目的企业自信纪念碑。 它坚固而壮观，平静地审视着它周围的一切，包括威斯敏斯特宫和十几个白厅部门。 凭借其迷宫般的走廊、数百个会议室以及无处不在的官僚主义永恒感，这座建筑一直是贝壳人的完美栖息地——因为该公司的员工曾经在全世界都被嘲笑。 按照传统，贝壳人除了名义上外都是官僚，与每天陪同他从郊区到滑铁卢车站上下班的公务员和推销员的区别只有一件事——他的薪水多寡。 他期待一生都能有稳定的工作，并在结束时获得与指数挂钩的养老金。 公司不仅为他而且为他的孩子提供乡村俱乐部会员资格。 当他被派往亚洲和非洲时——正如他经常作为他精心计划的公司晋升的一部分——他在排场和环境上与英国大使竞争，并且不惜在一边为他在英国的朋友做一点间谍活动。英国特勤局。

The Shell Centre, on the south bank of the Thames in the heart of London, is a striking monument to corporate self-confidence. Solid and imposing, it serenely surveys all that surrounds it, including the Palace of Westminster and a dozen Whitehall departments. With its labyrinthine corridors, hundreds of meeting rooms, and all-pervasive sense of bureaucratic permanence, the building has been a perfect habitat for Shell Man—as the company's employees were once mockingly known the world over. By tradition, Shell Man was a bureaucrat in all but name, differing from the civil servants and paper pushers who accompanied him on the daily commute from the suburbs to Waterloo Station in only one thing—the size of his paycheck. He looked forward to a lifetime of secure employment and an index-linked pension at the end of it. The company provided country-club membership not just for him but for his children. When he was posted to Asia and Africa—as he often was as part of his carefully planned progression up the company—he competed in pomp and circumstance with the British ambassador and was not above doing a little spying on the side for his friends in the British Secret Service.

位于华盛顿州的微软总部截然不同。 要到达软件巨头，您必须开车离开西雅图进入周围的红杉林，直到您来到 Microsoft Way。 公司已经放弃了企业摩天大楼

In Washington State, the headquarters of Microsoft could hardly be more different. To reach the software giant you have to drive out of Seattle into the surrounding redwood forests until you come to Microsoft Way. The company has dispensed with corporate skyscrapers

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

和令人惊叹的接待区：取而代之的是，参观者面对的是成群结队的白色建筑，这些建筑与传统总部办公室的高大和气势一样谦逊低矮。 微软员工看起来更像是研究生，而不是成功的商人：他们穿着运动衫和运动鞋，留着长发，扎着马尾辫。 平均年龄只有32岁； 而且这里的女性明显多于壳牌。 但是这些微软人和他们在壳牌的同行一样敬业，经常工作到深夜，靠比萨饼和免费的可口可乐维持生活； 而且，在大多数情况下，他们要富有得多。 那些坚持到底的人——其中很多人半途而废——往往最终成为百万富翁。

and awe-inspiring reception areas: instead, the visitor is confronted with groups of white buildings, as modest and low as traditional head offices are tall and imposing. Microsoft employees look more like graduate students than successful businessmen: they are dressed in sweat shirts and sneakers and sport long hair and pony tails. The average age is only 32; and there are noticeably more women around the place than at Shell. But these Microsofties are as dedicated as their counterparts at Shell, often working late into the night, sustained by pizza and free Coca-Cola; and, for the most part, they are a great deal richer. Those who have stayed the course—and a great many have fallen by the wayside—have often ended up as millionaires.

乍一看，局外人可能会得出结论，荷兰皇家/壳牌和微软处于两个不同的世界，一个是为基本产品通常需要十年艰苦勘探才能定位的行业设计的，另一个是衡量变化的企业在几周内。 局外人可能会补充说，壳牌看起来更像是一家公司的“经典”模式——其他公司会试图复制的那种东西，而有一天，微软会成熟起来。 然而，不是微软演变成壳牌，而是壳牌最近一直试图变得更像微软。 在过去的十年中，这家石油公司一直在努力提高创业精神并雇用更多的女性员工。 1995 年 3 月，当壳牌公司宣布它正在摆脱 1 时，这种微软化进程得到了加速，

At first sight, an outsider might conclude that Royal Dutch/Shell and Microsoft are in two separate worlds, one designed for an industry where the basic product often takes a decade of hard prospecting just to locate, the other for a business where change is measured in weeks. The outsider might add that Shell looks a bit more like the "classical" model of a company—the sort of thing that other firms would try to copy and that, one day, Microsoft would mature into. However, rather than Microsoft evolving into Shell, it is Shell that has recently been trying to become more like Microsoft. Over the past decade the oil company has strived, among other things, to become more entrepreneurial and to hire more female staff. In March 1995 this Microsoftization was speeded up when Shell announced that it was shedding 1,200 jobs in its headquarters, in an attempt to cut bureaucracy and rid itself of its "committee culture."

管理理论目前正试图理解公司组织的巨大转变，这种转变促使壳牌和类似的公司变得更像微软。 这项工作是第 5 章到第 9 章的起点，它们是关于现代管理的“大辩论”。 本章关注迫使现代公司质疑其关于规模、实力和结构的旧假设的不确定性。 第 6 章考虑了这些新的、更灵活的公司如何尝试使用知识。 第 7 章和第 8 章重点关注这些变化对公司领导者的影响。 他们现在应该如何制定战略？ 他们应该如何管理自己？ 他们对谁负责？ 最后，第 9 章探讨了所有这些公司变革对工作世界意味着什么。

Management theory is currently trying to understand the seismic shift in corporate organization that has driven Shell and companies like it to become more like Microsoft. This effort is the starting point for Chapters 5 to 9, which are about "the great debates" of modern management. This chapter is concerned with the uncertainty that has forced the modern company to question its old assumptions about size, strength, and structure. Chapter 6 considers how these new, more flexible companies try to use knowledge. And Chapters 7 and 8 focus on the implications of these changes for the leaders of companies. How should they now set strategies? How should they govern themselves? And to whom are they answerable? Finally, Chapter 9 examines what all these corporate changes mean for the world of work.

重新思考公司确定性的终结

Rethinking the Company The End of Certainty

在过去十年中，公司被迫重新思考管理智慧的几乎所有原则。 曾经，公司以其总部的规模和工资单的长度而自豪。 现在，他们正在出租总部办公室的空间，并裁减公司员工的数量。 曾经，公司以“垂直整合”为荣，并且像独立的帝国一样运作，尽可能少地求助于外来者。 现在他们在另一种意义上“坚持自己的编织”，专注于自己的核心业务，而将其他一切都外包给独立的专家。 一旦他们有了明确的指挥和控制线，从最高层的主席开始，一直延伸到最低级的下属。 现在他们正在把自己变成“倒金字塔”， 鼓励职场民主，把权力交给一线员工。 一旦他们清楚地知道他们对谁负责——他们的股东——以及他们应该追求什么——更高的利润。 现在，他们被敦促考虑他们的利益相关者并增加“福祉”而不仅仅是利润。

Over the past decade companies have been forced to rethink almost every tenet of managerial wisdom. Once companies prided themselves on the size of their headquarters and the length of their payrolls. Now they are renting out space in their head offices and cutting their corporate staff to the bone. Once companies prided themselves on "vertical integration" and were run like self-contained empires with as little recourse to outsiders as possible. Now they are "sticking to their knitting" in a different sense, focusing on their core businesses and contracting everything else out to independent specialists. Once they had a clear line of command and control, starting with the chairman at the top and stretching to the lowliest menial. Now they are turning themselves into "inverted pyramids," encouraging workplace democracy and handing power to front-line workers. Once they had a clear idea of to whom they were responsible—their shareholders—and what they were supposed to be chasing—ever higher profits. Now they are being urged to think about their stakeholders and to increase "well-being" rather than just profits.

是什么力量释放了这个漩涡？ 计算机科学家可能会说，世界正在艰难地从机器时代过渡到信息时代。 投资银行家会指出资本的流动性。 但是，世界各地的管理者面临变革的根本原因可能是两个因素，这两个因素都是彼得·德鲁克 (Peter Drucker) 最先发现的：不确定性和知识。

What forces have unleashed this maelstrom? A computer scientist might say that the world is struggling through a transition, from the machine age to the information age. An investment banker would point to the mobility of capital. But the fundamental cause of the change facing managers everywhere is probably two factors, both first identified by Peter Drucker: uncertainty and knowledge.

如今，变化是不连续的——或者更准确地说，比以往任何时候都更加不连续。 如果历史曾经是商业世界成功的指南，那么它肯定不再是了。 行业可以一夜之间被撼动，巨人可以被一击打倒。 在五年的时间里，人们可以从害怕 IBM 变成同情它； 几天之内，像巴林这样拥有百年历史的银行就会消失。 由于全球化，一家公司可能会被世界另一端国家的未知竞争对手吓到或智取。 技术日新月异，任天堂 Game Boy 现在的计算能力堪比用于控制美国导弹防御系统的超级计算机。 结果，尼科洛·马基雅维利 (Nicolo Machiavelli) 的格言“

Nowadays, change is discontinuous—or, perhaps more accurately, more discontinuous than it has ever been before. If history was ever a guide to success in the commercial world, it certainly is not any longer. Industries can be shaken overnight, giants felled by a single blow. In the space of five years one can go from being frightened of IBM to pitying it; in the space of a few days a centuries-old bank such as Barings can disappear. Thanks to globalization, a company can be surprised or outwitted by unknown competitors in countries on the other side of the world. Technology is changing so quickly that a Nintendo Game Boy now contains as much computing power as the supercomputers that used to control America's missile defense system. As a result, Nicolo Machiavelli's maxim, "Whoever desires constant success must change his conduct with the times," has emerged from relative obscurity to become a daily mantra.

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

在这个更加疯狂的世界中，唯一真正重要的货币是知识。 蛮力、大型工厂、分销网络、矿产资源，甚至金钱：所有这些都算不上什么。 到 1995 年年中，股票市场对通用汽车和福特（两家公司的总销售额超过 3000 亿美元）的估值约为 700 亿美元； 相比之下，由四家“以创意为基础”的公司——默克、微软、英特尔和迪士尼——的总销售额可能超过 800 亿美元，但它们的股票价值几乎是底特律两大巨头的三倍。 正如 Tom Peters 所说，“块状物的时代已经过去；蜉蝣的时代才刚刚开始。” 见证幻想和明星品质的巨大价值：饮料公司 Seagram 出价 60 亿美元进入娱乐业，2.0 亿美元。

In this more frantic world, the only currency that really matters is knowledge. Brute force, huge factories, distribution networks, mineral resources, even money: all count for far less. By mid-1995 the stock market valued General Motors and Ford (two companies with combined sales of more than $300 billion) at about $70 billion; by contrast, a group of four "ideas-based" companies—Merck, Microsoft, Intel, and Disney—could muster combined sales of just over $80 billion, but their stock was worth almost three times as much as the two Detroit juggernauts. As Tom Peters puts it, "The age of lumps is gone; the age of ephemera has just begun." Witness the enormous value of fantasy and star quality: the $6 billion that Seagram, a beverage company, bid to enter the entertainment industry, the $2.3 billion rise in the value of shares of companies that sponsored Michael Jordan just on the rumor that he might return to basketball, and the $1.3 billion fall in IBM's value when its chief financial officer, Jerome York, announced he was leaving.

全球化只会让知识变得更加重要。 随着通信价格下降到接近于零（很快从曼哈顿给德里打电话和给布朗克斯打电话一样便宜），数以百万计的廉价手和脑与西方人竞争，唯一可持续的优势可能是成为产生想法的能力。 “知识”也不只是硅谷和好莱坞的公司需要担心的东西。 即使是像美国 Chaparral Steel 这样一再打破生产力记录的小钢厂这样的大烟囱公司也表明，大脑比铁矿石更重要。 美国最受尊敬的公司之一是 Rubbermaid——这家公司源源不断地供应低技术含量的家庭用品等，但却以一种非常聪明的方式供应。

Globalization only makes knowledge more important. As the price of communication drops to close to zero (it will soon be as cheap to telephone Delhi from Manhattan as it is to call the Bronx), bringing millions of cheap hands and brains into competition with Western ones, the only sustainable advantage is likely to be the capacity to produce ideas. Nor is "knowledge" just something that firms in Silicon Valley and Hollywood need to be worried about. Even smokestack firms like America's Chaparral Steel, a small mill that has repeatedly broken productivity records, have shown that brains are more important than iron ore. One of America's most admired companies is Rubbermaid—a firm that makes an endless supply of low-tech housewares and the like, but does so in an outstandingly intelligent way.

恐慌的原因

Reasons to Panic

现代管理理论痴迷于一种或另一种“变化”：如何产生它，如何回应它，如何避免被它卷走。 考虑到许多知名公司要么最终进入了坟场，要么至少对围栏有了很好的了解，这也许并不奇怪。 在过去的十年里，人们不时对 Metallge-sellschaft、戴姆勒-奔驰、马自达、日产、卡特彼勒、飞利浦、布尔、奥利维蒂、杜邦、所罗门兄弟和西屋电气等公司提出质疑。

Modern management theory is obsessed with "change" of one sort or another: how to generate it, how to respond to it, how to avoid being swept away by it. This is perhaps not surprising given the number of celebrated companies that have either ended up in the boneyard or at least got a good look over the fence. At one time or another over the past decade doubts have been raised about the likes of Mettallge-sellschaft, Daimler-Benz, Mazda, Nissan, Caterpillar, Philips, Bull, Olivetti, Du Pont, Salomon Brothers, and Westinghouse.

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

大公司似乎并没有庆祝自己的规模，而是试图隐藏它，通过缩小总部、削减管理层级并将自己细分为更小、更易于管理的部门来模仿较小的竞争对手。 瑞士-瑞典工程巨头 ABB 拥有 171 名员工的公司总部，并将自己划分为 1,300 家本地公司，每家公司都是独立的法人实体。 公司创始人珀西·巴内维克 (Percy Barnevik) 说，他遵循 30% 的规则：每当他接管一家公司时，他都会将其官僚机构的规模减少三分之一。 一些公司甚至全力以赴，将自己拆分成独立的公司。 1995 年，美国最大的电话公司 AT&T 和其典型的联合企业 ITT 都一分为三。” 我已经很清楚，利用通信行业涌现出的难以置信的机会，最好的方法是拆分成更小、更专注的企业，”AT&T 的老板鲍勃艾伦解释道：“我们的整合结构对我们来说非常有效. 但这是一个已经过时的想法。”股市同意：新解散的 AT&T 的市值飙升，ITT 也是如此。在 1990 年代初期，英国纺织公司 Cour-taulds 和 ICI一家英国化工公司，一分为二，在宣布分手的三年内，ICI和Zeneca的合并市值是老ICI的两倍半。 AT&T 的老板鲍勃·艾伦 (Bob Allen) 解释说：“我们的一体化结构对我们来说非常有效。但这个想法已经过时了。” 股市同意：新解散的 AT&T 的市值飙升，ITT 的市值也是如此。 1990年代初，英国纺织公司Cour-taulds和英国化工公司ICI一分为二。 在宣布分拆后的三年内，ICI 和 Zeneca 的总市值是原来 ICI 的两倍半。 AT&T 的老板鲍勃·艾伦 (Bob Allen) 解释说：“我们的一体化结构对我们来说非常有效。但这个想法已经过时了。” 股市同意：新解散的 AT&T 的市值飙升，ITT 的市值也是如此。 1990年代初，英国纺织公司Cour-taulds和英国化工公司ICI一分为二。 在宣布分拆后的三年内，ICI 和 Zeneca 的总市值是原来 ICI 的两倍半。 一分为二。 在宣布分拆后的三年内，ICI 和 Zeneca 的总市值是原来 ICI 的两倍半。 一分为二。 在宣布分拆后的三年内，ICI 和 Zeneca 的总市值是原来 ICI 的两倍半。

Rather than celebrating their size, large companies seem to be trying to hide it, imitating their smaller rivals by shrinking their headquarters, slashing layers of management, and subdividing themselves into smaller, more manageable units. ABB, the Swiss-Swedish engineering giant, has a corporate headquarters of 171 people and has divided itself into 1,300 local companies, each one a separate legal entity. Percy Barnevik, the company's founder, says that he follows a 30 percent rule: whenever he takes over a company, he reduces the size of its bureaucracy by a third. Some firms have even gone the whole hog and broken themselves up into separate companies. Both AT&T, America's biggest telephone company, and ITT, its quintessential conglomerate, split themselves into three in 1995. "It has become clear to me that the best way to take advantage of the incredible opportunities springing up in the communications industry is to separate into smaller, more focused enterprises," explained Bob Allen, AT&T's boss: "Our integrated structure worked very well for us. But it is an idea whose time has past." The stock market agreed: the market capitalization of the newbroken-up AT&T, skyrocketed, as did that of ITT. In the early 1990s, Cour-taulds, a British textile company, and ICI, a British chemical company, divided into two. Within three years of announcing the breakup, the combined value of ICI and Zeneca was two-and-a-half times that of the old ICI.

甚至德国人也被迫加入所有这些“分拆”。 自从 Jurgen Schrempp 于 1995 年 5 月接管欧洲最大的公司戴姆勒-奔驰以来，它一直在剥离业务，几乎与收购它们时一样快：1996 年 3 月，Schrempp 让荷兰飞机制造商 Fokker 离开，他曾建议戴姆勒1993年买的，破产了。 在日本，丰田取消了七层管理层中的三层，并将薪酬与头衔脱钩。

Even the Germans have been forced to join in all this "unbundling." Since Jurgen Schrempp took over Daimler-Benz, Europe's biggest company, in May 1995, it has been offloading businesses almost as quickly as it once went about acquiring them: in March 1996 Schrempp let Fokker, a Dutch aircraft maker that he had advised Daimler to buy in 1993, go bankrupt. In Japan, Toyota has eliminated three of its seven layers of management and decoupled pay from titles.

这种思维转变也对企业的社会责任感产生了巨大影响。 即使是最像私有化福利国家的家长式企业，也被迫加入放血的行列，无情地牺牲了管理人员和工人。 一些 IBM 员工感到他们曾经仁慈的雇主如此滥用他们组建了 IBM Workers United，该组织每月发布一份名为 The Resistor 的时事通讯。 1 切割看起来会继续下去。 尽管对“企业厌食症”感到恐慌，但一些美国公司最近

This change of thinking has also had dramatic consequences for firms' sense of social responsibility. Even the most paternalistic companies, which ran themselves rather like privatized welfare states, have been forced to join the bloodletting, ruthlessly sacrificing managers as well as workers. Some IBM employees feel so misused by their once benevolent employer that they have formed IBM Workers United, which publishes a monthly newsletter called The Resistor. 1 And the cutting looks as though it will continue. Despite a panic about "corporate anorexia," some American companies have recently

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

引入了一种被称为“修剪”的做法——定期裁员，以促进幸存者的健康。

introduced a practice known as "pruning"—cutting the workforce regularly in order to promote the health of those who survive.

虚拟的优点

The Virtues of Virtuality

管理理论家对这种企业病症做出了截然不同的诊断。 其中许多都围绕着相关公司的规模。 总的来说，这是一个错误，因为无论是大还是小都不会带来内在优势：这在很大程度上取决于公司所处的市场类型、它提供的产品类型以及它的结构（正如我们将看到的，有有很多方法可以让巨人做小事，让小公司做大事）。 那么为什么辩论很重要呢？ 首先，直到最近，大还是成功的标志：传统公司基于规模经济原则。 其次，关于规模的争论开启了关于现代公司的大部分其他问题。

Management theorists have produced wildly differing diagnoses of this corporate malaise. Many of them revolve around the size of the companies concerned. In general, this is a mistake, since neither bigness nor smallness confers an inherent advantage: it depends enormously on what sort of market a company is in, what sort of product it provides, and how it is structured (as we shall see, there are plenty of ways for a giant to act small and for a small company to act big). So why is the debate important? First, until recently, bigness was sign of success: the traditional company was based on the doctrine of economies of scale. Second, the size debate opens up most of the other issues about the modern,company.

一种广泛持有的观点是，大公司已经过时了，并且正在迅速被更小、更灵活的组织所取代； 在最极端的形式中，这种论点认为未来属于“虚拟”公司——小型的、快速变化的、类似变形虫的组织聚集在一起完成一项工作，然后分崩离析，只是围绕另一个项目以不同的形式重新配置. 彼得德鲁克宣布“财富 500 强已经结束”。 汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters) 认为“小公司几乎在每个市场都在获益”。 2 查尔斯·汉迪 (Charles Handy) 谈到组织正在变成企业公寓——知识工作者的临时集合。 Inc Magazine 和 The Economist 都在不同时期大力宣传“小即是美” 争论并告诫政府支持垂死的巨石。 3个

One widely held view is that big companies have had their day and are rapidly being displaced by much smaller, nimbler organizations; in its most extreme form, this argument holds that the future lies with "virtual" companies—small, fast-changing, amoebalike organizations that come together to get a job done and then break apart, only to reconfigure in a different form around another project. Peter Drucker has announced that "The Fortune 500 is over." Tom Peters argues that "smaller firms are gaining in almost every market." 2 Charles Handy talks about organizations becoming corporate condominiums—temporary collections of knowledge workers. Both Inc Magazine and The Economist have at various times been aggressive promoters of "the small is beautiful" argument and cautioned governments for supporting dying monoliths. 3

虚拟组织的先知们指出，这些公司的固定成本（总部、公司津贴、养老金等）与规模较大的竞争对手相比几乎没有，但仍可以使用现代通信工具来模仿其全球影响力。 从这个角度来看，裁员和裁员的热潮只能避免大公司的死亡。 最后，他们能够与小公司竞争的唯一方法就是加入他们并将自己分成一千个部分。

The prophets of virtual organizations point out that such firms have few of the fixed costs of their bigger rivals—head offices, company perks, pensions, and the like—but can still use modern communication tools to imitate their global reach. From this point of view, the craze for downsizing and delayering can do little more than stave off the death of the big company. In the end the only way that they will be able to compete with small companies is to join them and break themselves up into a thousand parts.

大公司的批评者还指出，自 1970 年代以来，规模经济一直在急剧下降。 “精益制造”

Critics of big companies also point out that economies of scale have been falling dramatically since the 1970s. "Lean manufacturing"

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

和“准时制生产”已将重点从规模转移到及时性； 更自由的资本市场和更便宜、更好的通信从根本上降低了进入行业的壁垒，富裕的传播产生了对定制商品和服务的需求，将大众市场分割成数以千计的利基市场。 与此同时，“规模不经济”的问题越来越严重。 大公司产生官僚主义膨胀； 巨型工厂造成车间异化； 许多大公司无法吸引有创造力的员工，或者即使他们确实抓住了他们也无法充分利用他们。 更糟糕的是，从这些工厂涌出的标准化、同质化产品正遭受着双重挤压：

and "just-in-time production" have shifted the emphasis from size to timeliness; freer capital markets and cheaper, better communications have radically reduced barriers of entry into industries, and the spread of affluence has generated a demand for customized goods and services, fragmenting mass markets into thousands of niches. At the same time, the "diseconomies of scale" have loomed ever larger. Giant companies generate bureaucratic bloat; giant factories create shop-floor alienation; and many giant corporations fail to attract creative workers, or to make good use of them if they do get hold of them. Worse still, the standardized, homogenized products that pour out of these factories are suffering from a double squeeze: fashion-conscious customers are opting for goods that are tailored to their specific needs (or passing whims), while value-conscious ones are less and less willing to pay a premium price for a global brand.

大回来了

Big Is Back

自 1960 年代后期以来，整个工业世界的公司和工作场所的平均规模肯定在稳步下降，欧洲处于领先地位，而美国则在努力追赶。 但规模（或缺乏规模）本身并不能保证失败。 IBM 和戴姆勒-奔驰可能遇到了麻烦，但其他大公司——如麦当劳、玛莎百货和丰田——却繁荣了起来。 《财富》杂志 1995 年列出的美国最受尊敬的 10 家公司中，Rubbermaid 名列榜首，其次是微软、家得宝、英特尔、联合包裹服务公司、惠普，以及中坚力量可口可乐、摩托罗拉、3M 和宝洁公司. 对老牌大企业最有力的挑战者往往是其他大企业。 Sears Roebuck 在美国的市场份额主要输给了沃尔玛等其他大型零售商，

The average size of both companies and workplaces has certainly been falling steadily throughout the industrial world since the late 1960s, with Europe leading the way and America struggling to catch up. But size (or the lack of it) is in itself no guarantee of failure. IBM and Daimler-Benz may have run into trouble, but other big firms— such as McDonald's, Marks and Spencer, and Toyota—have prospered. Fortune's 1995 list of the 10 most admired companies in America consisted of Rubbermaid at the top, along with Microsoft, Home Depot, Intel, United Parcel Services, Hewlett-Packard, and the stalwarts Coca-Cola, Motorola, 3M, and Procter & Gamble. The most vigorous challengers to established big businesses are often other big businesses. Sears Roebuck has lost market share in America principally to other big retailers such as Wal-Mart, which increased its payroll by 182,000 in 1992-94.

事实上，最近出现了支持大公司的强烈反对。 在银行、医疗保健和媒体等行业，老板们深信规模、整合和协同效应是极好的属性，并着手进行大规模合并来证明这一点。 他们的逻辑看起来有问题。 在银行业，大通化学和劳埃德 TSB 等合并的唯一理由是降低成本——这不太可能改善该行业本已很低的客户服务标准。 （“为什么有人认为他们会产生一个

Indeed, there has recently been a backlash in favor of big firms. In industries such as banking, health care, and media, bosses have convinced themselves that size, integration, and synergy are wonderful attributes and embarked on enormous mergers to prove it. Their logic looked faulty. In banking, the only justification for mergers such as Chase-Chemical and Lloyds-TSB is cost reductions—something unlikely to improve the industry's already low standards in customer service. ("Why anybody thinks that they will produce a

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters) 在评论大通与化学公司的合作时评论道：“瞪羚让两只恐龙交配是我无法想象的事情。”但它们也可能扼杀对制药行业的大部分利润负责的公司的创新部分。在娱乐方面，电视网络等分销渠道从尽可能多的制作人那里购买节目和电影更有意义, 而不是仅仅接受其母公司的产品。至于规模，尽管工作室需要足够大才能产生足够的点击量来覆盖大量的哑弹，但还没有人证明像新迪斯尼一样大有任何好处-ABC 合并。当然，它最接近的竞争对手，时代华纳，很难说是垂直整合的鼓舞人心的例子。

gazelle by mating two dinosaurs is beyond me," commented Tom Peters with respect to the Chase-Chemical tie-up.) In health care, the mergers may provide a way for the industry to cope with the new cost-consciousness of its customers; but they could also stifle the innovative parts of companies that are responsible for most of the drug industry's profits. In entertainment, it makes more sense for a distribution channel, such as a television network, to buy shows and films from as many producers as possible, rather than to just take its parent's offerings. As for size, although a studio needs to be big enough to produce enough hits to cover the multitude of duds, nobody has yet proved that there is any gain from being as big as the new Disney-ABC combine. Certainly, its closest rival, Time Warner, is hardly an inspiring example of vertical integration.

《商业周刊》和美世管理公司 1995 年的一项研究调查了 1990 年代初完成的价值超过 5 亿美元的 150 笔交易，发现与同行业的其他公司相比，只有 17% 的交易创造了可观的回报； 而“非收购者”——未参与大型收购的公司——表现优于收购者。 4 这与哈佛大学 Michael Jensen 等学者在 1980 年代对收购进行的大量研究相一致，其中大部分研究表明杠杆收购和合并确实创造了价值——但主要是为被收购公司的股东创造价值。 换句话说，买家付出了太多。 为什么？ 哥伦比亚大学的 Mathew Hayward 和 Donald Hambrick 于 1995 年发表的一项令人愉快的研究发现了一种统计方法来证实我们都已经知道的事情： 老板支付的保险费与他们自己膨胀的自尊心之间存在联系，学术界通过老板的薪水与同龄人的薪水相比以及媒体奉承的报道来衡量这种自尊心。 一旦任何一位老板出现在美国商业杂志的封面上，一边摆弄着他的高尔夫球杆，一边写着“飓风杰克登陆绿地”之类的标题，就卖掉股票。

A 1995 study by Business Week and Mercer Management examined 150 deals worth more than $500 million completed in the early 1990s and found that only 17 percent created substantial returns in comparison with other companies in their sectors; and "nonacquir-ers"—companies that did not take part in big takeovers—outperformed acquirers. 4 This was in line with a host of studies of takeovers in the 1980s by academics such as Michael Jensen at Harvard, most of which showed that leveraged buyouts and mergers did create value—but mainly for shareholders in the companies that were bought. In other words, buyers paid too much. Why? One delightful study released in 1995 by Mathew Hayward and Donald Hambrick of Columbia University found a statistical way of confirming what we all knew already: there was a link between the premiums paid by bosses and their own inflated self-esteem, which the academics measured by things such as the boss's salary in comparison with that of his peers and the acres of flattering press coverage. The moment any boss appears on the cover of an American business magazine fondling his golf clubs alongside a headline such as "Hurricane Jack Lands on the Green," sell the stock.

然而，支持大型合并的可疑论点不应掩盖一个事实，即另一组较为安静的大公司已经证明，规模可以带来更坚实的优势。 最好的大公司——例如可口可乐、李维斯、雀巢和菲利普莫里斯——已经证明可以同时拥有两者：规模带来的重量和过去与小相关的灵活性。

However, the dubious arguments for megamergers should not obscure the fact that another quieter group of big companies have proved that size can have more solid advantages. The best big firms— such as Coca-Cola, Levi Strauss, Nestle, and Philip Morris—have shown that it is possible to have both: the weight that comes with size and the nimbleness that used to be associated with smallness.

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

小公司真的能经得起这些“精简”大公司的竞争吗？ 匹兹堡卡内基梅隆大学教授贝内特哈里森研究了小公司围绕大公司的方式，并认为，即使这些小公司算作独立的实体，他们的员工实际上也同样依赖于这些公司比在大公司工作的同行更重要。 5 硅谷的许多小公司并没有陶醉于他们的敏捷性，他们的主要当务之急是构建联盟和合并，以便他们能够获得必要的规模。 根据美国咨询公司 Broadview Associates 的数据，1995 年全球高科技行业共有 2,913 起并购，价值达到惊人的 1,340 亿美元（相比之下，1994 年为 1,861 起，价值 905 亿美元）。 世界上另一个因面积小而广受赞誉的地方也发生着几乎相同的事情：德国的中小型企业。 1995 年，德国约有 25,000 家中型公司倒闭。在削减成本的时期，机床等行业的中小型公司发现，“外包”东西比大公司更难； 他们还觉得自己在分销产品方面缺乏影响力——尤其是在海外。 “关键公司规模的概念在我们的行业中也适用，”一位著名的中型企业领导者承认道。 6 在日本，虽然一些新贵在零售业等行业成功地抢占了经连会的先机，但大多数小型独立企业都感到难以置信，尤其是因为它们缺乏资金。 1995年8月锦金融破产，

Can small firms really stand up to competition from these "lean and mean" big firms? Bennett Harrison, a professor at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, has looked at the way that small firms cluster around big ones and argued that, even if such small firms count as separate entities, their workers are in fact no less reliant on these corporate hubs than their peers working at the big firms. 5 Far from reveling in their nimbleness, the chief preoccupation of many small firms in Silicon Valley is structuring alliances and mergers so that they can gain the necessary scale. According to Broadview Associates, an American consultancy, there were 2,913 mergers and acquisitions worth a staggering $134 billion in the world's high-tech industry in 1995 (compared with 1,861 deals worth $90.5 billion in 1994). Much the same thing is going on in another part of the world much praised for its smallness: Germany's Mittelstand. Some 25,000 medium-sized companies went bust in Germany in 1995. In a time of cost cutting, small and mid-sized firms in industries such as machine tools found it harder to "outsource" things than big companies; and they also felt that they lacked clout when it came to distributing products—particularly overseas. "The notion of a critical company size holds true in our industry too," admits one prominent Mittelstand leader. 6 In Japan, although a few upstarts have managed to steal a march on the giant keiretsu in businesses such as retailing, most small independent firms feel incredibly exposed, particularly because of their lack of capital. The bankruptcy in August 1995 of Nishiki Finance, one of the few banks prepared to lend to small businesses, led to the bankruptcy of over 400 companies.

模特之死

The Death of a Model

关于规模的争论无疑将继续下去。 但是，如果规模本身不再是灾难的预兆，就像它曾经是成功的预兆一样，那么似乎可以公平地问一下所有关于企业革命的讨论是否合理。 一个大师学派对汤姆彼得斯等人提供的世界末日愿景越来越持怀疑态度。 Henry Mintzberg 是加拿大人，他在麦吉尔大学和 Insead 担任大西洋两岸的管理职位，是一位逆向投资者，他喜欢指出“动荡”并没有什么新鲜事：每

The arguments about size will no doubt continue. But if size per se is no more a portent of disaster than it once was of success, then it seems fair to ask whether all this talk about a corporate revolution is justified. One school of gurus takes an increasingly skeptical view of the apocalyptic visions offered by the likes of Tom Peters. Henry Mintzberg, a Canadian of contrarian bent who holds managerial chairs on both sides of the Atlantic, at McGill University and Insead, likes to point out that there is nothing new about "turbulence": every

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

这一代人认为，他们正经历着前所未有的企业诞生和死亡潮。

generation believes that it is living through an unprecedented spate of corporate births and deaths.

接受这个观点，就像许多经理偷偷做的那样，稍微夸大它，你就会得出两个结论之一。 首先，传统企业要做的就是自我完善——让战略更有远见，结构更精细，管控机制更完善。 事实上，过去二十年许多最成功的管理工具，例如波士顿咨询集团的“增长份额矩阵”——将市场分为摇钱树、明星和狗——旨在增强现有的管理系统。 第二种得过且过的解决方案是保留公司的基本结构，但建造或收购一个“创业”翼，里面挤满了电脑和穿 T 恤的人。 这种方法结合了官僚团结的优点和创业热情的优点。

Accept this point of view, as many managers secretly do, exaggerate it a little, and you reach one of two conclusions. The first is that all the traditional company needs to do is refine itself—to make its strategies more far-seeing, its structures more elaborate, its control mechanisms more comprehensive. Indeed, many of the most successful management tools of the last two decades, such as the Boston Consulting Group's "growth-share matrix"—which divides markets into cash cows, stars, and dogs—are intended to supercharge existing managerial systems. The second muddle-through solution is to keep the firm's basic structure but to build or acquire an "entrepreneurial" wing, crammed with computers and T-shirted people. This approach combines the virtues of bureaucratic solidity with those of entrepreneurial zeal.

这两种解决方案都是危险的自满。 怀旧可能会给战后时期增添光彩，但它肯定比 1980 年代和 90 年代稳定得多：欧洲工商管理学院的两位学者 NC Churchill 和 DF Muzyka 计算出“死亡率”（不再出现的名字的百分比）从一年到下一年）财富 500 强公司的 1990 年是 1970 年的四倍。7 即使是最优秀的管理者也发现，微调传统的命令和控制系统受制于递减法则回报。 同样，在等级森严的公司中打造一个创业翼，即使有效果，也只能在短时间内奏效。 IBM 在 1980 年代的部分问题在于，其个人计算机部门相对自由的思想心态从未影响到公司的其他部门。 通用汽车公司之一 购买 Electronic Data Systems 的想法是吸收一点计算机服务公司的企业文化； 它从来没有这样做，并被迫将公司卖回给其创始人 H. Ross Perot。

Both solutions are dangerously complacent. Nostalgia may add a glow to the postwar period, but it certainly was much stabler than the 1980s and 1990s: N. C. Churchill and D. F. Muzyka, two academics at Insead, have calculated that the "death rate" (the percentage of names that do not reappear from one year to the next) of the Fortune 500 companies was four times as high in 1990 as it was in 1970. 7 Even the best managers have found that fine-tuning traditional command-and-control systems is subject to the law of diminishing returns. Similarly, crafting an entrepreneurial wing onto a hierarchical company only works for a short time, if at all. Part of IBM's problem in the 1980s was that the comparatively free-thinking mentality of its personal computer division never reached the other parts of the company. One of General Motors's ideas behind buying Electronic Data Systems was to absorb a little of the computer-service company's entrepreneurial culture; it never did and was forced to sell the company back to its founder, H. Ross Perot.

谁杀死了阿尔弗雷德斯隆？

Who Killed Alfred Sloan?

公司确实正在经历一场革命，但解释在于规模（有争议的）消亡以外的其他因素。 越来越多的管理思想家认为，各种规模的公司都在经历从一种基于控制的公司模式向另一种基于企业家精神的公司模式的转变。 现任领导人

Companies are indeed undergoing a revolution, but the explanation lies in something other than the (debatable) demise of size. A growing band of management thinkers believe that companies of all sizes are living through a transition from one corporate model based on control to another based on entrepreneurialism. The current leaders

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

这所学校的主要成员是哈佛商学院的克里斯托弗巴特利特和伦敦商学院的苏曼特拉戈沙尔，但其成员还包括欧洲工商管理学院的伊夫多兹和陈金，伦敦商学院的加里哈梅尔和约翰斯托普福德以及密歇根大学的CK普拉哈拉德。

of this school are Christopher Bartlett, of Harvard Business School, and Sumantra Ghoshal, of London Business School, but its members also include Yves Doz and Chan Kim of Insead, Gary Hamel and John Stopford of London Business School, and C. K. Prahalad of Michigan.

即将离去的意识形态是斯隆主义，这是一种以阿尔弗雷德·斯隆命名的管理哲学，他于 1923 年接任通用汽车公司总裁。斯隆的伟大成就是在管理方面做了亨利·福特在劳动方面所做的事情——把它变成可靠、高效、像机器一样的机器过程。 事实上，在很大程度上，斯隆的系统被认为是对付像福特这样喜怒无常的先驱者的一剂解毒剂，福特不合理地不喜欢生产“T”型以外的任何东西（他曾经把一个稍微修改过的版本踢得粉碎）差点让他的公司破产。 斯隆想要创建一家可以自行运营的公司。 因此，他发明了现代多部门公司，其中企业被划分为一组半自治的运营单位， 每个部门负责维持单一业务或市场的市场份额和利润，每个部门的负责人向负责制定长期战略和分配资本的集团总部报告。 虽然斯隆主义公司是分散的，但有一个严格的（正式的）命令和控制系统。 甚至还有一个专业的管理者阶层来管理它——社会学家曾将这些人斥为“组织人”8，而现在评论员们对他们怀有越来越多的怀旧之情。 9 甚至还有一个专业的管理者阶层来管理它——社会学家曾将这些人斥为“组织人”8，而现在评论员们对他们怀有越来越多的怀旧之情。 9 甚至还有一个专业的管理者阶层来管理它——社会学家曾将这些人斥为“组织人”8，而现在评论员们对他们怀有越来越多的怀旧之情。 9

The departing ideology is Sloanism, a managerial philosophy named after Alfred Sloan, who took over as president of General Motors in 1923. Sloan's great achievement was to do for management what Henry Ford had done for labor—turn it into a reliable, efficient, machinelike process. Indeed, to a large extent, Sloan's system was supposed to be an antidote to temperamental pioneers like Ford, whose irrational dislike of producing anything other than the Model "T" (he once kicked to pieces a slightly modified version) nearly bankrupted his company. Sloan wanted to invent a company that could run itself. He thus invented the modern multidivisional firm, in which businesses are divided into a set of semiautonomous operating units, each responsible for maintaining the market share and profits of a single business or market and each having its division heads reporting to a group headquarters in charge of setting long-term strategy and allocating capital. Although the Sloanist firm was decentralized, there was a rigid (and formal) command-and-control system. And there was even a professional class of managers to run it—the people that sociologists once dismissed as "organization men" 8 and that commentators now remember with growing nostalgia. 9

斯隆主义启发了美国资本主义的一些最伟大成就。 这也是生产标准化商品的一种无与伦比的方式。 例如，通用汽车将其在美国市场的份额从 1920 年代初斯隆接手时的 18% 提高到 70 年代末的 45%，成为迄今为止世界上最大的汽车公司。 10

Sloanism inspired some of American capitalism's greatest achievements. It was also an unsurpassed way of producing standardized goods. General Motors, for example, raised its share of the American market from 18 percent in the early 1920s, when Sloan took over, to upward of 45 percent by the late 1970s, to make it by far the largest car company in the world. 10

然而，在过去的 30 年里，斯隆主义模式一直受到攻击。 正如已经指出的那样，它最吵闹的批评者可能是汤姆彼得斯。 但是，即使他从未成为超级大师，斯隆主义也注定会在现实世界中被四个对手破坏。 首先是日本商人，他们通过基于团队合作的“精益”生产，以更好、更便宜、更可靠的商品不断涌入西方市场，避免了斯隆系统的异化和浪费。 第二条战线由 Michael Milken 和 Ivan Boesky 开辟，尽管他们犯了很多错误，但他们证明了斯隆主义让许多美国公司成为

For the past 30 years, however, the Sloanist model has been under attack. As already pointed out, its noisiest critic has probably been Tom Peters. But, even if he had never become a megaguru, Sloanism was destined to be undermined in the real world by four antagonists. First came the Japanese businessmen who relentlessly inundated Western markets with better, cheaper, more reliable goods through "lean" production based on teamwork, which avoided both the alienation and the waste of Sloan's system. The second front was opened up by Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky, who, for all their faults, demonstrated that Sloanism had allowed many American firms to be

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

被对薪酬和津贴比对股东价值更感兴趣的经理劫持。 第三次攻击来自硅谷，那里的苹果公司的史蒂夫乔布斯和其他人一再证明，你可以在不发展庞大的官僚机构的情况下取得商业成功。 最后的攻击来自重组工程师，他们将“营销”、“生产”和“研究”等所有旧的斯隆主义职能部门拆散，并将工人推入跨职能团队，迫使他们使用计算机来弥合差距。

hijacked by managers more interested in their pay and perks than in shareholder value. The third attack came from Silicon Valley, where Apple's Steve Jobs and others there have repeatedly demonstrated that you can succeed in business without growing a giant bureaucracy. The last attack came from the reengineers who ripped apart all the old Sloanist functional departments such as "marketing," "production," and "research" and pushed workers into cross-functional teams, forcing them to use computers to bridge the gaps.

所有这些变化——以及一百个较小的变化——都可以追溯到不确定性和知识。 在他们的压力下，斯隆主义体系瓦解了——或者更准确地说，斯隆信仰之一的极端版本​​，权力下放，战胜了他的其他两个信条，强调正式控制和自给自足。

All of these changes—and a hundred smaller ones—can be traced back to uncertainty and knowledge. Under pressure from them, the Sloanist system has disintegrated—or, more accurately, an extreme version of one of Sloan's beliefs, decentralization, has triumphed over two of his other tenets, the emphasis on formal controls and self-sufficiency.

首先考虑一下斯隆公式的弱点，最显着的是他相信一个精心设计的层次结构，在这个层次结构中，最高级的经理只专注于长期规划，而最基层的则专注于日常问题的解决。 等级制度是一条缓慢移动的传送带，将信息转化为统计数据，并由中层管理人员重新解释给高层的战略制定者。 然而，现代公司必须由他们的客户驱动，而不是他们的官僚机构。 通用电气董事长杰克·韦尔奇 (Jack Welch) 曾斥责这家斯隆主义公司“脸对着首席执行官，屁股对着客户”。

Consider, first, the weak aspects of Sloan's formula, most notably his belief in an elaborately structured hierarchy in which the most senior managers concentrate only on long-term planning and the most junior on day-to-day problem solving. The hierarchy was a slowly moving conveyor belt, relaying information ground into statistics and reinterpreted by middle managers to strategy makers at the top. However, modern companies have to be driven by their customers, not their bureaucracies. Jack Welch, chairman of General Electric, once vilified the Sloanist company for having "its face toward the CEO and its ass toward the customer."

至于数据传送带，今天的市场就像水银一样，迟到的信息不值得拥有。 正如斯隆曾经说过的那样，与其担心理性和成为“一个客观的组织，区别于那些迷失在个性的主观性中的组织”的重要性，现代企业更渴望本能。 例如，理查德·布兰森 (Richard Branson) 在花了三天时间尝试接通 People Express 并发现电话一直处于通话状态时，萌生了成立一家航空公司的想法。 他推断，任何有这种需求的产品都必须严重短缺，因此他创立了维珍航空公司。 确实，将人员永久分配到任何类型的部门的想法似乎很奇怪。 即使部门是特定于行业的，例如“

As for the data conveyor belt, markets today are so like quicksilver that information that arrives late is not worth having. Rather than worrying about rationality and the importance of being "an objective organization, as distinguished from the type that gets lost in the subjectivity of personalities," as Sloan once put it, modern business has a craving for the instinctive. Richard Branson, for example, had the idea of setting up an airline when he spent three days trying to get through to People Express and found the phone permanently engaged. There had to be a severe shortage of any product for which there was such demand, he reasoned, and so he founded Virgin Airlines. Indeed, the idea of allotting people permanently into departments of any sort seems strange. Even if the departments are industry-specific, such as "our computer division," they can still be caught out by new markets and products that often spring up between the cracks of old industries.

重新思考墙内的公司

Rethinking the Company Inside the Walls

下一个受害者是每家公司都是一个完全自给自足的组织的想法。 斯隆主义公司是堡垒，生产许多自己的原材料。 现在，管理人员正在打破壁垒——不仅是与供应商的壁垒，也是与竞争对手的壁垒。 Booz, Allen & Hamilton 的数据显示，1987 年至 1992 年间，美国成立了 20,000 多个新联盟，而 1970 年代只有 750 个。 仅 Xerox 就有 300 个联盟——其中 50 个与 IBM。 现在全世界有 400 多个航空公司联盟，其中许多旨在绕过国界。 欧洲也抓住了联盟的漏洞。 France Telecom 和 Deutsche Telekom 将一半时间花在互相争吵（另一半时间则试图吸引各种美国公司加入他们的行列）。
