The next casualty is the idea of each company as a completely self-sufficient organization. Sloanist firms were fortresses, making many of their own raw materials. Now managers are smashing down barriers—not only with suppliers but also with competitors. More than 20,000 new alliances were formed in the United States between 1987 and 1992, compared with just 750 during the 1970s, according to Booz, Allen & Hamilton. Xerox alone has 300 alliances—50 of them with IBM. There are now more than 400 airline alliances around the world, many of them designed to get around national boundaries. Europe has also caught the alliance bug. France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom spend half their time hopping into bed with each other (and the other half trying to entice various American firms to join them).

联盟的成功率还是很低的。 调查表明这一比例约为五分之一。 他们的预期寿命也很短，很少超过四年。 在博兹询问的三分之一经理中，艾伦称结盟是危险的。 同样的变革力量使一家公司在某一天看起来像是理想的合作伙伴，但在下一天可能会变成竞争对手。 甚至当联盟奏效时，也可能存在关于如何分享战利品或与公司在该领域合作的方式完全不同的事情的问题：1995 年底，荷航和西北航空公司之间的营销联盟通常被认为是最有效的在航空业取得了成功，为每个合作伙伴带来了大约 1.5 亿美元的额外收入，但是，尽管它们具有明显的兼容性，但两家航空公司经常因非运营问题而分道扬镳，

The success rate of alliances is still very low. Surveys put it at about one in five. They also have a low life expectancy, rarely lasting longer than four years. A third of the managers questioned by Booz, Allen described alliances as dangerous. The same forces of change that make a company look like an ideal partner one day can turn it into a competitor the next. And even when alliances work, there can be problems about how to share the spoils or about things quite apart from the way the companies work together in the field: in late 1995 the marketing alliance between KLM and Northwest Airlines is generally deemed to be the most successful in the airline industry, bringing in some $150 million of extra revenue to each partner, but, despite their obvious compatibility, the two carriers have often come close to divorce over non-operational issues, such as shareholder rights.

尽管如此，大多数公司都将联盟视为获得外部专业知识的一种方式，而不必经历冗长的全面收购。 他们还让一家公司涉足一个它尚未完全了解的新行业。 通过企业风险投资等，葛兰素威康和默克等大型制药公司现在与生物技术行业的许多小兄弟公司签订了研究协议。

All the same, most companies see alliances as a way to gain outside expertise without having to go through the rigmarole of a full takeover. They also let a company dip its toe into a new industry that it does not yet fully understand. Through corporate venturing and the like, big drug firms such as Glaxo-Wellcome and Merck now have research agreements with strings of tiny cousins in the biotechnology industry.

公司与其供应商之间的关系也打破了旧的公司壁垒。 世界各地的公司都在减少供应商的数量，并与幸存者建立更密切的关系，向他们展示敏感信息，帮助他们改进程序，并将他们纳入公司奖金计划。 作为其大规模重组的一部分，福特 2000

The old corporate wall has also been breached in the relationship between a company and its suppliers. Around the world companies are reducing the number of suppliers and forging closer relations with those who survive, showing them sensitive information, helping them improve their procedures, and including them in company bonus schemes. As part of its huge reorganization, Ford 2000, the

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

底特律汽车制造商希望将其供应商数量减半（目前为 1,600 家）； 它还将以前在内部完成的各种工程任务交给他们。 部分动机是为了降低成本； 但也是为了获得更好的性能。 毕竟，值得信赖的供应商更有可能提出新产品的创意（如 Marks and Spencer 的食品供应商所做的那样）或为工作分配优秀人才。 福特和克莱斯勒从他们的供应商那里得到的业绩总是比通用汽车好，因为他们向他们承诺了长期交易。 ABB 的一家供应商在承担设计责任后将成本降低了 30%。 11

Detroit car maker hopes to halve its number of suppliers (currently 1,600); it is also handing them various engineering tasks it previously did in-house. The motive is partly to reduce costs; but it is also to get better performance. After all, a trusted supplier is more likely to come up with ideas for new products (as Marks and Spencer's food suppliers do) or to allocate good people to the job. Ford and Chrysler have always got better performance from their suppliers than General Motors because they have promised them long-term deals. One of ABB's suppliers knocked 30 percent off its costs once it was given design responsibility. 11

这种“关联公司”背后的基本假设是，任何产品或服务远非特定公司的特权，而是整个公司链的责任，从供应商开始，到分销商结束。 法国的雷诺甚至让其供应商为其 Twingo 车型设计前灯、仪表板和其他部件。 消费品公司宝洁公司和零售业巨头沃尔玛投资了一个联合信息系统，以协调生产和销售。

The basic assumption behind such "connected corporations" is that, far from being the prerogative of a particular company, any product or service is the responsibility of an entire chain of firms, starting with suppliers and ending with distributors. France's Renault even got its suppliers to design the headlights, instrument panel, and other parts of its Twingo model. Procter & Gamble, a consumer goods company, and Wal-Mart, a retail giant, have invested in a joint information system in a bid to coordinate production with sales.

随着联盟的流行，“供应链管理”的魅力可能被夸大了。 由于在国外寻找零件更便宜，率先提出这一想法的日本制造商正明显地试图从这些联姻中解脱出来。 当受邀合作伙伴被证明是竞争对手时，可能会出现许多问题。 然而，正如专门研究该主题的作者乔丹刘易斯指出的那样，经理们不能再孤立地考虑他们的特定公司。 即使他们的公司尚未与其他公司结成联盟，其内部结构也可能开始类似于公司不同部门之间的联盟网络。

As with the vogue for alliances, the charms of "supply-chain management" may have been exaggerated. Japanese manufacturers who pioneered the idea are noticeably trying to extricate themselves from these marriages now that it is cheaper to find parts abroad. A host of problems can arise when the invited partner turns out to be a competitor. Nevertheless, as Jordan Lewis, an author who specializes in the subject, points out, managers can no longer think about their particular firm in isolation. Even if their firm is not already entwined in a cats cradle of alliances with other firms, its own internal structure is probably beginning to resemble a network of alliances between different parts of the company.

从权力下放到赋权

From Decentralization to Empowerment

在斯隆的堡垒内邀请大量供应商和竞争对手是对这位伟人最珍视的一切的公然攻击。 因此，当前对扁平化等级制度的倾向也是如此。 现代管理层反对斯隆的另一种方式也许是最残酷的。 斯隆的批评者接受了他的一个想法，即权力下放，然后将其推向了他永远不会支持的极端。

Inviting lots of suppliers and rivals inside Sloan's fortress is a blatant attack on everything that the great man held most dear. So, too, is the current penchant for flattening hierarchies. Yet another way in which modern management has turned against Sloan is perhaps the most cruel. Critics of Sloan have accepted one of his ideas, decentralization, and then taken it to extremes that he would never have countenanced.

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

斯隆将通用汽车分为不同的部门，例如别克、庞蒂亚克和雪佛兰。 今天，一些大公司正试图将自己拆分成数以千计的小公司——从而希望为一线工人“赋能”。 该理论认为，在当今疯狂的商业世界中，快速做出错误的决定往往比缓慢做出正确的决定要好。 （当被要求解释他的战略时，美国最大的电话公司之一 MCI 的伯特·罗伯茨回答说：“我们疯狂地奔跑，然后我们改变方向。”）一些公司，例如英国的维珍公司，着重拆分子公司一旦他们达到一定的规模； 台湾电脑公司宏碁将自己拆分为 21 家子公司，每家子公司都打算在股票市场上市。

Sloan divided General Motors into separate arms, such as Buick, Pontiac, and Chevrolet. Today some big companies are trying to break themselves into thousands of small firms—thereby hoping to "empower" the workers in the front line. The theory is that in today's frantic business world it is often better to make the wrong decision quickly than the right one slowly. (Asked to explain his strategy, Bert Roberts of MCI, one of America's biggest telephone companies, replied, "We run like mad, and then we change direction.") Some companies, such as Britain's Virgin, make a point of breaking up subsidiaries once they reach a certain size; Acer, a Taiwanese computer company, is splitting itself into 21 subsidiaries, each of which it intends to float on the stock market.

正如通用电气的杰克韦尔奇所指出的，每家大公司都必须赋予其子公司权力，直到它受到伤害——然后再赋予它们更多权力。 对于一些管理理论家来说，即使是这种程度的权力下放也是不够的。 例如，Tom Peters 认为公司应该将每个员工视为一个独立的小公司。 他赞扬了丽思卡尔顿集团，该集团甚至赋予其最低级​​的侍者当场花费高达 2,000 美元来解决客户问题的权力。 彼得斯的商业英雄之一是旧金山丽思卡尔顿酒店四楼的女管家弗吉尼亚·阿苏埃拉 (Virginia Azuela)，她“拥有”该楼层，因为她做出了维护该楼层的所有决定。

As GE's Jack Welch has pointed out, each big company has to give its subsidiaries power until it hurts—and then give them more. For some management theorists even this level of decentralization is inadequate. Tom Peters, for instance, thinks that companies should treat each worker as a small company in his or her own right. He praises the Ritz-Carlton group, which has given even its lowliest bellhops the power to spend up to $2,000 on the spot to solve a customer's problem. One of Peters's business heroes is Virginia Azuela, the housekeeper on the fourth floor of the Ritz Carlton in San Francisco who "owns" that floor because she makes all the decisions involved in maintaining it.

这种规模的权力下放的问题在于它似乎离无政府状态只有一步之遥。 一些 Peters 助手的自然回答可能是：“好吧。踩油门！” 另一方面，宝洁和麦当劳等一系列大公司似乎也能像虚拟公司一样在新的混乱世界中蓬勃发展。 甚至更时髦、更扁平的公司，如微软、英特尔或麦肯锡，与其说是组织混乱，不如说是组织方式不同。 这些公司可能扁平而灵活，但它们也不仅仅是个人的集合。 有什么东西把他们联系在一起。 它是一种新型的积木。

The problem with decentralization on this scale is that it may seem only a step away from anarchy. The natural reply of some Peters acolytes might be: "Fine. Step on the gas!" On the other hand, a whole range of big companies, such as Procter & Gamble and McDonald's, seem just as capable of thriving in the new chaotic world as virtual companies. And even the trendier, flatter companies such as Microsoft, Intel, or McKinsey are not so much disorganized as organized in a different way. Such firms may be flat and flexible, but they are also more than just a collection of individuals. There is something holding them together. It is a new kind of building block.

新的组成部分： 1. 核心竞争力

The New Building Blocks: 1. Core Competencies

随着斯隆体系的崩溃，人们自然而然地倾向于寻找另一种结构来取代它——一组新的部门、部门和团队。 可惜没有万能的

With the collapse of the Sloanist system, the natural inclination is to look for another structure to replace it—a new set of departments, divisions, and teams. Unfortunately, there is no universal

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

之类的回答。 相反，管理理论倾向于关注横向公司可以跨越其许多部门以定义自己的技术。 这些包括网络建设和创业精神。 但每家公司的出发点都是管理理论中最丑陋但最重要的流行语之一：“核心竞争力”。

answer of that sort. Rather, management theory has tended to focus on techniques by which a horizontal company can stretch across its many divisions in order to define itself. These include network building and entrepreneurialism. But the starting point for every company is one of management theory's ugliest but most important buzzwords: "core competencies."

“核心能力”，按照加里·哈梅尔和 CK Praha-lad 的定义，是一种技能和能力，无论是编纂的还是未编纂的，它们赋予公司独特的风格，并且不能轻易被竞争对手模仿。 这些知识的集合构成了它的专业知识，这使公司具有竞争优势。 例如，索尼在微型化方面的核心竞争力使该公司能够生产从索尼随身听到摄像机再到笔记本电脑的所有产品； 佳能在光学、成像和微处理器控制方面的核心竞争力使其能够进入复印机、激光打印机、照相机和图像扫描仪等看似多样化的市场。

"Core competencies," as defined by Gary Hamel and C. K. Praha-lad, are the skills and capabilities, codified and uncodified, that give a company its unique flavor and that cannot be easily imitated by a rival. These collections of knowledge constitute its expertise, which is what gives companies their competitive edge. Sony's core competence in miniaturization, for example, allows the company to make everything from the Sony Walkman to videocameras to notebook computers; Canon's core competencies in optics, imaging, and microprocessor controls have allowed it to enter such seemingly diverse markets as copiers, laser printers, cameras, and image scanners.

然而，核心能力的重点与其说是公司做什么，不如说是决定不做什么（然后将其外包给专家）。 通常选择一项核心竞争力意味着将其自身排除在其表现不佳的生产过程中。 佳能可能擅长制造复印机，但这家日本公司从公司外部购买了 75% 的组件。 任天堂让其他人设计其视频游戏。 耐克设计和销售运动鞋，但不自行组装任何东西。 在半导体行业，“无晶圆厂”（或无制造）公司，如美国的 Cirrus Logic，一直坚持设计； 这为台积电等公司留下了销售服务的空间，即“代工厂”——接受订单的制造商。

However, the whole point of core competencies is not so much what a firm does as what it decides not to do (which it then contracts out to specialists). Often selecting a core competence means excluding itself from parts of the production process it performs poorly. Canon may be good at making photocopiers but the Japanese firm buys 75 percent of the components from outside the company. Nintendo lets others design its video games. Nike designs and sells sports shoes but does not assemble anything itself. In the semiconductor industry, "fabless" (or fabrication-less) firms, such as America's Cirrus Logic, have stuck to design; that has left room for companies such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation to sell their services as "foundries"—manufacturers who will work to order.

在 Brooks Brothers 将裁缝业务外包的时代，“外包”已不再是神圣不可侵犯的事情。 据估计，在 1980 年代末，小型分包商占美国大公司生产成本的近一半。 即使是相当小的公司也在挖空自己，以便专注于自己的核心竞争力。 罗莎贝丝·莫斯·兰特 (Rosabeth Moss Ranter) 为她最近的一本书《世界级：在全球经济中蓬勃发展》(World Class: Thriving Locally in the Global Economy) (1995) 访问了波士顿地区的 42 家公司，其中最有可能外包的事情是食品、工资单、清洁、建筑维护、邮件、安全、当地交通、旅行安排、公共关系、儿童保育、培训、

In an age when Brooks Brothers contracts out its tailoring, nothing is sacred where "outsourcing" is concerned. By one estimate, small subcontractors accounted for nearly half the production costs of large American firms at the end of the 1980s. Even fairly small companies are hollowing themselves out so that they can concentrate on their core competencies. At the 42 companies in the Boston area that Rosabeth Moss Ranter visited for her most recent book, World Class: Thriving Locally in the Global Economy (1995), the most likely things to be outsourced were food, the payroll, cleaning, building maintenance, mail, security, local transportation, travel arrangements, public relations, child care, training,

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

技术写作和印刷。 此外，制造公司正在外包金属加工、喷漆、模切甚至装配等活动。

technical writing, and printing. In addition, manufacturing companies were outsourcing activities such as metal fabrication, painting, die cutting, and even assembly.

总的来说，这似乎有利于相关公司。 Coopers & Lybrand 1993 年对近 400 家快速发展的公司进行的一项调查显示，外包的 65% 的公司比没有外包的公司表现更好。 快速浏览一下汽车行业就会发现，丰田和宝马（它们购买了大约 75% 的汽车零部件）比​​福特（50%）做得更好，而福特又比通用汽车（25%）做得更好。 与此同时，外包行业发展迅速，不仅催生了必能宝和 EDS 等巨头，也催生了无数小公司。 甚至修道院也参与其中。 弗吉尼亚州的圣十字修道院和肯塔基州的客西马尼修道院已将各种技术和知识数据库计算机化，并通过名为 Electronic Sc​​riptorium 的数据服务经纪人出售他们的服务。 12

In general, this seems to benefit the companies concerned. A 1993 survey by Coopers & Lybrand of nearly 400 fast-growing companies showed that the 65 percent that outsourced performed better than those that did not. A quick look at the car industry shows that Toyota and BMW (which buy about 75 percent of their car parts) have done better than Ford (50 percent), which in turn has done better than General Motors (25 percent). Meanwhile, the outsourcing industry has grown like topsy, fattening not only giants such as Pitney Bowes and EDS, but also countless smaller firms. Even monasteries have gotten in on the act. The Holy Cross Abbey in Virginia and Gethsemani Abbey in Kentucky have computerized various technical and intellectual databases, selling their services through a data services broker called the Electronic Scriptorium. 12

成功公司的核心竞争力比自己公司的核心竞争力更容易发现。 许多老式的企业集团通过覆盖广泛的领域来作弊。 在韩国，当政府试图将公司限制在少数核心业务时，财阀（对该国的企业集团的称呼）的回应是选择技术、工业和能源等广泛领域。 在法国，自来水公司似乎已经说服自己，有线电视对他们来说是一项自然而然的业务，因为就像水一样，它涉及管道并且有复杂的计费系统。 即使在美国，罗克韦尔和通用电气等许多大型多元化公司也将其核心竞争力建立在行业第一或第二等目标之上。

The core competencies of successful companies are somewhat easier to spot than those of one's own firm. Many old-fashioned conglomerates cheat by covering wide areas. In South Korea, when the government tried to restrict companies to a few core businesses, the chaebol (as the country's conglomerates are called) responded by choosing broad areas such as technology, industry, and energy. In France water companies seem to have persuaded themselves that cable television is a natural business for them to be in, because, like water, it involves pipes and has a complicated billing system. Even in America, many big diversified companies, such as Rockwell and General Electric, base their core competencies around objectives such as being number one or number two in an industry.

正如 Hamel 和 Praha-lad 承认的那样，核心竞争力的另一个问题是，如果市场发生变化，经理们墨守成规，他们很容易退化为“核心僵化”。 一个常见的问题是自满。 直到 1980 年代，西尔斯的内部立场文件甚至都没有提到沃尔玛是一个值得关注的竞争对手。 另一个问题是做太多好事。 到 20 世纪 90 年代中期，索尼对不断推出新产品的痴迷开始让客户感到厌倦。 然而，也许最大的问题是人性的基本保守主义：大多数人继续以相同的方式思考问题，使用相同的旧技术，并满足相同的旧客户。

Another problem with core competencies, as Hamel and Praha-lad admit, is that, if the market changes and managers get stuck in a rut, they can easily degenerate into "core rigidities." One common problem is complacency. Until well into the 1980s Sears's internal position papers did not even mention Wal-Mart as a competitor to be watched. Another problem is making too much of a good thing. By the mid-1990s Sony's obsession with churning out new variations on products was beginning to tire customers. Perhaps the biggest problem, however, is the basic conservatism of human nature: most people go on thinking about problems in the same way, using the same old technologies, and satisfying the same old customers.

大辩论 新的组成部分：2. 更新

THE GREAT DEBATES The New Building Blocks: 2. Renewal

因此，将核心竞争力视为一成不变的做法是危险的。 这就是为什么现代管理理论家总是在寻找让公司保持警惕的方法（用行话来说就是实践“更新”）。

It is dangerous therefore to treat core competencies as though they were set in stone. That is why modern management theorists are always looking for ways to keep a company on its toes (to practice "renewal," in the jargon).

在大多数情况下，重组公司的责任落在公司董事长身上。 最好的领导者往往是喜欢炸毁自己的作品的颠覆者。 然而，这不是一个可以经常应用的解决方案。 理论家们还提出了另外两种确保公司生存的方法。 再一次，整个组织都必须得到处理，因为这些不仅仅是可以附加到某个部门的可选附加功能。

In most cases the responsibility for shaking up the company falls on the company chairman. The best leaders are often subversives who enjoy blowing up their own creations. However, this is hardly a solution that can be applied too often. The theorists have also come up with two other ways of making sure that companies stay alive. Once again, the whole organization has to be treated, for these are not just optional extras that can be bolted onto some department.

其中第一个是企业家精神。 汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters) 曾将其定义为“基于不充分证据的不合理信念”的企业家船，正是斯隆的系统应该根除的东西。 然而，斯隆主义公司面临的最大问题之一是它们的保守主义：负责创新的与世隔绝的精英们太远离市场，太受传统智慧的束缚，无法认识到市场中出现的新需求。 企业家精神与创新之间的联系将在第 6 章中进行更深入的研究。这里只要说企业家精神基本上意味着创建小单位，赋予他们尝试想法的权力，也许最重要的是，允许他们犯错误。 这并不意味着向他们砸钱。 正如彼得斯经常指出的那样，

The first of these is entrepreneurialism. Entrepreneur ship, which Tom Peters once defined as "unreasonable conviction based on inadequate evidence," was precisely what Sloan's system was supposed to eradicate. Yet one of the biggest problems for Sloanist companies was their conservatism: the cloistered elite in charge of innovation were too far removed from the market and too bound by conventional wisdom to recognize the new demands arising in the marketplace. The link between entrepreneurialism and innovation is examined more closely in Chapter 6. Suffice it to say here that basically entrepreneurialism means creating small units, giving them the power to try out ideas, and, perhaps most important, allowing them to make mistakes. This does not mean throwing money at them. As Peters often points out, 75 percent of the firms on Inc Magazine's list of the 500 fastest-growing small firms in America in 1992 were started with less than $100,000 and 50 percent with less than $50,000.

另一个过程是联网，以确保这些创业理念在整个公司传播。 沃尔玛有一个视频链接，将所有商店与公司总部以及彼此之间连接起来：商店经理经常举行视频会议，交换有关哪些产品正在销售以及哪些促销活动有效的信息。 在日本消费品公司花王，内部信息网络让每个人都能了解与公司有关的一切，其实验室经常从世界另一端飞来公司的科学家参加会议。 瑞典爱立信已将 20 个国家 40 个研究中心的 17,000 名工程师连接到同一个计算机网络中。 复印

The other process is networking to make sure these entrepreneurial ideas spread throughout the company. Wal-Mart has a video link connecting all the stores to corporate headquarters and to each other: store managers frequently hold videoconferences to swap information on which products are selling and which promotions are working. At Kao, a Japanese consumer products company, an internal information network allows everybody to find out about everything to do with the company, and its laboratories frequently fly company scientists from the other end of the world to attend meetings. Sweden's Ericsson has linked 17,000 engineers in 40 research centers in 20 countries into the same computer network. Xerox

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

鼓励技术代表制作视频，讲述他们在解决棘手问题方面取得的成就，然后像科学家分发研究论文一样将其分发到世界各地。 福特有一个内部电视网络，可以让员工了解从世界汽车公司的股票价格到最新赛车结果的一切信息。

encourages technical representatives to make videos of themselves talking about their achievements in solving tricky problems and then distribute them all over the world, just as scientists distribute research papers. Ford has an internal television network that keeps employees informed about everything from the stock prices of the world's car companies to the latest motor racing results.

然而，电子网络通常是不够的。 经理们仍然需要面对面会面。 哈佛商学院教授威廉·布伦斯 (William Bruns) 指出，高级管理人员每 4 周中有 3 周出差的情况并不少见——或者提前 12 到 15 个月在彩色日记中制定时间表：红色代表欧洲，蓝色代表南美，绿色代表家庭办公室。

Often, however, electronic networking is not enough. Managers still need to meet face to face. William Bruns, a professor at Harvard Business School, points out that it is not uncommon for senior managers to spend three out of every four weeks on business trips—or to have their timetables worked out 12 to 15 months in advance in color-coded diaries: red for Europe, blue for South America, green for the home office.

但是一个人拥挤的日程并不能造就一个网络化的公司。 雀巢、联合利华和 ABB 等公司不断将组织不同部门的人员聚集在一起，希望他们能够发电。 （“技术转让不仅仅是一套工具，”联合利华的一位高级官员评论道。）沃尔玛使用其私人空军将商店经理运送到其位于阿肯色州本顿维尔的总部。 大多数公司通过看似奢侈的安排（例如高级管理人员的定期务虚会和营销部门的全球聚会）来获得资金的价值。 摩托罗拉甚至将来自新加坡和佛罗里达的工人派往山区度假胜地，以帮助他们更好地相处。

But one man's crowded schedule does not make a networked corporation. Companies such as Nestle, Unilever, and ABB constantly throw people from different parts of the organization together in the hope that they will generate electricity. ("Technology transfer is more that just a piece of kit," remarks one senior Unilever figure.) Wal-Mart uses its private air force to ferry store managers to its headquarters in Bentonville, Arkansas. Most companies get their money's worth from seemingly extravagant arrangements such as regular retreats for senior managers and global get-togethers for the marketing department. Motorola even sent workers from Singapore and Florida to a mountain resort to help them get along better.

如果不出意外，网络意味着摆脱排他性的部门——鼓励杰克韦尔奇所说的无边界行为：“每次你遇到某人，你都在寻找更好、更新和更大的想法。你对来自任何地方的想法持开放态度。 “ 13 思想和知识对企业成功的重要性意味着每个人都必须愿意分享他们的思想成果。 Verifone 有一句谚语：“Share, or screw you”。

If nothing else, networking means getting rid of exclusive departments—encouraging what Jack Welch calls boundary-less behavior: "Every time you meet somebody, you're looking for a better and newer and bigger idea. You are open to ideas from anywhere." 13 The importance of ideas and knowledge to corporate success means that everybody must be willing to share the fruits of their thinking. At Verifone there is a saying, "Share, or screw you."

文化如胶

Culture as Glue

核心能力、更新、网络和企业家精神：愤世嫉俗者可能会说这听起来像是一个相当模糊的清单，可以围绕它来建立公司。 愤世嫉俗者是对的。 事实上，与其试图从这些构建块中构建一个横向公司，不如争论在理智上更诚实

Core competencies, renewal, networking, and entrepreneurial-ism: a cynic might say that this sounds like a fairly vague list around which to build a company. And the cynic would be right. Indeed, rather than trying to construct a horizontal company out of these building blocks, it might seem intellectually more honest to argue

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

完美的后斯隆主义公司几乎是无结构的。 将它结合在一起的是它的文化——一种无形的东西，它激励员工自律，并允许经理和他们的员工（使用两个过时的术语）相互信任。 事实上，文化并不像听起来那么短暂。

that the perfect post-Sloanist company is almost structureless. All that holds it together is its culture—that intangible thing that inspires employees to be self-disciplined and allows managers and their workers (to use two outdated terms) to trust each other. In fact, culture is not as ephemeral as it sounds.

认为最成功的公司是那些拥有最强大企业文化的公司是一种自我实现的预言。 大多数经理只能梦想为一家大多数员工本能地知道他们应该做什么的公司工作。 但是，确实存在一些。 例如，在强生公司，“信条”——一种正式的使命宣言——在公司遍布世界各地的工厂中得到了印记； Credo 不仅帮助一家日益多样化的公司团结在一起，而且还被认为指导了公司对泰诺危机的原则性反应，当时一名疯子在公司的一些泰诺药片中掺入了氰化物。

Arguing that the most successful companies are those with the strongest corporate cultures is something of a self-fulfilling prophecy. Most managers can only dream of working for a company in which most of the employees know instinctively what they should be doing. However, a few do exist. At Johnson & Johnson, for instance, the "Credo"—a sort of formalized mission statement—is emblazoned in the company's factories throughout the world; the Credo has not only helped keep an increasingly diverse company together, but it is also credited with guiding the company's principled response to the Tylenol crisis, when a lunatic laced some of the company's Tylenol tablets with cyanide.

在大多数情况下，公司的文化无法体现在一些平淡无奇的使命宣言中。 在美国零售商 Nordstrom，整个员工手册相当于一张纸，上面写着“在任何情况下都要运用你的良好判断力”，但在那里工作的每个人都痴迷于客户服务。 同样，当惠普的员工谈论所谓的“惠普之道”时，他们指的并不是规则手册。 在基业长青：有远见的公司的成功习惯（1995 年）中，杰里波拉斯和詹姆斯柯林斯认为，最成功的公司坚持他们的核心价值观 - 一种核心竞争力的文化版本。 因此，虽然它的帝国现在从主题公园延伸到网络电视，但迪士尼基本上坚持其健康和让人们快乐的核心价值观。 IBM 之所以跌跌撞撞，是因为它不太关注其核心价值（客户服务），而是关注业务战略（主导大型计算机）。 回到 HP，Bill Hewlett 和 David Packard 拒绝接受大型政府合同，因为他们认为这会迫使他们采取先雇后解的心态，这会破坏作为 HP 方式的一部分的对个人的尊重。

In most cases, the company's culture cannot be captured in some anodyne mission statement. At Nordstrom, an American retailer, the entire employee manual amounts to one piece of paper saying "Use your good judgment in all situations," but everybody who works there is obsessed with customer service. Similarly, when people at Hewlett-Packard talk about something called "the HP way," they are not referring to a rule book. In Built to Last: Successful Habits of Visionary Companies (1995), Jerry Porras and James Collins argued that the most successful companies have stuck to their core values— a sort of cultural version of core competencies. Thus, though its empire now stretches from theme parks to network television, Disney has basically stood by its core values of wholesomeness and making people happy. IBM stumbled because it paid less attention to its core value (customer service) than to a business strategy (dominating mainframe computers). Back at HP, Bill Hewlett and David Packard refused to take on big government contracts because they thought it would force them to adopt a hire-and-fire mentality, which would destroy the respect for the individual that is part of the HP way.

企业文化不是刚出现的东西。 公司——尤其是老板——必须为此努力。 值得注意的是，当今的许多商业英雄，如维珍的理查德布兰森、美体小铺的安妮塔罗迪克或

Corporate culture is not something that just appears. Companies—and bosses in particular—have to work at it. It is noticeable that many of today's business heroes, such as Richard Branson of Virgin, Anita Roddick of the Body Shop, or Herb Kelleher of

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

Southwest Airlines 特别擅长激发员工的热情，甚至热情。 但即使是“鼓舞人心”的领导力也需要汗水。 罗迪克 (Roddick) 大部分时间都在与她的员工会面； 她在她的 700 家店铺中每家都安装了布告栏、传真机和录像机。 各地的高级管理人员都将更多时间花在 ABB 执行副总裁 Goran Lidahl 所说的“人体工程学”上：了解员工。

Southwest Airlines, are particularly talented at generating enthusiasm—and even passion—among their staff. But even "inspirational" leadership involves perspiration, too. Roddick spends much of her time meeting her employees; she has installed bulletin boards, faxes, and videocassette-recorders in each of her 700 shops. Senior managers everywhere are spending more time on what Goran Lidahl, ABB's executive vice president, calls "human engineering": getting to know workers.

然而，公司延续其文化最明显的地方是招聘和培训。 现代企业教育的目标之一是鼓励自律（在理想的后斯隆主义组织中，自律应该取代来自上层的权威）。 在整个 1980 年代，宜家创始人英格瓦·坎普拉德 (Ingvar Kamprad) 主持了为期一周的培训课程，培训对象是精心挑选的经理，内容涉及公司的历史、文化和价值观。 Andersen Consulting 是一家管理咨询公司，其培训计划非常全面，以至于其员工经常被嘲笑为“Andersen Androids”。 机器人从六周的强化训练开始，这与军队新兵训练营非常相似，每周 80 小时，并有严格的着装要求。 在公司的前五年，他们接受了大约 1,000 小时的正式培训。

However, the most obvious place for companies to perpetuate their culture is in recruitment and training. One aim of modern corporate education is to encourage self-discipline (which in the ideal post-Sloanist organization is supposed to replace authority from above). Throughout the 1980s Ingvar Kamprad, the founder of IKEA, led week-long training sessions for hand-picked managers on the company's history, culture, and values. Andersen Consulting, a management consultancy, has such a thorough training program that its employees are often mocked as "Andersen Androids." The Androids start off with six weeks of intensive training that resembles nothing so much as an army boot camp, with 80-hour weeks and a strict dress code. In their first five years with the company, they receive about 1,000 hours of formal training. On being recruited, all Androids are assigned to a "counseling partner" who meets them every six months to discuss their performance.

然而，只有当人们彼此信任时，自律才会起作用。 甚至在 Francis Fukuyama 将“信任”变成一个话题之前，管理理论家就已经越来越重视这个概念，这是正确的。 在这些松散得多的组织中，如果初级经理认为他们的上级将公司的最大利益放在心上，他们只会服从他们的上级； 高层管理人员只有在觉得可以信任他们的情况下才会将权力交给他们的下属。 根据对 3,500 家公司的调查和对 10 家领先公司的后续采访，欧洲工商管理学院教授 Chan Kim 和他的同事 Renee Mauborgne 证明，只有高层管理人员建立公平（“程序正义”，用他们的话说）进入公司的核心。

However, self-discipline only operates when people trust one another. Even before Francis Fukuyama turned "trust" into a talking point, management theorists had been putting more and more emphasis on the concept, and rightly so. Junior managers will only obey their seniors in these much looser organizations if they feel that their seniors have the company's best interests at heart; and senior managers will only hand power over to their juniors if they feel that they can trust them. On the basis of a survey of 3,500 companies and follow-up interviews with 10 leading companies, Chan Kim, a professor at Insead, and his colleague Renee Mauborgne, have demonstrated that trust only flourishes if top management builds fairness ("procedural justice," in their terms) into the heart of the firm. Senior managers must go to great lengths to ensure that decisions are fair, and seen to be fair, particularly in sprawling companies, where lines of control are vague and suspicion of political infighting is rife.

大辩论 但它稳定吗？

THE GREAT DEBATES But Is It Stable?

今天的商学院学者们对阿尔弗雷德·斯隆或许有些苛刻。 斯隆总是担心他的想法会被无聊的人和官僚滥用，他并不完全是人们现在想象的机器般服从的提倡者。 他认为管理者应该将自己视为工人的仆人而不是他们的主人，并试图鼓励知识独立。 在得知通用汽车的一个最高委员会就某个主题达成完全一致后，他提议推迟会议，直到人们形成一些独立的意见。 14

Today's business school academics are perhaps a little hard on Alfred Sloan. Always worried that his ideas would be misused by bores and bureaucrats, Sloan was not quite the advocate of machinelike obedience that people now imagine. He argued that managers should see themselves as workers' servants rather than their masters and tried to encourage intellectual independence. On being told that one of GM's top committees was in complete agreement on a subject, he proposed postponing the meeting until people had cultivated some independent opinions. 14

如果斯隆与后斯隆主义公司一起出现，他可以有理由指出模型中至少有三个突出的断层线已经取代了他的模型。 首先是它对魅力型领导者的巨大重视。 正如第 9 章所指出的，现代老板严重过度劳累。 公司还不得不面对斯隆主义所消除的问题：全能的老板可能会轻轻地偏离轨道，以及难以找到同样有魅力的继任者。 本章中多次出现的两家公司，ABB 和通用电气 (GE)，现在都依赖有魅力的领导者，他们总有一天会退休。 事实上，强大的领导者习惯于培养二流人才接替他们，这意味着继任危机可能会在企业场景中变得更加普遍。

If Sloan was presented with the post-Sloanist company, he could with reason point to at least three protruding fault lines in the model that has replaced his. The first is the enormous importance it ascribes to charismatic leaders. As Chapter 9 points out, the modern boss is seriously overworked. Companies are also having to confront problems that Sloanism banished: the risk that an all-powerful boss will gently go off the rails, and the difficulty of finding an equally charismatic successor. Two companies that have popped up several times in this chapter, ABB and General Electric (GE), now both depend on charismatic leaders who will one day retire. The fact that powerful leaders have a habit of grooming second-rate people to succeed them means that succession crises are likely to become more common on the corporate scene.

第二个问题是，随着公司变得越来越复杂，管理者的工作也变得越来越模糊。 曾经，管理者可以简单地告诉下属该做什么。 现在人们必须横向和纵向报告，跨越国界和国家内部，而且他们必须在越来越模糊的情况下这样做，竞争对手突然成为盟友，而经理过去用来引导的供应商现在得到了一个比同一家工厂的经理办公室更大的办公室。 或者，经理可能会被任命为一个将德国研究人员与加利福尼亚设计师聚集在一起的团队的“团队负责人”。

The second problem is that, as companies grow more complicated, the job of managers becomes more ill-defined. Once managers could simply tell their subordinates what to do. Now people have to report laterally as well as vertically, across borders as well as within countries, and they have to do so in conditions of mounting ambiguity, where competitors are suddenly allies and where the supplier the manager used to boot around is now given a bigger office than the manager's in the same factory. Or the manager might be made "team leader" of a group that has thrown German researchers together with Californian designers.

然而，斯隆最担心的可能是控制区。 公司发现从正式管理结构到非正式管理结构的转变充满了风险。 正式结构的弱化显然导致了一些惊人的灾难。 这

However, Sloan's biggest concern would probably have been over the area of control. Companies are finding that the shift from formal to informal management structures is rife with risks. The weakening of formal structures has clearly led to some spectacular disasters. The

反思公司

Rethinking the Company

Barings 家族失去了银行，因为管理层过度授权了一个人 Nick Leeson。 日本最大的两家银行 Daiwa 和​​ Sumitomo 也因未能控制交易员而损失了小笔财富。 在好莱坞，日本的索尼公司对有创造力的知识型员工做了本该做的事：它给了他们数十亿美元和大量的信任——结果却被踢了脸。 联合利华的一位高层人士现在将其 Persil Power 的惨败（它生产了更强效的洗涤剂，不幸地损坏了衣服）部分归咎于它决定将产品责任交给一个自治团队。

Barings family lost its bank because the management overempowered one individual, Nick Leeson. Two of Japan's biggest banks, Daiwa and Sumitomo, have also lost small fortunes by failing to control traders. In Hollywood, Japan's Sony did what one was supposed to with creative knowledge workers: it gave them billions of dollars and oodles of trust—and got kicked in the face. One senior figure at Unilever now blames its Persil Power fiasco (it produced a stronger version of its detergent that unfortunately damaged clothes) in part on its decision to hand responsibility for the product to a self-governing team.

理论上，所有这些外部控制来源都应该被“信任”和“自律”所取代。 即使他发现这些概念是可口的，斯隆也会指出，现代管理所做的所有其他事情已经大大降低了它们作为控制代理人的有效性。 取代他自己的系统充满了矛盾。

In theory, all these external sources of control are supposed to be replaced by "trust" and "self-discipline." Even if he had found these concepts palatable, Sloan would have pointed out that their effectiveness as controlling agents has been dramatically reduced by all the other things modern management is up to. The system that has replaced his own is fraught with contradictions.

由于裁员和裁员的流行，没有工人能确定他们的长期未来。 联盟的流动性意味着朋友会迅速变成敌人。 随着对速度的强调，人们很少有时间发展长期的信任关系。 时间和金钱的压力迫使公司压缩人员见面的培训课程。 多元文化公司的到来，意味着人们不能再靠共同的背景和默契将他们束缚在一起。 最糟糕的是，许多管理者被期望自愿参与到他们自己的毁灭中。 公司老板被要求将自己从地方大亨转变为忠诚的副手，中层管理人员被告知要开发不需要中层管理人员的系统。

Because of the popularity of downsizing and delayering, no workers can be sure of their long-term futures. The fluidity of alliances means that friends are rapidly transformed into enemies. With the emphasis on speed, people have less time to develop long-term trusting relationships. The pressure of time and money is forcing companies to compress training courses in which people meet each other. The arrival of multicultural companies means that people can no longer rely on shared backgrounds and tacit understanding to bind them together. Worst of all, many managers are expected to act as willing participants in their own destruction. Company bosses are asked to transform themselves from local barons into loyal lieutenants, and middle managers are being told to develop systems that will make middle management unnecessary.

这些矛盾已经迫使一些公司重新引入一些现代大师所鄙视的命令和控制。 还要注意的是，一些在对外民主方面大做文章的公司也是等级森严的公司。 把你的车停在好莱坞电影制片厂外别人的空间里，你很快就会发现所有的阿玛尼休闲装都掩盖了严格的阶级制度。 在巡回演出时，滚石乐队拥有 17 级安全通行证。 即使在微软，也有一种自动控制形式：任何有价值的东西都经过比尔盖茨的办公室。

These contradictions are already forcing some firms to reintroduce some of the command and control modern gurus despise. Note, too, that some of the companies that make a great fuss about being democratic to the outside world are also among the most hierarchical. Park your car in somebody else's space outside a Hollywood studio and you will soon discover that all the Armani casual wear disguises a rigid class system. When on tour, the Rolling Stones have 17 grades of security pass. Even at Microsoft, there is one automatic form of control: everything of any value goes through Bill Gates's office.

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

这是一种修正冲动，而不是逆转。 即使现代的“非正式”公司在某种程度上不如他们的斯隆主义前辈那么强大，但毫无疑问它们是未来的组织形式。 经理必须再次回到那些旧概念：不确定性，尤其是知识。 公司过去认为他们最宝贵的资源是资本，他们所需要的只是一小部分精英来分配资本和围绕员工的老板。 “为什么当我想要一双手时，我也得到了一个人，”亨利·福特曾经说过。 现在公司意识到他们最重要的资产是知识。 知识的麻烦在于它比资本更难管理：它不仅固定在讨厌的员工脑袋里而不是储存在银行里，

This is a correcting impulse rather than a reversal. Even if modern "informal" companies are somewhat less robust than their Sloanist predecessors, there seems little doubt that they are the organizational form of the future. Once again, the manager has to return to those old concepts: uncertainty and particularly knowledge. Companies used to think that their most precious resource was capital and all they needed was a small elite to allocate that capital and boss around workers. "How come when I want a pair of hands I get a human being as well," Henry Ford once remarked. Now firms realize that their most important asset is knowledge. The trouble with knowledge is that it is so much more difficult to manage than capital: not only is it fixed in the heads of pesky employees rather than stored in the bank, but it is infuriatingly volatile and short-lived to boot, as explained in Chapter 6.

第 6 章

CHAPTER 6

% 英镑

% £

£

£

韩国首都在最好的时候是一个令人沮丧的地方，建筑工地乱七八糟，标准公寓楼和狭小的街角商店，都在兜售人参和闪亮的“手工”西装。 但在隆冬时节，首尔简直就像地狱一般。 寒风刺骨； 结冰的路面几乎无法行走。 您花了很多时间争先恐后地乘坐出租车，将您从一家供暖良好的酒店带到另一家。 唯一令人欣慰的是，酒吧里存有大量威士忌，而陶醉于被称为“亚洲爱尔兰人”的当地人鼓励您畅饮至深夜。

South Korea's capital city is a dismal place at the best of times, a mess of building sites, standard-issue apartment towers, and poky corner shops, all touting Ginseng and shiny "hand-made" suits. But in the depth of winter, Seoul can be positively hellish. Freezing winds chill the bones; icy pavements make walking all but impossible. You spend much of your time scrambling for a taxi to take you from one well-heated hotel to another. The only consolation is that the bars are well-stocked with whisky, and the locals, who revel in being called "the Irish of Asia," encourage you to drink late into the night.

因此，1995 年 11 月，史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格和杰弗里·卡森伯格这两位洛杉矶较富有的居民都不是以喝威士忌而闻名，他们选择到访这座城市四天，这是一个陌生的城市。更奇怪的是，这两位大亨的主办方选择：Cheil Food and Chemicals，韩国最古板的公司之一，比电影更出名的是制作海藻汤等产品。

So it was a strange city for Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg, two of Los Angeles's wealthier inhabitants, neither of whom is famed for their whisky consumption, to have chosen to visit for four days in November 1995. Even odder perhaps was the two moguls' choice of host: Cheil Food and Chemicals, one of Korea's stodgiest companies, better known for making things like seaweed soup than movies.

这次不寻常的会面之所以发生，是因为 Cheil 向梦工厂投资了 3 亿美元，梦工厂是一家由斯皮尔伯格、卡岑伯格和大卫格芬创立的电影制片厂。 这笔投资使 Cheil 获得了梦工厂 11% 的股份，使其成为继微软联合创始人保罗·艾伦之后的最大单一外部投资者。 这笔交易是由韩国最强大的公司之一三星创始人的孙女、第一毛织的负责人李美琪策划的

This unusual rendezvous came about because Cheil had invested $300 million in DreamWorks, the film studio founded by Spielberg, Katzenberg, and David Geffen. The investment gives Cheil an 11 percent stake in DreamWorks and makes it the single largest outside investor after Paul Allen, the cofounder of Microsoft. The deal was masterminded by Miky Lee, a granddaughter of the founder of Samsung, one of Korea's most powerful companies, and head of Cheil's

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

新的多媒体部门，Lee Entertainment。 作为投资的回报，Cheil 获得了在亚洲大部分地区分销梦工厂产品的权利，李女士在梦工厂的五人执行委员会中占有一席之地，并有机会为 Cheil 的新电影制片厂借鉴梦工厂的专业知识， J-Com。 Cheil 还与香港电影大亨 Raymond Chow 成立了几家合资企业，在亚洲发行西方和亚洲电影，并建造大量的多厅电影院。 “五年后，”Cheil 的发言人预测，“我们将成为亚洲第一大多媒体娱乐集团。”

new multimedia division, Lee Entertainment. In return for its investment, Cheil got the rights to distribute DreamWorks' products throughout much of Asia, a seat on DreamWorks' five-member executive committee for Ms. Lee, and a chance to draw on DreamWorks' expertise for Cheil's new film studio, J-Com. Cheil is also forming several joint ventures with Raymond Chow, a Hong Kong film tycoon, to distribute Western and Asian films in Asia, and to build large numbers of multiplex cinemas. "Five years from now," a spokesman for Cheil predicts, "we'll be the first major multimedia entertainment group in Asia."

这里发生了什么？ 部分原因在于家庭政治。 Cheil 的老板 Jay Lee（Miky 的兄弟）曾期望最终能从他的祖父那里继承三星的最高职位。 但是他的家族分支被忽略了。 作为安慰奖，它获得了集团的食品和化工业务。 1993 年，Jay Lee 切断了 Cheil 与三星的联系，然后开始报复。 看到梦工厂已经拒绝了三星提出的向新的好莱坞工作室投资 8 亿美元的提议，Cheil 确保合作伙伴关系的妙招似乎更加令人愉快。 Cheil 通过在所有主要酒店挂上欢迎梦工厂的横幅并举办一场更适合亨利八世而不是来自好莱坞的骨瘦如柴的游客的宴会来宣扬它对三星的胜利。

What is going on here? Part of the explanation lies in family politics. Cheil's boss, Jay Lee (Miky's brother), had expected eventually to inherit the top job at Samsung from his grandfather. But his branch of the family was passed over. As a consolation prize, it received the group's food and chemical business. Jay Lee severed Cheil's connections with Samsung in 1993 and then set about getting his revenge. Seeing that DreamWorks had already rebuffed an offer by Samsung to invest $800 million in the new Hollywood studio, Cheil's coup in securing the partnership seemed all the more enjoyable. Cheil rammed home its triumph over Samsung by festooning all the leading hotels with banners welcoming DreamWorks and putting on a banquet fit more for Henry VIII than the scrawny visitors from Tinseltown.

但结盟还有更深层次、更具战略意义的原因：年轻的 Lees 真诚地认为 Cheil 必须成为“一家知识型公司”。 像他们这一代的许多人一样，Miky 和 ​​Jay Lee 是国际化的美国爱好者。 （按照韩国的标准，后者是一位新时代的经理人，他特意在未经通知的情况下闯入中层会议，并将公司餐厅设在总部的顶层，而这个位置通常是为董事长办公室预留的。）韩国公司向来擅长从西方购买技术诀窍。 Miky Lee 指出，她的祖父从面粉生意起家，最后从事半导体行业。 现在她认为是时候引进最新的西方工业，多媒体，

But there was a deeper, more strategic reason for the alliance: the younger Lees sincerely believe that Cheil has to become "a knowledge company." Like many of their generation, Miky and Jay Lee are cosmopolitan Americanophiles. (The latter, who is a new-age manager by Korean standards, makes a point of wandering unannounced into midlevel meetings and has put the company cafeteria on the top floor of its headquarters, a position normally reserved for the chairman's office.) Korean firms have always been adept at buying know-how from the West. Miky Lee points out that her grandfather started in the flour business and ended up in semiconductors. Now she thinks it is time to import the latest Western industry, multimedia, adding that the sort of management skills that can be learned from managing film companies—the ability to weave networks and create vivid images—will be increasingly useful in managing the food and chemical businesses.

从表面上看，李氏夫妇的决定似乎难以理解。 食物和电影之间没有协同作用（除了事实

On the surface, the Lees' decisions may seem difficult to fathom. There are no synergies between food and films (other than the fact

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

电影院是卖热狗和爆米花的好地方）。 韩国只有 4600 万人使用一种语言，本土电影业是非洲大陆最薄弱的国家之一，看起来不太可能成为亚洲的好莱坞。 此外，Cheil 的多媒体部门配备了一些冷漠的公司员工，他们在销售食品方面咬牙切齿，并希望在公司度过余生——这对于网络化、一分钟交易的世界来说，并不是一种合适的文化。多媒体。

that cinemas are good places to sell hot dogs and popcorn). South Korea, with a language that is spoken by only 46 million people and a native film industry that is one of the weakest on the continent, looks an unlikely Hollywood of Asia. Furthermore, Cheil is staffing its multimedia division with stolid company men who cut their teeth on selling food products and expect to spend the rest of their lives with the company—hardly the right sort of culture for the networking, deal-a-minute world of multimedia.

尽管他们的解决方案可能有点古怪，但 Lees 的诊断无疑是正确的：我们正处于向信息时代过渡的过程中，其中最重要的资源不是物质资源而是智力资源； 考虑到进行这种转变的难度，最好尽早开始。

Although their solution may be a little wacky, the Lees' diagnosis is surely right: we are in the middle of the transition to an information age, in which the most important resources are not physical but intellectual; and given the difficulty of making this transition, it is best to start early.

认识我，认识你

Knowing Me, Knowing You

如前所述，知识——连同不确定性——迫使公司大幅改变其结构。 但管理者的知识问题远不止于此。 他们不仅必须学习如何保护知识——像他们曾经积累的资本那样“增长”它——而且他们还需要学习如何与拥有知识的人打交道。 现代的宇宙大师是那些有幸天生聪明的人：律师、科学家、股票经纪人、熟练的机械师，事实上，任何能够比同龄人更迅速、更有想象力地建立联系和产生想法的人。 “知识”的问题也不是仅仅靠向技术砸钱就能解决的。 在 80 年代，通用汽车投入近 800 亿美元用于新工厂和设备，以减少对麻烦工人的依赖， 然而，它的生产力提高微乎其微。 相比之下，专注于打破董事会和车间之间壁垒的福特取得了显着增长。

As already mentioned, knowledge—alongside uncertainty—has forced companies to change their structure dramatically. But managers' problems with knowledge go much deeper than that. Not only do they have to learn how to husband knowledge—to "grow" it as they once grew their capital—but they also need to learn how to handle the people who possess it. The modern masters of the universe are those people who have had the good fortune to be born bright: lawyers, scientists, stockbrokers, skilled mechanics, indeed, anyone who can make connections and generate ideas more rapidly and imaginatively than their peers. Nor can the problem of "knowledge" be solved just by throwing money at technology. In the 1980s General Motors plowed nearly $80 billion into new factories and equipment to reduce its dependence on its troublesome workers, yet its productivity gains were minuscule. By contrast, Ford, which concentrated on knocking down barriers between the boardroom and the shop floor, achieved noticeable growth.

其结果是管理思想的发酵。 大多数公司习惯于衡量相对简单的事物，例如仓库中的库存量或收入流量。 但是他们应该如何衡量知识，这是他们甚至无法定义的东西？ 在传统的管理体系中，首要关注的是说服无聊的员工埋头苦干。 如今，这些员工被视为公司最有价值的人

The result has been a ferment in management thinking. Most firms are accustomed to measuring relatively simple things like the amount of stock in their warehouses or their income flows. But how should they be measuring knowledge, which is something they cannot even define? In the traditional managerial system, a primary concern was to persuade bored workers to keep their noses to the grindstone. Today, those workers are seen as the company's most valuable

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

资源，因为他们头脑中的知识。 为了利用这些知识，经理需要能够理解它、定义它、定位它、衡量它并鼓励它成长。 最重要的是，经理必须能够将这种抽象现象转化为成功的产品。 结果，一方面，咨询公司花了很长时间告诉公司如何最大化员工的“自尊”而不是利润。 关于如何将公司变成鼓励知识的地方（“学习型组织”）以及如何将知识转化为新产品（“创新”），管理理论也有一些明智的说法。 在这两种情况下，管理理论都没有提供成功的蓝图，但它确实描述了适当的基础。

resources because of the knowledge in their heads. To harness that knowledge, the manager needs to be able to understand it, define it, locate it, measure it, and encourage it to grow. Above all, the manager must be able to turn that abstract phenomenon into winning products. As a result, consultancies, for one, have spent long hours telling companies how to maximize not profit but the "self-respect" of their employees. Management theory also has sensible things to say about how to turn a company into a place where knowledge is encouraged ("a learning organization") and how to transform that knowledge into new products ("innovation"). In neither case does management theory offer a blueprint for success, but it does describe the proper foundations.

智慧的开始

The Beginning of Wisdom

在亨利·福特时代，很明显公司的资产不仅包括工厂等实物，还包括工人积累的技能。 智力资本现在被认为是最重要的。 在越来越多的情况下，公司的市值与其固定资产账面价值的比率达到两位数。 根据达特茅斯塔克商学院的 James Brian Quinn 的一项计算，即使在相当无聊的制造公司中，四分之三的附加值也来自各种形式的知识。 1个

In Henry Ford's time, it was already clear that a company's assets consisted not only of physical things, such as factories, but also of the accumulated skills of workers. Intellectual capital is now considered to be of paramount importance. In more and more cases, the ratio of a company's market value to the book value of its fixed assets is reaching double figures. Even in fairly boring manufacturing companies, three-quarters of the value added comes from knowledge, in its various forms, according to one calculation by James Brian Quinn of the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. 1

第一个注意到知识型社会兴起的人是富有先见之明的彼得德鲁克。 自 1960 年代以来，管理思想家一直在对个人和组织如何学习进行详细的学术研究。 三十年前，匹兹堡卡内基梅隆大学计算机科学教授、诺贝尔经济学奖获得者赫伯特·西蒙使用计算机模拟和分析组织做出决策的方式。 哈佛商学院心理学家克里斯·阿吉里斯 (Chris Argyris) 发现，失败比成功是更好的老师。 成功只能产生 Argyris 所说的“单循环”学习（我做了 X 并且成功了），而失败会产生“双循环学习”，这会导致人们质疑他们的失败及其背后的假设。 沃尔特·里斯顿

The first person to notice the rise of the knowledge-based society was the ever-prescient Peter Drucker. Since the 1960s, management thinkers have been conducting detailed academic research on how individuals and organizations learn. Three decades ago Herbert Simon, a professor of computer science at Pittsburgh's Carnegie-Mellon University and a Nobel prize winner in economics, used computers to simulate and analyze the way that organizations reach decisions. Chris Argyris, a psychologist based at Harvard Business School, found that failure is a better teacher than success. Success can only generate what Argyris calls "single-loop" learning (I did X and it worked), whereas failure can generate "double-loop learning," which leads people to question their failures and the assumptions behind them. Walter Wriston, former chairman of Citibank, puts the same point rather more succinctly: "Good judgment is the result of experience, and experience is the result of bad judgment."

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

这样的发现并不局限于大学。 Royal Dutch/Shell 在 1970 年代率先使用“计划即学习”。 公司的情景规划部门由 Pierre Wack 创立，多年来由 Arie De Geus 领导，充当了一种智囊团的角色，经理们在其中使用各种不同的未来版本来测试他们对公司、竞争对手和市场的假设. “全面质量”运动鼓励工人监督自己的进步并解决自己的问题，而不是简单地服从管理者，从而间接促进了学习。

Such discoveries were not confined to universities. Royal Dutch/Shell pioneered the use of "planning as learning" in the 1970s. The firm's scenario planning division, invented by Pierre Wack and headed for many years by Arie De Geus, acted as a sort of think tank in which managers used various versions of the future to test their assumptions about their company, their competitors, and the market. The "total-quality" movement indirectly promoted learning by encouraging workers to monitor their own progress and solve their own problems, rather than simply defer to managers.

到 20 世纪 80 年代中期，“学习”和“知识”都已成为赋予用户即时现代性的流行语。 甚至通用汽车也参与其中。 其创新的 Saturn 部门于 1985 年宣布，其特色之一是在田纳西州斯普林希尔的 Saturn 工厂隔壁建造了一个“学习实验室”。 它被称为工作场所发展中心，包括一个完整的装配线模型，用于拍摄和研究工作场所程序。

By the mid-1980s "learning" and "knowledge" had both become buzzwords that conferred instant modernity on the user. Even General Motors got in on the act. One of the features of its innovative Saturn division, announced in 1985, was a "learning laboratory" built next door to Saturn's factory in Springhill, Tennessee. Called the Workplace Development Center, it included a complete mock-up of an assembly line, which was used to videotape and study workplace procedures.

主流专家随后开始将注意力转向知识在工作场所的作用。 哈佛商学院教授 Shoshana Zuboff 认为，在智能机器时代，“学习是新的劳动形式……生产活动的核心。” 其他人警告说，那些依赖体力的人将会变得贫穷和被边缘化。 时任哈佛大学教授、现任美国劳工部长的罗伯特·赖希 (Robert Reich) 预测，知识工作者（他相当夸张地称他们为“符号分析师”）和体力劳动者之间的紧张关系将日益加剧，因为前者将能够利用全球化，而后者将成为陷入狭隘的贫困。 同样来自哈佛大学的 Rosabeth Moss Kanter 更为乐观地观察到，在以知识为基础的经济中，

Mainstream gurus then began turning their attention to the role of knowledge in the workplace. Shoshana Zuboff, a professor at Harvard Business School, argued that, in the age of the smart machine, "learning is the new form of labor . . . the heart of productive activity." Others warned that those who depended on brawn would be impoverished and marginalized. Robert Reich, then a Harvard professor and now America's labor secretary, predicted a growing tension between knowledge workers (whom he rather grandly dubbed "symbolic analysts") and manual workers because the former would be able to take advantage of globalization whereas the latter would become stuck in parochial poverty. Rosabeth Moss Kanter, also from Harvard, observed more optimistically that, in a knowledge-based economy, companies would have to share more power with their employees.

商界的共识似乎是学习是一件好事。 大多数人似乎都知道一个专注于学习的组织应该能够做什么。 许多人引用了本田摩托车经理的例子，他们去美国执行销售大型自行车的任务，但发现他们遇到的加利福尼亚人对这些经理用来拜访潜在客户的小型 50 cc 本田印象更深：尽管已经投资在大型自行车上花费了大量时间和金钱，本田转向小型

The consensus in the business world seems to be that learning is a good thing. And most people seem to know broadly what an organization focused on learning should be able to do. Many quote the example of the Honda motorcycle managers who went to America on a mission to sell big bikes but found that the Californians they met were more impressed by the small 50-cc Hondas the managers were using to visit their prospective customers: despite having invested a lot of time and money in the big bikes, Honda switched to the small

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

一个——并发了大财。 其他经常被引用的创意工厂例子是 3M 和 Rubbermaid。 管理作家指出，这些公司的问题在于太多人将自己视为产品而不是流程（这是一种更准确的设想方式）。 2 而能够解释如何创建学习型组织的经理少之又少。

ones—and made a fortune. Other frequently cited examples of ideas factories are 3M and Rubbermaid. The problem with such companies, management writers point out, is that too many think of themselves as a product rather than as a process (which is a more accurate way of envisaging them). 2 And the managers who can explain how to create a learning organization are few and far between.

Peter Senge 和第五项修炼

Peter Senge and the Fifth Discipline

即便是广为人知的“学习型组织”先知的管理思想家也难以下定论。 麻省理工学院组织学习中心主任、畅销书《第五项修炼》（1990 年）的作者彼得·圣吉认为，当今的公司之所以具有竞争优势，是因为他们有能力学习并不断学习. 简而言之，Senge 认为热衷于学习的人应该接受五项训练：他们应该抛开旧的“思维模式”，学会对他人开放（“自我超越”），了解他们的组织是如何真正运作的（“系统”思考”），就“共同愿景”达成一致，然后共同努力实现共同目标（“团队学习”）。

Even the management thinker widely known as a prophet of the "learning organization" is hard to pin down. Peter Senge, head of the Centre for Organizational Learning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the author of the best-selling The Fifth Discipline (1990), believes that today's companies owe their competitive edge to their ability to learn, and to keep on learning. In brief, Senge argues that people who are keen to learn should embrace five disciplines: they should put aside their old "mental models," learn to be open with others ("personal mastery"), understand how their organization really works ("systems thinking"), agree on a "shared vision," and then work together to achieve a common purpose ("team learning").

Senge 认为，如果经理们经历了“个人转变”，他们将只能从机器时代及其狭隘的、划分的工作观点跨越到信息时代，这将使他们立即对同事更加开放人类，并且更有能力将世界理解为一个连贯的系统。 他提供了一套心理工具来帮助人们在情感上和智力上实现飞跃。 一种旨在改善沟通的工具是“容器”——一个想象中的容器，会议中的所有参与者都将他们的恐惧和挫折放入其中。 随着容器装满，会议开始取得不受“负面”情绪影响的结果。 另一个旨在打破成见的工具是“推理阶梯”。 要想爬上阶梯，人们必须根据经验观察而不是偏见来做出决定。 森吉建议，在一次压力特别大的会议之后，高管们应该一起坐下来冥想，以恢复内心的平静。 然而，最强大的工具是“系统思考”，它使人能够“看到”驱动行为的结构。

Senge argues that managers will only be able to make the leap from the machine age, with its narrow, compartmentalized view of jobs, to the information age if they undergo a "personal transformation," which will leave them at once more open to their fellow men and better equipped to understand the world as a coherent system. And he provides a set of mental tools to help people to make the leap, emotionally as well as intellectually. One tool, intended to improve communication, is "the container"—an imaginary receptacle into which all the participants in a meeting place their fears and frustrations. As the container fills up, the meeting begins to achieve results unhampered by "negative" feelings. Another tool, intended to break down preconceptions, is the "ladder of inference." To climb the ladder people must base their decisions on empirical observation rather than prejudice. Senge recommends that, after a particularly stressful meeting, executives should all sit down together and meditate in order to restore their inner calm. The most powerful tool of all, however, is "systems thinking," which enables one to "see" the structures driving behavior.

坦率地说，第五修炼的巨大成功令人费解。 这本书不仅难以理解，而且在出版时

To be frank, The Fifth Discipline's huge success is puzzling. Not only is the book hard to understand but at the time of its publication

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

许多其他顾问争辩说，西方正处于从工业经济到知识经济的“范式转变”（使用管理理论行业钟爱的老掉牙的术语）的中间，而知识型经济经济需要一个具备新思维方式的“新人”。 Senge 自己承认，他的灵感来自许多“非凡的人”，尤其是 Jay Forrester，他指导了他的博士学位。 关于系统动力学的论文，以及 Chris Argyris。 Senge 说，系统动力学教会他将事物视为系统的一部分，而不是仅仅作为独立的实体——因此他对他的五个学科中的所有五个都给予同等重视。

dozens of other consultants were arguing that the West was in the middle of a "paradigm shift" (to use a well-worn term beloved of the management theory industry) from an industrial to a knowledge-based economy, and that the knowledge-based economy needed a "new man," equipped with new ways of thinking. By his own admission, Senge drew his inspiration from a number of "extraordinary people," notably Jay Forrester, who supervised his Ph.D. thesis on systems dynamics, and Chris Argyris. Systems dynamics, Senge said, taught him to look at things as parts of a system rather than just as independent entities—hence he placed equal emphasis on all five of his five disciplines.

Senge 对管理理论的贡献是双重的。 首先，所有这些想法都表现出一种时髦的新时代倾向。 （Senge 是禅宗的信徒。）其次，他的思想具有学术讨论中所缺少的实用优势。 尽管他的大部分想法听起来像是胡说八道，但圣吉已经能够说服公司采纳他的想法。 1994 年，圣吉和一组顾问出版了《第五项修炼手册》，这是一本案例研究和论文集，说明了他的想法如何在福特、联邦快递和英特尔等公司发挥作用——总的来说，这是一本更有帮助的书比它的前身。 他的研究中心始于 1990 年，拥有 18 家企业赞助商，包括 AT&T、福特、摩托罗拉和联邦快递。 每人向中心支付 80 美元， 000 每年尝试可能帮助组织学习的想法。 Senge 成立了自己的咨询和培训公司 Innovation Associates，最近被 Arthur D. Little 收购。 他还与 Learning Circle 有联系，Learning Circle 是一种为“学习型组织”的拥护者设立的俱乐部。

Senge's contribution to management theory has been twofold. First, all this thinking has exhibited a fashionable New Age slant. (Senge is a devotee of Zen.) Second, his ideas have a practical edge that has been missing from academic discussions. Although much of his thinking sounds like psychobabble, Senge has been able to persuade companies to adopt his ideas. In 1994 Senge and a group of consultants published The Fifth Discipline Handbook, a collection of case studies and essays that illustrate how his ideas worked at companies such as Ford, Federal Express, and Intel—and is, in general, a much more helpful book than its predecessor. His research center, started in 1990, has 18 corporate sponsors, including AT&T, Ford, Motorola, and Federal Express. Each pays the center $80,000 a year to try out ideas that might help organizations learn. Senge has set up his own consulting and training firm, Innovation Associates, which was recently bought up by Arthur D. Little. He is also connected with the Learning Circle, a sort of club for devotees of "learning organizations."

如果幸运的话，这些奉献者将被邀请参加 Senge 的定期管理务虚会之一。 这些会议通常在偏僻的乡村举行，在叮当作响的钢琴音乐或击鼓声（取决于一天中的时间）的背景下举行，包括户外活动，人们通过共同的身体痛苦建立联系。 目标是克服现代社会的碎片化，并将世界视为一个相互联系的系统。 Senge 认为西方正在遭受分裂的高级案例：身体健康已经脱离心理健康； 教育已经分裂成一堆陈腐的事实； 政府已经分裂为特殊利益集团的斗争。 所有这些碎片化的有害影响在管理方面最为明显：

If they are lucky, these devotees will be invited to one of Senge's regular management retreats. Usually held in a rural backwater, these meetings take place against a background of tinkling piano music or beating drums (depending on the time of day) and consist of outdoor events at which people bond through shared physical suffering. The objective is to overcome the fragmentation of modern society and appreciate the world as a connected system. Senge thinks that the West is suffering from an advanced case of fragmentation: physical health has broken away from mental health; education has fragmented into a collection of banal facts; and government has splintered into a battle of special interests. Nowhere is the harmful effect of all this fragmentation more evident than in management:

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

营销部门与制造部门交战，一线经理与公司总部交战，工人与老板交战。 森格认为，这位管理大师的目标是克服这种分裂，重新将世界视为一个整体。

marketing departments are at war with manufacturing, front-line managers with corporate headquarters, workers with bosses. The goal of the management guru, according to Senge, is to overcome this fragmentation and see the world as a whole once again.

什么是知识？

What Is Knowledge?

鉴于他一长串满意的企业客户，很难不相信圣吉更擅长将他的想法付诸实践，而不是他在纸上或会议上解释它们。 （“这不是管理；这是抽象艺术，”一位被激怒的中小型企业的商人承认，他曾在瑞士参加过一场座无虚席的 Senge 演讲。）幸运的是，对于那些发现 Senge 的新时代思维有点模糊的人来说，过去几年看过一系列关于公司如何创造和使用知识的更有分量的书，包括 Gary Hamel 和 CK Praha-lad 合着的 Competing for the Future (1994)； Wellsprings of Knowledge (1995)，哈佛商学院教授 Dorothy Leonard-Barton 着； 以及 The Knowledge-Creating Company (1995)，作者是野中郁次郎和竹内广孝，

Given his long list of satisfied corporate clients, it is hard not to believe that Senge is better at putting his ideas into practice than he is at explaining them on paper or at conferences. ("This isn't management; it's abstract art," one infuriated Mittelstand businessman confessed, having attended a sold-out Senge speech in Switzerland.) Fortunately for those who find Senge's New Age thinking a little fuzzy, the past couple of years have seen a succession of much more weighty books on how companies create and use knowledge, including Competing for the Future (1994), by Gary Hamel and C. K. Praha-lad; Wellsprings of Knowledge (1995), by Dorothy Leonard-Barton, a professor at Harvard Business School; and The Knowledge-Creating Company (1995), by Ikujiro Nonaka and Hirotaka Takeuchi, two Japanese management theorists.

大多数关于学习型组织的讨论都是从它想要培养的知识类型开始的，这会立即让人想到“核心竞争力”——赋予公司竞争优势的技能和传统（见第 5 章）。 核心能力围绕学习展开。 他们存在于公司员工的头脑中——这就是所有甜言蜜语中所说的“人是公司最宝贵的资源”的真正含义。 多萝西·伦纳德-巴顿 (Dorothy Leonard-Barton) 表示，三种知识是每项核心能力的核心：公共知识、行业特定知识和公司特定知识。 3个

Most discussions of the learning organization begin with the sort of knowledge it wants to cultivate, which immediately brings to mind "core competencies"—the skills and traditions that give the firm its competitive advantage (see Chapter 5). Core competencies revolve around learning. They reside in the heads of the firm's employees—which is what all this saccharine talk about "people being a company's most precious resource" really means. Three kinds of knowledge, says Dorothy Leonard-Barton, are at the heart of every core competence: public knowledge, industry-specific knowledge, and firm-specific knowledge. 3

因此，从学习型组织的角度来看，收集到的工人学位和资格仅代表其知识库的一部分。 知识和能力也存在于集体行为的各种传统中——存在于工厂的物理布局和数据库中。 4 这就是为什么理论家正在研究“隐性知识”——工人在处理日常问题时产生并在自助餐厅传播的非正式的职业知识，而不是记录在公司手册中并在强制性培训课程中传播的官方规则。

Thus, from a learning organization's point of view, the collected degrees and qualifications of workers represent only part of its knowledge base. Knowledge and competencies also reside in various traditions of collective behavior—in the factory's physical layout and databases. 4 That is why theorists are studying "tacit knowledge"— the informal, occupational lore that is generated by workers grappling with everyday problems and passed on in cafeterias, as opposed to the official rules recorded in company manuals and transmitted in compulsory training sessions.

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

在使用隐性知识方面的领导者可能是日本人。 参观一家日本工厂，你会看到很多员工在没有实际说话的情况下进行交流。 Nonaka 和 Takeuchi 认为，日本公司过去是挖掘员工群体的默契和直觉的大师。 事实上，日本公司比西方公司更不愿意摆脱中层管理人员，部分原因是他们承认中层管理人员在将不同种类的隐性知识整合在一起方面发挥的重要作用。 根据 Nonaka 和 Takeuchi 的说法，这些经理是知识创造公司真正的“知识工程师”。

The leaders in the use of tacit knowledge may be the Japanese. Visit a Japanese factory and you will see plenty of employees communicating without actually talking. Nonaka and Takeuchi argue that Japanese firms are past masters at tapping into the tacit insights and hunches of the mass of employees. Indeed, Japanese companies have been more reluctant to get rid of middle managers than Western ones in part because they acknowledge the vital role played by middle managers in bringing different sorts of tacit knowledge together. These managers are the real "knowledge engineers" of the knowledge-creating company, according to Nonaka and Takeuchi.

吸收想法。 . .

Sucking in Ideas . . .

学习型组织的标志是它不断地为这个知识宝库添砖加瓦。 它可以通过两种方式做到这一点：从外部吸收创意，并确保它们在公司内部流通。

The hallmark of a learning organization is that it keeps adding to this treasure trove of knowledge. It can do this in two ways: by sucking in ideas from outside its frontiers, and by making sure that they circulate inside the company.

根据定义，学习型组织应该在世界范围内寻找可以适应其特定目的的想法。 5 令人惊讶的是，公共领域中存在多少具有商业价值的知识； 每天都在产生越来越多的信息。 哈佛商学院教授 John Kao 指出，越来越多的公司雇用青少年在万维网上冲浪，以带回新想法。 6 日本公司连续多年在国外派驻研究人员，并派代表参加数量惊人的会议。 （任何参加科学会议的人都会熟悉前排的日本代表仔细拍摄每张幻灯片。）7 家日本公司已在尽可能靠近美国大学的地方建立了研究实验室：Hitachi' 其化学研究中心甚至与加州大学尔湾分校共用场地。 韩国三星公司定期派管理人员到位于帕洛阿尔托的设计公司IDEO的办公室工作，希望他们能从硅谷挑选一些创新人才。

Learning organizations, by definition, should be scouring the world for ideas that might be adapted to suit their particular ends. 5 It is surprising how much commercially valuable knowledge exists in the public domain; and more and more of it is being generated every day. John Kao, a professor at Harvard Business School, points out that a growing number of companies hire teenagers to surf the World Wide Web to bring back new ideas. 6 Japanese firms post researchers abroad for years on end and send representatives to an extraordinary number of conferences. (Any visitor to a scientific conference will be familiar with the Japanese delegate in the front row carefully photographing each and every slide.) 7 Japanese companies have established research laboratories as close as possible to American universities: Hitachi's Chemical Research Centre even shares premises with the University of California at Irvine. Korea's Samsung regularly sends managers to spend time in the offices of IDEO, a design company based in Palo Alto, in the hope that they will pick up some of Silicon Valley's talent for innovation.

虽然这种策略听起来有点偷偷摸摸，但从外部吸收知识的能力正在成为竞争优势的重要来源，因为即使是最大的公司也承认研究的成本太高，他们无法自行资助。 曾经奢华的研究设施，如 AT&T 的贝尔实验室和施乐的帕洛阿尔托

Although this tactic sounds a little sneaky, the ability to absorb knowledge from outside is becoming an important source of competitive advantage now that even the biggest firms admit that research is too expensive for them to fund on their own. Once lavish research facilities like AT&T's Bell Labs and Xerox's Palo Alto

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

研究中心未来面临承包资源或集体资助。

Research Center face a future of contracting resources or collective funding.

在许多情况下，这意味着与通常被视为敌人的公司建立机构关系。 福特和克莱斯勒已经成立了十几个联盟，合作设计碰撞假人和电池等产品。 Power PC 芯片由 IBM、摩托罗拉和苹果开发。 美国司法部指出，事实证明这些安排非常受欢迎，到 1990 年代初期，该国已有 325 个研究联盟。 但也许鼓励组织共享信息并获得另一家公司“核心竞争力”的更好方法是通过联盟、合资企业甚至合并。 例如，在汽车行业，美国和日本公司之间的合资企业，

In many cases this means forming institutional relationships with firms that would normally be regarded as enemies. Ford and Chrysler have formed a dozen consortia to collaborate in the design of items such as dummies for crashes and electric batteries. The Power PC chip was developed by IBM, Motorola, and Apple. These arrangements have proved so popular, points out the U.S. Department of Justice, that the country had 325 research consortia by the early 1990s. But perhaps an even better way of encouraging an organization to share information and gain access to another company's "core competencies" is through alliances, joint ventures, or even mergers. In the automobile industry, for example, joint ventures between American and Japanese firms, such as Chrysler and Honda or Ford and Mazda are one reason why the American firms have all but eliminated the productivity gap between themselves and the Japanese.

就底特律而言，结盟的原因很简单，就是为了制造更好的汽车——合作伙伴的选择相当明显。 但在科技行业，许多企业之间的界限正在瓦解，公司通常会结成联盟或合资企业，只是为了与它们未来可能依赖的行业保持联系。 这通常意味着与来自人们从未认为兼容的行业的公司合作。 例如，Electronic Data Systems (EDS)，其为客户的大型计算机提供服务的基本业务开始显得微弱，通过无数的联盟进军交互式媒体：与 Spectradyne 合作，在酒店房间提供电影； 与视频彩票技术一起提供赌博； 与美国旅游， 从飞机票到百老汇演出，从自动售票机分发门票； 并与美国西部和法国电信合作提供家庭银行服务。

In Detroit's case, the reason for forming alliances was simply to build better cars—and the choice of a partner was fairly obvious. But in technological industries, where the boundaries between many businesses are collapsing, firms often form alliances or joint ventures just to keep in touch with industries on which their future may depend. This often means consorting with companies from industries that one never considered compatible. For instance, Electronic Data Systems (EDS), whose basic business of servicing customers' mainframe computers is starting to look feeble, has pushed into interactive media through innumerable alliances: with Spectradyne, to provide movies in hotel rooms; with Video Lottery Technologies, to provide gambling; with USTravel, to dispense tickets from automated machines for everything from airline flights to Broadway shows; and with USWest and France Telecom to provide home banking.

. . . 并确保它们流通

. . . And Making Sure They Circulate

外部世界的想法如果一进入公司就卡住了，就没有多大用处。 一个真正的学习型组织是一个知识在系统中像弹球机中的球一样弹跳的组织。 换句话说，需要建立网络以将正式信息从公司的一端分流到另一端； 此外，需要发现和消除隐性知识的障碍。

Ideas from the outside world are of little use if they get stuck as soon as they enter the firm. A true learning organization is one in which knowledge ricochets around the system like a ball in a pinball machine. In other words, networks need to be built to shunt formal information from one end of the company to the other; moreover, barriers to tacit knowledge need to be discovered and removed.

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

实际上，任何公司范围内的信息系统，无论多么平凡，都可以帮助公司学习。 大多数大公司都使用 Lotus Notes 或类似的群件程序。 现在，管理咨询公司已经建立了专门的学习网络，其名称如“在线知识”和“知识交流”，使顾问能够汇集专业知识、交换想法并浏览案例研究库。

Virtually any company-wide information system, however mundane, will help a company to learn. Most big companies use Lotus Notes or a similar groupware program. Now management consultancies have set up special learning networks with names such as "Knowledge On-Line" and "Knowledge Xchange," which allow consultants to pool expertise, swap ideas, and browse through a library of case studies.

然而，机器只能做这么多。 因此，流行的做法是任命知识官和“导师”——高级员工，他们的工作就像老式英国私立学校的 fag 老师一样，是监督年轻员工的进步。 多萝西·伦纳德-巴顿 (Dorothy Leonard-Barton) 指出，一些公司寻找拥有“T 型”技能的人，即在一门学科（“T”的主干）具有深厚的专业知识，并且具备足够的知识范围以将该专业知识与其他领域相关联公司活动的许多其他领域（横梁）。 8个

However, machines can only do so much. Hence the fashion is to appoint knowledge officers and "mentors"—senior workers whose job, like that of the fag masters of old-fashioned British private schools, is to watch over the progress of younger workers. Some companies, Dorothy Leonard-Barton points out, look for people who possess "T-shaped" skills—that is, deep expertise in one discipline (the stem of the "T") combined with a sufficient intellectual range to relate that expertise to many other areas of corporate activity (the crossbar). 8

建立正式的知识传播网络是很有意义的。 也许此类系统的最大优势在于，顾问 X 或员工 Y 输入其中的信息在他或她离开公司后仍会保留很长时间。 但也许员工想要成功最需要的不是结构，而是自由——以及更多让他们保持头脑敏锐和技能与时俱进的机会。 许多软件公司已经开始像大学一样组织起来。 当 Lars Kolind 接任丹麦助听器制造商 Oti-con 的负责人时，他解散了整个正式组织，取消了职位名称。 他的目标是创建一个“意大利面条组织”，其中每个人都与其他人联系在一起。 微软将其位于华盛顿州雷德蒙德的总部称为园区。 在他的鼎盛时期，史蒂夫乔布斯， 苹果公司的创始人，培养了另类大学教授的风格，与他的运动鞋员工进行了自由流畅的争论。 Imagination 是一家英国设计公司，拥有一家内部餐厅和酒吧，员工下班后可以在这里闲逛和社交，其精神与学生在大学酒吧的精神大致相同。

It makes good sense to set up formal networks for the diffusion of knowledge. Perhaps the biggest advantage of such systems is that the information put into them by consultant X or worker Y will stay there long after he or she has left the company. But perhaps what workers need most to prosper is not structure but freedom—and many more opportunities to keep their minds sharp and their skills up to date. Many software companies have started to organize themselves like universities. When Lars Kolind took over as head of Oti-con, a Danish hearing-aid manufacturer, he dissolved the entire formal organization, abolishing job titles. His aim was to create a "spaghetti organization" in which everybody was connected to everybody else. Microsoft calls its headquarters in Redmond, Washington, a campus. In his heyday, Steve Jobs, the founder of Apple, cultivated the style of a professor at an alternative university, conducting free-flowing arguments with his sneakered staff. Imagination, a British design company, boasts an in-house restaurant and bar where employees hang around and socialize after work, in much the same spirit as students do in college bars.

大胆实验

Bold Experimentation

学习型组织的另一个特征是对实验的热情和失败的意愿。 实验使公司能够扩大其产品组合——它们是成功的关键

The other characteristic of a learning organization is a passion for experimentation—and a willingness to fail. Experiments allow companies to broaden their portfolio of products—they are the key to

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

企业在充满不确定性的时期的长期生存。 它们还帮助公司改变既定的做事方式，从而防止核心竞争力退化为核心僵化。 最近，许多此类实验都是精心设计的“自上而下”实验，其中高级管理人员试图通过例如接管其他公司来改变整个公司的方向。 然而，总的来说，老板退居二线并鼓励一种经常进行实验的文化要好得多。 看似微不足道的项目有时最终会改变公司的整个性质。 惠普开创了袖珍计算器业务，因为该公司的联合创始人之一比尔·休利特 (Bill Hewlett) 想要一种“电子计算尺”供自己使用。 康宁之所以打入光纤业务，是因为它的一些研究人员想到了将杂质引入玻璃中，从而使其内核的折射率高于外层，从而能够更好地传输光。 大多数成功的创新似乎都发生在离公司总部最远的办公室里。

a firm's long-term survival in periods of great uncertainty. They also help firms shake up established ways of doing things and thus prevent core competencies from degenerating into core rigidities. Recently, many such experiments have been elaborate "top-down" ones in which senior managers have tried to change the direction of the entire company by, for example, taking over other firms. On the whole, however, it is much better for bosses to take a back seat and encourage a culture where experiments are frequent. Seemingly insignificant projects can sometimes end up changing the entire nature of the company. Hewlett-Packard pioneered the pocket calculator business because one of the firm's cofounders, Bill Hewlett, wanted an "electronic slide rule" for his own use. Corning broke into the fiber-optics business because some of its researchers had the idea of introducing an impurity into glass so as to make its inner core more refractive than its outer layer and thus better able to transmit light. Most successful innovations seem to happen in the office furthest away from the corporate headquarters.

准学习型组织的主要错误之一是他们习惯于压制甚至惩罚不成功的创新。 在科学中，失败的实验与成功的实验一样具有启发性。 大多数商业组织不善于承认失败，也难以从中吸取教训。 这种对成功的偏见可能会对大多数组织的学习能力产生迟钝的影响（记住 Chris Argyris 的结论）。 学习型组织不仅要愿意承认错误。 他们应该准备好推广它们。 大多数创意产业比制造业更了解这一点。 创建华纳兄弟公司的史蒂夫罗斯的政策是“不犯错误的人被解雇”。

One of the main faults of would-be learning organizations is their habit of suppressing or even punishing unsuccessful innovations. In science, failed experiments can be as instructive as successful ones; most business organizations are poor at acknowledging failure and have difficulty learning from it. This bias toward success may have a dulling effect on the learning ability of most organizations (remember Chris Argyris's conclusions). Learning organizations should not only be willing to admit their mistakes. They should be prepared to promote them. This is something that most creative industries understand better than manufacturing ones. The policy of Steve Ross, who built up Warner Bros., was "people get fired who do not make mistakes."

另一种大胆的实验方法是招募不是“我们中的一员”的人。 Tom Peters 喜欢描述参观一个典型的公司务虚会（在棕榈泉或棕榈滩），他读了另一篇关于一家公司想要成为学习型组织但仍然发现自己生产了太多模仿产品的长篇描述。 当他走进研讨会的那一刻，他发现了原因：“150 人，其中 147 人是白人男性，年龄在 48 岁左右，144 人将穿着柠檬绿涤纶高尔夫球裤。” 9

Another bold way to experiment is to recruit people who are not "one of us." Tom Peters likes to describe visiting a typical corporate retreat (either at Palm Springs or Palm Beach), having read yet another long description of a company that wants to become a learning organization but still finds itself turning out too many me-too products. The moment he walks into the seminar, he discovers the reason why: "150 people, 147 of whom will be white, male, and around 48 years old, and 144 will be wearing lime-green polyester golf-trousers." 9

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

嘲笑有一个严肃的观点。 管理知识型员工的秘诀，就像制作马提尼酒的秘诀一样，在于混合。 生产日立大容量计算机磁盘驱动器的团队包括核工程师和化学工程师，以及计算机科学家。 在寻找其主管杰拉尔德赫什伯格所说的“创造性磨损”的过程中，日产国际设计公司故意以对比鲜明的方式雇用人员，例如平衡书呆子和嬉皮士。 10 它甚至鼓励员工在办公桌上展示他们“个性化”的彩色图表，以便管理人员可以更轻松地混合和匹配员工。 11

The jibe carries a serious point. The secret of managing knowledge workers, like the secret of making a martini, lies in the mixing. The group that produced Hitachi's high-capacity computer disk drive included nuclear engineers and chemical engineers, as well as computer scientists. In its search for what its director, Gerald Hirshberg, has called "creative abrasion," Nissan Design International deliberately hires people in contrasting pairs, balancing, say, nerds with hippies. 10 It even encourages workers to display a color chart of their "personalysis" on their desk so that managers can mix and match staff more easily. 11

微软的成功在很大程度上源于其招聘政策。 微软与顶尖教授建立关系，以便尽早发现人才。 它还针对具有它所谓的“带宽”的人（即那些表现出广泛兴趣的人），并寻找“交叉”——学术背景可能是音乐等领域但投入时间精通计算机的人. 之后，它将超逻辑的“小脑袋”与对艺术敏感的设计师聚集在一起。 正如一位内部人士所描述的那样：“设计师总是女性，很健谈，住在阁楼里，吃素，耳朵上戴着捡来的东西。开发人员总是男性，吃快餐，除了说‘不真的。' “ 12

Much of Microsoft's success stems from its recruitment policy. Microsoft cultivates relations with leading professors so that it can spot talent as early as possible. It also targets people with what it calls "bandwidth" (i.e., those who show a breadth of interest), and it looks out for "crossovers"—people whose academic background might have been in something like music but who have invested time mastering computers. After that, it throws together superlogical "bit heads" with artistically sensitive designers. As one insider describes it: "Designers are invariably female, are talkative, live in lofts, have vegetarian diets, and wear found objects in their ears. Developers are invariably male, eat fast food and don't talk except to say, 'Not True.' " 12

但这一切会创建一个学习型组织吗？ 答案是“不会太久”。 无论一个组织招募了多少怪人，无论它忘记了多少，无论其首席知识官知识渊博或技能如何“T”形，大多数公司仍然会发现它是一个难以攻击的目标。 即使一家公司保持警惕，与最意想不到的合作伙伴结成联盟，并例行处决三分之一的董事，它仍有可能发现其管理“知识”的效率不如预期。

But will all this create a learning organization? The answer is "not for long." No matter how many weirdos an organization recruits, no matter how much it forgets, no matter how knowledgeable its chief knowledge officers are or how "T"-shaped their skills, most companies will still find it a hard target. Even if a company keeps its eyes and ears open, forms alliances with the most unexpected partners, and routinely executes one out of every three directors, the chances are that it will still find it manages "knowledge" less effectively than it hoped.

原因很简单：学习是困难的——而且，像个人一样，组织也会有学习障碍。 即使一家公司似乎已经掌握了一项挑战，技术或其竞争对手也会提出另一项挑战。 没有神奇的单一答案可以使公司成为学习型组织。 然而，管理理论家似乎确实在向管理者展示在哪里寻找正确的答案。 在创新方面也可以这样说，所有这些积累的知识和学习都应该浮出水面。

The reason for this is simple: learning is difficult—and, like individuals, organizations can suffer from learning disabilities. Even when a company appears to have mastered one challenge, technology or its competitors throw up another one. There is no magic single answer that enables a company to become a learning organization. The management theorists, however, do seem to be showing managers where to look for the right answers. Much the same can be said when it comes to innovation, the area where all this accumulated knowledge and learning should bubble to the surface.

大辩论创新的挑战

THE GREAT DEBATES The Challenge of Innovation

大多数管理理论家现在都同意，生产出好的新产品的能力不仅仅是运气和祈祷的问题。 就像公司工作的任何其他方面一样，它可以被计划、管理和教授。 管理理论告诉我们，创新的艺术实际上是一系列平衡行为：着迷于开发新产品，但要确保它们符合您的长期愿景； 在自治团队中开发新产品，但为这些团队设定苛刻的目标； 倾听但不遵循客户的意见； 等等。 如果掌握了这些习惯，可以使创造源源不断的新产品的艺术更接近于一门科学。

Most management theorists now agree that the ability to produce good new products is not just a matter of luck and prayer. It can be planned, managed, and taught, just like any other aspect of a company's work. The art of innovation, management theory tells us, is really a series of balancing acts: be obsessive about developing new products, but make sure that they fit into your long-term vision; build new products in self-governing teams, but set demanding targets for those teams; listen to, but do not follow, what your customers say; and so on. If mastered, these habits can make the art of generating an endless stream of new products a little closer to a science.

追求创新的第一步是决定你想从中得到什么。 对于日本索尼公司和美国家庭用品制造商乐柏美公司而言，创新意味着产品扩散。 “我们的目标，”Rubbermaid 的 Wolf Schmitt 说，“是将竞争对手埋没在如此丰富的产品中，以至于他们无法复制我们。” 索尼意识到它无法阻止其随身听被抄袭。 因此，市场上充斥着各种类型的随身听——仅 1989 年就有 170 种型号。 速度对服装公司来说也很重要：许多香港裁缝可以比想出创意的巴黎时装店更快地为客户拿到巴黎最新时装的副本。

The first step in pursuing innovation is to decide what you want out of it. For Japan's Sony and Rubbermaid, the American household goods maker, innovation means product proliferation. "Our objective," says Wolf Schmitt of Rubbermaid, "is to bury competitors in such a profusion of products that they can't copy us." Sony realized that it could not prevent its Walkman from being copied. So it flooded the market with different types of Walkmen—170 models by 1989 alone. Speed is also essential for clothes companies: many Hong Kong tailors can get copies of the latest Paris fashions on the backs of their customers faster than the Paris fashion houses that dreamed up the ideas.

对于丰田这样的汽车制造商或宜家这样的专业零售商来说，成功意味着提供物有所值的产品：如果小型货车或沙发在该价格范围内提供最好的质量，就会卖出去。 对于像奥的斯和西屋这样的电梯公司来说，这意味着出色的售后服务。 如今，电梯公司的大部分收入来自服务产品，而不是制造产品。 对于芯片制造商英特尔而言，其目标是持续的技术改进，或者正如其首席执行官安迪格罗夫所说，“每年在每个价位上使机器性能翻倍。” 13 就在英特尔于 1989 年推出 486 芯片时，一个新的团队正在开发第五代芯片奔腾； 到 Pentium 出现时，另一个团队已经着手开发第七代芯片 P-7。

For a car manufacturer such as Toyota or a specialist retailer such as IKEA, success means offering value-for-money: a minivan or sofa will sell if it offers the best quality within that price range. For elevator companies like Otis and Westinghouse, it means outstanding after-sales service. Today, elevator companies make most of their money out of servicing their products, not building them. For Intel, a chip maker, the goal is continual technological improvement, or as its chief executive, Andy Grove, puts it, "Double machine performance at every price point every year." 13 Even as Intel launched the 486 chip in 1989, a new team was at work on the fifth-generation chip, the Pentium; and by the time the Pentium appeared, another team had already started on the P-7, the seventh-generation chip.

他们的目标可能不同，但大多数创新公司都痴迷于他们的产品。 电影《毕业生》中不断与达斯汀霍夫曼谈论塑料的角色可能不是一个特别有趣的人，但他在

Their aims may be different, but most innovative companies are obsessed with their product. The character in the film The Graduate who keeps talking to Dustin Hoffman about plastics may not have been a particularly interesting man, but he was ahead of his time in

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation
