他对他所生产的东西的热爱。 Arthur D. Little 顾问 Jean-Philippe Deschamps 和 P. Ranganath Nayak 表示，“产品巨头”或一系列获奖产品的标志是对公司产品的不自然的痴迷。 14 产品是将公司凝聚在一起的粘合剂，是主导走廊八卦的话题。 公司可以通过不同的方式灌输这种痴迷。 Rubbermaid 指示竞争对手的业务团队将尽可能多的新产品推向市场。 这些团队会面讨论他们的计划，并在一年一度的全公司产品展览会上比较他们的表现。 美国计算机公司惠普将一些经理的薪酬与他们推出的新产品的数量挂钩。 默克制药公司， 促使其研究人员每年获得一种主要治疗药物的政府批准。 许多日本公司试图超越他们最害怕的竞争对手——索尼的“BMW”口号生动地体现了这种态度：“无论如何都要打败松下。”

his devotion to what he produced. The hallmark of a "product juggernaut," or a succession of winning products, is an unnatural obsession with what a company makes, say Arthur D. Little consultants Jean-Philippe Deschamps and P. Ranganath Nayak. 14 The product is the glue that keeps the company together, the subject that dominates the corridor gossip. Companies can instil this obsession in different ways. Rubbermaid instructs rival business teams to get as many new products to market as possible. The teams meet to discuss their plans and compare their performance at an annual company-wide product fair. Hewlett-Packard, an American computer company, links the pay of some managers to the number of new products they introduce. Merck, a pharmaceutical company, prods its research staff to win governmental approval for one major therapeutic drug each year. Many Japanese companies try to outperform their most feared rivals—an attitude vividly captured in Sony's "BMW" slogan: "Beat Matsushita Whatsoever."

在许多最好的公司中，董事长负责营造一种执着的文化：他本人就是一个执着的人，他招募其他执着的人并鼓励他们将毕生精力投入到他们的产品中。 索尼的 Akio Morita 将原型放在口袋里，并向倒霉的访客展示。 Rubbermaid 的董事长 Wolf Schmitt 承认，他“可能是我们员工发送带有想法和剪报的笔记时最大的痛苦。我可能出现在世界上每个邮寄名单上，因为我购买了很多我在目录中找到的产品。我将它们发送给人们以激发新想法。” 15 微软的两位创始人 Bill Gates 和 Paul Allen 在青少年时期常常睡在他们的计算机终端下，以便他们醒来后能够尽快回到机器前。 几十年来，一些吉列

In many of the best companies the chairman is responsible for creating a culture of obsession: an obsessive individual himself, he recruits other obsessives and encourages them to devote their lives to their products. Sony's Akio Morita kept prototypes in his pocket and demonstrated them to hapless visitors. Rubbermaid's chairman, Wolf Schmitt, confesses that he is "probably the biggest pain to our people in sending out notes with ideas and clippings. I'm probably on every mailing list in the world because I buy a lot of products I find in catalogues. I send them to people to stimulate new ideas." 15 Microsoft's two founders, Bill Gates and Paul Allen, used to sleep under their computer terminals as adolescents, so as to be able to get back to the machines as soon as they woke up. For decades some of Gillette's male employees have come to work unshaven so that they can try out new razors—a different one on each side of the face.

但是，没有目标的痴迷最终可能会浪费精力； 因此，远见的重要性。 远景，可以被称为现代版的战略，在第 8 章中有更详细的讨论。但是为了创新的目的，远景是关于市场在未来和未来将如何发展（或可能如何发展）的想法。从而激励和关注员工。 这听起来很平庸，但它实际上是一种强大的武器。 日本的佳能公司看到了复印机体积小、价格低廉且无处不在的未来愿景，因此不顾外界的建议，坚持生产个人复印机。 鉴于

However, an obsession without a target can end up as wasted energy; hence, the importance of vision. Vision, which might be dubbed the modern version of strategy, is discussed in more detail in Chapter 8. But for the purposes of innovation, vision is an idea of how the market will look (or could be made to look) in the future and thus inspires and focuses workers. This may sound banal, but it is actually a formidable weapon. Japan's Canon saw a vision of a future in which photocopiers were small, cheap, and ubiquitous and persisted in producing its personal copier against all outside advice. In the view of

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

Hamel 和 Prahalad，摩托罗拉最大的资产是它对无线世界的愿景，每个人都拥有一部个人电话，并用一个终生的个人号码进行编程。 在研发上投入 60 亿美元的 IBM 被在加利福尼亚车库工作的史蒂夫乔布斯和史蒂夫沃兹尼亚克击败的一个原因是苹果公司的创始人梦想为“美国的每个男人，女人和孩子”提供一台电脑。 “

Hamel and Prahalad, Motorola's greatest asset is its vision of a wireless world with everybody owning a personal telephone, programmed with a life-long personal number. One reason why IBM, which spent $6 billion on R&D, was beaten to the punch by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak working from a California garage is that Apple's founders had a dream of a computer for "every man, woman, and child in America."

这是一个团队游戏

It's a Team Game

团队——尤其是跨越职能甚至国界的团队——对创新来说至关重要。 团队成员更容易专注于手头的事情。 最早做出这一发现的是日本人。 佳能和夏普等公司养成了让相互竞争的团队从事同一个项目的习惯，并要求一个团队为仍在筹划中的项目设计后续项目。 如今，团队几乎在任何地方都被视为礼仪——公司提供特殊设施来鼓励他们。 Sun Microsystems 为全天候工作的团队成员提供洗衣和干洗服务。 福特的设施之一包括一家理发店、一家洗衣店和几家餐馆。

Teams—particularly ones that span functional and even national boundaries—can be vital for innovation. Members of teams focus more readily on the matter at hand. The first people to make this discovery were the Japanese. Firms such as Canon and Sharp made a habit of setting rival teams to work on the same project and asking one team to design the successor to a project that is still on the drawing board. Nowadays, teams are regarded as de rigueur just about everywhere—and firms lay on special facilities to encourage them. Sun Microsystems offers laundry and dry cleaning services to members of teams who work round the clock. One of Ford's facilities contains a barber shop, a laundry, and several restaurants.

也许这种基于团队的方法最有价值的方面是它减少了将公司划分为职能封地所造成的浪费。 在旧体制下，设计师很少关注他们设想的产品是否能被制造出来。 基本的工程错误通常是在工作数月甚至数年之后才被发现的。 这就是为什么在建造 111 时，波音公司组建了大约 200 个“设计-建造”团队，迫使工程师、设计师甚至客户使用相同的计算机。 不仅错误被发现得更快，而且波音的庞大工厂似乎也更加紧密（“不再是这里的空调，那里的财务，那里的制造，”一位工程师评论道）。

Perhaps the most valuable aspect of this team-based approach is that it cuts down on the wastage created by dividing firms into functional fiefs. Under the old system, designers paid little attention to whether the products they envisioned could be made. Fundamental engineering errors were often only discovered after months or even years of work. This was one reason why, when it came to building the 111, Boeing formed some 200 "design-build" teams, forcing engineers, designers, and even customers to use the same computers. Not only were mistakes spotted sooner, but Boeing's huge factory seemed more tightly knit ("it was no longer a case of air conditioning over here, finance over there, and manufacturing over there," observes one engineer).

即使公司不将人员分组，仍然可以说服员工以不太正式的方式组队。 Silicon Graphics 在其香港研究中心（宽敞的）自助餐厅提供白板，以便其员工可以边吃饭边交流想法。 Glaxo-Wellcome 在英国剑桥的一个设施旨在迫使研究人员相互交谈：所有的化学物质都是

Even when companies do not divide people into teams, workers can still be persuaded to team up in less formal ways. Silicon Graphics provides white boards in the (spacious) cafeterias in its Hong Kong research center so that its staff can exchange ideas while they eat. One of Glaxo-Wellcome's facilities in Cambridge, England, is designed to force researchers to talk to each other: all the chemicals are

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

存放在一间公用商店； 报纸和杂志放在人们的房间里，让别人不得不借。

kept in a common store; newspapers and journals are put in people's rooms so that others have to ask to borrow them.

将权力下放给团队可能听起来不错而且花花公子，但必须为团队提供严格的目标（如果没有关于如何实现目标的严格指示）。 也许世界上研究最广泛的创意工厂是 3M，它在 1993 年注册了 543 项专利，其 60,000 种产品组合包括从文具到反光路标的所有产品。 公司鼓励其员工将 15% 的时间用于“盗版”——即从事他们自己的发明。 同时，它要求 30% 的年收入来自不到四年的产品。 而且目标正在收紧。 到 1997 年，3M 希望 10% 的收入来自不到一年的产品。 16

Devolving power to teams may sound fine and dandy, but teams have to be given strict goals (if not strict instructions on how to get there). Perhaps the most widely studied ideas factory in the world is 3M, which registered 543 patents in 1993 and whose portfolio of 60,000 products includes everything from stationery to reflecting road signs. The company encourages its workers to spend 15 percent of their time "bootlegging"—that is, working on their own inventions. At the same time, it demands that 30 percent of its annual revenues come from products less than four years old. And the targets are being tightened. By 1997, 3M wants 10 percent of revenues to come from products that are less than a year old. 16

其他公司也同样严格。 微软对员工的工作效率进行评分：“他们每年对你的进步进行两次评估，评分从 1 到 5，”一位微软人告诉安东尼桑普森。 “四表示出类拔萃；一表示你出局了。” 许多领先的公司，包括摩托罗拉和福特，都将他们的产品开发技能与竞争对手和其他市场领导者的技能进行“比较”。 总部位于马萨诸塞州的集成电路制造商 Analog Devices 公布了每个业务部门将产品开发时间或缺陷率减半所需时间的数据。 东芝跟踪其员工的技术和管理成就。 Hewlett-Packard 制作了图表来衡量每个团队成员在时间和金钱方面的贡献。

Other companies are similarly exacting. Microsoft grades employee productivity: "They review your progress twice a year, with marks from one to five," a Microsoftie told Anthony Sampson. "Four means exceptional; one means you're out." Many leading companies, including Motorola and Ford, "benchmark" their product development skills against those of their rivals and of other market leaders. Analog Devices, a Massachusetts-based manufacturer of integrated circuits, publishes figures on how long it takes each business unit to halve its product development time or defect rates. Toshiba tracks both the technical and managerial accomplishments of its employees. Hewlett-Packard produces graphs measuring the contribution of each team member in terms of time and money.

日本公司似乎要求特别高。 Ikujiro Nonaka 和 Hirotaka Takeuchi 引用本田的一位高管的话：“这就像把团队成员放在二楼，移开梯子，告诉他们跳下去，否则就跳下去。我相信创造力是通过将人们推到墙上并给他们施加压力而诞生的几乎到了极点。”

Japanese companies seem to be particularly demanding. Ikujiro Nonaka and Hirotaka Takeuchi quote an executive at Honda: "It's like putting the team members on the second floor, removing the ladder, and telling them to jump, or else. I believe creativity is born by pushing people against the wall and pressurizing them almost to the extreme."

客户几乎为王

The Customer Is Almost King

一家创新型公司还必须与客户取得平衡。 Arthur D. Little 进行的一项创新调查表明，绝大部分的好创意来自客户，而不是营销、销售或高层管理人员。 日本人再次领先。 最喜欢的方法是“产品搅动”：将

An innovative company also has to strike a balance with its customers. A survey of innovation conducted by Arthur D. Little showed that the greatest number of good ideas comes from customers, not marketing, sales, or top management. Once again the Japanese have led the way. A favorite approach is "product churning": putting

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

市场上有数百种不同的产品，然后支持消费者喜欢的产品。 日本每年推出大约一千种新的软饮料，但只有少数能够存活超过一年。 索尼在其位于东京银座区的陈列室中放置逼真的新产品模型，并观察购物者的反应。

hundreds of different products on the market and then backing the ones that the consumers prefer. About a thousand new soft drinks are brought out every year in Japan, but only a handful survive more than a year. Sony puts realistic-looking mock-ups of new products in its showroom in Tokyo's Ginza district and watches the reaction of shoppers.

这种将消费者转变为共同开发者的技术现已在西方被复制。 波音要求八家航空公司参与其双引擎777的规划和设计； 仅英国航空公司就对飞机的基本规格进行了 200 多项更改。 惠普在布里斯托尔运营的一个实验室将其研究人员派往医院急诊室，以确定医生如何使用该公司的移动通信设备。 生产小型打印机的爱普生公司要求其年轻的开发工程师在现场担任销售人员六个月，在服务部门工作六个月。 Harley-Davidson 的老板一半以上的时间都花在与客户相处上——在商店、摩托车集会上，以及在高速公路上燃烧。 施乐公司甚至聘请了人类学家来观察人们使用其复印机的情况。 17

This technique of turning consumers into codevelopers has now been copied in the West. Boeing asked eight airlines to participate in the planning and design of its twin-engine 777; British Airways alone made more than 200 changes to the aircraft's basic specifications. A laboratory run by Hewlett-Packard in Bristol sent its researchers to hospital emergency rooms to determine how doctors could use the company's mobile communications gear. Epson, which makes small printers, asks its young development engineers to spend six months in the field as salespeople, and six months in the service department. Harley-Davidson's boss spends more than half his time hanging around with his customers—in stores, at motorcycle rallies, and burning up the freeway. Xerox has even employed anthropologists to observe people using its photocopying machines. 17

但公司也可能在这个方向上走得太远。 客户通常非常保守； 他们想要更好、更便宜的现有产品，而不是创新产品。 没有客户能想出 3M 的便利贴； 事实上，当它们第一次出现时，人们对它们没什么兴趣——就像他们最初对传真机和 CNN 都嗤之以鼻一样。 尽管研究表明客户认为它看起来很奇怪，但克莱斯勒还是推出了它的小型货车； 它的开发人员正确地打赌人们一旦习惯它就会喜欢它。 如果康柏听取了其喜爱大型机的客户的意见，它就永远不会进入 PC 网络服务器市场。 正如佳能总裁御手洗肇 (Hajime Mitarai) 曾向福布斯解释的那样：“我们疯了……当人们说这很疯狂时，我们应该做点什么。

But companies can also go too far in this direction. Customers are usually very conservative; they want better, cheaper versions of what they already have rather than innovative products. No customer could have come up with 3M's Post-it notes; indeed, people showed little appetite for them when they first appeared—just as they initially scorned both the fax machine and CNN. Chrysler pushed through its Minivan despite research showing that customers thought it was strange looking; its developers bet correctly that people would like it once they got used to it. If Compaq had listened to its mainframe-loving customers, it would never have entered the market for PC-network servers. As Hajime Mitarai, Canon's president, once explained to Forbes: "We are crazy.... We should do something when people say it is crazy. If people say something is 'good,' it means that someone else is already doing it." 18

也许当前创新趋势最令人担忧的方面是它似乎产生了类似产品的扩散，而不是令人吃惊的新产品。 美国超市每年都会出现近 30,000 种新食品，但从肥皂到咖啡，大多数领先品牌都可以追溯到世纪之交。 当 Snapple 等产品唤醒软硬件市场时

Perhaps the most worrying aspect of the current trend toward innovation is that it seems to produce a proliferation of similar products rather than startling new ones. Close to 30,000 new food products appear each year in American supermarkets, yet, from soap to coffee, most of the brand leaders date back to the turn of the century. When products such as Snapple have awakened markets in soft

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

饮料或冰淇淋中的 Ben & Jerry's，它们往往来自小型“反文化”公司。 在最近的历史中，3M 见证了一系列进步，例如 Scotch Brite Never Rust 羊毛皂垫，但没有像便利贴这样的全新产品。

drinks or Ben & Jerry's in ice cream, they have tended to come from small "countercultural" firms. In its recent history 3M has seen a string of advances such as the Scotch Brite Never Rust Wool Soap Pad, but not another completely new item like Post-it.

在 1980 年代，像大前健一这样的大师曾经责骂美国公司总是在创新中追逐“本垒打”，而日本公司在他们持续改进的信条的指导下，连续取得了单打。 现在，索尼和松下正在注视消费电子行业更具创新性的部分迁移到硅谷，人们正在重新评估这个想法。 “渐进主义是创新的最大敌人，”多媒体的大祭司尼古拉斯·内格罗蓬特 (Nicholas Negroponte) 说。 19 Tom Peters 正确地指出，太多的汽车看起来是一样的：你无法分辨日产、本田和丰田之间的区别，现在质量接近完美（最后一辆车是什么时候你买的坏了？），人们越来越倾向于根据风格来选择东西。

During the 1980s, gurus such as Kenichi Ohmae used to scold American companies for always chasing "home runs" in innovation, while Japanese firms, guided by their doctrine of continual improvement, notched up a succession of singles. Now that Sony and Matsushita are watching the more innovative parts of the consumer electronics industry migrate to Silicon Valley, people are reassessing this idea. "Incrementalism is innovation's worse enemy," argues Nicholas Negroponte, the high priest of multimedia. 19 Tom Peters points out, correctly, that too many cars look the same: you can't tell the difference between the Nissans, the Hondas, and the Toyotas, and now that quality is close to perfect (when was it that the last car you bought broke down?), people are increasingly likely to choose things on the basis of style. If there is one area in which all Peters's predictions about craziness, ephemera, and consistent change are likely to pay off, it is innovation.

幼儿园还是兵营？

A Kindergarten or a Barracks?

正如关于创新的辩论所表明的，当今任何一家公司面临的最大问题之一就是控制。 大多数管理理论家都追随彼得德鲁克的脚步，认为新的知识经济正在做马克思和毛泽东试图做但失败的事情：将权力从“老板”转移到“工人”。 现实更令人沮丧。

As the debate about innovation shows, one of the biggest issues in any company nowadays is control. Most management theorists have followed Peter Drucker's lead and argued that the new knowledge-based economy is doing what Marx and Mao tried to do but failed: shifting power from "the bosses" to "the workers." The reality is more depressing.

确实，行事霸道的雇主很快就会因缺乏人才而倒闭。 感到不开心的员工可以简单地把他们的大脑带到另一个雇主那里——或者自己安排。 正如 Gary Hamel 所观察到的：

It is certainly true that employers who behave in a high-handed manner will soon go out of business for lack of talent. Employees who feel unhappy can simply take their brains to another employer—or else set up on their own. As Gary Hamel has observed:

在知识经济中，唯一值得拥有的员工是那些有许多其他就业选择的员工。 最有能力的知识工作者不太愿意将自己视为受欢迎的教员。 它不再是总部，而是公司园区。 . . . Beavis 和 Butthead 并不是唯一对权威有问题的人——试着赢

In the knowledge economy the only employees that are worth having are those with many other choices of employment. The most capable knowledge workers are less inclined to think of themselves as sought-after faculty members. It's not HQ any more, it's the corporate campus. . . . Beavis and Butthead are not the only ones who have a problem with authority—try winning

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

一个精明的 32 岁债券交易员或品牌经理基于原始的职位权威的忠诚度 20

the fealty of a whip-smart 32-year-old bond trader or brand manager on the basis of raw, positional authority 20

最成功的知识工作者确实可以向他们的雇主发号施令——或者，如果他们有冲动，也可以成为自由职业者或顾问。 公司吸引知识分子明星的方式与运动队吸引体育明星的方式非常相似：明星研究人员或专栏作家跳槽到竞争对手公司的消息足以压低公司的股价，并引发人才迁移。 在英国广告公司 Saatchi & Saatchi，股东们赶走了掌舵的兄弟，然后眼睁睁地看着他们成立了一家新的代理机构，吸引了很多老公司的客户。

The most successful knowledge workers can indeed dictate terms to their employers—or else set up as freelancers or consultants if they get the urge. Companies woo intellectual stars in much the same way as sports teams woo sports stars: the announcement that a star researcher or columnist is moving to a rival firm can be enough to depress a company's share price and set off a migration of talent into the bargain. At the British advertising firm Saatchi & Saatchi, shareholders drove out the brothers at the helm—and then watched them set up a new agency that lured away many of the old firm's clients.

这也不仅仅是少数才华横溢的人获得红地毯待遇的情况。 世界各地的公司都比以往更加尊重各类员工。 昨天的“雇工”变成了今天的“同事”或“同事”。 越来越多的公司鼓励员工使用他们的设施来完成他们自己的项目，就像 3M 所做的那样。 越来越多的公司给他们的员工休假来写书或者只是给他们充电。 {幸运的是，经济学人就是其中之一，否则这本书可能永远不会被写成。）

Nor is it just a case of a few talented individuals being given the red carpet treatment. Companies everywhere are treating workers of all sorts with more respect than they used to. Yesterday's "hired hands" have become today's "associates" or "colleagues." More firms encourage employees to use their facilities to work on their own projects, as 3M does. More and more companies give their employees sabbaticals to write books or just recharge their batteries. {The Economist is fortunately one of these, or this book might never have been written.)

正如“赋权”一词所暗示的那样，老板们不得不将权力移交给链条下游的人。 公司必须像推销产品和服务一样积极地推销会员资格——也许更是如此。 最好的雇主会不遗余力地通过照顾员工的福利（尤其是他们的教育福利）并为他们提供将知识用于工作的机会来赢得员工的忠诚度。

As the word "empowerment" implies, bosses have had to hand over power to people lower down the chain. Companies have to market membership just as aggressively as they market products and services—and perhaps more so. The best employers go out of their way to earn the loyalty of their workers by looking after their welfare (particularly their educational welfare) and providing them with opportunities to put their knowledge to work.

尽管如此，“知识经济”不会像许多人想象的那样成为工人的天堂。 公司的成功归功于许多因素，而不是员工的综合智商：他们的基本价值观、他们的管理系统、他们的传统惯例、他们定制的工厂，以及他们的当地传统。 换句话说，很大程度上取决于他们的组织记忆，这些记忆是他们在企业生涯中辛辛苦苦建立起来的。 一些最有价值的知识是高度特定于公司的：你需要加入公司才能获得它（因为它只传递给同修，而不是像共济会的传说），你需要留在公司的一部分

For all that, the "knowledge economy" is not going to be the workers' paradise that many people envisage. Companies owe their success to a whole host of things other than the combined IQs of their employees: their underlying values, their managerial systems, their traditional routines, their customized factories, and their local traditions. In other words, a great deal depends on their organizational memories, laboriously built up over their corporate lifetimes. Some of the most valuable knowledge is highly company-specific: you need to join the company in order to acquire it (because it is only passed on to initiates, rather like Masonic lore), and you need to remain part of the

知识、学习和创新

Knowledge, Learning, and Innovation

公司，如果你想使用它（因为它只有在与你同事的技能结合时才有意义）。

company if you want to use it (because it only makes sense when it is combined with the skills of your fellow employees).

学习型组织之所以成功，恰恰是因为它们善于以其他人无法模仿的方式产生知识。 成功的公司会在员工年轻且易受影响时进行招聘，并投入大量精力将这些新员工转变为公司男女员工，并派他们参加内部培训课程（摩托罗拉、迪士尼和许多其他公司都有自己的“大学” )，影响他们说话和穿着的方式，并鼓励他们与其他公司人员共度时光。 针对成功人士的培训计划通常会持续数年，让他们从一个工作岗位到另一个工作岗位，从一个国家到另一个国家，以便让他们对公司的运作方式有一个全面的了解。

Learning organizations are successful precisely because they are so good at generating knowledge in ways that others cannot imitate. Successful companies recruit people when they are young and impressionable and devote a lot of effort to turning these raw recruits into company men and women, sending them on in-house training courses (Motorola, Disney, and numerous other companies have their own "universities"), influencing the way they speak and dress, and encouraging them to spend their time with other company people. The training programs for high-flyers will often last for years and shuttle them from job to job and from country to country in order to give them an overall view of how the company operates.

公司可以高度重视知识，同时仍然让员工对真正的权力所在毫无疑问。 多次被管理理论家誉为模范学习型组织的折扣零售商沃尔玛，让新入职的员工举起右手发誓：“每当顾客来到我身边 10 英尺以内，我都会微笑，看着看着他，向他打招呼。帮帮我，山姆。” 直到最近，IBM 还要求其所有员工都穿白衬衫，系朴素的领带。 为 Nordstrom 工作的人愉快地称自己为“Nordies”，每天开始时高呼“我们想为 Nordstrom 做这件事”。

Companies can put heavy emphasis on knowledge while still leaving their employees with no doubt where the real power lies. Wal-Mart, a discount retailer that has been repeatedly praised by management theorists as a model learning organization, gets its new recruits to raise their right hand and swear that "every time a customer comes within 10 feet of me, I will smile, look him in the eye, and greet him. So help me Sam." Until recently, IBM expected all its employees to wear a white shirt and sober tie. People who work for Nordstrom happily refer to themselves as "Nordies" and start every day by chanting "We want to do it for Nordstrom."

对于许多工人，甚至可能是大多数工人来说，现代社会的根本划分将不是资本和劳动力之间的划分，而是内部人员和外部人员之间的划分——那些属于知识密集型公司并因此有机会提高智力和磨练技能的人之间的划分，一方面，另一方面，那些被冷落的人。 这对两类人来说尤其是坏消息。 首先，在经济衰退期间离开学校或大学的人，以及在下一轮招聘到来时被判断年龄太大的人，会发现政府资助的培训或通识教育再多也无法弥补公司的不足——具体技能。 第二，

For many workers, perhaps even most, the fundamental division in modern society will not be between capital and labor but between insiders and outsiders—between those who are part of knowledge-intensive companies and thus have a chance to sharpen their intellects and hone their skills, on the one hand, and those who are left out in the cold, on the other. This is particularly bad news for two sorts of people. First, people who leave school or university in the middle of a recession and who are judged too old when the next round of hiring comes along will find that no amount of government-sponsored training or general education can make up for the lack of company-specific skills. Second, middle-aged workers who become victims of the downsizing or delayering fashion and whose skills and values have been finely tuned by their previous employer will find, however hard they try, they cannot fit in elsewhere.

是否存在一个模型来展示知识型经济的样子？ 想到西尔维斯特·史泰龙 (Sylvester Stallone) 可能会忍不住想起来

Does a model exist to show how a knowledge-based economy might look? It may stick in the gullet to think of, say, Sylvester Stallone

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

作为一名知识工作者，但好莱坞的明星制度确实表明，其他行业中最有才华的人有一天可能会如何与他们的雇主达成交易。 一旦合同工绑定到工作室，演员现在是自由演员。 而且工作室不再是垂直整合的公司，拥有他们生产的一切。 相反，每一部电影都是由一个复杂的联盟制作的，在这个联盟中，制片厂只不过是银行家：几乎所有制作电影的重要方面——从选角和制作到特效——都被外包出去了。 好莱坞的另一个寓意是电影公司幸存了下来。 工作室可能无法绕过史泰龙，但绝大多数娱乐工作者都冒着危险穿越工作室。 该工作室的生产交易和联盟网络不断创造和传播更多知识。 他们是卓越的学习型组织； 但他们只在不得已的地方放弃了权力。

as a knowledge worker, but Hollywood's star system does suggest how the most talented people in other industries may one day strike deals with their employers. Once contract workers bound to studios, actors are now free agents. And the studios are no longer vertically integrated companies owning everything they produce. Rather, every film is made by a complex alliance in which the studio is no more than the banker: virtually all the important aspects of making a film—from casting and producing it to special effects—are contracted out. Another moral to be drawn from Hollywood is that the studios have survived. Studios may not be able to push around Stallone, but the vast majority of entertainment workers cross the studios at their peril. The studio's web of production deals and alliances continually creates and disperses more knowledge. They are learning organizations par excellence; but they have given away power only where they have had to.

<

<

第7章

CHAPTER 7

^J£%

^J£%

在巫医的世界里，有一种天赋最受重视：预测和控制未来的能力。 在过去，占卜者穿着奇怪的衣服，表演奇异的旋转动作，并献祭不幸的动物。 作为回报，部落首领会提供豪华的小屋和大量的处女供他们使用。 很自然地，巫医尽一切可能保护占卜的秘密，以免受到外人好奇的注视或愤世嫉俗者的批评。

In the witch doctor's world one talent is prized above all others: the ability to predict and control the future. In the old days, soothsayers donned strange clothes, performed exotic gyrations, and sacrificed unfortunate animals. In return, tribal chiefs put luxurious huts and a large supply of young virgins at their disposal. Naturally enough, the witch doctors did everything possible to protect the secrets of soothsaying from the curious gaze of outsiders or the critical questions of cynics.

管理理论家不得戴羽毛头饰或检查死动物的内脏——至少不能在公共场合这样做。 但是为了预测和控制未来，他们开发了听起来很奇特的技术，例如 SBU、PIM、PPBS 和 3X3 矩阵（仅举出最容易理解的）； 他们尽可能地保持这些技术的神秘性，通过复杂的数学公式和迷宫图来防止外行人窥探。 一名商学院学生回忆说，他参加了由该领域一位知名人士教授的 15 部分“战略”课程：“我学到了很多关于军事历史和儒家隐喻的知识。

Management theorists may not wear a feathered headdress or pore over the entrails of dead animals—at least not in public. But in their bid to predict and control the future they have developed exotic-sounding techniques, such as SBUs, PIMs, PPBSs, and 3X3 matrices (to name only the most comprehensible); and they have kept those techniques as mysterious as possible, protected from the prying eyes of laymen by complicated mathematical formulas and labyrinthine diagrams. One business school student recalls attending a 15-part course on "strategy" given by one of the leading names in the field: "I learned a great deal about military history and Confucian metaphors. But the only practical advice that we were given was that every company should send teams of people from different disciplines to country hotels every year to think about the future."

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

事实上，战略已经成为一门越来越迟钝的艺术。 在本世纪的大部分时间里，“战略规划”被视为管理思想的核心； 它通常有一个专门的部门。 规划——一个简洁、明确的军事概念——被改编和提炼成似乎是一门精确的科学。 然而，自 20 世纪 80 年代以来，战略规划——就像许多其他管理秘方一样——已经声名狼藉。 在不确定的时期，当很少有企业对预测下个月的利润感到高兴时，五年计划的想法让许多经理感到有点社会主义。 然而，拥有一些目标的吸引力——即使是一个不太容易实现、更短暂的目标——仍然存在。 战略因此被重新定义为新的术语，最突出的是“愿景”。

Indeed, strategy has become an ever more obtuse art. For most of this century, "strategic planning" was regarded as the very kernel of management thought; it often had an entire department devoted to it. Planning—a neat, definite, military concept—was adapted and refined into what seemed to be a precise science. Since the 1980s, however, strategic planning—like many other management nostrums—has been discredited. In uncertain times, when few businesses feel happy predicting their next month's profits, the idea of five-year plans strikes many managers as a little, well, socialist. Yet the appeal of having some goal to aim for—even a less attainable, more ephemeral one—remains. Strategy has thus been recast in new terms, most prominently as "vision." The question at the heart of this chapter is whether this is really an improvement.

构建计划机器

Building the Planning Machine

最容易受到管理理论可以赋予对未来的控制权这一说法的影响的组织是 1960 年代和 70 年代在美国实现其最佳繁荣的多部门公司。 从技术上讲，将计划置于企业生活中心的功劳应该归功于伊戈尔·安索夫 (Igor Ansoff) 和哈佛商学院的阿尔弗雷德·钱德勒 (Alfred Chandler) 等作家，他们在 1950 年代和 60 年代以不同的方式坚持认为所有公司都需要一个整体企业战略。 1 然而，这条路已经被熟悉的二人组——弗雷德里克·泰勒 (Frederick Taylor) 和阿尔弗雷德·斯隆 (Alfred Sloan) 开辟了。 通过将任务的执行与其协调分开，泰勒为新一代专业战略规划师的到来铺平了道路。 在斯隆的通用汽车公司， 公司总部的管理人员负责为整个组织制定长期战略。 2个

The organization that was most susceptible to the claim that management theory can confer control over the future was the mul-tidivisional firm that achieved its finest flowering in America in the 1960s and 1970s. Technically, the credit for putting planning at the center of corporate life should probably go to writers such as Igor Ansoff and the Harvard Business School's Alfred Chandler, who both, in their different ways, spent the 1950s and 1960s insisting that all companies needed an overall corporate strategy. 1 However, the trail had already been blazed by a familiar duo—Frederick Taylor and Alfred Sloan. By separating the performance of a task from its coordination, Taylor prepared the way for the arrival of a new class of professional strategic planners. At Sloan's General Motors, managers sitting in the corporate headquarters were responsible for crafting long-term strategy for the entire organization. 2

可以说，管理者对计划的迷恋比斯隆和泰勒还要深。 事实上，任何一本关于战略的书都包含一系列关于“侦察”或“良好情报”重要性的军事隐喻。 经理们总是幻想自己是军官阶层。 战略是他们与中士的区别。 计划部门就像他们中的许多人来到军官食堂一样接近。 在美国，有明确的军事联系。 美国军队在越南罕见地热衷于规划：美国“战略战略”政策的设计者之一

Arguably, managers' fascination with planning goes even deeper than Sloan and Taylor. Virtually any book about strategy contains a string of military metaphors about the importance of "reconnaissance" or "good intelligence." Managers have always fancied themselves an officer class. Strategy is what separates them from the sergeants. The planning department was as close as many of them came to an officers' mess. In America, there was an explicit military connection. The American army embraced planning with a rare fervor in Vietnam: one of the architects of America's policy of "strategic

战略

Strategy

轰炸”是 1950 年代福特公司战略规划的设计师罗伯特·麦克纳马拉 (Robert McNamara)。与此同时，在法国，战略规划人员试图管理整个国家，无论是公共部门还是私人部门。

bombing" had been an architect of strategic planning at Ford in the 1950s, Robert McNamara. Meanwhile, in France, strategic planners tried to run the whole country, public as well as private.

到 1960 年代初，规划仍然是一个相当简单的过程。 3 它通常包括三个阶段：设计描绘公司或部门未来的蓝图； 同意计划； 并最终实施它。 这个过程的每个部分，总共花费了大约一年的时间，都有自己的专职工作人员。 想法是计划部门的省。 协议留给了高级管理层和董事会。 执行是其他经理的工作，他们接受过专门针对此角色的培训（在通用电气的 Crotonville 中心等地方），并获得了重要的手册（例如 GE 著名的“蓝皮书”），告诉他们如何执行任务。 在安索夫看来，组织的功能是实施战略：一切——它的结构、它的等级——都遵循计划。

By the early 1960s, planning was still a fairly simple process. 3 It usually involved three stages: designing a blueprint setting out a company's or a division's future; agreeing on the plan; and finally implementing it. Each part of the process, which in total took about a year, had its own dedicated workers. Ideas were the province of the planning department. Agreement was left to senior management and the board. Implementation was the job of the other managers who had been specially trained for this role (at places like General Electric's Crotonville center) and were issued with weighty manuals (such as GE's famous "blue books") to tell them how to perform the task. The function of an organization in the eyes of Ansoff was to implement strategy: everything—its structure, its hierarchy—followed from the plan.

管理理论家为他们的创意的成功而受宠若惊，试图将计划转变为一门严谨而复杂的科学。 学术界将战略制定解构为其组成部分：使命、目标、外部分析、内部分析等。 面对对冗长乏味的反对意见，他们只会让战略制定过程变得更加复杂：管理理论家乔治·施泰纳 (George Steiner) 在《高层管理计划》(Top Management Planning, 1969) 中用了将近 800 页的篇幅来解释计划的基本原理。 4 十年后，在战略规划（副标题为 Everg 经理必须知道的内容）中，Steiner 甚至引入了一个新阶段，即“计划到计划”。 5个

Flattered by the success of their brainchild, management theorists tried to turn planning into a rigorous and sophisticated science. The academics deconstructed strategy making into its constituent parts: mission, objectives, external analysis, internal analysis, and so on. Confronted with objections to the rigmarole, they simply made the strategy-making process even more complicated: management theorist George Steiner took almost 800 pages to explain the rudiments of planning in Top Management Planning (1969). 4 Ten years later, in Strategic Planning (tellingly subtitled What Everg Manager Must Know), Steiner even introduced a new phase, the "plan to plan." 5

到 1960 年代末，通用电气等公司发现他们至少需要三个级别的战略制定者：首先是特定产品或部门的经理，然后是负责几个相关业务领域的“战略业务单元”层，最后是作为“投资组合规划师”的公司战略家，决定如何在各个战略业务部门之间分配公司的资源。 帮助规划者走出迷宫的工具很快风靡一时。 GE 自己开发了一个“行业-吸引力-企业-地位矩阵”，但最成功的援助是波士顿咨询集团的“增长-份额矩阵”，如第 5 章所述，它将企业分为摇钱树、明星、问号, 和狗。

By the end of the 1960s, firms such as General Electric found that they needed at least three levels of strategy makers: first the managers of particular products or divisions, then a layer of "strategic business units" that looked after several related areas of business, and finally a layer of corporate strategists who acted as "portfolio planners" deciding how to allocate the company's resources between the various strategic business units. Tools that helped planners through this maze were soon all the rage. GE itself developed an "industry-attractiveness-business-position matrix," but the most successful aid was the Boston Consulting Group's "growth-share matrix," which, as explained in Chapter 5, classified businesses into cash cows, stars, question marks, and dogs. The aim of all these devices was the same: to tell managers whether to invest, harvest, or

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

剥离，取决于他们的业务在图表上的位置。 6 到 1979 年，45% 的财富 500 强公司都在使用某种形式的投资组合规划。 7

divest, depending on where their business fell on the chart. 6 By 1979, 45 percent of the Fortune 500 companies were using some form of portfolio planning. 7

规划师波特

Porter the Planner

如果战略大师就他们正在尝试做的事情达成一致，所有这些复杂性可能都是可以容忍的。 但他们没有。 最大的分歧发生在强调案例研究并认为每个问题都有特定解决方案的哈佛商学院和波士顿咨询集团 (BCG) 之间，前者总是试图对公司的运营方式提供一个普遍的解释。 例如，BCG 认为，成功地将您的业务识别为摇钱树，对于棺材制造商和广告公司一样有用。 有一段时间，迈克尔·波特似乎可以解决这些争论，他在 1980 年代出版了一系列关于企业战略的书籍，然后才将注意力转向全球化（见第 10 章）。 波特给这个主题带来了一个拥有商学院 MBA 和博士学位的人的智力活力。 来自查尔斯河对岸商学院的经济学教员。 然而，他并不以简洁着称。

All this complexity might have been tolerable had the strategy gurus agreed on what they were trying to do. But they had not. The biggest split was between the Harvard Business School, which emphasized case studies and argued that each problem had a particular solution, and the Boston Consulting Group (BCG), which always tried to provide a universal explanation of the way that companies operated. For instance, the BCG believed that successfully identifying your business as, say, a cash cow was as useful to a coffin maker as to an advertising agency. For a while it looked as if these disputes might be solved by Michael Porter, who churned out a series of books on corporate strategy during the 1980s, before turning his attention to globalization (see Chapter 10). Porter brought to the subject the intellectual vigor of somebody who has both an MBA from the business school and a Ph.D. from the economics faculty that sits glowering at the business school across the Charles River. However, he is not known for his brevity.

在他的第一本书《竞争战略》（Competitive Strategy，1980 年）中，波特试图在这两种方法之间划出一条中间道路，认为在战略方面既有个别教训也有一般教训。 因此，他研究了个别公司，但将它们置于相关行业的背景下，他概述了“通用战略”，但强调不同的公司必须选择不同的成功之路。 在他的下一本书《竞争优势》（Competitive Advantage，1985 年）中，波特变得更加规范，概述了公司可以采取的通用战略。 他认为，在决定选择何种策略之前，公司需要做大量的功课。 这包括分析决定一个行业吸引力的“五种竞争力量”（潜在进入者、买家、供应商、替代品、 和竞争对手）并决定它是什么类型的行业（增长或衰退，成熟或成熟，等等）。 波特还认为，一家公司不应将自己视为一个单一的单位，而应将其视为离散活动（设计、生产、营销等）的“价值链”。

In his first book, Competitive Strategy (1980), Porter tried to plot a middle way between the two approaches, arguing that there were both individual and general lessons to be learned about strategy. Thus he studied individual companies but set them in the context of their relevant industries, and he outlined "generic strategies" but emphasized that different firms must choose different paths to success. In his next book, Competitive Advantage (1985), Porter became more prescriptive, outlining generic strategies that firms could take. Before deciding on what strategy to pick, he argued, a firm needed to do a lot of homework. This included analyzing the "five competitive forces" that determine an industry's attractiveness (potential entrants, buyers, suppliers, substitutes, and competitors) and deciding what sort of industry it was (growing or declining, ripening or mature, and so on). Porter also argued that a company should think of itself not as a single unit but as a "value chain" of discrete activities (designing, producing, marketing, etc.).

这种对分析的热爱解释了为什么波特成为规划者的神。 波特的作品不适合单行

This love of analysis explains why Porter became something of a god to planners. Porter's work does not lend itself to one-line

战略

Strategy

总结，然而，在他所有的列表和大量的例子之下，有一个相当简单的信息。 从本质上讲，战略就是在两种竞争方式之间做出选择。 一种选择是市场差异化，在为客户增加价值的基础上进行竞争，这样人们就会支付溢价来支付更高的成本。 另一种选择是基于成本的领导，以最低的成本提供产品或服务。 波特的数据表明，拥有明确战略的公司比那些缺乏明确战略或有意识地尝试走两条路并在价格和质量上领先的公司表现更好。

summaries, yet, underneath all his lists and copious examples there is a fairly simple message. In essence, strategy is about making a choice between two ways of competing. One choice is market differentiation, competing on the basis of value added to customers, so that people will pay a premium to cover higher costs. The other choice is cost-based leadership, offering products or services at the lowest cost. Porter's data showed that firms with a clear strategy performed better than those that either lacked a clear strategy or that consciously tried to follow both paths and lead the way on price and quality.

为什么计划机器停滞不前

Why the Planning Machine Stalled

这一切对波特来说都是不可思议的，他关于战略的大而方的书仍然是许多商学院的标准教材。 但这还不足以挽救计划的想法免于崩溃。 就在波特完善他的想法时，日本汽车公司正在推翻他的论点，在成本和质量上击败了美国人。 结果是计划很快就过时了。

All this was marvelous for Porter, whose big, square books on strategy remain standard texts in many business schools. But it was not enough to rescue the idea of planning from collapse. Even as Porter was refining his ideas, the Japanese car companies were demolishing his arguments, beating the Americans at both cost and quality. The result was that planning quickly went out of fashion.

日本人不仅设法将波特认为不相容的东西结合起来，而且他们没有费心准备战略计划就这样做了。 美国人对企业计划的沉迷让大前健一等日本思想家感到震惊，认为这是苏联对中央计划沉迷的私营部门版本，对创新和企业产生了同样的灾难性影响。 对战略规划的攻击不仅来自海外。 即使在哈佛商学院，对规划的挫败感也一直在增长。 罗伯特海耶斯指出，许多直线经理发现战略规划是良好管理的障碍。 8 阿米尔·比德 (Amir Bhide) 指出，在他采访过的快速成长型公司的创始人中，有三分之二的公司在创立公司时要么采用粗略的商业计划，要么根本没有商业计划。 9

Not only did the Japanese manage to combine things that Porter thought were incompatible, they did so without bothering to prepare strategic plans. The American addiction to corporate planning struck Japanese thinkers such as Kenichi Ohmae as a private sector version of the Soviet addiction to central planning, with the same disastrous impact on innovation and enterprise. The attacks on strategic planning came not only from overseas. Even in the Harvard Business School, frustration with planning had been growing. Robert Hayes pointed out that many line managers found strategic planning an impediment to good management. 8 Amir Bhide noted that two-thirds of the founders of fast-growing companies he had interviewed had started their companies with either back-of-the-envelope business plans or no business plans at all. 9

公司现在已经将注意力从规划未来转移到通过再造等学科来充分利用现在。 许多公司已经完全解散了他们的战略部门； 缺乏工作的战略咨询公司不得不加强再造。 一位领先的管理思想家亨利·明茨伯格 (Henry Mintzberg) 甚至写了一篇很长但非常出色的讣告，名为《战略规划的兴衰》(The Rise and Fall of Strategic Planning，1994 年)。

Companies have now shifted their attention from planning the future to getting the most out of the present through disciplines like reengineering. Many companies have disbanded their strategy departments entirely; and strategic consultancies, starved of work, have had to bone up on reengineering. One leading management thinker, Henry Mintzberg, has even written a long but excellent obituary called The Rise and Fall of Strategic Planning (1994).

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

那么战略和规划究竟有什么问题呢？ 指控单很长，但它基本上分为两个抱怨：实际困难和理论上不可能。 排在首位的困难是战略规划从未真正等同于战略思考。 相反，它变成了一种迂腐的年度仪式，每个部门的代表都试图抓住正在分发的任何资源。 这不仅会导致争吵（营销策略与制造策略相矛盾）； 这也意味着公司的战略往往不考虑可以引领未来市场的部门间联系。

So what exactly is wrong with strategy and planning? The charge sheet is a long one, but it essentially divides into two complaints: practical difficulties and theoretical impossibilities. Topping the list of difficulties is the fact that strategic planning never really amounts to strategic thinking. Instead it becomes a pedantic annual ritual in which representatives of each department try to grab whatever resources are being doled out. That not only leads to fights (the marketing strategy contradicts the manufacturing strategy); it also means that the company's strategy often takes no account of the interdepartmental connections that can lead the way to the markets of the future.

战略规划很快就变成了数字游戏。 通用电气这轮会议的真正内容是将数字相加，而不是讨论公司的未来。 在这个世界上，将一个部门的实际预算增加 1% 被视为过激举措，渐进主义才是王道。 诚然，IBM 的规划者确实逐渐向公司的个人电脑部门分配了更多资金，但他们从未意识到他们的行业发生了多么根本的变化。 鲁珀特·默多克 (Rupert Murdoch) 一直击败世界其他媒体巨头的原因之一是他依靠直觉而不是委员会。

Strategic planning soon becomes a numbers game. The real substance of General Electric's round of meetings was about making the numbers add up rather than discussing the company's future. And in this world, where increasing a department's budget by 1 percent in real terms is seen as a drastic move, incrementalism is king. True, IBM's planners did gradually allocate more money to the company's personal computer division, but they never grasped how radically their industry had changed. One reason why Rupert Murdoch has consistently beaten the world's other media giants to the punch is that he relies on instinct rather than committees.

矛盾的是，当一家公司的规划者确实决定（通常为时已晚）做某事时，他们往往会错误地进行大规模收购或多元化，但事实证明这些都不是战略性的。 想一想 West-inghouse 在 80 年代末进入金融服务业务的决定，或者 AT&T 试图通过收购 NCR 打入计算机业务，或者戴姆勒-奔驰对航空航天和电子产品的任何灾难性尝试。 好吧，有人可能会争辩说，但可以肯定的是，这一切都证明了战略可能执行不力。 关键是，计划往往是一项毫无意义的活动，即使在最有才华的经理手中也是如此。 最明显的问题是，既然未来就在未来，那么我们就无法知道它。 战略规划通常保守得无可救药， 将当前的做法投射到未来，而忽略了创新不断改变游戏规则的方式。 这种保守主义在 1950 年代的美国可能是合适的（尽管很多人甚至会对此提出异议），但它在环境可能发生根本变化且竞争优势的最大来源不存在的商业世界中没有立足之地

Paradoxically, when a company's planners do decide (usually too late) to do something, they often blunder into a big acquisition or diversification that proves to be anything but strategic. Think of West-inghouse's decision to enter the financial services business in the late 1980s or AT&T's attempt to break into the computer business with its acquisition of NCR, or any of Daimler-Benz's catastrophic forays into aerospace and electronic goods. Fine, someone might argue, but surely all that this proves is that strategy can be poorly executed. The point is, planning can frequently be a pointless activity, even in the hands of the most talented managers. The most obvious problem is that, since the future is, sensibly enough, in the future, we have no way of knowing it. Strategic planning is usually hopelessly conservative, projecting current practices into the future and ignoring the way that innovations are constantly changing the rules of the game. This conservatism may have been appropriate in, say, America in the 1950s (though many would dispute even that), but it has no place in a business world where the environment can change radically and where the greatest source of competitive advantage is not

战略

Strategy

真正的“成本”或“质量”而是“创意”。 规划保留了现有的思想类别，而创造力则将它们分开。

really "cost" or "quality" but "creativity." Planning preserves existing categories of thought, whereas creativity blows them apart.

即使是最好的计划者也可能把事情搞得一团糟。 考虑两个相当可预测的行业。 五年前，大多数西方金融机构仍然担心日本的银行会接管他们的业务，并制定了复杂的战略和简报文件来应对如何应对其市场的日本化。 今天，同样的银行和证券公司仍然担心东京的银行家——但只是因为他们可能会破产。 同样，在过去十年的大部分时间里，英国航空公司 (BA) 一直致力于阻止联合航空、美国航空和达美航空在希思罗机场建立相互竞争的“堡垒枢纽”。 现在，维珍航空——英航因不打领带而拒绝认真对待的人创立的新贵——是英航在大西洋航线上的主要竞争对手。 联合航空、达美航空也没有， 美国航空就是这么聪明：在过去十年的大部分时间里，他们都在互相争斗，而西南航空等小型航空公司则偷走了他们的客户。 请记住，航空公司和银行业都是受到高度监管的资本密集型企业。 谁愿意在 Netscape 这样的互联网先驱公司担任战略规划师？

Even the best planners can get things completely wrong. Consider two fairly predictable industries. Five years ago, most Western financial institutions were still terrified that Japan's banks would take over their business and drew up complicated strategies and briefing documents on how to cope with the Japanization of their markets. Today the same banks and securities houses are still worried about Tokyo's bankers—but only because they might go bust. Similarly, for most of the past decade British Airways (BA) has been obsessed with stopping United, American, and Delta from establishing competing "fortress hubs" at Heathrow. Now Virgin Atlantic—an upstart founded by a man BA refused to take seriously because he did not wear a tie—is BA's chief competitor on the Atlantic route. Nor have United, Delta, and American been that smart: they spent most of the past decade fighting each other while small airlines such as Southwest stole their customers. And, remember, both airlines and banking are highly regulated, capital-intensive businesses. Who would want to be a strategic planner at an Internet pioneer like Netscape?

第二个反对意见是统计数据并不像规划者认为的那样可靠。 （计划者往往类似于乔纳森·斯威夫特的《格列佛游记》中的小人国裁缝，他们用象限仪和六分仪测量格列佛，执行一系列复杂的计算，并在几天后返回一套“制作非常糟糕”的衣服。）客观和可信的统计数据往往基于脆弱的数据，并受到收集数据者的偏见的影响。 甚至在 80 年代后期，美国中央情报局的策划者就认为苏联拥有世界上最大的经济体之一——尽管事实上任何莫斯科出租车司机都可以告诉他们这是胡说八道。 Henry Mintzberg 一再指出，在任何组织中，最重要的知识不是在正式报告中写下并以数字表示的，而是在与客户、供应商和其他员工的非正式对话中交换的。 10

The second objection is that statistics are by no means as reliable as the planners believe. (Planners tend to resemble the Lilliputian tailors in Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels, who measure Gulliver with a quadrant and sextant, perform a set of complex computations, and return several days later with a suit of clothes "very ill made.") Far from being objective and trustworthy, statistics are often based on flimsy data and shaped by the prejudices of those who collect them. Even in the late 1980s the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency's planners argued that the Soviet Union possessed one of the world's biggest economies—despite the fact that any Moscow taxi driver could have told them this was nonsense. Henry Mintzberg has repeatedly pointed out that the most important knowledge in any organization is not what is written down in formal reports and expressed in numbers but what is exchanged in informal conversations, with customers, suppliers, and other workers. 10

最后一个反对意见是，战略规划将思考与行动分开。 战略制定者——通常是一小撮精英——会思考； 工人——其他所有人——都在行动。 战略家缺乏做出明智决策所需的组织的详细知识。 而拥有那种深厚知识的一线工作人员太过分了

The last objection is that strategic planning separates thinking from doing. The strategy makers—usually a tiny elite—think; the workers—everybody else—acts. Strategists lack the detailed knowledge of organizations needed to make informed decisions. And the front-line workers who possess that intimate knowledge are too far

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

从战略制定中删除以产生任何影响。 如果所有关于学习型组织等等的争论有任何意义的话，那就是公司的战略情报应该涉及其所有员工； 它不仅仅是一小群规划者的专利。

removed from strategy making to have any impact. If all the piffle about learning organizations and so on means anything at all, it is that a company's strategic intelligence should involve all its workers; it is not just the preserve of a small group of planners.

增长回归

Growth Is Back

战略显然有问题。 但其死亡的宣布有些夸张。 在过去的几年里，越来越多的经理人渴望战略思考的平静日子，如果不是战略规划的话。 这在很大程度上是对再造的一种反应。 经理们已经开始意识到，重组本身并不是一种战略，而是一种应对早期战略失败的手段。 通常情况下，裁员不会导致长期增长，而是会导致更多的裁员，而对短期的痴迷不会导致组织精通，而是会随波逐流和恐慌。 急事赶走重要事，转瞬即逝的时髦事分散了对真正机会的注意力。 被驱使产生短期利润，经理们忘了问他们的行业是否有长期的未来；

Strategy is clearly in trouble. But the announcement of its death is somewhat exaggerated. The past few years have seen more and more managers pining for the halcyon days of strategic thinking, if not quite strategic planning. To a large extent this is a reaction against reengineering. Managers have started to realize that restructuring is not in itself a strategy, but a means of dealing with the failure of earlier strategies. More often than not, downsizing leads not to long-term growth but to yet more downsizing, and the obsession with the short term leads not to organizational mastery but to drift and panic. The urgent drives out the important, and the fleetingly fashionable distracts attention from the real opportunity. Driven to produce short-term profits, managers forget to ask if their industry has a long-term future; determined to squeeze more out of less, they fail to spot new markets or invent new products.

在 Grow to Be Great: Breaking the Downsizing Cycle (1995) 中，来自 Mercer Management 的两位顾问 Dwight Gertz 和 Joao Bap-tista 研究了大约 1,000 家美国公司，发现在 1988-93 年表现最好的公司中只有 7%在过去的五年期间削减了成本。 投资于增长的公司股价年复合增长率为 15%，而投资于成本节约的公司股价仅上涨 11%。

In Grow to Be Great: Breaking the Downsizing Cycle (1995), two consultants from Mercer Management, Dwight Gertz and Joao Bap-tista, looked at some 1,000 American companies and found that only 7 percent of the best-performing ones in 1988-93 had cut costs in the previous five-year period. Companies that invested in growth were awarded with a compound 15 percent annual rise in their share price while those who invested in cost savings only saw an 11 percent rise.

过去十年美国企业的真正成功不是那些像通用电气和施乐这样英勇地完成了血腥转型的公司，而是那些从一开始就从未走错方向并不断发展壮大的公司。 例如，令人尊敬的老惠普公司的规模翻了两番。 到 1995 年年中，甚至那些大幅削减开支的公司也意识到未来的利润将来自增长。 “Union Pacific 过去有 80,000 名员工。如今我们只有不到 50,000 人，”该公司首席执行官德鲁·刘易斯 (Drew Lewis) 向《战略与商业》杂志宣称。 “仍有削减成本的空间，但除非我们通过改善服务和增加收入来增加收入，否则我们不会去任何地方

The real successes of American business of the past decade are not those companies such as General Electric and Xerox that have completed heroically bloody turnarounds, but those who never went in the wrong direction in the first place—and kept on growing. Venerable old Hewlett-Packard, for instance, has quadrupled in size. By mid-1995 even those companies that had cut back hard realized that future profits would come from growth. "Union Pacific used to have 80,000 employees. Today we have fewer than 50,000," Drew Lewis, the company's chief executive, declared to the periodical Strategy & Business. "There is still room to cut costs, but we're not going anywhere unless we grow our revenues through improved services and

战略

Strategy

令人满意的利润率。”11随着老板们的想法转向增长，他们的时间范围也延长了。1995 年底，博思艾伦咨询公司的顾问布赖恩·迪基估计，他的客户的“战略重点”已经大大延长到大约七年（“在较早的情况下，18 个月并不罕见”）。

satisfactory margins." 11 And as bosses' thoughts have turned to growth, their time horizons have lengthened. In late 1995 Brian Dickie, a consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, estimated that his clients' "strategic focus" had lengthened considerably to around seven years ("on earlier occasions 18 months was not unusual").

随着“增长”突然重新流行起来，管理理论家重新研究了战略——并得出了两个一般性结论。 首先是，尽管有种种缺点，但规划并不是一场彻头彻尾的灾难。 Royal Dutch/Shell 开创了一种情景规划系统，该系统更像是一种学习练习，而不是试图做出准确的预测。 然而，通过提出一系列“假设”问题，情景规划让石油公司更好地了解其优势和劣势。它还做出了一些相当准确的预测：壳牌是唯一一家预测 1973 年石油危机并有现成的应对策略。

With "growth" suddenly back in fashion, management theorists have reinvestigated strategy—and reached two general conclusions. The first is that, for all its faults, planning was not an unmitigated disaster. Royal Dutch/Shell pioneered a system of scenario planning that was meant to be more of a learning exercise than an attempt to make accurate predictions. However, by asking a succession of "what if questions, scenario planning gave the oil company a better understanding of its strengths and weaknesses. It also produced some fairly accurate predictions: Shell was the only major oil company to predict the 1973 oil crisis and to have a ready-made strategy for coping with it.

另一个更普遍的结论是，即使他们放弃了计划，最成功的公司仍然对思考未来有着浓厚的兴趣。 微软有一个先进的技术集团，东芝拥有一个生活方式研究所，而雅马哈在伦敦有一个“监听站”，里面装满了所有最新的音乐小玩意，它为欧洲最有才华的音乐家提供服务。 最具冒险精神的公司正在沉迷于沃尔特·迪斯尼所说的“想象”。 Electronic Data Systems 聘请了 Disney 校友帮助公司组织展览，展示信息技术将如何重塑人们的生活。 一些领先的商人，包括大型水泥制造商拉法基的前负责人奥利维尔·勒瑟夫和飞利浦的首席技术官弗兰克·卡鲁巴， 已经开始休假以反思未来。 12

The other more general conclusion is that, even if they have ditched planning, the most successful companies remain intensely interested in thinking about the future. Microsoft has an Advanced Technology Group, Toshiba boasts a Lifestyle Research Institute, and Yamaha has a "listening post" in London, chock full of all the latest musical gadgetry, which it makes available to Europe's most talented musicians. The most adventurous companies are indulging in what Walt Disney calls "imagineering." Electronic Data Systems hired Disney alumni to help the company put together an exhibit demonstrating how information technology would reshape people's lives. Some leading businessmen, including Olivier Lecerf, former head of Lafarge, a large cement manufacturer, and Frank Carruba, the chief technology officer of Philips, have started taking sabbaticals in order to reflect on the future. 12

管理咨询公司也开始开发超前思考的新技术。 Arthur D. Little 鼓励其客户想象一个特定技术（例如虚拟现实 (VR)）变得司空见惯的未来。 13 名儿童在 VR 游乐场消磨时光； 衣服买家在要求制作之前在 VR 镜子中“试穿”衣服； 学生“环游世界”寻找最佳VR教室。 客户必须考虑这一切对他们自己的业务意味着什么。 他们还要“书写未来的历史”，看看有哪些技术突破和

Management consultancies have also started to develop new techniques for thinking ahead. Arthur D. Little encourages its clients to imagine a future in which a particular technology—virtual reality (VR), say—has become commonplace. 13 Children spend their time in VR playgrounds; clothes buyers "try" on clothes in VR mirrors before asking for them to be made; students "tour the world" looking for the best VR classroom. Clients have to think about what all this means for their own business. They also have to "write a history of the future" in order to see what technological breakthroughs and

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

需要改变监管才能使这一“历史”成为可能。 该咨询公司认为，这种技术提供了一种思考未来的方式，既不从现在推断也不沉迷于预测的伪科学：这一点有点像壳牌的情景规划，只是问“如果……会怎样？”

regulatory changes are needed to make this "history" possible. The consultancy argues that this technique provides a way of thinking about the future without either extrapolating from the present or indulging in the pseudoscience of prediction: the point, a little like Shell's scenario planning, is simply to ask "What if. . . ?"

科幻小说的重要性

The Importance of Science Fiction

但是，是否可以将所有这些未来主义的想法转化为一项战略，而无需回到（通常是坏的）规划理念？ 根据许多理论家的说法，答案是提出一个战略愿景——为公司提供一种使命感，而无需中央计划的成本和限制。 根据他们的倡导者，愿景定义了一些突出的目标，公司可以围绕这些目标组织资源； 它们有助于激励员工追求共同目标：想想约翰·肯尼迪 (John F. Kennedy) 如何利用他在十年内将人类送上月球的愿景来激发美国的太空计划； 或 Apple 的梦想，即美国每个男人、女人和孩子都拥有一台电脑。 微软明确表达的“拥有桌面”的梦想可以追溯到 80 年代初期， 帮助它主导了操作系统，然后是应用软件，现在似乎正将它推向互联网。 近十年来，Sun Microsystems 坚持“网络就是计算机”的理念，并从中获益匪浅。

But can all this futuristic thought be translated into a strategy without falling back on the (generally bad) idea of planning? The answer, according to many theorists, is to come up with a strategic vision—something that provides a company with a sense of mission without the costs and constraints of central planning. Visions, according to their advocates, define a few outstanding goals around which companies can organize their resources; and they help to inspire the workforce to pursue common aims: think of the way that John F. Kennedy used his vision of putting a man on the moon within a decade to galvanize America's space program; or Apple's dream of a computer for every man, woman, and child in America. Microsoft's clearly articulated dream of "owning the desktop," which dates back to the early 1980s, has helped it to dominate first operating systems, then applications software and now seems to be pushing it toward the Internet. Sun Microsystems has reaped great benefits from sticking by its idea that "the network is the computer" for almost a decade.

愿景也不局限于穿着运动鞋的企业家。 在日本，即使是最下流的经理也会花一些时间凝视水晶球。 自从他在 1982 年出版了《战略家的思想》以来，大前健一一直指出，日本公司围绕着共同的愿景组织起来——而且，这些愿景是从持续的谈判过程中产生的，而不是从一个专横的领导者的头脑中产生的. 在 1980 年代，美国企业中唯一比普通日本经理更受尊敬的人物是杰克·韦尔奇 (Jack Welch)。 韦尔奇也痴迷于愿景。 14 当他放弃通用电气的所有战略规划机构时，他设定了一个相当简单的目标：“成为一个行业的一两个人——否则就退出。” 这个想法很容易理解，但很难成为鼓舞人心的愿景。 在 80 年代初期的大部分时间里，GE 的员工对战略的了解只是 Neutron Jack 宣布更多裁员的痛苦。 韦尔奇首次尝试更高的主题——试图

Nor are visions confined to sneakered entrepreneurs. In Japan even the dowdiest managers spend some of their time gazing into crystal balls. Ever since he published The Mind of the Strategist in 1982, Kenichi Ohmae has been pointing out that Japanese companies organize themselves around common visions—visions, moreover, that emerge from a continual process of negotiation, rather than from the mind of a single domineering leader. Perhaps the only creature more admired in American business during the 1980s than the generic Japanese manager was Jack Welch. Welch, too, has an obsession with visions. 14 When he dispensed with all GE's strategic planning apparatus, he set a fairly simple goal instead: "Be one or two in an industry— or else get out." This idea was easy to understand but hardly an inspiring vision. For much of the early 1980s all that GE's workers knew about strategy was the pain of Neutron Jack announcing yet more redundancies. Welch's first attempt at a loftier theme—trying to

战略

Strategy

说服通用电气的员工他们拥有这家企业——失败了。 他的 GE 就像一个“商业引擎”的想法取得了更大的成功，但他的信息直到 1988 年末他推出“Work Out”时才得到传达——这是一项授权计划，从 GE 员工参加的一系列会议开始可以宣泄他们的不满。

persuade GE's staff that they owned the business—flopped. He had a little more success with his idea that GE was like a "business engine," but his message did not get through until late 1988 when he launched "Work Out"—an empowerment program that began with a series of meetings in which GEers could air their grievances.

一旦韦尔奇的新愿景流行起来，想法就开始来自那些对他最敌对的中层管理人员。 多年来，韦尔奇每个月都会回到“The Pit”——位于克罗顿维尔的 GE 管理发展中心的圆形剧场，Work-Out 就是在这里构思出来的——向员工发表关于 Work-Out 的布道。 就像所有最好的愿景一样，它已经获得了自己的语言。 例如，“唾手可得的果实”是在工厂中很容易实现的节约； “蟒蛇”是一个缠绕在一起的官僚机构。 现在韦尔奇再次改变了他的信息，他梦想把通用电气变成一个“无边界的组织”。 “公司需要包罗万象的主题来创造变革，”韦尔奇争论道。 “如果只是有人推销一个噱头或一个程序，没有一个总体主题，你可以”

Once Welch's new vision caught on, ideas started coming from the very middle managers who had been most hostile to him. For years Welch returned every month to "The Pit"—the amphitheater at GE's Management Development Center in Crotonville where Work-Out was conceived—to deliver a sermon on Work-Out to employees. Already—like all the best visions—it has acquired its own language. "Low-hanging fruit," for instance, are easy-to-make savings in factories; a "python" is an entwining bureaucracy. Now Welch has changed his message again, and he dreams of turning GE into a "boundaryless organization." "Companies need overarching themes to create change," Welch has argued. "If it's just somebody pushing a gimmick or a program, without an overarching theme, you can't get through the wall." 15

所有这一切都足以将梦想变成一个管理行业。 现在几乎每家公司都有一份使命宣言，旨在阐明其对未来的看法。 越来越多的公司组建了“愿景工作组”。 即使是像乔治·布什一样对“愿景”持同样轻蔑态度的老板们也不得不屈服。 郭士纳 (Lou Gerstner) 进入 IBM 时宣称，这家计算机巨头不需要的是另一种愿景； 到 1995 年，他开始喃喃自语“建设一个网络化的未来”。

All this has been enough to turn dreaming up visions into a management industry in its own right. Virtually every firm now has a mission statement that purports to articulate its view of the future. An increasing number of companies assemble "vision task forces." Even bosses who took the same dismissive attitude to "the vision thing" as George Bush have had to knuckle under. Lou Gerstner came into IBM declaring that the one thing that the computer giant did not need was another vision; by 1995 he had begun mumbling about "building a networked future."

甚至会计师现在也有梦想的冲动。 1994 年，亚瑟·安达信 (Arthur Andersen) 的审计部门在五年前开始了一个名为 Vision 2000 的项目，决定是时候发布一个名为“创造我们的未来”的新信息了。 愿景工作组由 100 人组成：75 名合伙人和 25 名年轻的成功人士。 它在芝加哥、里斯本、柏林和新加坡举行会议，“有远见的人”在这些聚会之间在网上喋喋不休。 安徒生还咨询了杰克韦尔奇等客户和查尔斯汉迪等专家。 在考虑过诸如“到 2005 年安达信将成为世界上最大的律师事务所”之类的命题之后，梦想家兼会计师们决定，公司的目标应该是从审计客户的账簿转变为审计他们的业务。 见面

Even accountants now feel the urge to dream. In 1994 Arthur Andersen's auditing arm, which five years earlier, had embarked on a project called Vision 2000, decided it was time for a fresh message called Creating Our Future. The vision task force was made up of 100 people: 75 partners and 25 young high-flyers. It met in Chicago, Lisbon, Berlin, and Singapore, and the "visionaries" chattered away on-line between these gatherings. Andersen also consulted clients, such as Jack Welch, and gurus, such as Charles Handy. Having played around with propositions such as "By 2005 Arthur Andersen has become the biggest law firm in the world," the dreamer-accountants decided that the company's aim should be to change from auditing the books of its clients to auditing their businesses. To meet

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

在这个更具咨询性的角色中，会计师们想出了一个方程式和一个口号。 等式是 K = (P + I)S，其中 K 是知识； P，我们的人； J、信息； S，分享的力量。 口号是安徒生，“世界上最伟大的地方做伟大的工作”。 虽然这肯定算作历史上最卑鄙的战斗口号之一，但安达信的会计师发誓说，这个过程帮助他们重新调整了公司的方向——五年太长了，等不及下一个梦想； “愿景必须是一个持续的过程。”

this more consultative role, the accountants came up with an equation and a slogan. The equation was K = (P + I)S, where K is knowledge; P, our people; J, information; and S, the power of sharing. The slogan was Andersen, "The World's Greatest Place to do Great Work." Although this must surely count among the shabbiest battle cries in history, Andersen's accountants swear that the process has helped redirect their company—and that five years is too long to wait for another dream; "visioning has to be an ongoing process."

新合成

The New Synthesis

愿景真的可以充实为实际战略吗？ 稍微概括一下，学术界倾向于分成两组。 第一组希望将战略主题推向更短暂的领域。 哈佛商学院教授 John Kao（本身也是一位成功的企业家）认为，公司的主要战略目标应该是鼓励创造力。 在过去，计划者通常会分发乐谱，并准确描述每个人应该演奏的曲目。 现在，根据 Kao 的说法，战略就像爵士乐。 战略家应该设定总体方向，但让个人即兴发挥。 这种创造性的方法被证明非常受欢迎，以至于 1995 年美国管理协会的一篇“论文”由一群爵士音乐家组成，他们竭尽全力发挥作用。

Can visions really be fleshed out into meaty strategies? To generalize slightly, academics have tended to split into two groups. The first group wants to push the subject of strategy into more ephemeral fields. John Kao, a professor at the Harvard Business School (and a successful entrepreneur in his own right), argues that the chief strategic aim of a company should be to encourage creativity. In the old days planners used to hand out sheet music with exact descriptions of what each person should play; now, according to Kao, strategy is like jazz. The strategists should set the overall direction, but let individuals improvise. This creative approach is proving so popular that one "paper" at the 1995 American Management Association consisted of a bunch of jazz musicians, jamming for all they were worth.

第二组思想家在采用更有纪律的波特式方法后仍在倾听。 例如，在《公司成功的基础》（Foundations of Corporate Success，1993 年）一书中，英国经济学家转变为管理理论家约翰·凯 (John Kay) 采用了一种几乎与波特的方法一样复杂的方法。 凯认为，战略应该围绕确定每个公司在四个领域的优势来制定：它的声誉（可以包括品牌）、它的创新能力、它的战略资产（比如药品专利或政府批准的垄断），以及它的“架构”，他指的是公司内外的关系网络（他特别热衷于 Marks and Spencer 的供应商网络）。 凯对特定公司成功的原因进行了出色的分析，但他仍然坚信每家公司的立场都不同， 战略成功没有通用的答案。 这很可能是一种严谨的思想方法，但很难为他赢得读者。

A second group of thinkers still hearken after a more disciplined, Porterish approach. For instance, in Foundations of Corporate Success (1993), John Kay, a British economist-turned-management-theorist, took on an approach almost as complicated as Porter's. Kay argues that strategy should be built around identifying each firm's strength in four fields: its reputation (which can include brands), its ability to innovate, its strategic assets (such as a drug patent or a government-sanctioned monopoly), and its "architecture," by which he means the network of relationships within and outside a firm (he is particularly keen on Marks and Spencer's supplier network). Kay offers an excellent analysis of why particular firms have succeeded, but he remains adamant that each firm's position is different, and that there are no generic answers to strategic success. This may well be an intellectually rigorous approach, but it is hardly designed to win him readers.

对战略影响最大的书《为未来而竞争》，由 Gary Hamel 和 CK 于 1994 年 9 月出版

The book that has had the biggest impact on strategy, Competing for the Future, published in September 1994 by Gary Hamel and C. K.

战略

Strategy

Prahalad，结合了两种方法的元素。 普拉哈拉德帮助他的雇主密歇根大学商学院成为美国最重要的商业战略思考中心之一。 哈梅尔可以说是他那一代人中最聪明的（而且，根据他的同龄人，也是最富有的）商业思想家。 《为未来而战》的成功也归功于该书出版商哈佛商学院出版社的营销头脑，该出版社斥资 75,000 美元对该书进行营销，确保在《财富》杂志上连载，并派作者到全国巡回宣传他们的想法。

Prahalad, combines elements of both approaches. Prahalad has helped turn his employer, the University of Michigan Business School, into one of the foremost centers of thinking on business strategy in America. Hamel is arguably the brightest (and, according to his peers, the richest) business thinker of his generation. The success of Competing for the Future also owed something to the marketing savvy of the book's publisher, Harvard Business School Press, which spent $75,000 marketing the book, secured serialization in Fortune, and sent the authors on a national tour to publicize their ideas.

为未来而战的核心主张是，最重要的竞争形式是创造和支配新兴机会的战斗，而整个传统战略思想，从高级管理人员的角色到战略本身的性质，都需要根据这种洞察力重新思考。 传统战略家将公司视为产品和业务部门的集合； Hamel 和 Prahalad 将它们视为技能的集合。 传统战略家试图在现有市场中尽可能巧妙地定位他们的组织； Hamel 和 Prahalad 认为，公司应该通过遵循愿景来重塑整个行业。 作为一个例子，Hamel 和 Prahalad 引用了摩托罗拉的“无线”梦想 在这个世界上，电话号码是分配给个人而不是分配给地点的，而且每个人都有一部便携式电话。 应对日益不确定的世界的最佳方式不是逃避短期主义，而是想象 10 年或更长时间后的市场情况，然后拼命努力实现目标。 获胜者可以通过多种方式获得利益：通过建立对特定产品的垄断，无论多么短暂（就像克莱斯勒对小型货车和索尼对随身听所做的那样）； 通过制定标准或拥有知识产权（就像松下对 VCR 所做的和微软对 DOS 所做的那样）； 或者通过制定游戏规则（就像沃尔玛对城外大卖场所做的那样）。 至于失败者，他们将陷入不断缩小规模的循环。 应对日益不确定的世界的最佳方式不是逃避短期主义，而是想象 10 年或更长时间后的市场情况，然后拼命努力实现目标。 获胜者可以通过多种方式获得利益：通过建立对特定产品的垄断，无论多么短暂（就像克莱斯勒对小型货车和索尼对随身听所做的那样）； 通过制定标准或拥有知识产权（就像松下对 VCR 所做的和微软对 DOS 所做的那样）； 或者通过制定游戏规则（就像沃尔玛对城外大卖场所做的那样）。 至于失败者，他们将陷入不断缩小规模的循环。 应对日益不确定的世界的最佳方式不是逃避短期主义，而是想象 10 年或更长时间后的市场情况，然后拼命努力实现目标。 获胜者可以通过多种方式获得利益：通过建立对特定产品的垄断，无论多么短暂（就像克莱斯勒对小型货车和索尼对随身听所做的那样）； 通过制定标准或拥有知识产权（就像松下对 VCR 所做的和微软对 DOS 所做的那样）； 或者通过制定游戏规则（就像沃尔玛对城外大卖场所做的那样）。 至于失败者，他们将陷入不断缩小规模的循环。 获胜者可以通过多种方式获得利益：通过建立对特定产品的垄断，无论多么短暂（就像克莱斯勒对小型货车和索尼对随身听所做的那样）； 通过制定标准或拥有知识产权（就像松下对 VCR 所做的和微软对 DOS 所做的那样）； 或者通过制定游戏规则（就像沃尔玛对城外大卖场所做的那样）。 至于失败者，他们将陷入不断缩小规模的循环。 获胜者可以通过多种方式获得利益：通过建立对特定产品的垄断，无论多么短暂（就像克莱斯勒对小型货车和索尼对随身听所做的那样）； 通过制定标准或拥有知识产权（就像松下对 VCR 所做的和微软对 DOS 所做的那样）； 或者通过制定游戏规则（就像沃尔玛对城外大卖场所做的那样）。 至于失败者，他们将陷入不断缩小规模的循环。

The central claim of Competing for the Future is that the most important form of competition is the battle to create and dominate emerging opportunities, and that the whole of traditional strategic thinking, from the role of senior managers to the nature of strategy itself, needs to be rethought in the light of this insight. Traditional strategists looked upon companies as a collection of products and business units; Hamel and Prahalad look upon them as a collection of skills. Traditional strategists tried to position their organization as cleverly as possible in existing markets; Hamel and Prahalad argue that a company should try to reinvent its whole industry by following a vision. As one example, Hamel and Prahalad cite Motorola's dream of a "wireless" world in which telephone numbers are assigned to people rather than places and everybody has a portable phone. The best way of dealing with an increasingly uncertain world is not to take refuge in short-termism but to imagine what the market will be like 10 or more years hence and then try desperately to get there. The winners can reap benefits in numerous ways: by establishing a monopoly, however briefly, of a particular product (as Chrysler did with minivans and Sony with the Walkman); by setting standards or owning intellectual property rights (as Matsushita has done with VCRs and Microsoft with DOS); or by establishing the rules of the game (as Wal-Mart did with out-of-town hypermarkets). As for the losers, they are consigned to a perpetual cycle of downsizing.

对这一论点的一个明显回应是，有远见的公司可能会赢得管理理论家的喝彩，但真正赚钱的却是追随他们的勤劳者。 为什么不让领导者进行所有投资并承担所有风险，然后像比尔盖茨那样简单地复制或购买他们的产品呢？ 直到最近，大多数学术研究都倾向于暗示“先行者”具有很大的优势（据统计，25 家市场领导者中有 19 家

One obvious response to this argument is that visionary companies may earn the applause of management theorists, but it is the plodders who come after them who make the real money. Why not let the leaders make all the investments and take all the risks and then simply copy or buy their product, just as Bill Gates did? Until recently most academic research tended to hint that "first movers" had a big advantage (by one count 19 of the 25 firms that were market leaders

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

在 1923 年的各种消费品中，60 年后仍然名列前茅）。 然而，此类调查往往只涉及幸存的公司和幸存的品牌。 例如，每个人（包括宝洁公司）都倾向于认为该公司在 1961 年推出帮宝适时发明了一次性尿布业务。事实上，另一个品牌，名字不雅且现已停产的 Chux，已经有四分之一的历史了世纪，尽管它集中在富有的家庭和旅行的人身上。 帮宝适不是新产品； 它只是更便宜并且针对更广泛的市场。 同样的故事也适用于录像机。 美国公司 Ampex 于 1956 年率先推出该产品，但 20 年后被松下和索尼等日本制造商的廉价型号扫地出门。

in various consumer products in 1923 were still on top 60 years later). However, such surveys often tend to deal only with surviving companies and surviving brands. For instance, everybody (including Procter & Gamble) tends to believe that the firm invented the disposable diaper business when it launched Pampers in 1961. In fact another brand, the inelegantly named and now defunct Chux, had already been going for a quarter of a century, though it had concentrated on wealthy households and people who were traveling. Pampers was not a new product; it was just cheaper and aimed at a wider market. The same story can be told about videorecorders. An American firm, Ampex, pioneered the product in 1956 but was swept out of the way 20 years later by cheaper models from Japanese manufacturers such as Matsushita and Sony. Gerard Tellis of the University of California and Peter Golder of New York University's Stern School of Business have completed a detailed study of over 50 markets in which they look at the brands that have perished as well as those that survived: the pioneers, they have discovered, are leaders in only 1 in 10 of the markets, and, on average, the current leaders entered the market 13 years after the "first mover" 16 .

总的来说，这类研究对哈梅尔和普拉哈拉德的论点提出了挑战，但并未使之无效。 在许多情况下，追随者的产品差异很大，几乎可以算作是新产品。 即使某些跟单者可能在过去获胜，但对于未来而言，这似乎并不是一个诱人的策略。 复制领导者的问题在于，有数十家其他公司正试图做同样的事情，但利润率却越来越低。 在大多数品牌商品业务中，几乎所有的利润都被前两种产品蚕食掉了。 此外，以下公司不仅要模仿产品； 他们还必须复制帮助产生它的核心竞争力。 飞利浦、汤姆逊和真力时让日本竞争对手在便携式摄像机领域处于领先地位后，发现根本无法赶上； 日本手机制造商的情况也差不多，他们仍在追赶摩托罗拉、爱立信和诺基亚。 对 Hamel 和 Pra-halad 的另一种攻击方式是，如果没有资源支持，愿景并不意味着无花果。 整个管理思想家学派都支持“公司的资源基础理论”，该理论认为，真正重要的是公司为战斗带来的物质火力。 事实上，物质资源变得越来越不重要

On balance, this sort of research challenges but does not invalidate Hamel and Prahalad's argument. In many cases the follower's product was sufficiently different that it could almost count as a new one. And even if some copiers may have won in the past, it does not look like a tempting strategy for the future. The problem with copying the leaders is that there are dozens of other companies that are trying to do the same thing, on ever narrower profit margins. In most branded-goods businesses, nearly all the profits are chewed up by the leading two products. Besides, following companies not only have to imitate a product; they also have to copy the core competencies that helped produce it. Having let Japanese competitors take the lead in camcorders, Philips, Thomson, and Zenith have simply found it impossible to catch up; much the same has happened to Japanese producers in cellular phones, where they are still chasing Motorola, Ericsson, and Nokia. An alternative line of attack on Hamel and Pra-halad is that visions do not mean a fig if one does not have the resources to back them up. An entire school of management thinkers support the "resource-based theory of the firm," which argues that what really matters is the physical firepower a company brings to the battle. In fact, physical resources are becoming less and less important

战略

Strategy

作为竞争优势的来源。 如果一家公司不仔细考虑十年后的发展方向，那么世界上所有的金钱和积累的脑力都无法挽救一家公司。 IBM 每年在研发上花费 60 亿美元，但未能看到市场正在从大型机转向个人计算机：直到 1991 年，其研发预算的三分之一都花在了“大型机”上。 回到手机领域，松下和索尼的所有影响力都没有阻止小型诺基亚在它们周围运行。

as a source of competitive advantage. All the money and accumulated brain power in the world will not save a company if it fails to think carefully about where it will be a decade hence. IBM spent $6 billion a year on research and development but failed to see that the market was shifting from mainframes to personal computers: as late as 1991 a third of its R&D budget was spent on "big iron." Returning to cellular telephones, all Matsushita and Sony's clout have not stopped tiny Nokia running rings around them.

伸展自己

Stretch Yourself

此外，Hamel 和 Prahalad 不仅仅是空灵的未来主义者。 他们坚持认为，公司应该首先花钱思考未来（就像微软、东芝、雅马哈、迪斯尼、摩托罗拉和 EDS 所做的那样）； 公司需要他们所谓的“战略架构”——了解他们希望为客户提供什么利益以及他们应该使用什么交付机制来提供这些利益。 两个概念对于战略架构至关重要。

Besides, Hamel and Prahalad are more than just ethereal futurists. They insist that companies should first spend money on thinking about the future (as Microsoft, Toshiba, Yamaha, Disney, Motorola, and EDS do); and that firms need what they call a "strategic architecture"—a sense of what benefits they want to deliver to their customers and what delivery mechanisms they should use to deliver those benefits. Two concepts are crucial to strategic architecture.

第一个是“延伸”——在不告诉人们如何到达那里的情况下尝试获得巨大的收益。 传统的规划部门专注于设计目标和资源之间的紧密配合； Hamel 和 Prahalad 认为战略是关于“延伸”的——关于使用未来的愿景来激励员工走得更远一点。 这种雄心壮志和使命感在初创企业中最为常见。 （Tracy Kidder 对 Data General 的扣人心弦的描述，The Soul of a New Machine [1981]，展示了如果经理们能够用伟大的愿景激励他们的员工，他们如何愉快地实施 80 小时的工作周和不可能完成的最后期限。）但是大公司已经也采取了同样的手段，尤其是在日本。 东芝要求其员工设计一款新的 VCR，使用一半的零件数量，并花费一半的时间和一半的成本。 派出了一个小组——工作完成了。 正如令人钦佩的杰克韦尔奇指出的那样：“在日本没有人问'你能获得多少生产力？' 就好像它是一个有限元一样。”

The first is "stretch"—trying for huge gains without telling people how to get there. Traditional planning departments were preoccupied with engineering a tight fit between goals and resources; Hamel and Prahalad argue that strategy is about "stretch"—about using a vision of the future to inspire workers to go that little bit further. This sort of ambition and sense of purpose is most common in start-ups. (Tracy Kidder's gripping account of Data General, The Soul of a New Machine [1981], shows how managers can happily impose 80-hour working weeks and impossible deadlines if they can inspire their workers with a vision of greatness.) But big firms have also pulled off the same trick, especially in Japan. Toshiba told its employees to design a new VCR using half the number of parts and taking half the time at half the cost. A team was dispatched—and the job was done. As an admiring Jack Welch has pointed out: "Nobody in Japan asks 'How much productivity can you get?' as if it were a finite element."

另一方面，压榨员工和毁掉他们之间似乎只有一线之隔。 当首席执行官设定自己的目标时（例如，他们的股票期权盈利的“行使价”），他们很少会竭尽全力。 通用电气 (General Electric) 的学习官史蒂夫·克尔 (Steve Kerr) 在

On the other hand, there seems to be a very thin line between stretching employees and destroying them. When chief executives set their own targets (for instance, the "strike price" at which their share options become profitable), they rarely stretch themselves. Steve Kerr, General Electric's Learning Officer, warned Fortune in

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

1995 年 11 月，纪律可能具有破坏性：“为了实现延伸目标，人们使用一种不受约束的资源，这是他们的个人时间。我认为这是不道德的......我看到全国各地的人们都在晚上工作周六工作，周日工作以实现延伸目标。”

November 1995 that the discipline can be destructive: "To meet stretch targets, people use the one resource that is not constrained, which is their personal time. I think that's immoral. .. . I'm seeing all around this country people working evenings working Saturdays, working Sundays to achieve stretch targets."

Hamel 和 Prahalad 的另一个概念是我们的老朋友核心竞争力（见第 5 章和第 6 章）。 对于 Hamel 和 Prahalad，定义核心竞争力是设计战略的第一步。 如果一家公司知道自己擅长什么——联邦快递就是物流管理——它就可以选择一些目标——比如“准时交货”。 能力也构成了现代投资组合管理的基础：如果一家公司知道自己擅长什么，它只会冒险进入可以应用其核心技能来创造新产品的新领域，并且它只会购买那些可以大大增加其技能组合。

Hamel and Prahalad's other concept is our old friend core competencies (see Chapters 5 and 6). For Hamel and Prahalad, defining core competencies is the first step in designing a strategy. If a firm knows what it is good at—logistics management in the case of Federal Express—it can then choose something to aim at—like "on-time-delivery." Competencies also form the basis for the modern equivalent of portfolio management: if a firm knows what it is good at, it will venture only into new areas where its core skills can be applied to create new products, and it will buy only the companies that can add substantially to its portfolio of skills.

如前所述，核心能力的一个问题是它们很容易变得像五年计划一样不屈不挠。 而且，它们不是唯一的答案。 一些世界上最受尊敬的公司——例如 ABB、BTR 和美国的通用电气——都遵循了深思熟虑的“多业务”战略。 三位英国学者——安德鲁·坎贝尔、迈克尔·古尔德和马库斯·亚历山大——认为战略应该基于控股公司的“养育”技能，而不是其子公司技能之间的任何联系。 17 在鼎盛时期，英国的汉森发现了管理糟糕的成熟企业，然后对它们进行严格的财务管理。 一个好父母知道什么时候该退出特定的行业，也知道什么时候该进入。1995 年， 3M 决定退出磁带业务，尽管它有利可图，而且与其他子公司的合作非常融洽。 3M 高级管理人员的技能在于培养不断发展的技术业务：对于效率变得比技术更重要的企业来说，这将是一个糟糕的母体。

As already mentioned, one problem with core competencies is that they can easily become just as unbending as five-year plans. Moreover, they are not the only answer. Some of the world's most admired companies—such as ABB, BTR, and America's General Electric—have followed deliberate "multibusiness" strategies. Three British academics—Andrew Campbell, Michael Goold, and Marcus Alexander—have argued that strategy should be based on the "parenting" skills of the holding company rather than on any links between the skills of its subsidiaries. 17 In its heyday, Britain's Hanson spotted mature businesses that were being appallingly managed and then subjected them to fierce financial management. A good parent knows when to get out of a particular line of business as well as when to get in. In 1995, 3M decided to get out of the tape business, even though it was profitable and fitted in quite nicely with its other subsidiaries. The skills of 3M's senior managers lie in fostering growing technical businesses: it would have been a bad parent for a business in which efficiency was becoming more important than technology.

有人可能会争辩说，核心能力和育儿之间的区别通常是语义上的区别：一个人的育儿技巧是另一个人的核心能力。 从表面上看，“经济增加值”(EVA) 或“市场增加值”(MVA) 是截然不同的方法，因为它们基于公司使用资本的效率，而不是基于任何关于协同作用的抽象概念.

One could argue that the distinction between core competencies and parenting is often one of semantics: one man's parenting skill is another's core competence. On the face of it, "economic value added" (EVA) or "market value added" (MVA) are radically different approaches, since they are based on the efficiency with which a company uses its capital rather than on any abstract ideas about synergy.

战略

Strategy

在 EVA 下，一家公司通过从该业务中获得净营业利润，然后扣除为赚取该利润而部署的资本成本来判断某事是否值得做； 总部位于纽约的咨询公司谢尔曼·斯图尔特 (Sherman Stewart) 倡导的 MVA 基本上计算股东投资于企业的金额，然后从其市值中减去该金额。

Under EVA a company judges whether something is worth doing by taking the net operating profit from that business and then deducting the cost of the capital deployed to make that profit; MVA, which has been championed by Sherman Stewart, a New York-based consulting firm, basically calculates the amount of money shareholders have invested in a business—and then subtracts that sum from its market value.

这个想法是为了鼓励经理甚至车间工人完全像股东一样思考。 英国的 ICI 已经派出大约 1,000 名经理参加一个课程，旨在说服他们“拉动创造股东价值的杠杆”，这迫使工厂老板学习贝塔因子和自由现金流。 罗伯托·戈伊祖塔 (Roberto Goizueta) 使用 MVA 公式成为美国最成功的老板——他为可口可乐公司增加了 590 亿美元的价值（以微弱优势击败了为通用电气公司增加 520 亿美元的杰克·韦尔奇）——一直使用他祖父自己的口袋版 EVA教他：“你以一定的利率借钱，然后以更高的利率投资，然后赚取差价。” 正是这个公式让 Goizueta 进入了好莱坞（可口可乐曾短暂拥有哥伦比亚电影公司）。 更成功的是，它引导了可口可乐' 专注于软饮料业务的战略； 只要可口可乐能够继续以 10% 的利率借入资金并获得 30% 的回报，它的战略就会保持不变。

The idea is to encourage managers and even shop-floor workers to think exactly like shareholders. Britain's ICI has sent some 1,000 managers on a course designed to persuade them to "pull levers that create shareholder value," which has forced factory bosses to learn about beta factors and free cash flow. Roberto Goizueta, who used the MVA formula to become America's most successful boss—he added $59 billion to Coca-Cola's value (narrowly beating Jack Welch, who added $52 billion to GE's)—has always used his own pocket version of EVA that his grandfather taught him: "You borrow money at a certain rate and invest it at a higher rate and pocket the difference." It is this formula that led Goizueta into Hollywood (Coke briefly owned Columbia Pictures). More successfully, it has guided Coca-Cola's strategy of concentrating on its soft drinks business; as long as Coke can continue to borrow money at 10 percent and earn returns of 30 percent, its strategy will stay the same.

有趣的是，纪律也蔓延到股东权重较小的领域。 德国大型公用事业公司 Veba 使用 EVA 系统将自身重组为仅 50 件。 在三菱公司的带领下，领先的日本公司正在采取更严格、更数学化的投资组合管理路线，通过股本回报率来判断其部门的业绩。

Interestingly, the discipline is also spreading to areas where shareholders have less weight. Veba, a huge German utility, used an EVA system to restructure itself into a mere 50 pieces. Led by the Mitsubishi Corporation, leading Japanese companies are taking a much harder, more mathematical line to portfolio management, judging the performance of their divisions by their return on equity.

核心竞争力和经济附加值并不像乍看起来那样不相容。 事实证明，企业提高股东回报的最佳方式是专注于核心业务。 摩根大通投资银行的研究人员构建了一个衡量公司专注程度的指数，评分范围为 1 到 100。“澄清”其业务的美国公司在接下来的两年中跑赢市场 11%； 多元化的公司表现不佳约 4%。 机构投资者宁愿通过购买不同专业公司的一系列股票来实现自己的多元化，而不是投资于一个集团。 专注的公司通常更容易管理

Core competencies and economic value added are not as incompatible as they seem at first glance. It turns out that the best way for companies to improve their returns to shareholders is to focus on their core businesses. Researchers at the J. P. Morgan investment bank have constructed an index measuring a company's focus on a scale of 1 to 100. American companies that "clarified" their businesses outperformed the market by 11 percent in the following two years; firms that diversified underperformed by about 4 percent. Institutional investors would rather do their own diversification by buying a range of shares in different specialists rather than investing in a conglomerate. And focused firms are usually easier to manage

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

比多元化的公司。 1996 年，AT&T 将自己拆分为三个独立的业务时，所追求的正是这种有益的清晰。

than diversified firms. It is this sort of gainful clarity that AT&T was pursuing when it split itself up into three separate businesses in 1996.

为过去而战

Competing for the Past
