Inviting workers into the boardroom is surely one reason why Germany's manufacturers are now battling with high wages and comparatively low productivity.

在与知识工作者打交道时，利益相关者资本主义看起来更不令人印象深刻。 到目前为止，残酷的旧股东资本主义已被证明是未来产业更为有效的培育基地。 硅谷在加州而不是鲁尔区。 德国只能召集三个具有重要意义的软件公司：Software AG、SAP 和西门子。 与任何开始喋喋不休地谈论解放知识工作者的利益相关者资本主义的拥护者一起玩的一个有趣的游戏是让他或她说出任何不以“S”开头的德国高科技公司的名字。

Stakeholder capitalism looks even less impressive when it comes to dealing with knowledge workers. So far, cruel old shareholder capitalism has proved a far more effective nursery for the industries of the future. Silicon Valley is in California not the Ruhr. Germany can muster only three software companies of any significance: Software AG, SAP, and Siemens. An interesting game to play with any advocate of stakeholder capitalism who starts prattling on about emancipating knowledge workers is to ask him or her to name any German high-technology firms that do not begin with "S."

壁虎与帝国

Gekko versus Reich

支持利益相关者资本主义的另一种论点是，利益相关者的利益与股东的利益之间确实没有矛盾。 事实上，持股方式符合股东的最佳长期利益。 罗伯特·沃特曼 (Robert Waterman) 认为，“企业文化倾向于将三个支持者——

An alternative argument in favor of stakeholder capitalism is that there is really no contradiction between stakeholders' interests and those of shareholders. Indeed, a stakeholding approach is in the best long-term interest of shareholders. Robert Waterman reckons that "corporate cultures that tend to put three constituencies—

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

股东、客户和员工——在同一个平面上，而不是把股东放在第一位，反而是那些为股东做得最好的人。”22“你要对不止一个选民负责，”哈佛大学的约翰科特警告老板们。

shareholders, customers and employees—on the same plane, as opposed to putting shareholders first, are perversely the ones that do best for shareholders." 22 "You're accountable to more than one constituency," John Kotter at Harvard has warned bosses.

这听起来像是一个诱人的蓬松妥协。 毕竟，在大多数正常情况下，各个利益相关群体的利益与股东的利益是一致的。 心满意足的员工提供更好的服务； 满意的客户造就了一家盈利的公司。 善待员工——尤其是知识型员工——确实符合股东的利益。 然而，在困难时期，一视同仁地对待所有选民是行不通的。 缺乏明确的问责制使管理者难以做出艰难的决定——德国人和日本人最近都发现了这一点。

This sounds like a temptingly fluffy compromise. After all, in most normal circumstances, the interests of the various stakeholding groups coincide with those of the shareholders. Contented workers deliver better services; contented customers make for a profitable company. It is indeed in shareholders' interest to treat workers—particularly knowledge ones—well. However, treating all the constituencies as equals does not work when times get tough. The lack of clear accountability makes it difficult for managers to make tough decisions—as both the Germans and Japanese have recently discovered.

在战后的大部分时间里，德国和日本的经济都在蓬勃发展，各利益相关者的利益是一致的。 但在 20 世纪 90 年代中期，决策变得更加紧迫，经理们捏造或拖延决策的习惯变得更具破坏性。 结果是，公司保留了可能在其他地方更好就业的工人； 在这两个国家，经济都未能进入附加值更高的行业和服务业。 相比之下，盎格鲁-撒克逊资本主义以其更清晰的权力界限和来自股市的持续压力要求管理者做出令人不快的决定。 随后的裁员和重组可能是痛苦的，但它们提高了经济效率。

For most of the postwar era, the economies of Germany and Japan boomed, and the interests of the various stakeholders have coincided. But in the mid-1990s the decisions became more pressing, and managers' habit of fudging or delaying them became more damaging. The result was that companies kept workers who might be better employed elsewhere; and in both countries the economy failed to move into higher value added industries and services. By contrast, Anglo-Saxon capitalism, with its clearer lines of authority and constant pressure from the stock market to perform, forced managers to take unpalatable decisions. The downsizing and restructuring that followed may have been painful, but they increased economic efficiency.

这种对股权的辩护听起来可能过于自满。 那些给自己支付巨额薪水的肥猫呢？ 那么让这些重量级的猫科动物在失败中致富的金色降落伞呢？ 事实上，解决引发最近利益相关者争论的焦虑的最好方法是赋予股东更多而不是更少的权力。 研究几乎所有的公司灾难——从 Maxwell Communications 的倒闭到 80 年代日本公司决定多付钱购买美国财产——你会发现董事会在没有任何人注意的情况下采取行动。

This defense of shareholding may sound horribly complacent. What about all those fat cats paying themselves gigantic salaries? And what about the golden parachutes that allow these weighty felines to get rich on failure? In fact, the best way to deal with the anxieties that have given rise to the recent stakeholder debate is to give more power to shareholders, not less. Study almost any corporate disaster—from the collapse of Maxwell Communications to the decision by Japanese firms to overpay for American property in the 1980s—and you find a board acting without anybody looking over its shoulder.

正如马修·毕晓普 (Matthew Bishop) 在《经济学人》的公司治理调查中总结的那样，“很少有问题是由于股东的过多干预造成的。” 23 Bishop 认为，一个理想的系统会做三件事。 “首先，它会给老板足够的自由来管理好。这将确保他利用这种自由来管理

As Matthew Bishop concluded in a survey of Corporate Governance in The Economist, "Few if any woes have stemmed from too much shareholder interference." 23 An ideal system, argued Bishop, would do three things. "It would, first, give a boss enough freedom to manage well. It would ensure that he used that freedom to manage

董事会风暴

Storm in the Boardroom

公司以股东利益为重。 如果其他人能做得更好，他就会让他去做。”从经济学家的角度来看，关键概念是可竞争性——如果经理做得不好，股东可以更换经理的能力。最好的那么，解决公司治理问题的方法就是在其中创造市场。

the firm in the interests of shareholders. And if somebody else could do a better job it would let him." The key concept, from an economist's point of view, is contestability—the ability for shareholders to be able to change managers if they are not doing a good job. The best way to solve the problem of corporate governance, then, is to create a market in it.

没有人可以否认股东有时会在收购中很快出卖，但这并不能掩盖这样一个事实，即大多数收购中最大的输家通常是收购公司的股东。 当 Saatchi & Saatchi 的股东最终在 1994 年底迫使 Maurice Saatchi 离开时，他们很可能犯了一个战术错误（Saatchi 成立了一家竞争对手公司，然后赢得了他以前雇主的许多客户）。 但是，“老萨奇”走向危险境地的真正原因是萨奇兄弟将股东的钱花在了疯狂的收购上。

Nobody can deny that shareholders are sometimes a little quick to sell out in takeovers, but that does not obscure the fact that the biggest losers in most takeovers are usually the shareholders in the acquiring company. When the shareholders in Saatchi & Saatchi finally forced Maurice Saatchi out at the end of 1994, they may well have made a tactical mistake (Saatchi founded a rival agency that then won many of his previous employer's clients). But the real reason why "Old Saatchi" reached its parlous state was that the Saatchi brothers had spent their shareholders' money on a wild acquisition spree.

结束有关利益相关者和股东的部分可能不是一种流行的方式，但也许最后的发言权应该属于 Gordon Gekko——华尔街虚构的掠夺者。 他对一群股东发表的“贪婪即善”的演讲是每个自由派人士的噩梦。 但它还包含以下段落：

It may not be a popular way to end a section on stakeholders and shareholders, but perhaps the last word should belong to Gordon Gekko—the fictional raider in Wall Street. His "greed-is-good" speech to a group of shareholders is every liberal's nightmare. But it also contained the following passage:

现在，在自由市场时代，当我们的国家是顶级工业强国时，就存在问责制。 卡内基家族、梅隆家族，这些建立了这个伟大工业帝国的人确信这是因为这是他们的钱。 今天，管理层没有持有公司股份。 坐在那里的那些人总共拥有不到公司百分之三的股份。 你拥有公司，没错，你，股东，你正被这些官僚们用他们的股票午餐、他们的狩猎和钓鱼旅行、他们的公务机和他们的金色降落伞搞得一团糟。

Now in the days of the free market when our country was a top industrial power there was accountability. The Carnegies, the Mellons, the men who built this great industrial empire made sure it was because it was their money at stake. Today management has no stake in the company. All together those men sitting up there own less than three percent of the company. You own the company, that's right, you, the stockholders, and you are being royally screwed by these bureaucrats with their stock lunches, their hunting and fishing trips, their corporate jets and their golden parachutes.

试图将股东资本主义转变为利益相关者资本主义的假设是，前者有机会发挥作用，但失败了。 大多数证据表明它没有。

Trying to change shareholder capitalism into stakeholder capitalism assumes that the former has been given a chance to work and has failed. Most of the evidence suggests it has not.

第九章

CHAPTER 9

日本最大的人力服务机构 Pasona 的老板 Yasuyuki Nambu 在他办公室的墙上，从地板到天花板都贴满了照片。 他们都以南部为特色与世界上最著名的政治家合影：玛格丽特·撒切尔（多次）、罗纳德·里根、比尔·克林顿和米哈伊尔·戈尔巴乔夫，更不用说查尔斯王子等皇室成员了。 （被问到他是如何认识查尔斯王子的，Nambu 回答说是罗纳德·里根介绍他们的。）按照日本的标准，整个办公室都散发着一种炫耀的气息：颜色大胆而明亮，秘书们（人数众多）都非常漂亮，穿着无可挑剔。

Yasuyuki Nambu, the boss of Pasona, Japan's biggest manpower-services agency, has covered the walls of his office, from floor to ceiling, with photographs. They all feature Nambu posing with the world's best-known politicians: Margaret Thatcher (several times), Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, and Mikhail Gorbachev, not to mention royal persons such as Prince Charles. (Asked how he got to know Prince Charles, Nambu replies that Ronald Reagan introduced them.) The whole office exudes, by Japanese standards, an ostentatious air: the colors bold and bright, the secretaries (of whom there are an impressive number) all strikingly pretty and impeccably dressed.

如果他选择了不同的职业并创立了不同类型的公司，日本的机构可能会原谅 Nambu 所有这些事情——甚至可能是他骑自行车上班时穿的猩红色短裤。 在一个理想是成为终生束缚于某家安全大公司的工薪族的国家，Nambu 是一名企业家。 他还在上大学时就创办了自己的第一家公司，一家佛教式幼儿园，聘请同学担任老师。 注意到日本充斥着整天无所事事的无聊母亲，以及因员工太少而无法满足激增的需求而感到沮丧的公司，他决定创办日本第一家临时工中介机构：Pasona Group。 这

The Japanese establishment might have been able to forgive Nambu all these things—even perhaps the scarlet shorts he wears to bicycle to work—if he had chosen a different career and founded a different sort of company. In a country in which the ideal is to become a salaryman chained for life to some big, safe corporation, Nambu is an entrepreneur. He started his first company, a Buddhist-style kindergarten, when he was still at university, employing his fellow students as teachers. Noticing that Japan was filled with bored mothers who had nothing to do all day and frustrated companies with too few staff to meet surges in demand, he decided to start Japan's first temporary worker agency: the Pasona Group. The

工作的未来

The Future of Work

业务迅速增长：到 1995 年底，它拥有 120,000 名员工和约 28,000 名客户，Nambu 已成为千万富翁。

business grew rapidly: by late 1995 it had 120,000 employees and some 28,000 clients, and Nambu had become a multimillionaire.

Nambu 的财富惊人地提醒人们，“工作”的性质已经发生了多大的变化。 1995 年，在劳动部的年度调查中，日本人有史以来第一次认为工作满意度比公司忠诚度更重要。 看来，即使是日本人也不再愿意为单一雇主的命令而花费一生； 雇主再也不能让员工留在账簿上，不管他们增加了多少价值。 兼职和临时工已经占日本劳动力的四分之一以上。

Nambu's wealth is a striking reminder of how much the nature of "work" has changed. In 1995, for the first time ever, the Japanese questioned in an annual survey by the Ministry of Labor, decided that job satisfaction was more important than company loyalty. Even the Japanese, it seems, no longer want to spend their lives doing the bidding of a single employer; and employers can no longer afford to keep people on the books regardless of how much value they are adding. Part-time and temporary workers already make up more than a quarter of Japan's workforce.

然而，对于日本企业来说，临时工意味着无政府状态。 劳动部阻止了南部相对无害的计划，该计划旨在帮助中层管理人员从试图瘦身的大公司转移到希望扩张但支付不起高薪的小公司。 他的策略是让大公司补贴小公司的工资单。 该计划的一个严重障碍是该部只允许临时工从事 16 类工作。 受现行规则“保护”的人员包括护士、电话营销人员、接待员，甚至是看门人——换句话说，是世界其他地区人力资源机构的中坚力量。

To the Japanese establishment, however, temporary workers spell anarchy. The Ministry of Labor has blocked Nambu's relatively innocuous scheme to help move middle managers from big firms that are trying to slim down to smaller ones that would like to expand but cannot afford to pay much. His strategy is to get the big companies to subsidize the wage bills of the smaller firms. One serious obstacle to this scheme is that the ministry allows temps to work in only 16 categories of jobs. Those "protected" by the current rules include nurses, telephone marketers, receptionists, and even janitors—in other words, the stalwarts of manpower agencies in the rest of the world.

Nambu 显然很享受他作为局外人的身份，并向来访者展示他与日本官僚机构斗争的新闻剪报。 但他也决心继续经营下去。 他认为，日本公司除非摆脱死板的商业惯例，否则将在当今残酷的世界中沉没。 他继续说，转向临时工作不一定会导致无政府状态，只要处理得当。 Nambu 以 Pasona 的现代风格以及它在年轻一代中的成功而自豪。 他甚至成立了一个从年轻员工中选出的初级执行委员会，以产生想法并向他提供建议。 每年，在公司创立周年纪念日，他都会举办“挑战日”，鼓励所有员工提出新想法。

Nambu clearly relishes his status as an outsider and showers visitors with press cuttings about his struggles with the Japanese bureaucracy. But he is also determined to keep his operation going. Japanese firms, he argues, will sink in today's cutthroat world unless they get rid of their hidebound business practices. The move toward temporary work, he continues, will not necessarily produce anarchy, so long as it is handled correctly. Nambu prides himself on Pasona's modernity—and its success with the younger generation. He has even set up a junior executive board, elected from among the younger employees, to generate ideas and offer him advice. Every year, on the anniversary of the company's creation, he holds a "challenge day," when all employees are encouraged to suggest new ideas.

Nambu 最关心的是确保临时工有属于 Pasona 的感觉。 高级管理人员坐在公司巨大的开放式办公室中间高台上的办公桌前，这样他们就可以会见来领薪水的临时工。 Nambu 每天发出 30 份或更多的“英雄图”：优雅的手写便条，表达他对出色工作的赞赏。 顶楼很多

Nambu's biggest concern is to ensure that temporary workers feel they belong to Pasona. Senior managers sit at desks on a raised platform in the middle of the company's giant open-plan office, so they can meet temps coming to collect their paychecks. Nambu sends out 30 or more "herograms" a day: elegant, handwritten notes that express his appreciation for outstanding work. Much of the top floor

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

有一家时尚的咖啡馆供员工社交，还有一家健康中心可供员工进行体检或享受 3 美元的按摩服务。 Nambu 认为，临时工作并不意味着不受赏识或被冷落。 他的临时工可以像任何上班族一样感到需要和安全； 此外，他们的优势是可以在他们想去的时候去。 他们不仅仅是动产。

is taken up with a stylish cafe where workers can socialize and a health center where they can get a checkup or a $3 massage. Temporary work does not mean going unappreciated or being left out in the cold, argues Nambu. His temps can feel just as needed and secure as any salaryman; moreover, they have the advantage of being able to go when they want to. They are not just chattel.

你的工作结束了吗？

The End of Your Job?

Nambu 只是一个参与者，尽管是一个相当浮夸的参与者，参与了一场关于工作性质不断变化的全球辩论。 如果弗洛伊德是对的，而且工作就像爱情一样是自尊的主要来源，那么大多数现代经理人都在接受心理攻击课程。 解雇多余的车间工人一直是一项管理工作。 现在是经理们自己被解雇了。 在战后的大部分时间里，他们被誉为使资本主义如此成功的看得见的手，但现在却常常被认为是不必要的软弱无能。 许多理论家认为，他们身上有更深刻、更可怕的事情：工作本身——他们的权力单位，他们管理他人的地方——正面临灭绝。

Nambu is just one participant, albeit a rather flamboyant one, in a worldwide debate about the changing nature of work. If Freud was right, and work, like love, is a prime source of self-esteem, then most modern managers have been on a psychological assault course. Sacking surplus shop-floor workers has always been a managerial chore. Now it is the managers themselves who are getting the sack. Having been celebrated for much of the postwar period as the visible hand that made capitalism so successful, they are now often dismissed as so much unnecessary flab. Many theorists argue that something even more profound and frightening is upon them: the job itself—their unit of power, the place where they manage others—is facing extinction.

在一篇名为“美国的诱惑”（1993 年 3 月 19 日）的文章中，时代杂志警告说，“美国已经进入临时工或临时工、顾问和分包商、即时劳动力的时代——流动的，灵活，一次性。这就是未来。它传达的信息是：'你要靠自己。'”一年后，在题为“工作的终结”（1994 年 9 月 19 日）的封面故事中，《财富》甚至更悲观。 “正在消失的不仅仅是一定数量的工作岗位——或者某些行业的工作岗位，或者美国某些地区的工作岗位，甚至是整个美国的工作岗位。正在消失的是事情本身：工作。那么人们所寻求的之后，饱受诽谤的社会实体，就像一个已经超过其进化时间的物种一样消失了。”

In an article called "The Temping of America" (March 19,1993), Time magazine warned that "America has entered the age of the contingent or temporary worker, of the consultant and subcontractor, of the just-in-time workforce—fluid, flexible, disposable. This is the future. Its message is this: 'You are on your own.'" A year later, in a cover story entitled "The End of the Job" (September 19, 1994), Fortune was even more pessimistic. "What is disappearing is not just a certain number of jobs—or jobs in certain industries or jobs in some parts of the country or even jobs in America as a whole. What is disappearing is the very thing itself: the job. That much sought after, much maligned social entity, is vanishing like a species that has outlived its evolutionary time."

《财富》杂志的这篇文章摘自威廉·布里奇斯 (William Bridges) 的一本书，名为《换工作：如何在没有工作的工作场所取得成功》(1994)，该书认为，在快速发展的经济中，传统工作是对流动问题的固定、人为的解决方案。 Bridges 指出，在 18 世纪末之前，“工作”指的是一项特定的事业，而不是一个固定的职位，这与今天的“演出”一词没什么不同。 他估计很快，它就会恢复到原来的意思。 和

The Fortune article was an extract from a book called Jobshift: How to Prosper in a Workplace without Jobs (1994) by William Bridges, which argues that in a fast-moving economy the traditional job is a fixed, artificial solution to a fluid problem. Before the late eighteenth century, Bridges points out, a "job" referred to a specific undertaking rather than a fixed position, not unlike the word "gig" today. Soon he reckons, it will return to that original meaning. And

工作的未来

The Future of Work

与杰里米·里夫金 (Jeremy Rifkin) 的《工作终结》(The End of Work) 相比，Jobshift 是积极乐观的，后者预测未来将出现大规模失业和社会动荡。

Jobshift is positively optimistic compared with The End of Work, by Jeremy Rifkin, which predicts a future of mass unemployment and social unrest.

过去，当新技术取代特定部门的工人时，总会出现新的部门来吸收被取代的劳动力。 今天，所有三个传统经济部门——农业、制造业和服务业——都在经历技术置换，迫使数百万人失业。 唯一扩张的部门是知识部门，它由一小部分企业家、科学家、技术人员、计算机程序员、专业人员、教育工作者和顾问组成。 尽管该行业正在增长，但预计在未来几十年内吸收的数亿 [工作岗位] 不会超过一小部分。 1个

In the past when new technologies have replaced workers in a given sector, new sectors have always emerged to absorb the displaced laborers. Today all three of the traditional sectors of the economy—agriculture, manufacturing, and services—are experiencing technological displacement, forcing millions onto the unemployment rolls. The only expanding sector is the knowledge sector, made up of a small elite of entrepreneurs, scientists, technicians, computer programmers, professionals, educators, and consultants. While this sector is growing, it is not expected to absorb more than a fraction of the hundreds of millions [of jobs] eliminated in the next several decades. 1

政客们在七国集团会议上讨论了“工作的未来”。 撰写有关该主题的论文是布鲁塞尔和华盛顿的新兴产业。 在整个富裕国家，工作场所日益增加的焦虑被归咎于经济改善但人们仍然感到痛苦的“无投票复苏”。 就业基本法正在被颠覆的想法鼓励了詹姆斯戈德史密斯爵士和帕特布坎南爵士等特立独行的人举起保护主义的旗帜，呼吁建立障碍以保护就业。

Politicians have discussed "the future of work" at meetings of the G7 countries. Writing papers on the subject is a growth industry in both Brussels and Washington. Throughout the rich world, increased anxiety at the workplace has been blamed for "voteless recoveries" where economies improve but people still feel miserable. The idea that the basic laws of employment are being turned upside down has encouraged mavericks such as Sir James Goldsmith and Pat Buchanan to raise protectionist banners, calling for barriers to be erected to protect jobs.

愤世嫉俗者可能会争辩说，就穷人而言，工作一直是“肮脏、野蛮和短暂的”。 当前风波的不同之处在于它影响了管理阶层。 现在有一股中产阶级对信息时代的焦虑浪潮。 普遍的感觉是，30 年前，大多数经理人都有合理的机会建立一个安全的职业生涯。 他们去了一家他们用通用汽车或通用电气等缩写称呼的公司工作，并在那里待了大约 40 年，所做的工作逐渐减少。 变老意味着获得更大的办公室、更多的权力和更好的头衔。 今天，裁员、外包、分包、“在家办公运动”等都在把人变成临时工。 甚至 BBC 和 IBM 等著名的家长式中产阶级组织也放弃了终生工作的想法。 这对浪费大学时光阅读有关书籍的一代人来说是一个打击。

A cynic might argue that, as far as the poor are concerned, jobs have always been "nasty, brutish, and short." What is different about the current furor is that it has affected the managerial class. There is now a tidal wave of middle-class angst about the information age. The general feeling is that 30 years ago, most managers had a reasonable chance of building a safe career. They went to work for a firm they referred to by an abbreviation like GM or GE and stayed there for about 40 years, doing progressively less work. Getting older meant getting a bigger office, more power, a better title. Today, downsizing, outsourcing, subcontracting, "the home office movement," and so on are all turning people into temporary workers. Even famously paternal middle-class organizations such as the BBC and IBM have dispensed with the idea of a job for life. This has come as a blow for a generation who idled away their university years reading about

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

人口短缺和技术对工作的预期影响：更少的工作时间换取更多的报酬。

the expected effect of demographic shortages and technology on work: fewer hours for more pay.

这一切都是真的吗？ 还是一个理应值得深思的主题被激起了煽动偏执狂的主题？ 更平凡的事实是，工作与其说是结束，不如说是在变化。 是的，向知识社会（这正是我们真正谈论的）过渡的某些方面将是痛苦的； 但总的来说，这种变化应该是有益的。 最重要的是，像他们这样的受害者，将主要是穷人和未受过教育的人——而不是仔细阅读有关未来工作书籍的管理者。

Is all this really true? Or has a subject that rightfully deserves contemplation been whipped up into one that incites paranoia? The more mundane truth is that jobs are not so much coming to an end as just changing. Yes, some aspects of the transition to a knowledge society (which is what we are really talking about) will be painful; but the change should by and large be beneficial. Above all, the victims, such as they are, will be primarily the poor and the uneducated—not managers who pore over books about the future of work.

普特尼圣人

The Sage of Putney

开始任何关于未来工作的讨论的最佳地点是普特尼 (Putney) 的一处宽敞优雅的公寓，普特尼是伦敦西部繁华的郊区，也是英国最著名的大师的故乡。 查尔斯·汉迪之所以脱颖而出，不仅是因为一段时间以来他一直在悄悄地说出许多作家现在在山顶尖叫的事情，还因为他的一些预言已被证明是正确的。 他十年前预测，到世纪之交，只​​有不到一半的劳动力将从事“适当的”全职工作，这在西欧即将实现； 在美国，失业、个体经营或签订短期合同的人口比例目前约为 35%。

The best place to begin any discussion about the future of work is a large, elegant flat in Putney, a prosperous suburb in West London and the home of Britain's best-known guru. Charles Handy stands out not only because he has been quietly saying for some time what many writers are now screaming from the hilltops, but also because some of his prophesies have been proved right. His forecast a decade ago that fewer than half the workforce would be in "proper" full-time jobs by the turn of the century has just about come true in Western Europe; in America the proportion of people who are unemployed, self-employed, or on short-term contracts is currently about 35 percent.

Handy 认为，技术和竞争正在开创一个新时代，在这个时代“工作是你做的事，而不是你去的事”。 公司将生存下来，但处于一个大大减少的状态。 公司的核心（他曾多次将其比作甜甜圈的中心和三叶草的心脏）将由一小群企业家和官僚组成，并由“V2-by-2-by -3” 企业健身法则：一半的人做三倍的工作会得到两倍的报酬。 有两种人会试图向这个内环出售他们的服务。 第一个将是一般的、不熟练的“某人”（如“某人可以做到”）。 第二类将是“组合人” ——知识型员工，他们已经掌握了一系列技能，可以将其出售给各种公司。 个人在 20 多岁时成为组合员工，在接下来的两三年加入组织的核心，然后在他们的“三重时代”重新成为组合员工的情况并不少见。 的确，

Technology and competition, Handy has argued, are ushering in a new era in which "work is something you do rather than something you go to." Companies will survive, but in a much diminished state. The core of a company (which he has at various times likened to the center of a doughnut and the heart of a shamrock) will be staffed by a small squad of entrepreneurs and bureaucrats, and governed by the "V2-by-2-by-3" rule of corporate fitness: half as many people will be paid twice as much for doing three times as much work. Two sorts of people will try to sell their services to this inner ring. The first will be the general, unskilled "somebodies" (as in "somebody can do that"). The second class will be "portfolio people"—knowledge workers who have assembled a portfolio of skills that they can sell to a variety of companies. It will not be unusual for individuals to be portfolio workers when they are in their 20s, to join the core of an organization for the next two or three decades, then to return to being a portfolio worker in their "troisieme age." Indeed,

工作的未来

The Future of Work

Handy 反复出现的主题之一是，工人将继续工作更长的时间（尽管是兼职），部分原因是为了赚更多的钱，部分原因是为了让自己有事可做。

one of Handy's recurring themes is that workers will continue working much longer in life (albeit on a part-time basis) partly to earn more money and partly to give themselves something to do.

Handy 的诊断可能很严厉，但他的处方通常相当温和——有些人会说太温和了。 Handy认为，追求利润并不是一切，公司应该改变股权结构，赋予员工和客户等利益相关者更多与股东相关的权力。 培训、教育和志愿工作仍然是 Handy 的重要主题。

Handy's diagnosis may be harsh, but his prescriptions are usually fairly soft—some would say too soft. Handy believes that the pursuit of profit is not everything and that companies should change their ownership structure to give stakeholders, such as workers and customers, more power in relation to shareholders. Training, education, and voluntary work remain important Handy themes.

Handy 可能更擅长激发思想而不是规定解决方案（他与德鲁克共有的缺点或优点）。 但值得注意的是，他的哲学至少植根于一个现实：他自己的现实。 我们应该感到惊讶的是，投资组合工作者和 troisieme 时代的先知本人是一个 60 多岁的人，他向各种客户（包括伦敦商学院和几个慈善机构）“出售”他的服务； 漂泊在普特尼、英国乡村和托斯卡纳之间； 一年只花六个月在自己的项目上？ 当然，生活比利润更重要的想法更容易从一个思想家那里得到，他将自己限制在每年大约十几个高薪“歌舞表演”，并免费或为慈善做其余的演讲任务。

Handy may be better at provoking thought than prescribing solutions (a fault or virtue that he shares with Drucker). But it is worth noting that his philosophy is rooted in at least one reality: his own. Should we be surprised that the prophet of the portfolio worker and the troisieme age is himself a man in his mid-60s who "sells" his services to a variety of clients (including the London Business School and several charities); drifts between Putney, the English countryside, and Tuscany; and spends only six months a year working on his own projects? Certainly, the idea that there is more to life than profit is easier to take from a thinker who limits himself to about a dozen high-paying "cabarets" a year and does the rest of his speaking assignments either for free or for charity. In many ways the questions that need to be asked about Handy are not just whether his prediction of the future and his suggestions for change are correct, but also whether he is a fair representative of his audience.

什么没有改变

What Is Not Changing

任何认为技术威胁到工作的新事物的经理都应该阅读乔治·艾略特的《米德尔马契》。 随着铁路越来越靠近这部小说中心的维多利亚集镇，人们开始担心新技术对其居民意味着什么。 但恐惧是否合理？ 当然，铁路极大地改变了人们的生活，但不一定会变得更糟。 铁马每让一名驿马车司机失业，就创造了许多其他工作岗位，不仅在铁路本身，而且在现在与外界相连的企业和商店中。 即使其中一些变化是痛苦的，但从长远来看，工作肯定会更安全

Any manager who thinks that there is something new about technology threatening jobs should read George Eliot's Middlemarch. As the railway moved ever closer to the Victorian market town at the center of this novel, panic mounted about what the new technology would mean for its inhabitants. But was the fear justified? Certainly, the railway changed people's lives dramatically, but it did not necessarily do so for the worse. For every stagecoach driver the iron horse put out of work, it created many other jobs, not only on the railway itself but also in businesses and shops that were now connected to the outside world. Even if some of these changes would have been painful, in the longer run jobs would surely have been safer in a

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

像米德尔马奇这样与铁路相连的城镇，比那些没有铁路的城镇要好。

town such as Middlemarch that was connected to the railway, than in those that were not.

有三个理由相信这种乐观的历史版本会重演：一个植根于基本市场经济学，两个植根于（稍微更可疑的）统计数据。 他们并没有反驳预测“工作结束”的理论，但他们确实建议对他们的想法持保留态度。

There are three reasons for believing that this optimistic version of history will repeat itself: one is rooted in basic market economics and two in (slightly more suspect) statistics. They do not disprove theories predicting "the end of work," but they do suggest that their ideas should be taken with a pinch of salt.

自从 19 世纪初卢德分子起来并砸毁了他们的织布机以来，市场经济学长期以来一直不断地反驳对新技术的警告。 2 在过去的两个世纪里，无数的工作岗位被机器推到一边，但更多的工作岗位也在不断创造。 悲观主义者反驳说，计算机——或者更准确地说，计算机加电话——将比像珍妮纺纱机这样让勒德分子如此恼火的机器产生更广泛的影响。 根据一些计算，工业界四分之三的工作是可以自动化的重复性工作。 这其中有一些道理：许多经济学家认为，劳动力市场创造新工作可能会有短暂的延迟。 很难想象一个流离失所的铁路工程师（预计美国就业下降幅度最大）会迅速找到家庭健康助理的工作（增长幅度最大）。 3个

Ever since the Luddites rose up and smashed their looms in the early nineteenth century, market economics has had a long, unbroken record of disproving warnings about new technology. 2 Over the past two centuries countless jobs have been pushed aside by machines, but more have been created on the way. The pessimists counter by claiming that the computer—or, more accurately, the computer-plus-telephone—will have a far wider effect than machines like the Spinning Jenny that so annoyed the Luddites. By some calculations, three out of four jobs in the industrial world are the sort of repetitive ones that might be automated. There is something in this: many economists reckon that there may be a short delay while the labor market invents new jobs. It is hard to imagine a displaced railroad engineer (the biggest predicted job decline in America) rapidly picking up work as a home health aide (the biggest increase). 3

但这是对时机的争论。 至少到目前为止，这一波技术变革​​浪潮与之前的浪潮之间的相似之处似乎远多于不同之处。 如果以过去的经验为指导，保护主义措施看起来只是行不通。 （Goldsmith 和 Buchanan 到底是怎么想象他们会把廉价的第三世界产品和技术拒之门外的呢？）这些措施也会适得其反：对技术的壁垒只会导致经济衰退，就像维多利亚时代英格兰的城镇一样，这些城镇没有连接到铁路。

But this is a quibble over timing. So far, at least, there seem to be far more similarities than differences between this wave of technological change and previous ones. If past experience is any guide, protectionist measures only look impracticable. (How on earth do Goldsmith and Buchanan imagine that they will keep out cheap Third World products and technology anyway?) Such measures are also counterproductive: barriers against technology will simply produce economic decline, as in the towns of Victorian England that were not connected to the railway.

上面提到的两组统计数据也应该让忧心忡忡的经理们感到些许安慰（尽管都不是决定性的）。 首先是，虽然经理们现在比以前更容易失业，但他们也更有可能找到工作。 在美国，“管理和专业”工作现在占劳动力的最大部分——而且他们正在快速增长。 在英国，华威大学就业研究所 1995 年发表的一项研究发现，尽管十年来关于

The two sets of statistics referred to above should also be of some comfort to worried managers (though neither is conclusive). The first is that, although managers are now more likely to lose their jobs than before, they are also much more likely to find them. In America, "managerial and professional" jobs now make up the biggest slice of the workforce—and they are growing fast. In Britain, a study published in 1995 by the University of Warwick's Institute for Employment Research found that, despite a decade of headlines about

工作的未来

The Future of Work

裁员，1981-94 年英国创造了 135 万个新的管理职位； 它还预测到 2001 年将新增 630,000 个管理职位，使总数达到 490 万人，占就业劳动力的 18.5%。 像往常一样，输家是穷人和没有技能的人。

downsizing, 1.35 million new managerial jobs were created in Britain in 1981-94; it also predicted that another 630,000 new managerial posts would be created by 2001, bringing the total up to 4.9 million people, or 18.5 percent of the employed labor force. As usual, the losers are the poor and the unskilled.

对这样的统计数据的标准反驳是，这只是一个标签问题：在工厂，组长和工作主管现在是经理； 在大街上，音像店服务员通常也可以是经理。 这一点是公平的，但并不能完全使统计数据无效。 例如，华威大学的研究人员确信，即使考虑到这一趋势，经理的数量“也将以拳头增长”。

The standard retort to statistics like this is that it is simply a matter of labeling: in factories, team leaders and work supervisors are now managers; in the high street, a video store attendant can often be a manager too. This point is a fair one, but it does not completely invalidate the statistics. For example, the researchers at Warwick were convinced that even allowing for this trend, the number of managers "is going to grow hand over fist."

忧心忡忡的经理应该牢记的第二组统计数据表明，到目前为止，终生工作并没有变得更加稀缺。 从 1971 年到 1991 年，在一份工作中工作八年以上的美国人比例几乎没有变化； 如果有的话，中年美国人为一个雇主工作的平均时间实际上已经从 1966 年的六年多一点增加到 1991 年的七年多一点。大多数其他国家也有类似的数据记录。

The second set of statistics that the worried manager ought to bear in mind suggests that—so far—the job for life is not becoming any rarer. The proportion of Americans who stayed in one job for more than eight years hardly changed at all between 1971 and 1991; if anything, the average length of time middle-aged Americans spend with one employer has actually edged up, from a little over six years in 1966 to just over seven years in 1991. Similar figures have been recorded in most other countries.

再次强调，过度解读这些数字是不明智的。 一方面，他们是否包括所有临时工是值得怀疑的，而且最近的数据只能追溯到 1990 年代初，那时裁员的全部影响还没有体现出来。 另一方面，变化的迹象很明显：55 岁或更早退休（或被淘汰）的人数有所增加。 总体数字可以掩盖公司内部的相当大的动荡，因为他们会在各地调动员工。

Once again, it would be unwise to read too much into these numbers. For one thing, it is doubtful that they include all temporary workers, and the most recent figures date back only as far as the early 1990s, before the full effects of downsizing had been felt. For another, signs of change are evident: there has been an increase in the number of people who have retired (or been pushed out) at the age of 55 or earlier. And the overall figures can hide considerable turbulence within companies as they switch employees around all over the place.

那些预测工作结束的人倾向于将传统工作视为专注于做一件事的固定八小时时间段。 事实上，工作——尤其是管理工作——总是涉及做“这个”和“那个”。 由于假期和疾病，人们无休止地互相掩护。 项目是根据下一个进门的人来分配的。 阅读一篇夸张的描述，比如说，CNN 是一个“虚拟组织”，其中人们被分配到甚至可能与他们的经验领域无关的项目，人们往往会忘记新闻机构一直是自然作家的混乱场所有时被派去报道最近在阿比西尼亚的战争。 如果

Those predicting the end of work tend to think of the traditional job as an inflexible eight-hour block dedicated to doing one thing. The truth is that jobs—particularly managerial ones—have always involved doing "a bit of this" and "a bit of that." People endlessly cover for each other as a result of holidays and illnesses. Projects are assigned on the basis of whoever comes through the door next. Reading an inflated description of, say, CNN as "a virtual organization" in which people are assigned to projects that may not even be connected with their field of experience, one tends to forget that news organizations have always been chaotic places in which nature writers are sometimes sent off to cover the latest war in Abyssinia. If

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

威廉·伦道夫·赫斯特 (William Randolph Hearst) 走进 CNN，他会对这些小玩意儿感到困惑，对没有酒精感到困惑，但他会认识到一个世界，在这个世界里，大故事主宰着每个人的生活，编辑们不管人们以前的经历如何，都会把他们扔给故事.

William Randolph Hearst wandered into CNN, he would be bemused by the gadgets and nonplussed by the absence of alcohol, but he would recognize a world in which the big story dominates everybody's lives, and in which editors throw people at stories regardless of their previous experience.

尽管如此，统计数据（更不用说经济学）表明，管理世界末日比一些人担心的要远一些，而且工作的变化并不像许多人声称的那样剧烈。 “工作”与公司乃至城市等其他受诽谤的机构一样，不会在不久的将来消失。 20 年后，你仍然可以走进任何办公室，发现一群白发苍苍的员工聚集在一台不含咖啡因的咖啡机周围，抱怨他们的上司，讨论谁和谁睡觉并抱怨咖啡。

Nevertheless, the statistics (not to mention economics) imply that the managerial Armageddon is a little further off than some have feared, and that work is changing less radically than many people have claimed. The "job," like other maligned institutions, such as the company and even the city, is not going to disappear in the immediate future. In 20 years' time, you will still be able to walk into any office and discover a group of greying employees gathered around a decaffeinated coffee machine bitching about their superiors, discussing who is sleeping with whom and complaining about the coffee.

听班加罗尔

Listen to Bangalore

关键是管理理论家在谈论工作结束时夸大了他们的情况。 他们中较诚实的人也承认这一点。 这并不意味着工作场所没有变化。

The point is that the management theorists have exaggerated their case when they talk about the end of the job. The more honest among them admit as much. That does not mean that the workplace is not changing.

任何想要参观印度软件公司 Wipro Infotech 位于班加罗尔尘土飞扬的办公室的西方工会会员都有心脏病发作的风险——而不仅仅是因为要爬四层楼梯。 所有三种变革力量——技术、通信和全球竞争——都在展示。 这里有印度人的手和脑子在做西方人过去做过的工作——重新设计通用电气的内部软件系统——而且这样做的成本只有在西方的五分之一。 印度工程师完成后，他们的产品将通过建筑物屋顶上的卫星天线传送到美国。 在印度的其他角落，人们正在为瑞士航空公司等公司做后台工作，有些人甚至正在研究视频屏幕，担任美国办公场所的保安。

Any Western trade unionist wanting to visit the dusty office of Wipro Infotech, an Indian software firm, in Bangalore would risk a heart attack—and not just because of the climb up four flights of stairs. All three forces of change—technology, communication, and global competition—are there on display. Here are Indian hands and brains doing the work that Western ones used to do—redesigning General Electric's internal software system—and doing so for a fifth of what it would cost in the West. After the Indian engineers have finished, their product will be transmitted to America via the satellite dish on the building's roof. In other corners of India people are doing back-office work for companies such as Swissair, and some are even studying videoscreens, acting as security guards for premises in America.

甚至西欧和美国的农村也正在被一种新的工人重新安置。 Exmoor 的一家旧铁匠铺现在是一家公司的所在地，该公司使用远在日本的组件为 80 个国家/地区的客户制造带有计算机控制机械手的昂贵显微镜。 4 不难看出

Even the countryside of Western Europe and America is being repopulated by a new kind of worker. An old smithy in Exmoor is now home to a company that uses components from as far afield as Japan to make expensive microscopes with computer-controlled manipulators for customers in 80 countries. 4 It is not difficult to see

工作的未来

The Future of Work

为什么人们会对所有这些事情可能产生的影响产生幻想。 正如 Handy 所说：

why people might get dreamy about the possible impact of all these things. As Handy says:

600 年前发明和开发印刷机时，我们的世界即将发生与技术事件一样重大的变化，它在许多方面将欧洲带入了一个新时代。 人们第一次能够在自己的时间在自己的家中用自己的语言阅读圣经。 . . . 他们现在可以自己决定是非，上帝与魔鬼。 结果，教会的权威崩溃了，大多数机构的权威也随之崩溃。 个人自由导致创造力，从而导致文艺复兴。 . . . 电视机和电话，最后是计算机，我们现在所关注的有线和无线世界，是印刷机的现代等价物。 当摩托罗拉实现了在我们每个人出生时就拥有个人号码的梦想时， 那么电话将真正属于一个人而不是一个地方。 这听起来微不足道，但这意味着办公室将变得像教堂一样变得不必要。 5个

Our world is about to see a change as significant as the technological event which, in many ways, launched Europe into a new age 600 years ago when the printing press was invented and developed. For the first time then people were able to read the Bible in their own language in their own home in their own time. . . . They could now make up their own minds about right and wrong, God and devil. As a result, the authority of the Church crumbled, and with it the authority of most institutions. Individual freedom led to creativity, which led to the Renaissance. . . . The television set and the telephone, with the computer at the end of it, the wired and unwired world which we now contemplate, are the modern equivalents of the printing press. When Motorola achieves its dream of a personal number for each of us at birth, then a telephone will truly belong to a person not a place. Insignificant as that sounds, it means that the office will become as unnecessary as the churches became. 5

再一次，很容易在细节上与 Handy 争论不休：在古腾堡之后五百年，教堂对包括 Handy 在内的许多人来说仍然是“必需的”。 然而，工作世界显然正在发生变化，即使不像某些人声称的那么多。 颠覆旧秩序的暗流——尤其是困扰管理者的——提出了三个普遍问题：我们在哪里工作？ 我们为谁工作？ 我们该怎么办？

Once again, it is easy to quibble with Handy over details: five hundred years after Gutenberg, churches remain "necessary" for many people, including Handy. Yet the world of work is clearly changing, if not quite as much as some people claim. The undercurrents upsetting the old order—and troubling managers in particular—raise three general questions: Where do we work? Who do we work for? And what do we do?

在家给我打电话

Ring Me at Home

Handy 关于工作正在成为我们所做的事情，而不是我们去的地方的论点正在慢慢成为现实。 将近 4300 万美国人在家完成部分工作——这个数字比 1988 年高出 75%。其中 1200 万是全职员工。 在许多情况下，推动变革的力量不仅来自于技术，也来自于高昂的办公室价格：无论是在全职劳动力还是兼职劳动力中，女性在所有地方都占据了更大的比例。 据华威大学的研究人员称，2001 年英国就业劳动力的 46% 将是女性。 他们还预测，届时将增加 130 万

Handy's argument that work is becoming something we do, rather than the place where we go is slowly coming true. Close to 43 million Americans do some portion of their work at home—a figure that is 75 percent higher than in 1988. Twelve million of these are full-timers. In many cases the force for change is demography as much as technology or high office prices: everywhere women are accounting for a larger share of both the fully employed workforce and the part-time one. According to the researchers at Warwick University, 46 percent of Britain's employed labor force in 2001 will be female. They also predict that by then there will be an extra 1.3 million

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

兼职工作，个体经营者将增加 43.6 万人，达到 370 万人，占就业劳动力总数的 14%。 所有这些类型的工人都倾向于在家里做一些工作。 美国的 AT&T 猜测，到本世纪末，每两个美国人中就有一个将至少在家中完成部分工作。

part-time jobs, and the number of self-employed will rise by 436,000 to 3.7 million, or 14 percent of the total employed labor force. All these sorts of workers tend to do some of their work at home. America's AT&T has guessed that by the end of the decade one of every two Americans will do at least some of their work from home.

在美国和欧洲的许多地方，“SoHo”（或单一运营商家庭办公室）运动正在兴起。 三分之一的美国家庭已经拥有一台电脑； 其中大约 40% 的人拥有调制解调器，可以让他们的计算机与外界对话。 几乎每个推销员或女士都有一部便携式电话。 五年之内，大多数调制解调器很可能是蜂窝式的，这意味着拜访客户的销售人员甚至不必找到电话插孔即可下载最新的销售信息。 热心人士声称，在家工作不仅更方便——尤其是对女性而言——而且效率更高。 大量研究表明，从事办公室工作的人有一半时间都在自己工作。 根据一些计算，如果一个工人呆在家里，他或她的生产率会提高 15% 到 20%。

In America and many parts of Europe there is a growing "SoHo" (or single-operator home office) movement. One in three American homes already has a computer; some 40 percent of these have modems allowing their computers to talk to the outside world. Virtually every salesman or woman has a portable telephone. Within five years most modems will in all likelihood be cellular, meaning that a salesperson visiting a client will not even have to find a phone-jack to download the latest sales information. Enthusiasts claim that not only is working at home more convenient—especially for women— but it is also more efficient. Numerous studies have shown that people in office jobs spend half their time working by themselves. By some calculations, a worker's productivity rises by 15 to 20 percent if he or she stays at home.

这是真的？ 呆在家里效率最高的最好论据通常是上班效率低下。 Booz, Allen & Hamilton 对 90,000 名经理进行的一项研究发现，人们将四分之一的时间浪费在工作上。 把花在毫无意义的会议、通勤和在咖啡机周围闲逛的时间加起来，你会发现这是一个低估的时间。 许多公司允许人们呆在家里，并发现生产力得到了提高。 在一项实验中，康柏公司为所有销售人员提供了连接到主网络的个人电脑（这样他们就可以即时访问所有最新信息和价格），并告诉他们在家工作。 Compaq 不仅节省了办公空间，还节省了办公空间。 它还发现它可以用原来销售人员的三分之二来解决问题，这主要是因为每个销售人员销售的电脑数量是原来的六倍。

Is this true? The best argument for the efficiency of staying at home is usually the inefficiency of going to work. One study of 90,000 managers by Booz, Allen & Hamilton found that people waste a quarter of their time at work. Add up the hours spent in pointless meetings, commuting, and hanging around the coffee machine and you should find this is an underestimate. Plenty of companies have allowed people to stay at home and found that productivity improved. In one experiment, Compaq gave all its salespeople personal computers connected to its main network (so that they had instant access to all the latest information and prices) and told them to work from home. Not only did Compaq save on office space; it also found it could get by with two-thirds of the original salesforce, largely because each salesman sold six times as many computers. At The Economist, it is noticeable that all but the laziest foreign correspondents are more productive than their London counterparts: one reason is that they gain roughly a day a week in terms of meetings that they do not have to attend.

但在家工作真的是一种如此迷人、富有成效的生活吗？ 在许多国家/地区，居家办公的员工不可能或很复杂地从所得税中扣除全部费用。 在日本，电子集团东芝已经开始尝试让软件研究人员呆在家里。 但是日本的大部分房子

But is working at home really such a charmed, productive life? In many countries it is either impossible or complicated for home-office workers to claim their full expenses against their income taxes. In Japan, Toshiba, an electronics group, has begun to experiment with letting software researchers stay at home. But most houses in Japan

工作的未来

The Future of Work

太小了，人们无法舒适地生活，更不用说在那里工作了； 电话费用会使整个过程非常昂贵。 此外，那些回复调查的人的动机看起来很可疑。 如果您是一位有三个小孩的母亲，您会不会声称在家工作效率更高？ 轶事证据表明，许多在家办公的狂热者都是独来独往的人，他们的注意力非常集中。 大多数“正常”员工，尤其是管理人员，担心在家就意味着被排除在外。 在任何一个普通的家庭中，都会有很多让人分心的事情，从电视上的体育赛事到性爱，这些在办公室通常是没有的（试着坐在家里写一本书，尤其是关于管理的书）。

are too small for people to live in comfortably, let alone work there; and telephone costs can make the whole exercise punitively expensive. Moreover, the motives of those replying to surveys look suspect. If you were a mother with three small children, would you not claim that working at home was more productive? Anecdotal evidence suggests that many of the home-office fanatics are loners with formidable powers of concentration. Most "normal" workers, particularly managers, worry that being at home means being out of the loop. In any normal home there are plenty of distractions, ranging from athletic events on the television to sex, that are not usually available in the office (try sitting at home and writing a book, particularly on management).

SoHo 运动的支持者也有选择性地举例。 他们对一些从国内环境中涌现出来的年轻公司大做文章，例如 Apple 和 Mrs. Fields's Cookies。 但这算不上新趋势。 像迪士尼和福特这样的大公司都是从以家庭为基础的企业开始的。 同样，关于任何类型的员工现在都可以在家工作的说法也是无稽之谈。 同一群在家工作的人一次又一次地出现——管理顾问、作家等等。 这样的组合工人在当地很少见。 正如同样在各种舒适的职业之间穿梭的英国大师约翰凯在评论汉迪的一本书时所说的那样，“有查尔斯汉迪和我，但其他人不多。” 6个

The supporters of the SoHo movement are also selective with their examples. They make a great fuss about the number of young companies that have sprung from domestic surroundings, such as Apple and Mrs. Fields's Cookies. But this is hardly a new trend. Companies as big as Disney and Ford both started as home-based businesses. Similarly, the suggestion that just about any type of worker can now work at home is nonsense. Time after time the same groups of home workers pop up—management consultants, writers, and so on. Such portfolio workers are rare on the ground. As John Kay, a British guru who also flits between various comfortable careers, observed when reviewing one of Handy's books, "There is Charles Handy, and me, but not many others." 6

这是临时工的世界

It's a Temp's World

临时工并不是一个新现象，尤其是在欧洲，但他们正变得越来越普遍。 英国管理学会 1995 年 10 月的一份报告发现，英国公司中有将近十分之九使用兼职和临时工（比前一年分别增加了 15% 和 8%）。 1990-95年期间，英国临时工数量增加了35万，而劳动力总数却减少了75万。 这些临时工中越来越多的人受雇于工厂。

Temporary workers are not a new phenomenon, particularly in Europe, but they are becoming more common. A report in October 1995 by Britain's Institute of Management found that nearly 9 out of 10 British companies used part-time and temporary workers (a rise of 15 and 8 percent over the previous year). In the period 1990-95, the number of temporary workers in Britain increased by 350,000 at the same time that the overall workforce declined by 750,000. And an increasing proportion of these temporary workers were employed in factories.

在美国，兼职人员、租赁雇员和个体经营者现在占劳动力的四分之一。 美国最大的私人雇主不再是通用汽车公司，而是万宝盛华，这是一家临时职业介绍所，在册员工达 60 万人。 有

In America, part-timers, leased employees, and the self-employed now account for one-quarter of the workforce. America's biggest private employer is no longer General Motors but Manpower, a temporary employment agency with 600,000 people on its books. There are

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

现在美国大约有 6,000 家临时工中介——是 10 年前的两倍。 1995 年，《Inc》杂志快速发展公司名单上的 500 家公司中有 38 家报告了各种人员配置问题。 即使在终身雇佣的神殿日本，尽管制度受到高度管制，像南布康之这样的异教徒也以前所未有的数量出现。 “你可以在自己喜欢的时间和喜欢的工作地点工作，”Nambu 说，“不受一家公司的约束。” 7

now about 6,000 temp agencies in America—double the figure of 10 years ago. In 1995, 38 out of the 500 firms on Inc magazine's list of fast-growing companies reported staffing concerns of one sort or another. Even in Japan, that temple of lifetime employment, heretics such as Yasuyuki Nambu are appearing in unprecedented numbers, despite a highly regulated system. "You can work at the place of your choice at the time you like and the job you like," says Nambu, "without being bound to one company." 7

从雇主的角度来看，Nambu 对临时工作优点的乐观态度可能是有道理的。 美国的狂热者谈论存在“应急现货市场”。 8 在 Jobshift 中，Bridges 举了 Home Corporation 的例子，这是一家位于阿拉巴马州蒙哥马利的公司，该公司拥有公寓大楼，并决定从一家名为 Action Staffing 的临时机构租用其全部 500 名物业管理人员。 9 临时工不需要像全职员工那样的福利； 他们也更容易裁员。 Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Rhode Island 在五年内裁员了 40%，却没有解雇一名“真正的”员工。 英国职业介绍所 Reed Personal Services 于 1995 年 10 月发表的一份报告，

From an employer's point of view, Nambu's optimism about the virtues of temporary work may be justified. Enthusiasts in America talk about there being "a contingency spot market." 8 In Jobshift, Bridges gives the example of Home Corporation, a Montgomery, Alabama, firm that owns apartment complexes and that decided to lease its entire 500-strong property management staff from a temporary agency called Action Staffing. 9 Temporary workers do not need the same benefits that full-timers do; they are also much easier to lay off. Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Rhode Island cut its workforce by 40 percent over five years without having to sack one "real" worker. A report published in October 1995 by Reed Personal Services, a British employment agency, indicated that demand for temporary staff was at an all-time high but warned that too many employers were short-changing temps when it came to holidays, training, sick pay, and so on.

这类问题解释了为什么 Handy、Drucker 和 Peters 认为如此令人兴奋的“公司公寓”和“虚拟公司”可能会在一段时间内出现。 大多数临时工并没有因为现在向他们开放的选择而感到振奋，反而感到不安全——他们的工作表明了这一点。 引入临时工导致质量下降的例子很多。在一个安全套工厂，管理人员可以通过从装配线另一端跳下的有缺陷产品的数量来判断临时工何时到达。 调查显示，大约 60% 的应急劳动力更愿意从事全职工作。

This sort of problem explains why the "corporate condominiums" and "virtual corporations" that Handy, Drucker, and Peters find so exciting may be some time in coming. Far from being invigorated by the choice now open to them, most temporary workers feel insecure—and their work shows it. There are ample examples of quality declining when temporary workers are brought in. At one condom factory, the managers could tell when the temporary workers had arrived by the number of faulty products tripping off the other end of the assembly line. Surveys have shown that roughly 60 percent of the people in the contingency labor force would rather have full-time jobs.

然而，有一些希望的迹象。 临时工的技能越高（即，他们越接近成为“组合工人”而不仅仅是“某人”），他们就越有可能出于选择而做他们所做的事情。 在公司的高层，聘请公司医生的传统由来已久。 （举个例子

However, there are some signs of hope. The higher the skill of the temps (i.e., the closer they get to becoming "portfolio workers" rather than just "somebodies"), the more likely they are to be doing what they do out of choice. At the top level of companies there has been a long tradition of bringing in company doctors. (One example

工作的未来

The Future of Work

来自公共部门的戴维·格根 (David Gergen) 被召来修复克林顿总统的新闻关系。）在美国，越来越多的机构正在雇用老板和项目经理或技术工人，例如律师和撰稿人。 聘请高科技专家是 Manpower 业务增长最快的部分。 微软和 Silicon Graphics 等公司严重依赖这种短期帮助——并支付高额报酬。 白领临时工的收入通常比正式员工高。

from the public sector is David Gergen, who was called in to mend President Clinton's press relations.) In America a growing number of agencies are hiring out bosses and project managers or skilled workers such as lawyers and copy writers. Hiring out high-technology specialists is the fastest-growing part of Manpower's business. Companies such as Microsoft and Silicon Graphics rely heavily on this short-term help—and pay them well. White-collar temps often earn more than permanent staff.

小即脆弱

Small Is Fragile

现在问任何人他们为谁工作，答案很可能是“一家小公司”。 无论大公司和小公司的相对优势如何，一个人更有可能为小公司工作——而这家公司更有可能倒闭。

Ask anybody who they work for nowadays, and the answer is likely to be "a small company." Whatever the relative merits of big and small companies, one is more likely to work for a smaller company—and that company is more likely to go bust.

在美国 2100 万家商业企业中，只有 14000 家拥有超过 500 名员工。 10 据一些统计，这种规模的企业的增长速度比整体经济快两到三个百分点。 即使是小公司数量较少的经济体，它们也常常是新工作岗位的主要来源。 例如在半社会主义的瑞典，该国 70% 的制造业员工为像沃尔沃这样的大公司辛勤工作，这是唯一在 1985-92 年增加工作岗位的公司，雇员人数不到 20 人。

Of the 21 million business enterprises in the United States, only 14,000 have more than 500 employees. 10 By some counts, businesses of this size are growing about two to three percentage points faster than the economy as a whole. Even economies where small firms are less numerous, they are often the prime source of new jobs. For instance in semisocialist Sweden, where 70 percent of the country's manufacturing employees toil for big companies like Volvo, the only type of company to add jobs in 1985-92 employed fewer than 20 people.

然而，小公司仍然是脆弱的生物。 对加利福尼亚州等州就业增长的研究指出了“瞪羚”公司的重要性：这些公司不一定是新公司，但通常是相当小的公司，它们突然向前飞跃，但也可能绊倒。 与大多数其他州的人相比，加利福尼亚人更有可能被解雇，也更有可能被雇用。 如果关注行业而不是地区，就会出现类似的情况。 大约 60% 的高科技初创企业在五岁生日前就夭折了。

However, small companies remain fragile creatures. Studies of employment growth in states such as California have pointed to the importance of "gazelle" companies: firms, not necessarily new ones but usually fairly small ones, that suddenly leap forward but can also trip up. Californians are both more likely to be sacked and more likely to be hired than those in most other states. A similar story emerges if one looks at industries instead of regions. Some 60 percent of high-tech start-ups die before their fifth birthday.

在所有这些创造性的破坏中工作可能不符合每个人的口味，但它似乎吸引了最优秀和最聪明的人。 在《新规则：如何在当今的后企业世界中取得成功》（1995 年）中，约翰·科特追踪了 115 名哈佛商学院 1974 届毕业生。只有 23% 的人受雇于拥有 10,000 名员工的公司。 大多数人在不到 1,000 人的公司工作，其中 40% 自称是企业家。 到 1991

Working in the midst of all this creative destruction may not be to everybody's taste, but it appears to attract the best and the brightest. In The New Rules: How to Succeed in Today's Post-Corporate World (1995), John Kotter tracked 115 members of the Harvard Business School's Class of 1974. Only 23 percent were employed at companies with 10,000 people. Most worked for companies with less than 1,000—and 40 percent of them claimed to be entrepreneurs. By 1991

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

那些受雇于小企业的人的平均工资为 450,000 美元——是他们在大公司工作的同学的两倍。

those employed at the smaller businesses were paid an average of $450,000—twice as much as their classmates at the bigger firms.

即使是为大公司工作的员工也无法摆脱这种不确定性。 正如已经指出的那样，最成功的大公司变得更具企业家精神，将决策制定推向下层并围绕团队进行重组。 如今，在大型联合工程集团的一部分（例如 ABB Asea Brown Boveri）工作与在一家小公司（例如意大利北部贝纳通周围的小型服装供应商网络中的一家公司）工作之间的区别越来越大不清楚。 在过去，如果一家子公司要求更多的独立性，它可能会被告知去死吧； 如今，人们更有可能通过大量关于“在我们的城市中创建村庄”的必要性的热情而模糊的谈话来鼓励它。

Even employees who work for big companies are not free from this sort of uncertainty. As already noted, the most successful big companies have become more entrepreneurial, pushing decision making down the ranks and restructuring themselves around teams. The difference nowadays between working for one part of a large federated engineering group, such as ABB Asea Brown Boveri, and working for a small company, such as one in the network of small clothing suppliers around Benetton in Northern Italy, is becoming more and more unclear. In the old days, if a subsidiary asked for more independence it would probably have been told to go to hell; nowadays it is more likely to be encouraged with lots of warm and fuzzy talk about the need "to create villages within our cities."

这种方法对人们的工作方式有影响。 即使在一家大公司，人们也不能再将职业视为从最卑微的办公室直接通往董事会的阶梯。 相反，它已成为一系列由堤道连接的岛屿，由一艘小型浮动旗舰松散地管理。 从很多方面来说，从通用电气的一个角落跳到另一个角落，就像离开一家硅谷初创公司跳槽到另一家一样可怕。

This approach has an effect on the way people work. Even in a big company, people can no longer afford to see a career as a ladder leading straight from the humblest office to the boardroom. Rather, it has become a series of islands connected by causeways, loosely governed by a small floating flagship. In many ways hopping from one corner of General Electric to another can be just as terrifying as leaving one Silicon Valley start-up and going to another.

我们所做的

What We Do

无论经理的工作是在大公司还是小公司，这份工作的许多特征都在发生惊人的变化——从经理监督的人员类型到他们的工作时间，以及他们是否有办公室，甚至是办公桌。 这解释了为什么管理上的不安全感比仅仅害怕失去工作更深层次。

Whether a manager's job is at a big firm or a small one, a striking number of characteristics of that job are changing—from the kind of people the manager supervises to what hours they work and whether they have an office, or even a desk. This explains why managerial insecurity runs much deeper than mere fear of losing a job.

随着越来越少的人承担越来越多的任务，传统的职位描述不得不被抛弃。 突然间，经理们被他们曾经认为是下属的人告知该怎么做，他们不得不分享曾经属于他们的信息。 管理者不仅要监督临时工，还要监督为其他公司工作的人。 打电话给你的计算机部门，Electronic Data Systems 或 Computer Services Corporation 的人可能会来解决你的问题； 打电话到收发室，您可能正在与 Pitney Bowes 邮递员通话。

As fewer people take on more and more tasks, conventional job descriptions have to be thrown out. Suddenly managers are being told what to do by people they once considered their juniors, and they have to share information that was once theirs exclusively. Managers have to supervise not only temporary workers but also people who work for other companies. Call up your computer department and someone from Electronic Data Systems or Computer Services Corporation may come to fix your problem; ring down to the mailroom and you may be talking to a Pitney Bowes postman.

工作的未来

The Future of Work

即使你在装配线上对某人大喊大叫，结果也可能是分包商的代表。 至于你自己的员工，他们很可能不在你的控制范围内。 Walters Hexagon 是一家供应不同类型螺钉和紧固件的英国小公司，其 120 名员工中有 10 名是“工程特使”，他们坐在客户的工厂里，负责将货物从送货人员那里运送到正确的客户部门。 11

Even if you shout at somebody on the assembly line, it might turn out to be a subcontractor's representative. As for your own workers, they may well be outside your control. Ten out of the 120 employees at Walters Hexagon, a small British company that supplies different types of screws and fasteners, are "engineering envoys" who sit in its customers' factories and ferry goods from its delivery people to the correct customer department. 11

经理们甚至正在失去他们地位、办公室和办公桌的传统象征。 最时髦的公司正在引入“漫游办公”和“即时办公”。 一些公司这样做是为了减少混乱并更富有想象力地利用他们的空间。 （Digital Equipment 的芬兰办事处利用由此产生的空间建造了一间桑拿浴室，供其客户使用。）其他人发现，它鼓励员工减少对地位和等级的关注，并迫使他们上路。 Gemini 拒绝为其顾问提供他们自己的办公桌，因为它希望他们将大部分时间花在客户身上，而不是在办公室里闲逛。 用开放式隔间代替个人办公室的时尚也已经传播到更稳重的工业公司。 在美国铝业公司， 首席执行官保罗·奥尼尔 (Paul O'Neill) 拆除了行政套房内的所有永久性墙壁和门。 美国铝业公司的工业巨头现在显然在“通讯中心”一起闲逛或在小厨房一起做饭。 12

Managers are even losing those traditional symbols of their status, their offices and desks. The trendiest companies are introducing "hotdesking" and "just-in-time desks." Some companies are doing this to reduce clutter and to make more imaginative use of their space. (Digital Equipment's Finnish office has used the resulting space to build a sauna for the use of its clients.) Others find that it encourages workers to become less preoccupied with status and hierarchy, and that it forces them to get on the road. Gemini refuses to give its consultants their own desks because it wants them to spend most of their time with their clients rather than hanging around the office. The fashion for replacing individual offices with open-plan cubicles has also spread to more staid industrial firms. At the Aluminum Company of America, the chief executive, Paul O'Neill, has removed all the permanent walls and doors in the executive suite. The industrial titans at Alcoa now apparently hang out together in a "communications center" or cook food together in the kitchenette. 12

但在许多情况下，真正的原因无疑是成本。 通过将人员与办公桌的比例从 2:1 更改为 12:1，Digital Equipment 的英国分公司每年节省 350 万英镑。 通过重组其不动产（并迫使 20,000 名经理共享办公室），IBM 节省了 140 亿美元。 正如 Charles Handy 指出的那样，人们使用办公空间的效率远低于机器，机器每周可以工作整整 168 小时，而人类很少超过 60 小时。更糟糕的是，越来越多的人甚至在工作期间都不在办公室他们可以在那里的时间。 据康奈尔大学国际工作场所研究项目主任富兰克林贝克尔说，“大约 70% 从事管理咨询、销售和客户服务工作的人通常不在办公桌前。” 13

But the real reason in many cases is no doubt cost. By changing its person-to-desk ratio from 2:1 to 12:1, Digital Equipment's British arm saved £3.5 million a year. By reorganizing its real estate (and forcing 20,000 managers to share offices) IBM saved $14 billion. As Charles Handy points out, people are much less efficient at using office space than machines, which can work for a full 168 hours a week whereas humans rarely get beyond 60. Worse, an increasing number of people are not even in the office during the hours that they could be there. According to Franklin Becker, director of the International Workplace Studies Program at Cornell University, "About 70 % of the people who work in management consultancy, sales and customer service are usually not at their desks." 13

但是，尚不清楚所有这些轮用办公桌是否受员工欢迎。 具有讽刺意味的是，美国家具设计公司赫曼米勒 (Herman Miller) 为员工提供手推车，供他们携带

However, it is not clear whether all this hotdesking is popular with employees. Ironically enough, Herman Miller, an American furniture design company, gives its employees carts in which to carry

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

在他们的个人物品周围，以便他们可以在他们那里时个性化他们的工作站。 同样，当前流行的开放式“网络”办公室可能会剥夺人们思考的空间。 在英国连锁超市 Asda 的一处，想要独处的员工必须戴上红色帽子。

around their individual belongings so that they can personalize their workstation while they are there. Similarly, the current vogue for open-plan "networking" offices can deprive people of having a place to think. At one part of Asda, a British supermarket chain, employees who want space to themselves have to wear red caps.

对于任何经理来说，这似乎都足以让人迷失方向。 然而，在英特尔和微软等时髦的科技公司，经理们必须习惯于成为临时工作组的成员，而不是永久部门的领导者：通常没有精确的物理位置或工作。 而且节奏不一样。 该项目不是常规的朝九晚五的工作日，而是倾向于在午夜建立比萨饼，你看不到你的孩子渐强，然后在一切结束后放假。

This might seem disorientating enough for any manager. Yet at hip technology companies such as Intel and Microsoft managers have to get used to being a member of a temporary task force rather than the leader of a permanent division: there are often no precise physical locations or job. And the pace is different. Rather than working a regular 9-to-5 day, the project tends to build to a pizzas-at-midnight, you-can't-see-your-children crescendo, followed by a holiday after it is all over.

在某些方面，围绕创意爆发建立的职业似乎更接近前工业时代的职业。 在 Jobshift 中，Bridges 使用长途交通来说明从就业前世界到工作世界再到失业世界的转变。 在 18 世纪，当主要的交通工具是轮船时，几乎没有永久性的工作（每次航行都会雇用你）。 在海上，虽然一天被划分为手表，但大多数任务都是由人们一起完成的（例如，拉下帆）。 虽然船主通常是个贪水的商人，但几乎所有实际的决定都必须留给船长。 然后是铁路，这需要更多的组织。 时间表和价格由总部制定。 工人有特定的工作（售票员不铲煤）。 客机随后引入了进一步的变化。 一开始，工作的世界大同小异。 现在，年轻的航空公司通过让员工从事各种工作（在西南航空公司，飞行员或“领队”帮助人们搬运行李），抢占了老牌航空公司的先机。 剩下的就是航天飞机了，它是布里奇斯最恰当的失业未来的例子，虽然每个机组成员都有自己的专长，但最重要的技能将是团队技能。

In some respects, a career built around creative bursts seems much closer to a career in the preindustrial age. In Jobshift, Bridges uses long-distance transport to illustrate the shift from the pre-job world to the world of jobs and then to the dejobbed world. In the eighteenth century, when the primary means of transport was the ship, there was little permanent employment (you were hired for each voyage). At sea, although the day was divided into watches, most tasks were accomplished by people working together (e.g., pulling down the sails). Although the boat's owner was usually a landlubbing merchant, almost all the practical decisions had to be left to the captain. Then came the railway, which required far more organization. Schedules and prices were set by the head office. Workers had specific jobs (conductors did not shovel coal). The airliner then introduced further change. At the start, the world of jobs was much the same. Now young carriers are stealing a march on their older peers by letting their staff do a variety of jobs (at Southwest Airlines, the pilots or "team leaders" help people with their baggage). That leaves the Space Shuttle, Bridges's most appropriate example of the dejobbed future, where, although each crew member has his own specialty, the most important skills will be team ones.

中间人

Men in the Middle

总而言之，布里奇斯可能在用航天飞机类比。 大多数公司仍处于客机阶段，而且可能会持续一段时间。 （毕竟西南不让其

On balance, Bridges may be straining the analogy with the space shuttle. Most companies are still very much at the airliner stage—and likely to remain so for some time. (After all, Southwest does not let its

工作的未来

The Future of Work

行李搬运工负责驾驶飞机。）尽管许多公司都在一定程度上按照基于项目的方式进行了重组，但很少有人像微软或英特尔那样走得那么远。 此外，还有一些人反对更结构化的工作方式。 没有什么比对中层管理人员的态度更能代表这种修正了。

baggage handlers fly the aircraft.) Although many companies have reorganized to some extent along project-based lines, few have gone as far as Microsoft or Intel. Besides there is something of a backlash in favor of a more structured approach to work. Nothing typifies this correction more than the attitude toward middle managers.

直到最近，大多数公司对中层管理人员的反应就像斯大林对富农的反应一样。 中层管理人员是时间服务器的官僚阶层，他们笨拙地坐在车间和工厂之间，阻碍了信息的快速流动，并且占美国自 1988 年以来失去的所有工作岗位的五分之一。正如汤姆彼得斯所说： “他们的鹅煮熟了。”

Until recently most companies reacted to middle managers the way that Stalin responded to the Kulaks. Middle managers were the bureaucratic class of time servers who sat awkwardly between the shop floor and the factory, who impeded the swift flow of information, and who account for a fifth of all the jobs lost in America since 1988. As Tom Peters put it: "Their goose is cooked."

然而时尚在变。 到 20 世纪 90 年代中期，理论家开始谈论中层管理人员将“中层”视角带入公司的工作。 他们是军士：只有对车间和客户有足够了解的人才能够告诉高层的战略思想家如何将他们的想法付诸实践。 康涅狄格大学的 Steven Floyd 和马萨诸塞大学的 Bill Wooldridge 研究了 20 家美国公司的管理，他们声称，在制定战略时给予中层管理人员发言权的公司比那些没有给予中层管理人员发言权的公司表现更好。 14 中层管理人员非但不是大公司创新的障碍，反而往往是创新的拥护者：他们是大公司中唯一知道如何完成工作的人。 麦吉尔大学的 Frances Westley 指出，中层管理人员也是熟练的人际关系网，永远与其他公司的同事建立非正式联盟。 15 中层管理人员是职业阶梯的重要组成部分：它为基层员工提供目标，并提供几年的培训，使成功人士可以在其中取得平衡。

Yet fashions change. By the mid-1990s, theorists had begun to talk of middle managers bringing a "midlevel" perspective to a company's work. They are the sergeants: the only people who know enough about the shop floor and customer to be able to tell strategic thinkers in the upper ranks how their ideas can be put into practice. Steven Floyd of the University of Connecticut and Bill Wooldridge of the University of Massachusetts, who studied management at 20 American firms, claim that companies that gave middle managers a say in forming strategy performed better than those that did not. 14 Far from being barriers to innovation in big companies, middle managers are often champions of it: they are the only people who know how to get things done in big organizations. Frances Westley of McGill University points out that middle managers are also skilled networkers, forever making informal alliances with colleagues from other companies. 15 And middle management is a vital part of the career ladder: it gives workers at the bottom something to aim for, and it provides a few years of training in which high-fliers can get their balance.

问题不在于是否要有中层管理人员，而是如何使用他们而不让他们沉迷于层级建设和文书工作的弱点。 Digital 和 3M 等一些公司试图将中层管理人员转变为企业家，他们的工作是发明好点子并说服高级管理人员支持他们。 在日本，一个长期以来对中层管理人员比西方更友好的国家，本田通过给中层管理人员一个总体目标（使其对年轻人友好和省油）并让他们完成其余的工作来开发思域模型。

The question is not whether to have middle managers, but how to use them without letting them indulge their weaknesses for hierarchy building and paperwork. Some firms such as Digital and 3M have tried to turn middle managers into entrepreneurs whose job is to invent good ideas and persuade senior managers to back them. In Japan, a country that has long looked on middle managers more kindly than the West, Honda developed its Civic model by giving middle managers a general goal (make it youth-friendly and fuel-efficient) and letting them do the rest.

所有这些谈话的结果是，即使是以精益为荣的大公司也被迫重塑中间层

The result of all this talk is that even big companies that pride themselves on being lean have been forced to reinvent middle

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

管理者——尽管冠以“促进者”、“跨界者”、“流程管理者”和“员工教练”等头衔。 与现代工作场所相关的大多数其他事物一样，大公司也在发生变化——但变化幅度没有悲观主义者预测的那么大。

managers—albeit under titles such as "facilitators," "boundary spanners," "process managers," and "employee coaches." As with most other things connected with the modern workplace, big companies are changing—but not by as much as the pessimists predict.

被奴役还是被赋予权力？

Enslaved or Empowered?

任何接受工作正在发生变化（至少是一点点）这一观点的人都会立即陷入两场激烈的辩论。 第一个问题围绕着新的工作文化是解放还是奴役了工作的男人或女人。 它会使天平向有利于雇主或雇员的方向倾斜吗？ 人们会过上更充实的生活，还是注定要被焦虑折磨？ 第二场辩论往往被第一场的诊断所影响，转向处方。 应该怎样做才能使工作更加自由？ 经理应该向他或她的雇主提出什么要求？

Anybody who accepts the notion that work is changing (at least, a little) is immediately plunged into two fierce debates. The first revolves around the question of whether the new work culture liberates or enslaves the working man or woman. Does it tip the balance in favor of the employer or the employee? Are people going to live more fulfilled lives or are they destined to be racked by anxiety? The second debate, which tends to be greatly colored by the diagnosis of the first, turns to prescription. What should be done to make jobs more liberating experiences? What should a manager demand from his or her employer?

Tom Peters 给人的印象是，个人计算机对管理者的作用与 William Wilberforce 对奴隶的作用大致相同。 他表示，经理们正处于一个新的、赋权的时代的边缘。 “忘掉忠诚吧。或者至少是对公司的忠诚。试试对你的 Rolodex——你的网络——的忠诚吧。” 16 彼得斯认为，如今的工作就是恢复（是的，他确实将另一个名词变成了动词）：每个人都应该成为独立承包商或将自己视为一个人。 “无能为力是一种心态，”彼得斯宣称。

Tom Peters gives the impression that the personal computer will perform much the same role for managers that William Wilberforce did for slaves. Managers, he suggests, are on the verge of a new, empowered age. "Forget loyalty. Or at least loyalty to one's corporation. Try loyalty to your Rolodex—your network—instead." 16 To work nowadays, argues Peters, is to resume (yes, he does turn yet another noun into a verb): everybody should become an independent contractor or think of themselves as one. "Powerlessness is a state of mind," declares Peters.

相比之下，许多其他专家认为“无能为力”正是大多数管理者的现状。 最悲观的是“下班”人群。 但对未来工作的悲观预测（以及相应的市场监管需求，这将导致这种困境）已成为各地左翼政治的主要内容。 美国劳工部长罗伯特赖希和英国工党领袖托尼布莱尔都谈到了“焦虑阶层”的崛起，他们中的大多数人都有工作，但有理由对他们缺乏安全感和担心孩子的孩子感到不安未来。

By contrast, many other gurus reckon that "powerless" is exactly what most managers are. The most downbeat are the "end-of-work" crowd. But a gloomy prognosis of the future of work (and a corresponding need to regulate the market, which will cause this distress) has become a staple of left-wing politics everywhere. Both America's labor secretary, Robert Reich, and Tony Blair, the leader of Britain's Labour Party, have talked about the rise of "the anxious class," most of whom hold jobs but are justifiably uneasy about their lack of security and fearful of their children's future.

第三组人，包括查尔斯汉迪，似乎从围栏的一边跳到另一边，有时庆祝那些拥有必要技能和知识以在新经济中蓬勃发展的人，有时同情那些将被抛弃的人

A third group of people, including Charles Handy, seem to hop from one side of the fence to the other, sometimes celebrating those who have the necessary skills and knowledge to flourish in the new economy, sometimes sympathizing with those who will be left

工作的未来

The Future of Work

在后面。 例如，罗莎贝丝·莫斯·坎特 (Rosabeth Moss Kanter) 将人们分为富有 3 C（“概念、能力和联系”）的“新世界主义者”和“本地人”——她相当于汉迪的“组合工人”和“某人”。

behind. Rosabeth Moss Kanter, for instance, divides people into "New Cosmopolitans" rich in the 3 Cs ("concepts, competence, and connections") and "locals"—her equivalent of Handy's "portfolio workers" and "somebodies."

每个人似乎都同意存在越来越大的分歧。 悲观主义者所犯的错误是认为西方世界的大多数人都属于失败者阵营。 有一个庞大且不断增长的工人群体应该从这项技术中获益，这种技术使人们更容易自己建立起来。 您不必成为约翰·科特 (John Kotter) 的哈佛 MBA 之一，就可以抓住现代经济带来的机遇。 漫步在丹佛郊区甚至科茨沃尔德的村庄，你会发现许多中等资质的人为自己工作——而且通常会因此获得更高的报酬。 同样，转向小型企业似乎也有助于工人。 许多各地的小公司都在迅速扩张，以至于他们发现很难找到“好人”。 1995 年 10 月《商业周刊》调查的四分之一美国小企业将“缺乏合格的工人”列为三大问题之一（这一比例每年都在上升）。 对于那些留在大公司的人来说，更扁平的管理结构意味着聪明的人现在可以更容易地登上高层。

Everyone seems to agree that there is a growing division. The mistake the pessimists make is to assume that most people in the Western world fit into the losing camp. There is a big, and growing, group of workers who should gain from the technology that is making it easier for people to set up on their own. You do not have to be one of John Kotter's Harvard MBAs to seize the opportunities presented by the modern economy. Wander around a Denver suburb or even a Cotswold village and you will find any number of moderately qualified people working for themselves—and usually being paid more for it. Similarly, the move toward small businesses seems to help workers. Many small companies everywhere are expanding so quickly that they find it difficult to find "good people." A quarter of the small American businesses surveyed by Business Week in October 1995 rated "a lack of qualified workers" as one of their three biggest problems (a proportion that has risen annually). As for those who remain inside big companies, flatter management structures mean that bright people can now bound to the top more easily.

话虽如此，但也有一类人注定会在职场的变迁中落败。 这个群体中肯定包括一些运气不佳的经理：例如，中年经理，被推迟了工作，现在重新雇用他们的成本比刚毕业的年轻大学毕业生还要高。 然而，总体而言，管理职位似乎并不短缺。 例如，大多数人都读过《高管忧郁：美国企业的落魄》（1995 年），这是一本关于一位名叫 GJ 迈耶的经理接受失业的自传，作为一种新型“工作恐怖”类型的主要例子：“在爱德华·蒙克 (Edvard Munch) 的《呐喊》(The Scream) 中，一个孤独的空洞人物站在马路上，捂着头，嘴巴张得大大的，”这位自怜的作者宣称。 “我希望'

That said, there is also a class of people who are doomed to lose out from the changes in the workplace. This group certainly includes some managers who are down on their luck: for example, the middle-aged manager, delayered out of a job, who is now more expensive to rehire than a fresh young college graduate. In the aggregate, however, there does not appear to be a shortage of managerial jobs. For instance, most people read Executive Blues: Down and Out in Corporate America (1995), an autobiography of a manager named G. J. Meyer coming to terms with unemployment, as a primary example of a new sort of "work-horror" genre: "In Edvard Munch's The Scream, a solitary empty-eyed figure stands in a roadway clutching its head, mouth open wide," proclaims the self-pitying author. "I hope that's not what I look like as I walk the streets of Manhattan." At the end of Executive Blues, however, the author has to admit that he has found "a job that I like very much with a company that I like very much on the outskirts of Cleveland."

真正的输家是没有技能的穷人，他们现在更有可能在短期工作之间徘徊，或者也许

The real losers are the unskilled poor, who are now more likely to spend their lives drifting between short-term jobs, or perhaps

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

完全退出正式工作。 1995 年，46% 的欧洲失业者失业时间超过一年。 正如杰里米·里夫金 (Jeremy Rifkin) 所指出的那样，当早期的自动化浪潮在 1950 年代开始对美国的制造业造成影响时，受打击最严重的是非熟练工人，尤其是黑人。 到 1964 年，黑人失业率达到 12%，而此前的战后失业率高达 8.5%。 相比之下，白人失业率从 4.6% 攀升至 5.9%。 17 同样的事情似乎再次发生。 几乎在所有地方，贫富之间的“不平等差距”都在扩大。

dropping out of formal work entirely. In 1995, 46 percent of Europe's unemployed had been out of work for longer than a year. As Jeremy Rifkin has pointed out, when an early wave of automation began taking its toll in America's manufacturing sector in the 1950s, the hardest hit were unskilled workers—particularly blacks. By 1964 black unemployment had reached 12 percent, against a previous postwar high of 8.5 percent. By contrast, white unemployment crawled up from 4.6 percent to 5.9 percent. 17 The same appears to be happening again. Virtually everywhere, "the inequality gap" between the rich and poor has widened.

偏执狂经理

The Paranoid Manager

前面的评论表明，管理者应该担心穷人而不是他们自己。 然而，在这个新的工作世界中，赢家和输家应该从心理和物质的角度来判断。 在这里，经理们的表现不太好。 对于所有关于赋权的讨论，大多数都是害怕和焦虑的生物。 许多因素都可以解释这种不安全感：最近的裁员浪潮； 事实上，管理者是保守的人，他们往往不喜欢改变，即使它是有益的，他们喜欢等级制度，即使它们是限制性的； 成为投资组合工作者的实际困难（如果您只是签订短期合同，请尝试安排抵押贷款）； 甚至可能是关于终生工作结束的无情宣传。

The preceding remarks suggest that managers should be worried about the poor and not themselves. However, the winners and losers in this new world of work should be judged in psychological as well as material terms. Here managers fare less well. For all the talk of empowerment, most are scared and anxious creatures. Any number of factors could account for this insecurity: the recent waves of downsizing; the fact that managers are conservative people who tend to dislike change, even if it is beneficial, and who like hierarchies, even if they are restrictive; the practical difficulties of being a portfolio worker (try arranging a mortgage if you are only on a short-term contract); even perhaps the relentless propaganda about the end of the job for life.

造成这种心理不安的主要原因可能是过度劳累。 发展中国家最大的问题之一（管理理论应该为此承担部分责任）是现代经济似乎将不断上升的失业率与工作人员更长的工作时间结合在一起。 总的来说，Handy 的规则（大约一半的人得到两倍的报酬却做三倍的工作）看起来有些夸张； 但是，即使他们的工作强度只是过去的一倍半，大多数员工仍感到心灰意冷。

The main contribution to this psychological unease is probably overwork. One of the developing world's biggest problems (and one for which management theory should take part of the blame) is that modern economies seem to combine rising unemployment with longer working hours for those in jobs. On balance, Handy's rule (about half the number of people being paid twice as much to do three times as much work) looks like an exaggeration; but, even if they are working only one-and-a-half times as hard as they used to, most workers feel shattered.

在《过度劳累的美国人》（1992 年）中，哈佛大学经济学家朱丽叶·肖尔计算出，她的同胞在 1989 年比 1969 年每年多花相当于 4 周的时间在工作上。美国人现在平均每周工作 52 小时——46 小时在办公室，还有 6 个在家里。 通勤时间变长，假期变短。 与工作有关的疾病，例如重复性劳损，是

In The Overworked American (1992), Juliet Schor, an economist at Harvard, calculated that her countrymen spent the equivalent of four weeks more a year on the job in 1989 than in 1969. The average American now works 52 hours a week—46 hours in the office and a further 6 at home. Commuting times have grown longer and holidays shorter. Work-related ailments, such as repetitive strain injury, are

工作的未来

The Future of Work

在上升。 根据麻省理工学院的一项研究，抑郁症每年给美国经济造成 470 亿美元的损失。 在日本，人们每年的工作时间比大多数欧洲人多 400 小时，他们甚至有一个词叫过劳死：kaoroshi

on the rise. According to one study by MIT, depression costs the American economy $47 billion a year. In Japan, where people work some 400 hours a year longer than most Europeans, they even have a word for death from overwork: kaoroshi

经理几乎总是工作最努力的人。 管理时尚再一次负有部分责任。 分层减少了可用于工作的经理人数。 再造迫使经理们负责整个过程：突然之间，你不再只是另一个研发经理； 相反，你负责整个“新产品开发”过程，负责销售和生产人员以及你熟悉的白大衣科学家团队。 如果一家公司将工作规格的数量从 1,300 人减少到 32 人——就像 Rosabeth Moss Kanter 访问过的一家电子公司所做的那样——那么你必然会增加经理的工作量。 公司的每位经理现在负责 24 名员工，而不仅仅是 12 名。

Managers are nearly always the hardest working of the lot. Once again, management fashion is partly responsible. Delayering reduces the number of managers available to do jobs. Reengineering forces managers to take charge of an entire process: suddenly you are no longer just another R&D manager; instead you are in charge of a whole "new product development" process, responsible for people from sales and production as well as your familiar team of white-coated scientists. If a company reduces the number of job specifications from 1,300 to 32—as did one electronics firm visited by Rosabeth Moss Kanter—then you are bound to increase a manager's workload. Each manager at the company now looks after 24 workers rather than just 12.

为了增加这些心理压力，长时间的时尚与灵活性的时尚齐头并进。 工人们常常全身心地投入到他们的公司中，几乎将他们的社交生活排除在外。 钻研报告取代了爱好； 电话网络取代了正常的社交活动。 人们为了到国外任职而扰乱家庭生活。 他们还在工作中建立了许多最牢固的友谊。 但突然间，公司进行了重组，他们变得过剩。 那些充实他们生活并赋予他们人生目标的东西从他们身边被夺走了。 过度劳累的公司员工突然变成了另一个失常的公民。

To add to these psychological strains, the fashion for long hours has gone hand in hand with the fashion for flexibility. Workers often devote themselves to their companies almost to the exclusion of their social lives. Poring over reports takes the place of hobbies; networking on the telephone takes over from normal socializing. People disrupt their family lives in order to take foreign postings. They also make many of their strongest friendships at work. But then suddenly the firm is reengineered, and they become surplus to requirements. The thing that has filled their days and given their life purpose is taken away from them. The overworked company man suddenly becomes just another anomic citizen.

有一天这可能会改变。 公司可能会雇佣更多的人，让他们工作更少。 工人们会同意以奇怪的轮班工作，以换取更少的工作时间和相同的报酬。 一些公司，包括惠普，已经沿着这些思路进行了试验。 但大多数公司宁愿让现有的员工工作到骨子里，并相应地奖励他们。 英国电信高管协会对英国电信经理的一项研究表明，每周工作 50 到 60 小时的人比那些没有工作的人更有可能在年度考核中获得前两名之一。 整个激励薪酬体系旨在说服全体员工——尤其是管理人员——更加努力地工作。

One day this may change. Companies may employ more people and make them work less. Workers will agree to work at strange shifts in exchange for working fewer hours and getting paid the same. A few companies, including Hewlett-Packard, have experimented along these lines. But most companies would rather work their existing workforce to the bone and reward them accordingly. A study of British Telecom managers by Britain's Society of Telecom Executives showed, perhaps unsurprisingly, that those who worked 50 to 60 hours a week were much more likely to get one of the top two grades in their annual reviews than those who did not. The whole system of incentive pay is geared toward persuading staff in general—and managers in particular—to work ever harder.

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

换句话说，新的工作秩序不是在生产“失业的经理”，而是在生产偏执的经理。 可能性仍然坚定地对他有利（仍然主要是“他的”而不是“她的”）：他将保住他的工作； 即使他失去了它，他也会很快重新就业； 他比以往任何时候都有更多的机会来决定他想在哪里工作； 他可能会更早获得更多权力； 而且他应该担心他的不熟练的同事而不是他自己。 让他精神错乱的不是概率，而是可能性：他可能成为少数被解雇并且不再受雇的经理之一； 技术将取代他的工作而不仅仅是让它变得更容易的可能性。 当他返回帕萨迪纳的家时， 这位多疑的经理并不认为他的新邻居是一名顾问，在家工作并且赚的钱比他想象的要多，这让他感到鼓舞，而是感到害怕。 而他自己的公司则利用这种不安全感，告诉他只有努力工作才能得到更多报酬。 怎样做才能让他更有安全感？

In other words, the new work order is producing not "the unemployed manager," but the paranoid manager. The probabilities remain firmly in his favor (it is still predominantly "his" rather than "her"): he will keep his job; even if he loses it, he will be reemployed fairly quickly; he has more opportunities than ever before to decide where he wants to work; he will probably be given more power earlier; and he should be worried about his unskilled colleagues rather than himself. It is not the probabilities that have unhinged him, but the possibilities: the possibility that he could be one of the minority of managers who get sacked and are not employed again; the possibility that technology will replace his job rather than just make it easier. As he commutes back to his home in Pasadena, the paranoid manager does not find the idea that his new neighbor is a consultant who works from home and earns more money than he does encouraging, but frightening. And his own company plays on this insecurity by telling him that he will only be paid more if he works harder. What can be done to make him feel more secure?

新道德契约

The New Moral Contract

几个世纪以来，人与社会之间的社会契约一直是哲学辩论的支柱。 管理理论的等价物是关于公司对其员工的责任的争论。 有人谈论雇主与雇员之间的“新道德契约”。 但是公司欠员工什么？ 管理理论提出了很多答案，从“除了高薪就什么都没有”到“就业能力”再到“公司的股份”。

The social contract between man and society has been a mainstay of philosophical debate for centuries. Management theory's equivalent is the dispute over the responsibilities a company owes to its workers. Some people talk about "a new moral contract" between employer and employee. But what does a company owe its workers? Management theory has proposed a number of answers, ranging from "nothing except a good pay packet" to "employability" to "a stake in the company."

对于很多老板来说，劳资关系可以归结为一个词：薪酬。 这不仅是大多数员工想要谈论的话题，而且在工作保障和薪资包的大小之间往往存在明显的权衡。 没有人会同情一个在几年内积累了数百万美元而被解雇的债券交易员。 许多人正是带着这个目标进入债券交易行业的。 如今，即使是最单调的工作也可以被“激励”。 大约十分之六的美国公司都有奖励员工绩效的制度。

For many bosses, employee-employer relations can be brought down to a single word: pay. Not only is this what most workers want to talk about, but there is often a clear trade-off between job security and the size of a pay packet. Nobody pities a bond trader who accumulates several million dollars in a few years before being sacked. Many people go into the bond trading business with exactly that aim. Nowadays, even the most humdrum jobs can be "incentivized." Roughly 6 out of 10 American companies have a system for rewarding their employees for performance.

薪酬是一个有吸引力的解决方案，尤其是对着迷于风险回报模型的经济学家而言。 但这不是一个完整的解决方案。 之一

Pay is an attractive solution, particularly to economists fascinated by risk-return models. But it is not a complete solution. One of

工作的未来

The Future of Work

中产阶级的焦虑最令人恼火的一点是，这种焦虑往往来自同一类人，他们决定从事市场营销而不是教学，因为他们认为后者太有保障而且薪水太低。 此外，激励薪酬仍然是一种生硬的工具，尤其是在任何组织中的较低级别。 在许多情况下，奖励性薪酬往往会增加而不是缓解偏执狂。 如果一群人做得非常好，并获得了他们可能获得的奖金的 96%，那么接受者的反应可能是有人偷走了他们应得奖金的 4%。
