the most irritating things about middle-class angst is that it often springs from exactly the same sort of people who decided to go into, say, marketing rather than teaching because they thought that the latter was too secure and badly paid. Moreover, incentive pay remains a blunt tool, particularly lower down in any organization. In many cases, incentive pay tends to increase paranoia rather than soothe it. If a group of people do extremely well and are rewarded 96 percent of their possible bonus, the likely response of the recipients will be that somebody has stolen 4 percent of what they deserved.

所以还需要更多东西。 “终生工作”的承诺是否符合要求？ 仍有相当多的公司通过为员工提供稳定的就业机会而获得回报。 例如，在 1990 年代初期路虎揽胜工厂推出以工作换生活的承诺之前，只有 11% 的员工费心参加年度“建议”竞赛，因为他们担心提高效率可能会让他们失去工作; 之后这一比例上升到 84%。 仅一项提议就为公司节省了 1 亿英镑——足以雇用一两个剩余工人。 日本和德国公司长期以来一直在审视这种权衡并得出了类似的结论，这导致他们在严格的经济逻辑本应将他们派往国外之后很长一段时间内将工作岗位留在国内。

So something more is needed. Does the promise of "a job for life" fit the bill? There are still a fair number of companies that reap the rewards from offering workers secure employment. For instance, before a jobs-for-life pledge was introduced at a Range Rover factory in the early 1990s, barely 11 percent of the employees bothered to enter an annual "suggestions" competition because they were worried that improved efficiency might cost them their jobs; afterward the proportion rose to 84 percent. One proposal alone saved the company £100 million—enough to employ one or two surplus workers. Japanese and German companies have long looked at this trade-off and reached a similar conclusion, which led them to keep jobs at home long after strict economic logic would have dispatched them abroad.

正如日本人和德国人最近发现的那样，问题在于这样的承诺往往是不可持续的。 1995 年，索尼做出了一个具有里程碑意义的决定，它不情愿地停止在日本生产出口电视。 在过去的五年里，梅赛德斯-奔驰和宝马一直在不懈地增加德国以外的生产，总是向他们昂贵的德国员工保证，新车仅用于出口，也许总有一天，路虎揽胜也会后悔自己的承诺。 它目前的模式可能会成功，但无法保证 2010 年也会如此。零售银行业或计算机生产领域的终身就业承诺不值一提。

As both the Japanese and the Germans have recently discovered, the problem is that such promises are often not sustainable. In 1995 Sony reached a landmark decision when it reluctantly stopped making televisions for export in Japan. Over the past five years Mercedes-Benz and BMW have relentlessly increased production outside Germany, always assuring their expensive German staff that the new cars are for export only One day, perhaps, Range Rover, too, will regret its promise. Its current models may be successful, but it is impossible to guarantee that the same will be true in 2010. A jobs-for-life pledge in retail banking or computer production is not worth the paper it is printed on.

就业还是可就业？

Employed or Employable?

乍一看，“终生就业能力”的概念似乎是一个糟糕的替代品。 例如，当 IBM 的员工关系主管在 1990 年代中期宣布“无条件终身雇用不再是游戏的名称；相反，它是终身的

At first glance, the concept of "lifetime employability" looks like a poor substitute. For instance, when IBM's director of employee relations announced in the mid-1990s that "unconditional lifetime employment is no longer the name of the game; instead it's lifelong

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

就业能力，”他只是面对事实。毕竟，自 1986 年以来，蓝色巨人已经解雇了 175,000 人。但告诉工人真相肯定比为他们提供终身工作并让他们对任何其他工作毫无准备要好。

employability," he was only facing facts. After all, Big Blue had laid off 175,000 people since 1986. But it is surely better to tell workers the truth than to offer them a job for life and leave them unprepared for any other employment.

在 Apple Computer 任职期间，约翰·斯卡利 (John Sculley) 向员工提出了一项“新的忠诚度”承诺：“Apple 不能向你承诺终身工作。即使是五年或十年。也许甚至几年都不会。但 Apple 能做什么？”可以——并且确实——承诺的是，无论你在船上呆三个月、六个月、六年，或者不太可能，十六年，你将不断学习，不断挑战。最后你会如果你没有花时间在我们这里，你在当地或全球劳动力市场上的地位显然会更好。”

During his tenure at Apple Computer, John Sculley offered staff a "new loyalty" pledge: "Apple can't promise you a job for life. Not even for five or ten years. Maybe not even for a couple of years. But what Apple can—and does—promise is that, whether you're aboard for three months, six months, six years, or, unlikely as it may be, sixteen years, you will be constantly learning, constantly challenged. At the end you will be demonstrably better positioned in the local or global labor market than you would have been had you not spent time with us."

“培训”是公司在谈论“就业能力”时经常引用的一个词。 总部位于硅谷的工业产品公司 Raychem 明确表示，其员工没有一个人终身有工作，但有学习的机会。 该公司甚至设有内部职业中心，帮助员工在公司其他部门或公司外找到新工作。 18 福特每年向其员工提供高达 3,100 美元的资金用于批准的课程。 Andersen Consulting 将其总收入的 6% 用于培训，员工平均每年在课堂上花费 135 小时。 ISS 是丹麦的一家清洁承包商，在为他们提供拖把和刷子之前，先让所有员工参加短期培训课程。

"Training" is a word often invoked by companies that talk about "employability." Raychem, an industrial products company based in Silicon Valley, has made it clear that none of its employees has a guaranteed job for life, but it has guaranteed the opportunity to learn. The firm even has an in-house careers center to help employees get new jobs either in other parts of the company or outside the firm. 18 Ford offers its staff up to $3,100 a year to spend on approved courses. Andersen Consulting spends 6 percent of its gross revenues on training, and the average employee spends 135 hours each year in a classroom. ISS, a Danish cleaning contractor, sends all its employees on a short training course before giving them their mops and brushes.

人们会想象“支持”训练就像“反对”殴打妻子一样。 一家不关心员工情绪状态，更不用说他们的长期就业能力的公司有很多充分的理由投资于他们的教育。 然而，美国公司在员工教育上的支出仅相当于其工资总额的 1.4% 左右。

One would imagine that being "for" training is like being "against" wife-beating. There are many good reasons for a company that does not care about the emotional state of its staff, let alone their long-term employability, to invest in their education. However, American companies spend the equivalent of only about 1.4 percent of their payroll on educating their workers.

此类统计数据总是被培训行业用来刺激雇主和政府提供更多课程。 然而，知识本身并不能完全保证某些人认为的就业能力。 问题是很多知识都是你工作的公司特有的：如果你搬到汉堡王，你在麦当劳非常了解财务总监这一事实对你没有多大帮助。 知识也是特定于工作的，而不是特定于公司的。 如果您受雇于 General Electric 的电视部门 NBC，您的 Rolodex 是否能帮上大忙值得怀疑

Such statistics are always seized on by the training industry to goad employers and governments into providing more courses. However, knowledge, on its own, is not quite the guarantee of employability that some people suppose. The problem is that a good deal of knowledge is specific to the company you work for: the fact that at McDonald's you know the finance director really well does not help you much if you move to Burger King. Knowledge is also job specific, not company specific. If you are employed by General Electric's television arm, NBC, it is doubtful that your Rolodex will be much help

工作的未来

The Future of Work

如果你被调到它的涡轮机制造部门。 即使工作更相似，人们也往往需要时间才能适应。许多擅长销售冰淇淋的联合利华品牌经理在鱼条方面都失败了。

if you are moved to its turbine-making division. Even when the jobs are more similar, it often takes people time to settle in. Many a Unilever brand manager who has been good at selling ice cream has flopped when it came to fish sticks.

出于同样的原因，仅仅为了提高员工的就业能力而调动员工并不总是符合公司的利益：这可能会破坏员工对特定雇主的主要价值（他们的知识）以及他们作为团队成员的感觉。 就业能力既是雇员的责任，也是雇主的责任。

By the same token, it is not always in the company's interest to move people around just to improve their employability: it can destroy the workers' main value to that particular employer (their knowledge) and their sense of being a team member. Employability is as much the employee's responsibility as the employer's.

工会和利益相关者

Unions and Stakeholders

自然地，如果知识工作者对雇主有一定的权力，他们就更有能力扩大他们的名片夹并更新他们的教育。 至少在理论上，公司几乎在所有地方都在“赋予”员工权力。 麻省理工学院估计 80% 的美国雇主参与了某种责任或赋权计划。 毫不奇怪，工人们并不完全相信。 他们想要结构和文字。 对无能为力的传统反应是联合工会。 然而，从日本到苏格兰，工会正在撤退。 美国私营部门工人中只有大约十分之一属于工会。 即使在工会会员资格相当不错的斯堪的纳维亚半岛，年轻人加入工会的可能性也只有他们父母的一半。 更差， 人们怀疑知识工作者的工会是否有意义。 19 战线肯定远非固定的，敌对双方按阶级和金钱划分。 工会往往是男性，以制造业为导向的团体，擅长与通用汽车等恐龙谈判，而不是小型多媒体公司。 大多数知识工作者的问题都与合同、授权、就业能力、育儿假和兼职工作有关。

Naturally, knowledge workers are in a stronger position to expand their Rolodex and renew their education if they have some power over their employer. In theory at least, companies are "empowering" workers just about everywhere. MIT reckons that 80 percent of employers in America participate in some kind of responsibility or empowerment program. Not surprisingly, workers are not entirely convinced. They want structures as well as words. The traditional response to powerlessness has been to band together in unions. However, from Japan to Scotland unions are in retreat. Only about 1 in 10 of America's private sector workers belong to a union. Even in Scandinavia, where union membership has held up reasonably well, young people are only half as likely to join unions as their parents. Worse, there are doubts about whether unions for knowledge workers even make sense. 19 The battle lines are certainly far from fixed, with the opposing sides divided by class and money. Unions tend to be male, manufacturing-oriented groups that are good at negotiating with dinosaurs such as General Motors, not small multimedia companies. Most of the knowledge worker's problems have to do with contracts, empowerment, employability, parental leave, and part-time work.

坦率地说，工会的变化远小于公司。 具有讽刺意味的是，工会问题的解决方案可能就在他们自己的历史书中。 大多数工会都起源于古代工匠行会。 如果时光倒流，他们会做得更好。 从这个角度来看，好莱坞8000名编剧的工会美国编剧协会很有意思。 许多工作室负责人仍然将行会视为共产主义的温床。 它也有过毫无意义的罢工。 然而，它的基本结构是面向

Put bluntly, unions have changed far less than companies have. Ironically, the solution to the unions' problems maybe sitting in their own history books. Most unions grew out of ancient guilds of craftsmen. If they could turn back the clock, they would do much better. From this point of view, the Writer's Guild Of America, the union for Hollywood's 8,000 scriptwriters, is interesting. Many studio chiefs still regard the guild as a hotbed of communism. It has also had its share of pointless strikes. However, its basic structure is oriented

大辩论

THE GREAT DEBATES

为一组个人而不是一个统一的暴徒提供服务。 除了与工作室就不同类型的剧本协商固定的最低费率外，行会还为其知识工作者提供养老金和健康计划以及法律咨询。 它的律师已经为多媒体程序员起草了标准合同。

toward providing services for a set of individuals rather than one uniform mob. As well as negotiating fixed minimum rates with the studios for different sorts of scripts, the guild offers its knowledge workers pension and health plans and legal advice. Its lawyers have already drawn up standard contracts for multimedia programers.

在意大利甚至英国等其他地方也出现了类似的迹象，表明更开明的工会如雨后春笋般涌现。 但越来越多的理论家认为，如果不进行某种结构性改变，雇主和雇员之间就不会有新的道德契约。 在大多数情况下，这意味着改变公司的公司治理，以牺牲股东利益为代价，赋予员工等利益相关者更多权力。 第 8 章讨论了这是否合理。值得注意的是，到目前为止，人们工作方式的变化本身并不能证明改变股东资本主义是必要的。 首先，我们必须将未来知识产业在“善良”的利益相关者德国的匮乏与它们在“残酷”的利益相关者美国的蓬勃发展进行比较。

There are similar signs of more enlightened unions springing up in other places such as Italy and even Britain. But an increasing number of theorists believe that there will be no new moral contract between employers and employees without some kind of structural change. In most cases this means a change in the corporate governance of the firm to give stakeholders such as employees more power at the expense of shareholders. Whether that is justified on any grounds was discussed in Chapter 8. It is worth noting that so far the changes in the way that people work do not by themselves seem to warrant changing shareholder capitalism. For a start, one has to compare the dearth of futuristic knowledge industries in "kind" stakeholder Germany with the flowering of them in "cruel" shareholder America.

对股东资本主义罪恶的大惊小怪是对未来工作产生的所有恐慌中的最后一个（也许也是最危险的）。 就像工作和中层经理，以及情节中所有其他被认为注定要失败的角色一样，公司将继续存在——也许以略有不同的形式——但它显然仍然是同一件事。 阅读大量关于工作场所未来的文献，让人想起 1960 年代那些曾预测世纪末的书籍。 每天开始时，人们都会爬上一套多功能的多功能套装，然后吃一颗早餐丸。 事实上，衬衫、裙子和领带仍然存在（尽管款式和面料与 1960 年代不同）； 早餐也是如此，尽管我们现在吃含低脂牛奶的牛奶什锦早餐，而不是含奶油的玉米片。

The fuss about the iniquities of shareholder capitalism is the last (and perhaps most dangerous) of all the panics arising about the future of work. Like the job and the middle manager, and all the other supposedly doomed characters in the plot, the company will live on—perhaps in a slightly different shape-but it will still manifestly be the same thing. Reading much of the literature about the future of the workplace, one is reminded of those books in the 1960s that used to forecast the end of the century. Each day would begin with people clambering into an all-in-one, omnipurpose suit and taking a single breakfast pill. The fact is that shirts, skirts, and ties are still around (albeit in styles and fabrics different from those of the 1960s); and so is breakfast, although we now eat muesli with low-fat milk rather than cornflakes with cream. The most horrifying thing about "the future of work" may be just how familiar it will be.

第四部分

PART FOUR

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

第 10 章

CHAPTER 10

欧洲出产的管理巨星少之又少。 但毫无疑问，电气工程巨头 ABB Asea Brown Boveri 的老板珀西·巴内维克 (Percy Barnevik) 无疑符合这一要求。 一个高大、留着胡子、说话很快的瑞典人，以一个精力充沛的人的不安分的态度，Barnevik 赢得了他的职业所能授予的几乎所有荣誉，从“新兴市场年度 CEO”到（两次）“欧洲最受尊敬的公司。” 在《哈佛商业评论》等地，他的名字被管理专家删除的频率几乎与通用电气的杰克韦尔奇的名字一样频繁。 差距正在迅速缩小。 “我们最大的竞争对手不再是 GE，”一位日本竞争对手承认道。 “我们最要提防的就是ABB。”

Europe has produced unusually few management superstars. But one man who unquestionably fits the bill is Percy Barnevik, the boss of electrical engineering giant ABB Asea Brown Boveri. A tall, bearded, and fast-talking Swede, with the restless manner of a man overendowed with energy, Barnevik has won almost every honor his profession can bestow, from "emerging markets' CEO of the year" to (twice) boss of "Europe's most respected company." His name is dropped by the management panjandrums at places like the Harvard Business Review almost as frequently as that of Jack Welch of General Electric. And the gap is closing fast. "Our greatest rival is no longer GE," confesses one Japanese competitor. "The one we have to be most on guard against is ABB."

这一次，夸张在很大程度上是有道理的。 赞扬 Barnevik 的原因有很多。 首先，他展示了一家公司如何可以同时变大和变小：ABB 由 1,300 家独立的公司组成，分为 5,000 个利润中心。 他还开创了内部基准测试、卓越中心和企业管家等流行做法。 也许他最重要的品质是他对全球化的理解。

For once, the hyperbole is largely warranted. There are several reasons to praise Barnevik. To begin with, he has shown how a company can be big and small at the same time: ABB consists of 1,300 separate companies divided into 5,000 profit centers. He has also pioneered such popular practices as internal benchmarking, centers of excellence, and corporate parenting. Perhaps his foremost quality is his understanding of globalization.

传统观点认为，世界市场将逐渐变得越来越同质化。 在 Barnevik 看来，情况不会那么简单。 虽然纯粹是国企

Conventional wisdom has it that world markets will gradually become more and more homogeneous. In Barnevik's view, the picture will not be quite that simple. Although purely national companies

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

随着政府放松管制以及旅行和信息成本的暴跌，市场将很难繁荣发展，市场将继续存在差异。 因此，对于公司来说，在当地市场扎根很重要。 Barnevik 推动了他所谓的“多元文化跨国公司”结构——一个多元化的国际化企业集团，足以响应当地口味，但又足够团结，其价值超过其各部分的总和。

will have little chance of thriving as governments deregulate and as the cost of travel and information plummets, markets will continue to differ. Thus it will be important for companies to keep deep roots in local markets. Barnevik pushes for what he calls a "multicultural multinational" structure—a cosmopolitan conglomerate diverse enough to respond to local tastes but united enough to amount to more than the sum of its parts.

1988 年，Barnevik 从两家拥有百年历史的公司中组建了 ABB：ASEA，他从 1980 年开始经营的瑞典工程集团，以及同样引以为豪的瑞士竞争对手 Brown Boveri。 从那时起，该公司参与了 100 多项收购和合资企业，业务扩展到东欧和亚洲，并在 40 个国家/地区增加了 18,000 名员工（经过多次裁员）。

In 1988 Barnevik fashioned ABB from two century-old companies: ASEA, the Swedish engineering group that he had run since 1980, and Brown Boveri, an equally proud Swiss competitor. Since then, the company has been involved in more than 100 acquisitions and joint ventures, expanding into Eastern Europe and Asia, and adding (after many layoffs) 18,000 workers in 40 countries.

Barnevik 对如何将这个不同的帝国结合在一起进行了大量思考。 他强迫所有员工阅读他的“圣经”，这是一本关于公司目标和价值观的小册子。 他将英语作为公司的官方语言，尽管只有三分之一的员工以英语为母语（Barnevik 本人有明显的瑞典口音）。 他将 ABB 的总部迁至苏黎世，这样合并就不会看起来像瑞典的收购。 但他让总部员工人数较少（目前来自 19 个国家的 171 人），以避免给人留下 ABB 现在是一家瑞士公司的印象。 在裁员时，他相当平均地分摊了负担，尽管据说他对自己的祖国瑞典过于严厉； 他曾经在那里需要一名保镖来保护他免受愤怒的前雇员的伤害。

Barnevik has put a lot of thought into how to bind this disparate empire together. He forces all employees to read his "bible," a short booklet on the company's aims and values. He made English his firm's official language, although only a third of the employees speak it as their mother tongue (Barnevik himself has a noticeable Swedish accent). He moved ABB's headquarters to Zurich so that the merger would not look like a Swedish takeover. But he keeps the headquarters staff small (currently 171 people from 19 countries) in order to avoid the impression that ABB is now a Swiss company. In making cuts, he spread the burden fairly evenly, although it is said that he treats his native Sweden rather too harshly; he once needed a bodyguard there to protect him from angry former employees.

ABB 通过由 500 名全球经理组成的精英干部培养多元文化主义，这是巴内维克精心挑选的禁卫军，特别关注其成员的文化敏感性，以及他们的配偶快速从一个地方搬到另一个地方的意愿。 根据 Barnevik 的说法，这些管理人员比黄金更有价值，他们将组织团结在一起，并将专业知识传授到世界各地。 另一个协调设备是 Abacus，这是一个对公司所有员工开放的信息系统。 Abacus 收集公司 5,000 个利润中心中每个利润中心的数据，并将它们的绩效与以当地货币和美元计算的预算和预测进行比较。 公司还使用该系统传播最佳实践，

ABB has fostered multiculturalism through an elite cadre of 500 global managers, a praetorian guard that Barnevik selects carefully, paying particular attention to the cultural sensitivity of its members, and to their spouses' willingness to move from place to place quickly. Worth more than their weight in gold, according to Barnevik, these managers knit the organization together and transfer expertise around the world. Another coordinating device is Abacus, an information system that is open to all the company's employees. Abacus collects data on each of the company's 5,000 profit centers and compares their performance with budgets and forecasts in both the local currency and American dollars. The company also uses the system to spread best practice, sending out a chart of the relative performance of various divisions in ABB and encouraging the worst performers to learn lessons from the best.

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

然而，最终，ABB 的企业粘合剂归结为 Barnevik 自己的不懈努力。 世界各地的 ABB 人都对他每晚只睡四个小时的能力以及他对组织的每个角落的熟悉程度充满敬意。 他估计他每年都会与 5,500 名员工进行个人谈话。 他每周只在总部呆几天（通常是周六和周日）； 其余大部分时间，他都在公务机的空中办公室里。 Barnevik 说明了现代管理的悖论之一：公司越是试图下放权力，它就越是依赖强大的领导者。

In the end, however, ABB's corporate glue comes down to Barnevik's own relentlessness. ABBers around the world speak reverently about his ability to get by on four hours sleep a night and his familiarity with every nook and cranny of the organization. He reckons that he speaks personally to 5,500 of his employees every year. He spends only a couple of days a week at headquarters (often Saturday and Sunday); much of the rest of the time he is in an airborne office in a corporate jet. Barnevik illustrates one of the paradoxes of modern management: that the more a company tries to devolve power, the more it relies on a strong leader.

Barnevik 说，ABB 背后的想法只不过是常识。 他问道，在头脑正常的情况下，谁不想既全球化又本土化？ 又有谁认为你可以通过践踏地方差异而在全球取得胜利？ 他补充说，他的任务中唯一棘手的部分是管理如此复杂的组织。 但 Barnevik 低估了自己。 多元文化跨国公司实际上是从管理理论最持久的争论之一：围绕全球化的争论中得出的最复杂的解决方案。

Barnevik says that the thinking behind ABB is little more than common sense. Who in their right mind, he asks, would not want to be both global and local? And who on earth thinks that you can triumph globally by trampling on local differences? The only tricky part of his task, he adds, is managing such a complicated organization. But Barnevik undersells himself. The multicultural multinational is in fact the most sophisticated solution to emerge from one of management theory's most enduring debates: the one surrounding globalization.

时机已到的想法

An Idea Whose Time Has Come

在这位管理大师的词典中，没有一个词像“全球化”那样被人们津津乐道。 走进任何一家书店的商业区，你会看到几乎所有其他书上都印有这个词； 与任何一家大公司的董事长交谈，不久之后，您就会发现它开始主导谈话。 全球化——以及如何应对它——现在是几乎每一家大型跨国公司的主要关注点（有些人会说是存在的理由）：它影响到他们的办公室和工厂的位置、他们的产品以及他们雇用的人。 这也是数以千计的小公司日益关注的问题。 1994 年，即使在像美国这样大的国内市场，员工人数少于 500 人的公司中也有 20% 出口了一些商品或服务——而且这一比例还在迅速增长。 1个

Of all the words in the management guru's lexicon, none is used with quite so much relish as "globalization." Go into the business section of any bookstore, and you will see the word emblazoned on almost every other book; talk to the chairman of any big company, and, before long, you will find that it starts dominating the conversation. Globalization—and how to deal with it—is now the leading concern (some would say the raison d'etre) of nearly every big multinational company: it affects where they have their offices and factories, what they make, and who they employ. It is also a growing concern for thousands of smaller firms. Even in a domestic market as big as America's, 20 percent of the firms with fewer than 500 people exported some good or service in 1994—and the proportion is growing quickly. 1

过去十年，世界经济在一体化方面取得了巨大进步。 各国政府通过关税及贸易总协定 (GATT) 的乌拉圭回合以及在国内逐步降低国际贸易壁垒

Huge strides toward integrating the world economy have been made in the past decade. Governments have progressively lowered trade barriers both internationally, through the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and within

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

区域，通过欧盟、北美自由贸易协定 (NAFTA) 和拉丁美洲的南方共同市场。 世界各地的政府现在不再将跨国公司视为需要避免的掠夺者，而是投资、建议和最重要的就业机会的来源。 就连曾经承诺要将资本主义走狗从地球表面抹去的中国政府，现在也邀请他们来办厂。 在过去十年中，在全球范围内，外国直接投资的增长速度是世界产出的四倍，是世界贸易的三倍：1995 年跨国公司在海外投资了 3250 亿美元。 大约三分之一的贸易流量是单个公司内部的支付这一事实表明，大多数公司的生产系统遍布全球。 据联合国称，有近40,000“

regions, through the European Union, the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), and Latin America's Mercosur. Governments everywhere now regard global companies not as predators to be avoided but as sources of investment, advice, and above all jobs. Even the Chinese government, which once promised to wipe the capitalist running dogs from the surface of the earth, now invites them to set up factories. Worldwide, over the past decade, foreign direct investment has been growing four times as fast as world output and three times faster than world trade: in 1995 multinationals invested $325 billion overseas. The fact that roughly a third of trade flows are payments within individual companies shows that most companies have production systems stretching around the world. According to the United Nations, there are close to 40,000 "transnational" companies, three times the figure 25 years ago. Together they control about a third of all private sector assets, and their combined GDP in 1993 was $5.5 trillion—almost as much as that of the United States.

也许比统计数据更能说明问题的是态度的变化。 在过去，全球化是关于一家大公司懒洋洋地在世界范围内推出一种产品。 现在，像微软这样相对较小的公司可以同时从上海到圣地亚哥推出像Windows 95 这样相对复杂的产品。 对于很多管理者来说，当地国际机场的商务休息室比自己的客厅还熟悉。 与此同时，即使是那些设法避免这种生活的人，也会花很多时间与国外的供应商、客户和同事交谈。 您可以在 Internet 上向开罗发送消息，就像向芝加哥发送消息一样容易。 如前所述，随着“距离的消亡”，通过电话与世界另一端的人交谈很快将几乎不花什么钱。

More telling perhaps than the statistics is the change in attitudes. In the old days, globalization was about a big company lazily rolling out a product across the world. Now, a relatively small company such as Microsoft can launch a relatively sophisticated product such as Windows 95 simultaneously from Shanghai to San Diego. For many managers, the business lounge of the local international airport is more familiar than their own living room. Meanwhile, even those people who manage to avoid this sort of life spend a good part of their day talking to suppliers, customers, and colleagues in foreign places. You can send a message on the Internet to Cairo as easily as to Chicago. With "the death of distance," as mentioned earlier, it will soon cost virtually nothing to talk to somebody on the other side of the world by telephone.

世界正在变小的想法似乎很简单。 然而，在管理理论中，它并不是那么一成不变。 第一个问题是定义。 尽管在管理书籍中无处不在，但“全球化”并没有标准含义。 前一刻，它可以指代全球营销活动，下一刻可以指代某种组织矩阵，或者指代国界的无关紧要。 全球化不是一个连贯的概念，而是一种模糊的感觉。 如果不是因为人们对全球化的期望过高，这可能就不那么重要了。 人们最常从这片云中摘取的三个想法——全球化将迎来标准化时代

The notion that the world is getting smaller seems straightforward enough. Yet in management theory it is not so cut-and-dried. The first problem is definition. Despite its ubiquity in management books, "globalization" has no standard meaning. One moment, it can refer to a worldwide marketing campaign, the next to some kind of organizational matrix, or to the irrelevance of national frontiers. Globalization is not a coherent concept, but a fuzzy feeling. This might matter less were it not for people's exaggerated expectations in globalization's regard. The three ideas that people have most often plucked out of this cloud—that globalization would usher in an era of standardized

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

“全球”产品； 那些大的、全球性的公司会取得胜利； 并且地理无关紧要 - 已经证明是神话。

"global" products; that big, global companies would triumph; and that geography would not matter—have turned out to be myths.

全球化的三个迷思

The Three Myths of Globalization

也许对全球化现象的定义最明确的尝试出现在西奥多·莱维特 (Theodore Levitt) 发表于 1983 年 5 月至 6 月期的哈佛商业评论上的一篇文章“市场的全球化”中。 哈佛大学最受尊敬的营销大师莱维特提出了一个极端但连贯一致的建议：他说，技术正在创造“一个新的商业现实——全球市场以前所未有的规模出现。” 世界将被标准化产品和具有普遍吸引力的品牌所主宰，例如可口可乐。 按照莱维特的推理，基督徒和穆斯林可能崇拜不同的神，但他们仍然需要洗头——而且他们想要最好的产品来完成这项工作。 忽视“肤浅”的跨国公司 区域和国家差异以及通过在各地以相同方式销售相同产品来利用规模经济，不仅会很快排挤本地小公司，还会排挤老牌跨国公司，因为它们一直试图“尊重”当地的怪癖和过失. “地球是圆的，”莱维特争辩道，“但是，对于大多数目的来说，把它当作平的是明智的。”

Perhaps the clearest attempt at a definition of the globalization phenomenon appears in "The Globalization of Markets," an article by Theodore Levitt that appeared in the May-June 1983 issue of the Harvard Business Review. Levitt, Harvard's most respected marketing guru, put forward an extreme, though admirably coherent, suggestion: technology, he said, was producing "a new commercial reality— the emergence of global markets on a previously unimagined scale of magnitude." The world would be dominated by standardized products and universally appealing brands such as Coca-Cola. Christians and Muslims, went Levitt's reasoning, may worship different gods, but they still have to wash their hair—and they want the best product to do the job. Global companies that ignored "superficial" regional and national differences and exploited economies of scale by selling the same things in the same way everywhere would soon push aside not only small local companies but also the old multinational company that spent all its time trying to be "respectful" of local quirks and peccadilloes. "The earth is round," argued Levitt, "but, for most purposes, it's sensible to treat it as flat."

这个未来——由全球经理人经营的巨型公司像许多巨人一样横跨莱维特扁平化的世界，并满足全球幻想，比如让地球上每个男人、女人和孩子都能触手可及的软饮料——正是这样的事情，许多经理多年来一直梦想着。 毕竟，如果不违背地理条件，成为一家大公司还有什么意义呢？ 关于跨国公司的经典著作之一是海湾主权（菲利普弗农，1971 年出版）。 菲亚特公司董事奥雷里奥·佩切伊曾声称，跨国公司“是社会国际化最强大的推动者”。 Carl Ger-stacker，曾任陶氏化学董事长，承认“

This future—where gigantic firms run by global managers bestrode Levitt's flattened world like so many colossi and entertained global fantasies such as putting a soft drink within arm's reach of every man, woman, and child on the planet—was exactly the sort of thing that many managers had dreamed about for years. After all, what was the point of being a big company if not to defy geography? One of the classic books on multinationals was called Sovereignty at Bay (by Philip Vernon, published in 1971). Aurelio Peccei, a director of Fiat, once claimed that the multinational corporation "is the most powerful agent for the internationalization of society." Carl Ger-stacker, sometime chairman of Dow Chemical, confessed that "I have long dreamed of buying an island owned by no nation and of establishing the world headquarters of the Dow company on the truly neutral ground of such an island, beholden to no nation or society."

这并没有发生。 大多数相同的产品可以以相同的方式到处销售的想法已经彻底

This has not happened. The idea that most of the same products can be sold everywhere in the same way has been thoroughly

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

名誉扫地。 诚然，一些大件物品（例如大型喷气式飞机）存在全球市场，尽管参观波音公司西雅图工厂的任何人都会接受长篇大论，讲述每架飞机的制造方式都不同，以满足公司的需求。顾客。 同样真实的是，有一些利基产品以相同的方式在世界范围内吸引了广泛相同的人：在采访中被骚扰的全球主义者总是引用的一个是经济学人杂志。 然而，在广大的消费市场上，一项又一项的调查显示，真正的全球品牌只有少数，如可口可乐、麦当劳和万宝路，即使是这屈指可数的品牌，在中国也肯定不是一个意思。 ，比如说，北京（在那里他们都是地位的象征），就像他们在巴尔的摩所做的那样。

discredited. True, there is a global market for a few big-ticket items—jumbo jets, for instance, although anybody who visits Boeing's factory in Seattle will be given a long lecture about the fact that every aircraft is made differently in order to satisfy the firm's customers. Also true, there are a few niche products that appeal to broadly the same people in the same way around the world: one invariably cited by harassed globalists in interviews is the magazine, The Economist. In the broad consumer market, however, survey after survey has shown that there are only a few truly global brands, such as Coca-Cola, McDonald's, and Marlboro, and even the items in this select handful certainly do not mean the same thing in, say, Beijing (where they are all status symbols), as they do in Baltimore.

仔细观察可口可乐的战略就会发现，对于所有无处不在的“永远是可口可乐”的广告，这家亚特兰大公司利用而不是忽视了国家差异。 它使用独立的当地装瓶商将其产品推向当地市场。 它还会在不同国家/地区调整产品的配方——有时在这些国家/地区内部。 在日本，日本南部人喜欢他们的可口可乐比东京人稍微甜一点，公司也同意了。 在销售其他饮料时，可口可乐采用了非常本地化的策略。 可口可乐三分之二的日本产品是专门为当地市场生产的：例如佐治亚咖啡，在东京随处可见，但在可口可乐的佐治亚总部却鲜为人知。

A close look at Coca-Cola's strategy shows that, for all the ubiquitous "Always Coca-Cola" advertisements, the Atlanta company exploits rather than ignores national differences. It uses independent local bottlers to get its products to local markets. It also tweaks the product's recipe from country to country—and sometimes within them. In Japan, the southern Japanese like their Coca-Cola slightly sweeter than people in Tokyo, and the company obliges. And when it comes to selling other drinks, Coke adopts a very local strategy. Two-thirds of Coca-Cola's Japanese products are made specifically for the local market: Georgia Coffee, for example, can by seen everywhere in Tokyo but is unknown in Coca-Cola's Georgia home.

几乎每个全球品牌都不得不对当地口味做出让步，以实现其无处不在。 在日本，麦当劳跌跌撞撞，直到它允许一位当地企业家在东京市中心开设小型小吃店，而不是母公司青睐的大型郊区餐馆； 他还确保汉堡是用当地的肉做的，这种肉比美国用的肉肥得多，甚至把罗纳德改成了唐纳德麦当劳，因为日本人发音“r”有困难。 同样在日本，麦当劳的汉堡包可选配红烧酱（就像在墨西哥配红辣椒一样）。 可口可乐的老对手百事可乐也在各国调整配方和信息。 例如，在上海，它不得不放弃 Cindy Crawford' 她的魅力（因为当地人不知道她是谁），它不得不重新命名为“7-Up”，因为在当地方言中，这句话的意思是“喝酒致死”。 通常产品可以跳一个边界而不是两个边界：米奇

Virtually every global brand has had to make concessions to local taste in order to achieve its ubiquity. In Japan, McDonald's stumbled until it allowed a local entrepreneur to set up small snack-bars in the center of Tokyo, rather than the large suburban eateries favored by the parent company; he also ensured that burgers were made with local meat, which is much fattier than that used in America, and even changed Ronald to Donald McDonald because the Japanese have difficulty pronouncing "r." Also in Japan, McDonald's hamburgers come with optional Teriyaki sauce (just as they come with chili peppers in Mexico). Coke's old rival, PepsiCo, also adjusts both its recipe and its message from country to country. For instance, in Shanghai it has had to dispense with Cindy Crawford's charms (because the locals do not know who she is), and it has had to rename "7-Up" because in the local dialect, the phrase means "death through drinking." Often products can jump one border but not two: Mickey

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

老鼠和同伴成功进入东京的迪斯尼乐园，但在巴黎失败了。

Mouse and company were hurdled successfully into Tokyo's Disneyland but flopped in Paris.

如果说有什么不同的话，那就是近年来的营销已经着迷于对客户进行细分，而不是将他们捆绑在一起。 回到 1983 年，莱维特写道，他假设美国是一个市场。 从那时起，向“带连字符的美国人”（例如亚裔美国人）进行营销一直是一项蓬勃发展的业务。 比如说，在出售一辆吉普车时，以不同的方式接近堪萨斯州的一位可能会实际使用它的农民，这与洛杉矶的一位只会摆姿势的律师不同。 信息技术正在推动营销进入更具体的领域，使用从结账扫描仪和信用卡收据中提取的数据来挑选更小的人群，然后将这些人群作为直邮和定制产品的“目标”。

If anything, marketing in recent years has become obsessed with segmenting customers rather than bundling them together. Back in 1983 Levitt wrote as if he assumed that America was one market. Since then, marketing to "hyphenated Americans" (such as Asian-Americans) has been a booming business. It makes sense when selling, say, a Jeep to approach a farmer in Kansas, who might actually use it, in a different way from an attorney in Los Angeles, who will only pose in it. And information technology is driving marketing into ever more particular areas, using data culled from checkout scanners and credit-card receipts to pick out smaller groups of people, who are then "targeted" with direct mail and tailored products.

最重视莱维特建议的公司可能是英国的盛世长城。 萨奇兄弟对《哈佛商业评论》上的这篇文章印象深刻，邀请莱维特加入他们的董事会。 宣称，“大则好；好则更好；两者兼而有之”； 并一头扎进了扩张中。 这适合 Saatchi 的一些客户，尤其是英国航空公司，他们以“全球”口号告终：“世界上最受欢迎的航空公司”。 但许多客户希望当地代理商的分布范围更广，并抱怨 Saatchi 只是在地图上向他们提供点。 股东们的处境更糟，因为该机构大大超出了自己的范围。 它的股价跌至之前水平的五十分之一，萨奇兄弟最终在 1995 年初被迫退出。

The firm that took Levitt's advice most seriously perhaps was Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi. Impressed by the article in the Harvard Business Review, the Saatchi brothers invited Levitt to sit on their board; proclaimed, "To be big is good; to be good is better; to be both is best"; and threw themselves headlong into an expansion. This suited a few of Saatchi's clients, notably British Airways, which ended up with a "global" slogan: "The World's Favorite Airline." But many customers wanted to have a wider spread of local agencies and complained that Saatchi was just offering them dots on the map. Shareholders fared even worse, as the agency greatly overreached itself. Its share price fell to a fiftieth of its previous level, and the Saatchi brothers were eventually pushed out in early 1995.

自莱维特撰写他的文章以来的这些年里，从全球化中获益最多的往往是小公司，而不是大公司。 全球化非但没有让少数几家大公司瓜分世界，反而显然让这些公司陷入了卑微的竞争之中。 随着贸易壁垒的降低、放松管制的普及以及运输和通讯成本的直线下降，一家公司不再需要成为一个庞大的跨国组织才能在全球市场上进行贸易。 在许多国家，传统跨国公司的主要资源——它精心培养的与政府的关系以及耗费巨资积累的当地监管怪癖知识——的价值已经缩水。

In the years since Levitt wrote his article, it has often been small companies rather than big ones that have gained most from globalization. Far from allowing a handful of giant firms to carve up the world between them, globalization has clearly subjected these firms to humbling competition. With the lowering of trade barriers, the spread of deregulation, and the plummeting of transport and communication costs, a firm no longer needs to be a huge multinational organization in order to trade in the global marketplace. In many countries the traditional multinational's prime resources—its carefully cultivated relationships with the government and expensively accumulated knowledge of local regulatory quirks—have dwindled in value. Microsoft and Swatch both manage to sell software and watches around the world despite keeping most of their employees in Seattle and Switzerland.

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

其他的发展也让小公司得以进入大型跨国公司的领地。 资本市场放松管制使更多的小公司有可能借到大笔资金。 由于及时生产和精益生产等制造技术的传播，跨国公司不再垄断管理智慧。 事实上，盗版、逆向工程和其他形式的工业盗窃的流行已经粉碎了对他们自己想法的垄断。 信息技术价格的下降让小公司能够从事曾经属于巨头公司的那种依赖信息的创新。 事实上，许多巨头发现自己处于明显的劣势，因为他们的计算机系统，

Other developments, too, have allowed smaller companies to muscle in on the big multinational's territory. The deregulation of the capital markets has made it possible for more small companies to borrow serious money. Thanks to the spread of manufacturing techniques, such as just-in-time production and lean manufacturing, multinationals no longer have a monopoly of managerial wisdom. In fact, an epidemic of pirating, reverse engineering, and other forms of industrial theft has crushed the monopoly even on their own ideas. And the falling price of information technology allows smaller companies to engage in the sort of information-dependent innovation that was once the preserve of the giants. Indeed, many of the giants have found themselves at a distinct disadvantage because their computer systems, expensively installed at the dawn of the computer age, have become hopeless anachronisms.

彼得·德鲁克 (Peter Drucker) 等大师充分强调了这样一个事实，即带领美国、英国和德国走出最近的衰退的出口商都是小公司——通常是专家。 其中一位是德鲁克在加利福尼亚州的邻居，他为医院制造特殊的医疗蜂鸣器。 2 德鲁克早已不再对这个人出售设备的地方感到惊讶。 邻居说，这份工作相当没有风险。 自从 1960 年代英镑贬值的惨痛经历后，该男子就以美元向客户收费，从而消除了汇率风险。 “语言和文化呢？” 德鲁克从大阪安装新系统回来后，曾问过他的朋友。 “我不需要了解日本，”男人回答道。 “我了解医院。”

Gurus such as Peter Drucker make much of the fact that the exporters who led America, Britain, and Germany out of their recent recessions were all small companies—often specialists. One of these is a neighbor of Drucker's in California who makes special medical beepers for hospitals. 2 Drucker has long since given up being amazed by the places where the man sells his equipment. The job is fairly risk-free, says the neighbor. Ever since a nasty experience with a sterling devaluation in the 1960s, the man has billed his clients in dollars, thereby eliminating the exchange risk. "What about the language and culture?" Drucker once asked his friend after he had returned from installing a new system in Osaka. "I don't need to understand Japan," the man replied. "I understand hospitals."

仔细观察就会发现，跨国公司的跨国性往往远不如表面上看的那么大。 他们中的许多人只迁移到他们所在的地区。 美国公司在中美洲和南美洲投资，日本公司在少数亚洲国家投资，欧洲公司在其他欧洲国家投资。 这种模式的一个明显原因是更容易与距离很短的航班的人打交道。 语言和文化纽带是另一个重要因素。 例如，日本人比欧洲人更乐于与东南亚的非正式联盟和扩展的公司网络打交道。 如果说有什么不同的话，那就是现代管理技术正在强化这种区域化趋势：强调最大限度地减少库存并根据需要提供供应品，

Closer inspection reveals that multinationals are often much less multinational than they seem. Many of them migrate only as far as their local regions. American firms invest in Central and South America, the Japanese in a handful of Asian countries, and European firms in other European countries. An obvious reason for this pattern is that it is easier to deal with people who are just a short flight away. Language and cultural ties are another important factor. The Japanese, for example, are much happier dealing with the informal alliances and extended company networks of Southeast Asia than are Europeans. If anything, modern management techniques are reinforcing this trend toward regionalization: with the emphasis on minimizing stocks and delivering supplies on a need-to-use basis, suppliers now want to be located as close as possible to their clients.

全球化意味着什么？ 地理有多重要？

What Does Globalization Mean? How Much Does Geography Matter?

在关于地理重要性的更广泛辩论中，主要主角是日本顾问 Kenichi Ohmae 和哈佛商学院教授迈克尔波特。 两者都比莱维特采取了更微妙的立场，尽管 Ohmae 在某种程度上同意莱维特对一个更加同质化的世界的看法。 有趣的是，Ohmae 炫耀他的全球地位。 他在美国的声誉很大程度上取决于他用从底特律到达拉斯的人们都能理解的方式解释日本的能力（《金融时报》曾不怀好意地将他比作东京的 Benihana，这是一家销售西式日本食品的连锁餐厅）。 与此同时，在他曾为麦肯锡工作的东京，Ohmae 被视为西方所有事物的使徒——例如更清洁的政治和自由贸易。

The chief protagonists in the wider debate about the importance of geography have been Kenichi Ohmae, a Japanese consultant, and Michael Porter, a professor at Harvard Business School. Both take a more subtle position than Levitt did, although Ohmae is in some agreement with Levitt's vision of a more homogenized world. Interestingly, Ohmae flaunts his global status. His reputation in America is largely based on his ability to explain Japan in terms that people from Detroit to Dallas can understand (the Financial Times once unkindly compared him to Benihana of Tokyo, a restaurant chain that sells Westernized Japanese food). Meanwhile in Tokyo, where he used to work for McKinsey, Ohmae is seen as the apostle of all things Western—such as cleaner politics and free trade.

Ohmae 的书中确实包含一些例子，说明“全球”公司如何成为内部人士。 就芭比娃娃而言，日本的销量一直很差，直到当地经销商缩小了芭比娃娃的乳房尺寸，并将她的金发换成了棕色。 然而，正如《无国界世界》（The Borderless World，1990）等书名所暗示的那样，Ohmae 相信拥有他所谓的“安克雷奇视角”（以阿拉斯加城市命名，距离东京、纽约和日本仅七小时路程）的公司杜塞尔多夫）将获胜。 长期以来，他一直认为，一家公司需要在日益相似的三位一体经济体——美国、日本和欧洲——中的每一个中。 Ohmae 的最新著作《民族国家的终结》（1995 年）介绍了全球化主题的另一种变体。 他认为，今天的增长引擎不是“

Ohmae's books do contain examples showing how "global" firms have become insiders. In the case of Barbie dolls, sales in Japan remained poor until the local distributor reduced the size of Barbie's breasts and replaced her blonde hair with brown. Nevertheless, as the titles of books such as The Borderless World (1990) suggest, Ohmae believes that firms with what he calls "an Anchorage perspective" (named after the Alaskan city, which is exactly seven hours away from Tokyo, New York, and Dusseldorf) will win. He has long argued that a firm needs to be in each of the increasingly similar triad economies—America, Japan, and Europe. Ohmae's most recent book, The End of the Nation State (1995), introduces yet another variant on the globalization theme. Today's engines of growth, he argues, are not "dysfunctional" nation-states but "natural economic zones" that cross national boundaries such as Hong Kong-South China or Tijuana-San Diego.

将 Ohmae 确定的这些跨界实体与新兴的超级国家（例如欧盟和互联网创建的网络国家）放在一起，您就会开始为民族国家的衰落提供一个听起来似是而非的理由。 但事实并非如此。 全球化无疑正在迫使各国政府减少孤立，更加相互依存。 它还（感谢上帝）教导人们更多地了解彼此。 但仍然存在明显的分歧。 共产主义的失败并没有让各国争吵不休——无论是伊斯兰教、亚洲价值观还是渔业政策。 在世界上大部分地区都有可识别的

Put these transborder entities identified by Ohmae together with the emerging superstates such as the European Union and the cyber-state created by the Internet, and you begin to have a case for the decline of the nation-state that sounds plausible. But it is not. Globalization is certainly forcing national governments to be less insular and more interdependent. It is also (thank God) teaching people more about each other. But there are still clear divisions. The defeat of communism has not left any shortage of things for nations to quarrel about—whether it be Islam, Asian values, or fishing policies. And throughout most of the world there are recognizable

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

想要保持其传统形状的国家。 诚然，各国已经将一些经济权力移交给贸易组织，但是，除了欧盟之外，它们几乎没有表现出想要让出政治主权的迹象。 尽管西欧可能会走到一起，但东欧已经分崩离析。

nations that want to keep their traditional shapes. True, countries have handed over some economic power to trade organizations, hut, the European Union aside, they have shown very few signs of wanting to yield political sovereignty. And although Western Europe may he coming together, Eastern Europe has broken up.

正如 Michael Porter 所指出的，这对公司和政治家都很重要，因为公司在很大程度上归功于它们的本土起源。 在 The Competitive Advantage of Nations (1989) 中，波特认为不同的国家（和地区）具有不同的竞争优势：德国人擅长高质量工程和化学，日本人擅长小型化和电子，英国人擅长流行音乐和出版，美国人在电影和电脑上。 一家德国工程公司如果变得不那么日耳曼化而更加全球化，不一定会在工程方面变得更好，或者如果一家加利福尼亚软件公司变得不那么加利福尼亚化，它不一定会在工程方面变得更好； 如果要找到优秀的员工和供应商，或者更重要的是，它需要保留其本地根基，

As Michael Porter has pointed out, this matters to companies as well as politicians, for firms owe a remarkable amount of what makes them tick to their local origins. In The Competitive Advantage of Nations (1989), Porter argued that different countries (and regions) have different competitive strengths: the Germans excel at high-quality engineering and chemicals, the Japanese at miniaturization and electronics, the British at pop music and publishing, the Americans at films and computers. A German engineering firm will not necessarily become any better at engineering if it becomes less Germanic and more global, or a Californian software company if it becomes less Californian; it needs to retain its local roots if it is to find good recruits and suppliers or, what is more important, if it is to remain in daily contact with challenging competitors.

现代经济学的奠基人之一阿尔弗雷德·马歇尔曾在对谢菲尔德炼钢的分析中指出，某些技能似乎在某些地区“悬而未决”。 这些卓越中心中的一些很熟悉：计算机领域的硅谷、时尚和设计领域的意大利北部普拉托地区、电影制作领域的好莱坞。 在一个日益流动的世界中，这些地方代表着顽固的固定资源：他们的技能与当地文化息息相关，无法轻易复制到其他地方。 还没有人试图建立一个更便宜的好莱坞。

Alfred Marshall, one of the founders of modern economics, once remarked in an analysis of steelmaking in Sheffield that certain skills seem to be "in the air" in some regions. Some of these centers of excellence are familiar: Silicon Valley in computing, the Prato region of Northern Italy in fashion and design, Hollywood in film making. In an increasingly mobile world, such places represent stubbornly immobile resources: their skills are too bound up with the local culture to be easily copied elsewhere. Nobody has yet tried to build a cheaper Hollywood.

跨国公司非但没有轻蔑地忽视这些地理上的刺激，反而屈服于它们。 以在硅谷设有前哨基地的日本电子公司的数量为例； 也见证了已经扎根于卓越中心的公司正在深入挖掘、支持学校、资助慈善机构等的方式。 伦敦商学院的约翰·斯托普福德 (John Stopford) 认为，公司应该将他所谓的“世界产品授权”交给位于正确领域的分支机构。 例如，美国杜邦公司将其电子相关业务转移到日本，德国西门子将其空中交通管理业务转移到英国，韩国现代公司将其个人电脑业务转移到日本。

Far from contemptuously ignoring these geographic irritations, multinationals now bow down before them. Witness the number of Japanese electronics firms that have an outpost in Silicon Valley; witness, too, the way that firms that already have roots in centers of excellence are digging deeper, supporting schools, funding charities, and so on. John Stopford of the London Business School argues that firms should hand across what he calls their "world product mandates" to affiliates located in the right areas. Thus America's Du Pont has moved its electronics-related businesses to Japan, Germany's Siemens has moved its air-traffic-management business to Britain, and South Korea's Hyundai its personal-computer business

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

到美国。 一些小公司已经全力以赴，将自己彻底连根拔起。 TomTec Imaging Systems 是一家德国公司，营业额为 2100 万美元，在医学超声市场的一个小型高科技部分处于世界领先地位。 1993 年，意识到许多客户都在美国这一事实，它从慕尼黑附近的基地搬到了科罗拉多州的博尔德。 3个

to the United States. A few small companies have gone the whole hog and uprooted themselves entirely. TomTec Imaging Systems is a German company with a turnover of $21 million that is the world leader in one small, highly technological part of the medical ultrasound market. In 1993, conscious of the fact that many of its customers were in America, it moved from its base near Munich to Boulder, Colorado. 3

成为内部人士不仅仅意味着购买一些资产——无论它们有多昂贵。 从表面上看，索尼和松下收购了娱乐业的“卓越中心”——好莱坞，这是正确的选择。 然而，这两家日本公司都对这个行业感到困惑，因为这个行业性格喜怒无常，交易者随心所欲，而且依赖“耳朵”或“眼睛”来预测艺术家是否会出售或电影是否会成功。 结果，他们在给挥霍无度的员工太多自由之间摇摆不定（有一段时间，好莱坞的山丘上挤满了建筑商的卡车和送货车辆，它们蜿蜒驶向日本支付的大亨迅速扩张的房屋）突然夹紧。 MCA 长期担任主席的原因之一， Lew Wasserman 在 1995 年反对松下，因为这家日本公司不会让工作室在音乐和多媒体等领域扩张。 贝塔斯曼 (Bertelsmann) 是一家沉稳的德国出版公司，收购了几家美国音乐和图书出版集团，比日本公司做得更好，但日子并不轻松——尤其是因为它的高管在会议期间用德语进行私下谈话，惹恼了 RCA 的坚定支持者.

Becoming an insider means more than just buying a few assets— however expensive they might be. On the face of it, Sony and Matsushita did the right thing by buying into the entertainment industry's "center of excellence"—Hollywood. However, both Japanese companies were utterly confused by the industry, with its temperamental personalities, free-wheeling deal makers, and reliance on "ears" or "eyes" who could predict if an artist would sell or a film would be successful. As a result, they vacillated between giving their spendthrift employees much too free a hand (for a time, the Hollywood hills were jammed with builders' trucks and delivery vehicles winding their way up to the rapidly expanding homes of Japanese-paid moguls) and then suddenly clamping down. One reason why MCA's long-time chairman, Lew Wasserman, rebelled against Matsushita in 1995 was that the Japanese company would not let the studio expand in areas such as music and multimedia. Bertelsmann, a staid German publishing company that bought several American music and book-publishing groups, has done better than the Japanese but has not had an easy time of it—not least because its executives annoyed RCA stalwarts by conducting private conversations in German during meetings.

然而，像内部人士一样思考的最佳理由，而不仅仅是安克雷奇（不是世界上最富裕的城市之一）的公民，仅仅是因为您销售了更多产品。 记住可口可乐和麦当劳在日本本土化的努力。 或者请注意，瑞士的雀巢公司通过向日本家庭提供口味像海藻的包装麦片等产品，已成为日本最大的外国食品公司。 相比之下，美国的汽车制造商没有对日本人偏爱小型汽车或在道路左侧驾驶的习惯做出让步——这是乔治·布什 1992 年可笑的东京之行，当时他和一群汽车公司高管试图迫使日本开放市场，但收效甚微。

However, the best reason for thinking like an insider, not just a citizen of Anchorage (not one of the world's wealthier cities), is simply that you sell more products. Remember Coca-Cola and McDonald's efforts to go native in Japan. Or notice that Switzerland's Nestle has built itself into the biggest foreign food firm in Japan by offering Japanese families products such as packaged cereals that taste like seaweed. By contrast, America's car makers made no concessions to the Japanese preference for small cars or custom of driving on the left-hand side of the road—something that George Bush's ludicrous trip to Tokyo in 1992, when he and a group of car company executives tried to force Japan to open its markets, did little to change.

他们手中的世界 跨国公司

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS The Transnational Corporation

现在应该清楚的是，全球化并不预示着单一公司的胜利、地方差异的消失或许多人设想的全球产品的无处不在。 同时，全球化并不是一个无意义的名词。 它源于真实事件：贸易壁垒的降低，以及思想、人员和资金在全球范围内的快速流动。 全球化作为一种​​商业战略可能没有多大意义，但作为一种现象，它仍然为各种规模的公司带来问题和机遇。

By now it should be clear that globalization does not portend the triumph of monolithic companies, the eclipse of local differences, or the omnipresence of global products many people envisage. At the same time, globalization is not a meaningless term. It sprang from real events: a lowering of trade barriers, and the rapid movement of ideas, people, and money around the globe. Globalization may not make much sense as a business strategy but as a phenomenon it still presents both problems and opportunities to companies of all sizes.

尤其是一家可以在全球范围内生产产品，利用不同文化而不是践踏它们的公司，看起来非常强大。 这样的公司可能会在各个地方卓越中心之间充当套利者的角色，例如让意大利设计师与日本小型化专家取得联系，然后将这些不同的地方技能与它可以获得的任何全球资源相结合。

In particular, a firm that can manufacture its products globally, making use of the different cultures rather than trampling all over them, looks like a very powerful one. Such a company might act as an arbitrageur between various local centers of excellence, putting, for instance, Italian designers in touch with Japanese experts in miniaturization, and then combining these various local skills with whatever global resources it can gain access to.

到 20 世纪 90 年代中期，有迹象表明，这种更微妙的、地理上敏感的全球化版本大有可为。 一如既往，问题是如何建立一家可以利用它的公司。 到目前为止，最好的两个答案是“跨国公司”，这是哈佛商学院的克里斯托弗·巴特利特和伦敦商学院的苏曼特拉·戈沙尔共同创造的一个词，以及“多元文化的跨国公司”，以巴内维克的 ABB 为代表。 这些听起来不太可爱的组织都涉及到大多数跨国公司核心的矩阵系统，人们既向地域老板（如国家经理）报告，又向产品经理（全球汽车部门负责人）汇报工作.

By the mid-1990s, there were signs that this subtler, geographically sensitive version of globalization had a lot going for it. The question, as ever, was how to construct a company that could take advantage of it. The two best answers so far are "the transnational corporation," a phrase coined jointly by Christopher Bartlett of Harvard Business School and Sumantra Ghoshal of London Business School, and "the multicultural multinational," epitomized by Barnevik's ABB. These unlovely-sounding organizations both involve playing around with the matrix systems that lie at the heart of most multinationals, where people report to both a geographic boss (such as a country manager) and a product manager (the head of the global car division).

跨国公司是一个整理实体。 在本世纪的大部分时间里，大公司都是碰巧同名的全国性公司的松散隶属关系。 福特和联合利华等公司最初通过在其经营所在的所有国家进行自我克隆，拥有自己的总部、设计设施和生产工厂来解决高关税、高昂的运输成本和严格的本地内容规则等问题. 这在最好的时候是非常昂贵的。 有一次，福特在路上有两辆完全独立设计和建造的“Escorts”。 现在关税低得多，许多这些活动

The transnational corporation is a tidying-up entity. For most of this century big companies were loose affiliations of national firms that happened to share the same name. Companies such as Ford and Unilever originally dealt with the problems of high tariffs, prohibitive transport costs, and stringent local-content rules by making clones of themselves in all the countries where they operated, with their own head offices, design facilities, and production plants. This was extremely expensive at the best of times. At one point, Ford had two "Escorts" on the road that had been designed and built entirely separately. Now that tariffs are much lower, many of these activities

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

可以集成到全球系统中，而不必破坏公司的本地感觉。

can be integrated into a global system without necessarily destroying the company's local feel.

最近，一些公司尝试让国家子公司负责全球产品或全球职能，部分是为了分散整个组织的决策制定，部分是为了获取当地的专业知识。 雀巢，其中之一，已将其面食业务的总部设在意大利。 强生公司已授权其德国子公司在全球范围内生产卫生棉条。 IBM 的路易斯·郭士纳 (Louis Gerstner) 已经建立了 14 个广泛的全球产品组，这些产品组削弱了公司曾经无所不能的国家首脑的权力。

Recently, some companies have tried giving national subsidiaries responsibility for global products or global functions, partly to disperse decision-making throughout the organization and partly to capture local expertise. Nestle, for one, has put the headquarters of its pasta business in Italy. Johnson & Johnson has given its German subsidiary a worldwide mandate for tampons. And Louis Gerstner at IBM has set up 14 broad global product groups that have reduced the power of the company's once-all-powerful national chieftains.

建立跨国公司最雄心勃勃的尝试是 1995 年 1 月开始的“福特 2000”计划。这家美国汽车制造商在过去十年中一直致力于打造“世界汽车”，其帝国的不同部门在设计方面展开合作。 但其董事长亚历克斯·特罗特曼 (Alex Trotman) 决定可以走得更远：在福特 2000 的领导下，该公司取消了欧洲和北美的数十个独立的国家部门，取而代之的是五个产品团队，其中一些团队的总部设在欧洲。 Trotman 承认，只有通过允许不同地点的人在同一个项目上工作的技术才能使该项目成为可能：访问位于密歇根州迪尔伯恩的福特设计中心，您会听到日耳曼人的声音从扬声器中传出， 当大西洋两岸的工程师为出现在他们面前的屏幕上的形状讨价还价时。 通过开发一种通用的小型汽车底盘，到 1999 年将总体开发时间从 37 个月缩短到 24 个月，福特希望将其产品开发成本（目前每年 80 亿美元）削减 30%。 同时，通过建立全球采购系统并剔除供应商，Trotman 希望将每辆车的制造成本降低 700 美元。

The most ambitious attempt to build a transnational company is the "Ford 2000" plan that began in January 1995. The American car maker had edged toward building "world cars" over the previous decade, with different parts of its empire collaborating on design. But its chairman, Alex Trotman, decided it could go further: under Ford 2000, the company abolished a score of separate national units in Europe and North America and replaced them with five product teams, some of them headquartered in Europe. Trotman admits the project has only been made possible by the sort of technology that allows people in different locations to work on the same project: visit Ford's design center in Dearborn, Michigan, and you will hear Germanic voices booming out of loudspeakers, as engineers on both sides of the Atlantic haggle over the shapes appearing on the screens in front of them. By developing one common small-car chassis and cutting the overall development time from 37 months to 24 by 1999, Ford hopes to cut its product development costs (currently $8 billion a year) by 30 percent. Meanwhile, by setting up a worldwide purchasing system and weeding out suppliers, Trotman hopes to knock $700 off the cost of manufacturing each vehicle.

当然，这种一体化只是全球化的另一个名字？ 不同之处在于，跨国公司对他们认为可以跨境营销的产品更加挑剔，而且对营销方式也更加敏感。 例如，福特 2000 不是全球计划：它仅适用于北美和欧洲。 它也只经营小型汽车，虽然底盘现在可能是一样的，但造型和营销仍然主要掌握在当地经理手中。 面对地域差异，跨国公司通常会退却。 通用电气只是打破分拆政策的几家公司之一

Surely this sort of integration is just globalization by another name? The difference is that transnational companies are much more particular about which products they think they can market across borders and far more sensitive in the way that they do it. For instance, Ford 2000 is not a global program: it applies only to North America and Europe. It also deals only with smaller cars, and, although the chassis may now be the same, the styling and marketing remain very much in the hands of local managers. Confronted by a geographic difference, a transnational company usually retreats. General Electric is only one of several companies to break with policies of dividing

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

通过在亚洲设立区域总部，将业务融入全球产品线。 在中国，跨国公司很快了解到北京喜欢只与一位可以代表公司所有产品线的当地老板打交道：因此急于建立“中国中心”。

operations into global product lines by setting up a regional headquarters in Asia. In China, multinationals are learning quickly that Beijing likes to deal with just one local boss who can speak for all the company's product lines: hence the rush to set up "China centers."

有时，这种敏感性会导致一些相当混乱的公司历史——正如联合利华 (Unilever) 在西欧的食品业务所展示的那样。 在 1990 年代初期，作为代号为“贝多芬”的计划的一部分，这家英荷巨头将其食品业务集中起来，为 1992 年的单一市场做准备。 4 然后它意识到自己做得太过火了，于是将一些营销权交还给了它的国家首领。 但它继续集中生产。 到 1996 年，联合利华在欧洲生产的冰淇淋中有 20% 销往国外，是 1992 年比例的七倍； 随着工厂迅速（并且无情地）合并，目标是到 1999 年达到 35%。联合利华还将其在欧洲每个国家的食品业务分为两个基于产品的单位（基本上是冷冻和非冷冻）。 这 ”

Sometimes this sensitivity makes for some fairly confusing corporate history—as Unilever's Western European food operations show. In the early 1990s, as part of a plan code-named "Beethoven," the Anglo-Dutch giant centralized its food operations in preparation for the 1992 Single Market. 4 Then it realized that it had gone too far, so it handed back some marketing powers to its national chieftains. But it continued to centralize production. By 1996, 20 percent of Unilever's ice-cream production in Europe was sold across borders, seven times the proportion in 1992; with factories being consolidated rapidly (and ruthlessly), the aim was to reach 35 percent by 1999. Unilever also divided its food business in each country in Europe into two product-based units (basically, frozen, and nonfrozen). This "market locally but produce regionally" strategy might seem relatively simple but there was also a separate "master plan." It dictated that the company should try to expand in some products (basically, ice cream and margarine) and in some markets (Latin America and Asia), though not necessarily in both at the same time. Analysts expect Niall FitzGerald, its new British chairman, to push through another bout of centralization—though that, doubtless, will be followed by more fits of localization.

全球化的理由

Reasons to Be Global

这种来来回回引发了一个更基本的问题：为什么要麻烦？ 原因是人们相信，一个协调得当的跨国公司可以将比国内公司或老式跨国公司更多的资源投入到任何特定产品上。 在某些行业，例如喷气式飞机和半导体，公司总是需要在全球范围内销售其产品以收回投资。 现在，整个行业的创新成本都在飙升。 在 1960 年代，西门子只需要占领一半的德国市场就可以分摊开发机电开关的成本； 很快它将不得不占领全球市场的 20%。 好莱坞过去只考虑美国的票房； 如今，如果没有外国市场，它就会破产。

This to-ing and fro-ing prompts a more fundamental question: why bother? The reason is the belief that a properly coordinated multinational company can devote far more resources to any particular product than either a national company or an old-fashioned multinational. In some industries such as jet aircraft and semiconductors, companies have always needed to sell their products globally to recoup their investments. Now the cost of innovation has skyrocketed in a whole range of businesses. In the 1960s Siemens had to capture only half of the German market to amortize the cost of developing an electromechanical switch; soon it will have to capture 20 percent of the global market. Hollywood used to think only about the American box office; nowadays it would go bust without foreign markets.

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

尽管麦当劳坚称它是一家当地连锁餐厅，由当地人提供员工，而且通常归他们所有，但它也将一些东西集中起来以削减成本。 其全球专家团队可以在短短 11 天内用模块化部件建造一家新的麦当劳餐厅，将建造餐厅的成本削减三分之一。 全球采购团队通过削减供应商数量每年为公司节省 2 亿美元。 宜家有专门的团队来开设新店。 该团队规划大楼、监督施工、策划发布、经营商店并培训当地团队； 一年后，它将业务移交给当地人，然后前往世界其他地方做同样的事情。

Although McDonald's insists that it is a chain of local restaurants staffed by local people and often owned by them, it also centralizes some things to cut costs. Its global team of specialists can erect a new McDonald's restaurant out of modular parts in as little as 11 days, cutting the cost of building the restaurant by a third. A global purchasing team has saved the company $200 million a year by cutting back on the number of its suppliers. IKEA has a specialized team to set up new stores. The team plans the building, supervises its construction, masterminds the launch, runs the store, and trains the local team; after a year it hands the operation over to the locals and heads off to do the same thing somewhere else in the world.

像麦当劳或宜家这样的优秀“大公司”可以使用相同的基本广告策略在全球范围内销售其产品。 总部位于伦敦的咨询公司 OC&C Strategy 计算出，说服客户试用新产品所需的广告和促销成本平均比不熟悉的品牌低 36%。 在欧洲、日本和美国开发国际品牌的成本高达 10 亿美元。 一家大型跨国公司也有能力进行试验（如果产品或策略在瑞典失败，那就这样吧）。

A good "big firm" like McDonald's or IKEA can use the same basic advertising ploy to sell its product around the globe. OC&C Strategy, a London-based consultancy, has calculated that the advertising and promotion costs needed to persuade a customer to try out a new product are, on average, 36 percent less for a recognized brand than for an unfamiliar one. The cost of developing an international brand in Europe, Japan, and the United States has been put as high as $1 billion. A big multinational can also afford to experiment (if a product or a strategy fails in Sweden, then so be it).

正如第一轮失败的全球化所证明的那样，就其本身而言，这种规模经济意义不大。 但是，如果它们可以被纳入一个混合和匹配来自世界各地的知识的网络，它们就会变得更加强大。 关注跨国公司的联合国贸易和发展会议区分了两种类型的整合，简单的和复杂的。 在简单的整合中，公司将最复杂的业务留在本国，但将其他生产外包给发展中国家。 这往往适合较小的跨国公司。 美国运动服装制造商耐克在其家乡俄勒冈州进行所有产品开发和营销，但将生产分包给其他 40 个地点，其中大部分在亚洲。 每当东道国的工资过高时， 该公司只是将生产转移到成本更低的国家。 日本的 Mabuchi Motors 生产驱动相机和挡风玻璃刮水器等微型轮子，已将其所有常规生产转移到海外，其中大部分转移到中国广东省，但它把所有最有价值的活动都留在了国内。

By themselves, such economies of scale count for little, as the first failed round of globalization proved; but if they can be subsumed into a network that mixes and matches knowledge from around the world, they become much more potent. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which keeps watch on transnational companies, distinguishes between two types of integration, simple and complex. In simple integration, companies keep their most sophisticated operations in their home country but contract out other production to the developing world. This tends to suit smaller multinationals. Nike, an American sportswear maker, does all its product development and marketing in its home town in Oregon, but subcontracts production to 40 other locations, mostly in Asia. Whenever the wages in the host country get too high, the firm simply shifts production to a cheaper country. Japan's Mabuchi Motors, which makes the tiny wheels that drive things like cameras and windshield wipers, has moved all its routine production offshore, much of it to China's Guangdong Province, but it has kept all its most valuable activities at home.

在复杂的整合中，企业根据市场逻辑定位其所有活动。 他们还分散决策

In complex integration, companies locate all their activities according to the logic of the market. They also disperse decision-making

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

遍及他们的组织，而不是将其保留在总部。 它们的特点是信息在各个方向（水平和垂直）上源源不断地流动。 办公设备制造商 Xerox 是这种演变的一个很好的例子。 在 1980 年代初期，施乐只是一个全国性子公司的联盟，例如英国的 Rank Xerox 和日本的 Fuji Xerox：几乎每家公司都自己做。 但来自佳能等更便宜、更灵活的日本公司的竞争迫使施乐整合其业务。 施乐引入了全球产品开发团队和集中采购，将供应商数量从5000家减少到400家。但它也表明它是平等联盟，希望大家出主意。

throughout their organizations rather than keeping it in head office. Their hallmark is the endless flow of information in all directions, horizontally as well as vertically. Xerox, an office equipment maker, is a good example of this evolution. In the early 1980s, Xerox was just a coalition of national affiliates, such as Britain's Rank Xerox and Japan's Fuji Xerox: each firm did virtually everything itself. But competition from cheaper, more flexible Japanese companies such as Canon forced Xerox to integrate its activities. Xerox has introduced global product-development teams and centralized procurement, reducing the number of suppliers from 5,000 to 400. But it has also indicated that it is a union of equals, all of which are expected to come up with ideas.

重塑公司以更好地利用知识总是很复杂（见第 7 章），但跨国界这样做尤其困难。 有时，跨国公司不得不应对企业大亨的大规模反抗，就像 IBM 在意大利所做的那样。 在 20 世纪 80 年代的失败之后，公司对从上层实施全球化计划变得更加谨慎。 特罗特曼承认，在 1994 年的大部分时间里，福特都由“第二团队”管理，因为他迫使高级管理人员将大部分时间花在研究如何实施“福特 2000”上。 公司位于迪尔伯恩的总部展示了一块巨大的展板，所有高级管理人员都在上面签名，表达了他们对“福特 2000”的承诺。

Reinventing companies to make better use of knowledge is always complex (see Chapter 7), but doing so across borders is particularly difficult. Occasionally, transnational companies have had to deal with wholesale revolts by corporate barons, as IBM did in Italy. After the failures of the 1980s, companies have become more cautious about imposing globalization plans from above. Trotman admits that for much of 1994 Ford was run by "the second team" because he forced senior managers to spend most of their time working out how they were going to implement "Ford 2000." The firm's headquarters in Dearborn has a huge board on display, signed by all its senior managers expressing their commitment to "Ford 2000."

尽管特罗特曼关心并致力于变革，但福特的文化可能需要十年时间才能重塑。 在另一家试图重组的美国大公司孟山都公司，高级职员将集中化称为“C 字”。 1995 年，荷兰皇家壳牌公司，一家一直以权力下放为生的大公司，也转向了围绕产品组组织的层次结构。 这似乎肯定会带来生产率的提高，但内部人士担心这些会被“软性”损失所抵消——例如公司著名的“壳人”文化。 一位前主管承认，存在“婴儿和洗澡水一起被倒掉”的风险。

Despite Trotman's care and commitment to change, Ford's culture will probably take a decade to reinvent. At Monsanto, another big American company that is trying to reorganize, senior staff refer to centralization as "the C-word." In 1995 Royal Dutch/Shell, a big firm that has always thrived on decentralization, also moved to a hierarchy organized around product groups. This seemed certain to produce productivity gains, but insiders worried that these would be wiped out by "softer" losses—such as the company's famous "Shell-man" culture. There is a risk, one former director admitted, of "the baby being thrown out with the bath water."

多元文化跨国公司

The Multicultural Multinational

这些话似乎都在强调一个基本点，那就是在全球化的过程中，公司的人比产品更重要。 这是小公司的主要原因，例如

These remarks seem to underline a fundamental point, namely, when it comes to globalization, a company's people are more important than its products. This is the main reason that small firms, such

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

作为彼得·德鲁克 (Peter Drucker) 的“了解医院的朋友”，迄今为止，它们的表现普遍优于全球大公司。 看看几乎所有失败的全球化战略，你会发现公司的员工并不赞同。 无论萨奇兄弟多么频繁地告诉他们屡获殊荣的伦敦代理机构推荐他们在纽约的代理机构，夏洛特街的撰稿人和客户主管都将他们的曼哈顿分公司视为二级机构——有时他们也会这样告诉他们的客户。 大多数全球化战略的坟墓上都可能出现“不是在这里发明”的字样。

as Peter Drucker's "friend who understands hospitals," have so far generally done so much better than big global firms. Look at virtually any failed globalization strategy and you will find that the company's staff did not go along with it. No matter how often the Saatchi brothers told their award-winning London agency to recommend their New York one, the copywriters and account executives in Charlotte Street regarded their Manhattan branch as a second-division outfit— and sometimes told their clients so. The words "Not Invented Here" could appear on the graves of most globalization strategies.

如果说跨国公司经常代表世界上最坏的一面，那么它们也——诱人地——承诺有一天会代表大多数人中最好的一面。 因为他们目前的弱点——他们的多样性——也应该是他们最大的优势。 跨国公司比小公司拥有更多的管理人才； 它还会受到更广泛的刺激，例如消费者需求、技术变革和竞争对手的行动。 如果跨国公司不使用这些知识，那么它还不如关闭其子公司并雇用分包商； 但如果它利用多元文化主义，效果应该是触电的。 Barnevik 在 ABB 追求的正是这个圣杯。

If multinational firms often represent the worst of all worlds, they also hold out—tantalizingly—the promise of one day representing the best of most. For their current weakness—their variety—should also be their greatest strength. A multinational has access to a much larger pool of management talent than a small firm; it is also exposed to a wider range of stimuli, about such things as consumer needs, technological changes, and competitors' moves. If a multinational does not use that knowledge, then it might as well close its subsidiaries and hire subcontractors; but if it exploits that multiculturalism, the effect should be electric. It is this holy grail that Barnevik is pursuing at ABB.

然而，对多元文化跨国公司的追捕始于健康警告。 在很多情况下，一个企业最宝贵的资源就是其内部文化，越有特色越好。 拜访世界上最伟大的公司之一就像拜访一个邪教：人们有他们当地的英雄（创始人、现任董事长和其他一两个人），他们当地的战争故事（创始人如何想到他的成功想法），以及甚至他们的当地语言。 “HP Way”就像不含咖啡因的咖啡一样具有加州特色。 福特员工似乎对迪尔伯恩总部的一切都有昵称。

The hunt for the multicultural multinational begins with a health warning, however. In many cases a firm's most valuable resource is its internal culture, the more distinctive the better. Visiting one of the world's great companies is rather like visiting a cult: people have their local heroes (the founder, the current chairman, and one or two others), their local war stories (how the founder hit upon his winning idea), and even their local language. The "HP Way" is as Californian as decaffeinated coffee. Ford workers seem to have nicknames for everything in their Dearborn headquarters.

但跨国公司不应因健康警告而退缩。 原因之一是多元文化主义应该像对国家一样对公司起作用。 从香港到加利福尼亚，有一种可靠的方法可以为经济注入活力：移民。 美国经济在 1980 年代领先于欧洲和日本，部分原因是它向外国投资和外国人才开放。 日本的技术诀窍和竞争帮助振兴了美国的锈带。 毫无疑问，个别公司可以从将外来文化引入自身中获益。

But multinationals should not be put off by the health warning. One reason is that multiculturalism should work for companies just as it does for countries. From Hong Kong to California, there has been one sure-fire way to inject some vitality into the economy: immigration. America's economy pulled ahead of Europe's and Japan's in the 1980s in part because it opened itself up to foreign investment and foreign brainpower. Japanese know-how and competition helped to revitalize America's rust belt. Surely individual companies can gain from introducing alien cultures into their midst.

这似乎是有可能的，因为即使是最普通的知识也可以成为一种有力的武器。 例如，一个法国人

This seems likely given that even imported knowledge of the most mundane sort can be a potent weapon. For example, a French

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

达能公司通过引进“饼干技术”生产不易碎的饼干，迅速成为亚洲最大的饼干公司。 飞利浦最近最成功的产品之一是高档大屏幕电视，直到这家荷兰公司的总部收到其香港营销团队负责人杰克·刘 (Jack Lau) 的绝望备忘录后，才开始投产，强调对电视的需求急剧增加该地区的此类产品。 飞利浦现在正将越来越多的电子业务转移到东南亚，这可能是世界上最具创造力和竞争力的电子市场。

company, Danone, has rapidly become the biggest biscuit firm in Asia by importing "biscuit technology" to make biscuits that do not crumble. One of Philips's most successful recent products, an upmarket large-screen television, was only pushed into production when the Dutch firm's head office received a desperate memo from Jack Lau, head of its marketing team in Hong Kong, highlighting the dramatic increase in demand for such products in the region. Philips is now moving more and more of its electronics business to Southeast Asia, which is probably the world's most creative and competitive electronics market.

大多数大公司也将变得更加多元文化，因为他们别无选择。 多元文化主义的三大先驱——壳牌、联合利华和ABB——都是异族通婚的产物。 “我们习惯于将荷兰人和英国人聚在一起；添加其他品种相当容易，”一位 Shellman 指出，并指出公司总部有 40 个国籍。 在欧洲，单一市场使通婚成为规则而不是例外。 已经有大约 150,000 名英国人为德国公司工作； 许多人争辩说他们两全其美。

Most big companies will become more multicultural also because they have no choice. The three pioneers of multiculturalism—Shell, Unilever, and ABB—were all the products of mixed marriages. "We were used to pushing together Dutch and English people; adding other varieties was fairly easy," points out one Shellman, noting that there are 40 nationalities in the company's head office. In Europe, the single market is making miscegenation the rule rather than the exception. Already some 150,000 Britons work for German companies; many argue that they get the best of both worlds.

据大型电子集团 NEC 的董事长 Tadahiro Sekimoto 称，日本公司过去常常实行他所谓的“径向全球化”，即海外办事处与位于中心的总部联系在一起。 5 未来，常态很可能成为“连接所有海外分支机构的有机网络”。 他认为，管理必须变得更加“完整”：即“每个部分独立行动，但从整体上看，一切都是平衡的”。 要达到这种和谐状态，关键因素是公司自身的企业文化。 “在这个全球化时代，企业文化已经成为与劳动力、物质、资本、信息并驾齐驱的第五大管理资产。” 即使在亚洲，日本公司也发现将当地人视为“

Japanese companies, according to Tadahiro Sekimoto, the chairman of NEC, a giant electronics group, used to practice what he calls "radial globalization," in which overseas offices were tied to the head office at the center. 5 In the future, the norm is likely to become "an organic network that links all overseas branches." Management, he believes, must become more "holonic": that is, "each part acts independently but when viewed from the whole all is in balance." To attain this state of harmony, the vital ingredient is a company's own corporate culture. "In this age of globalization, corporate culture has become the fifth management asset that stands on a par with labor, material, capital, and information." Even in Asia, Japanese firms have discovered that treating locals as "dumb terminals" is self-defeating. Korea's chaebol may also be forced to reach the same conclusion: they have feuded with German employees over works councils, and there have been rumors of fistfights between locals and their militaristic superiors.

在美国，未来多元文化的压力不仅来自全球化，也来自国内人口结构。 到 2000 年，白人男性将仅占美国劳动力的 45%。 美国消费者也在变色

In America, the pressure for a more multicultural future is coming not only from globalization but also from domestic demographics. By the year 2000 white males will make up only 45 percent of America's workforce. American consumers, too, are changing color

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

和性别。 1993 年，亚特兰大 Avon Products 的一位销售经理发现了韩国和越南移民的涌入，于是她迅速招募了一批亚洲女士来销售化妆品。 雅芳洗干净了。 它现在有一个“多元文化参与委员会”，以鼓励员工多元化。 自从该公司招聘讲西班牙语的员工以来，靠近西班牙裔地区的 Sears 商店的销售额有所上升。 AT&T 通过其 Language Line 建立了新移民的支持，提供 140 种语言的翻译。

and gender. In 1993 a sales manager for Avon Products in Atlanta spotted an influx of Korean and Vietnamese immigrants, so she quickly recruited a squadron of Asian ladies to sell cosmetics. Avon cleaned up. It now has a "multicultural participation council" to encourage diversity among employees. Sales at Sears stores close to Hispanic areas have risen since the firm recruited Spanish-speaking workers. AT&T has built support among recent immigrants with its Language Line, offering translations in 140 languages.

有一些迹象表明，这种混合的美国公司在国外做得更好。 例如，雅芳在中国和南美都非常成功。 更普遍地说，全球化为这些连字符的美国人提供了其他种类的机会：例如，人们急于寻找在美国出生的华人送往中国。 由于担心“丑陋的美国人”、不会说任何语言以及对文化差异极不敏感的形象，公司已经开始向美国商学院施加压力，要求它们变得更加国际化——从尽可能多的国家招募员工和学生。可能的。

There are a few signs that such intermingled American firms do better abroad. Avon, for instance, has been very successful in both China and South America. More generally, globalization gives these hyphenated Americans other kinds of opportunities: there has been a rush, for example, to find American-born Chinese to send to China. Worried about the image of the "ugly American," unable to speak any languages, and brutally insensitive to cultural differences, companies have begun to put pressure on American business schools to become more international—to recruit their staff and students from as many countries as possible.

这种新敏感性的结果之一是跨国公司形象发生了戏剧性的转变。 在糟糕的过去，当越南抗议者高呼“我们不会为德士古而战”时，“跨国公司”这个词是 ITT 等公司的同义词，这些公司试图颠覆智利政府，并花费数百万美元非法收购在印度尼西亚、伊朗和意大利（仅命名以“I”开头的国家）开展活动。 如今，跨国公司拥有更清洁、更环保的形象。 他们排队支持有价值的国际协议，例如国际商会的可持续发展商业宪章。 更令人惊讶的是，

One result of this new sensitivity has been a dramatic turnaround in the image of multinationals. In the bad old days, when Vietnam protesters used to chant, "We won't fight for Texaco," the word "multinational" was synonymous with firms such as ITT, which tried to subvert the Chilean government and spent millions of dollars on illegal activities in Indonesia, Iran, and Italy (to name only the countries beginning with "I"). Nowadays, multinationals have a cleaner, greener image. They line up to endorse worthy international agreements such as the International Chamber of Commerce's Business Charter for Sustainable Development. More surprisingly, they usually stick to them—partly because a single global standard is easier to follow and partly because it usually makes life more difficult for their poorer local competitors.

人民考验

The People Test

每个跨国公司都乐于拥有更好的形象。 但图像是脆弱的东西。 1996 年初，福特在欧洲遭遇骚乱，因为它篡改了一则英国广告，将其达根汉姆工厂工人的所有黑脸换成了白人，然后才让该广告出现在波兰。 具有讽刺意味的是，这家美国汽车制造商的

Every multinational is happy to have a better image. But images are fragile things. In early 1996 Ford faced a rumpus in Europe because it had doctored a British advertisement, replacing all the black faces of workers from its Dagenham factory with white ones before letting the ad appear in Poland. Ironically, the American car maker's

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

借口虽然在英国媒体中受到嘲笑，在达格纳姆受到辱骂，但对多元文化跨国公司的学生来说是有道理的：福特声称它是敏感的，根据当地口味调整全球运动（波兰的黑人面孔并不多）。

excuse, though mocked in the British press and reviled in Dagenham, would make sense to students of multicultural multinationals: Ford claimed it was being sensitive, adapting a global campaign to local tastes (there are not many black faces in Poland).

这个离奇的插曲表明，公司要保持其多元文化声誉是多么困难。 比保持外表更难的是让这个想法成为现实。 多元文化主义的真正考验——更不用说它唯一持久的利润来源——是一家公司如何使用自己的员工。 一个值得一看的地方是会议室。 毕竟，通过只任命少数外国面孔，一家公司可以发出一个明确的信息，即高层职位并非只留给本地人。 乍一看，大公司似乎做得很好。 20 年前谁会猜到福特将由苏格兰人（Alex Trotman）经营，欧莱雅由威尔士人经营（林赛欧文琼斯），亨氏由爱尔兰人经营（Tony O'Reilly），麦肯锡由印度人经营（Rajat）古普塔）？

This bizarre episode shows how hard it is for companies to keep up their multicultural reputation. Even harder than keeping up appearances is making a reality of the idea. The real test of multicultur-alism—not to mention the only lasting source of profits from it—is how a firm uses its own people. One good place to look is the boardroom. After all, by appointing only a handful of foreign faces, a company can send a clear message that the top positions are not reserved for locals only. At first glance, big companies seem to have done pretty well. Who would have guessed 20 years ago that Ford would be run by a Scot (Alex Trotman), L'Oreal by a Welshman (Lindsay Owen Jones), Heinz by an Irishman (Tony O' Reilly), and McKinsey by an Indian (Rajat Gupta)?

然而在表面之下，许多跨国公司仍然顽固地以种族为中心。 对于关本的所有关于整体管理的谈话，日本公司仍然是最严重的违规者，但美国公司也有罪。 据欧洲工商管理学院教授苏珊施耐德称，1991 年美国最大公司的外国出生董事会成员的比例与 1981 年相同，均为 2.1%。 再往下看这个组织，你会发现民族偏袒的嫌疑比比皆是。 例如，福特装配业务被欧洲员工称为“仅限美国人”。 1995 年，总部设在马萨诸塞州列克星敦的国际高管发展研究联合会要求来自 12 家大公司的 1,500 名管理人员对他们在 34 个类别中的能力进行排名：“培养全球思维模式”排在最后。

Yet beneath the surface many multinationals are still stubbornly ethnocentric. For all Sekimoto's talk of holonic management, Japanese firms remain the worst offenders, but American firms are also guilty. The proportion of foreign-born board members of America's biggest firms was the same in 1991 as in 1981, 2.1 percent, according to Susan Schneider, a professor at Insead. Look further down the organization and you find suspicions of national favoritism abound. Ford Assembly Operations, for example, is known as "For Americans Only" by European staff. In 1995 the International Consortium for Executive Development Research, which is based in Lexington, Massachusetts, asked 1,500 managers from 12 large companies to rank their abilities in 34 categories: "cultivating a global mind-set" finished last.

鉴于这些困难，很少有跨国公司充分利用文化融合也就不足为奇了。 毕竟，像耐克那样，让美国人的大脑在亚洲人的手下指挥并没有什么特别的多元文化。 你想看到在国外生产的不仅仅是运动鞋，还有创意。 根据英国雷丁大学经济学家约翰·坎特威尔的一项研究，在 1980 年代授予美国跨国公司的专利中，只有 9% 是由海外公司完成的。 对于欧洲公司来说，这个比例是 30%——尽管这些创意中的大部分很可能来自其他欧洲国家。

Given these difficulties, it is not surprising that few multinationals make the most out of cultural mixing. After all, there is nothing particularly multicultural about letting American brains boss around Asian hands, as Nike does. What you want to see being produced abroad is not just sneakers but ideas. According to a study by John Cantwell, an economist at Britain's Reading University, only 9 percent of the patents issued to American multinationals in the 1980s were for work done by overseas companies. For European firms the ratio was 30 percent—though the chances are that most of those ideas came from other European countries.

全球化意味着什么？

What Does Globalization Mean?

最强大的变革力量是技术——或者更准确地说，是信息。 视频会议、Lotus Notes 等软件程序以及现在的在线公司网络“Intranet”都允许来自不同地方的人们针对相同的想法开展工作。 在最极端的情况下，这可能意味着让德国和美国的设计师在网上就同一发动机部件进行讨价还价（福特已经这样做了）。 使用信息技术的最佳方式之一是在公司范围内传播最佳实践。 许多公司都拥有明星工厂，例如摩托罗拉在佛罗里达州的寻呼机工厂，他们鼓励其他人击败它。

The most powerful force for change is technology—or, to be more accurate, information. Videoconferencing, software programs such as Lotus Notes, and now the "Intranet" of on-line company networks all allow people from different places to work on the same ideas. At its most extreme, this can mean letting German and American designers haggle on-line about the same engine part (as already happens at Ford). One of the best ways of using information technology is to spread best practice around the company. Many companies have star plants, like Motorola's pager plant in Florida, which they encourage everybody else to beat.

然而，技术只能做这么多。 最后，“多元文化的跨国公司”也需要大量的人力。 雀巢定期召开内部会议，定期安排短期访问，并在各个技术和研究中心之间轮换关键人员。 理查德·布兰森 (Richard Branson) 邀请维珍员工和维珍大西洋航空公司最常出差的旅客（及其家人）到他家参加混乱的夏季野餐。 尽管如此，大部分负担都落在了老战马，即“前任”经理身上。 这并不理想。 外派人员的费用高得惊人，是雇用当地人的两倍多，而且越来越难招到他们——尤其是如果提供的工作地点是在北京或卡拉奇，而不是在伦敦或巴黎。 性别平等也削弱了他们的灵活性：双职工夫妇的兴起意味着一家公司经常不得不把两个人连根拔起，把一个人派到某个地方。 然而，如果没有某种国际军官阶层，离心力就会接管。

However, technology will only do so much. In the end, "multicultural multinationals" require an enormous amount of human effort as well. Nestle sets up periodic internal conferences, arranging regular short-term visits and rotating key personnel between its various technical and research centers. Richard Branson invites Virgin employees along with Virgin Atlantic's most frequent travelers (and their families) to chaotic summer picnics at his house. All the same, much of the burden falls on that old warhorse, the "ex-pat" manager. This is not ideal. Ex-pats are horrendously expensive, costing more than double what it takes to employ a local, and they are becoming hard to get hold of—particularly if the job being offered is in Beijing or Karachi rather than London or Paris. Their flexibility has also been undermined by sexual equality: the rise of the dual-career couple means that a firm often has to uproot two people to send one somewhere. However, without an international officer class of some sort, centrifugal forces take over.

前方的战斗

The Battle Ahead

多元文化组织能否以智取胜，例如彼得德鲁克的朋友“了解医院”或在世界各地使用分包商的公司？ 答案是现在说还为时过早。 正如 ABB 的联席主席戴维·德普里 (David De Pury) 在 1994 年所说：“多元文化的跨国公司非常少；真正的全球多元文化公司还不存在。” 每一个新的内部信息系统都可以帮助一家巨型公司变得更加人性化和灵活，有一个互联网站点可以让小企业家们就他们的行业交换想法。

Can multicultural organizations outwit people such as Peter Drucker's friend "who understands hospitals" or a firm using subcontractors around the world? The answer is that it is too early to say. As David De Pury, ABB's cochairman, put it in 1994: "There are very few multicultural multinationals; the truly global multicultural company does not yet exist." For every new internal information system that helps one of the monster companies become more human and flexible, there is an Internet site that allows small entrepreneurs to swap ideas about their industries.

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

但可以肯定的是，尽管全球化和地理问题可能是棘手的问题，但它们是任何规模的公司都必须面对的问题。 此外，这种新的基于知识的、多元文化的全球化版本比它的前身征服地理学更有机会与地理学合作。 这就是为什么珀西·巴内维克 (Percy Barnevik) 没完没了的旅行可能是值得的。

It can be said with certainty, however, that, even though globalization and geography may be intractable problems, they are ones that every company of any size has to face up to. Furthermore, this new knowledge-based, multicultural version of globalization stands a far better chance of working with geography than its predecessor stood of vanquishing it. That is why Percy Barnevik's endless peregrination may just be worthwhile.
