第十一章

CHAPTER 11

tfWX*

tfWX*

在西方，家长式的公司曾经有建设公司城镇的习惯。 在日本，丰田建立了公司城市。 从东京西南方向乘坐子弹头列车两小时，丰田市是日本制造业持续实力的证明（如果有的话）。 这座城市拥有 10 家大型汽车厂，每年生产 300 万辆汽车，主导着整个地区的生活。 周边城镇的存在唯一目的是为丰田市的工厂生产零件。 在这座城市的 350,000 名居民中，很少有人在他或她的夹克或棒球帽上的某个地方没有丰田徽章。 实际上，整个地方就是一台巨大的机器，永远在磨削丰田的产品。

In the West, paternalist companies used to be in the habit of building company towns. In Japan, Toyota has built a company city. Two hours southwest of Tokyo by bullet train, Toyota City is proof, if any was needed, of the continuing might of Japanese manufacturing. Home to 10 gigantic car plants, which churn out three million vehicles a year, the city dominates the life of the entire region. The surrounding towns exist for the sole purpose of producing parts for Toyota City's factories. It is rare to see one of the city's 350,000 inhabitants without a Toyota badge somewhere on his or her jacket or baseball cap. The whole place is, in effect, a gigantic machine, forever grinding out Toyota products.

但是，引起世界关注并改变世界的是这台机器进行研磨的方式，而不是它令人惊叹的尺寸。 这里还是各族厂商前来围观的地方。 它也是为数不多的可以被归类为应用管理理论成功展示的工厂之一。

But it is the way the machine does the grinding, rather than its awesome size, that has captured the attention of the world—and also changed it. This is a place where manufacturers of all races still come to gawk. It is also one of the few factories that can be classed as a successful showcase for applied management theory.

乍一看，这似乎是一个奇怪的说法。 丰田市工厂内的生活似乎与世界各地汽车工厂的生活非常相似——发出咔嗒声的机器人、挥舞着喷灯的焊工，当然还有装配线的常见组合。 但仔细观察就会发现重要的差异。 堵塞西方装配线周围通道的工人大军不见了。 几乎每个人都在丰田

At first sight, this seems a strange claim. Life inside Toyota City's factories seems much like life in car factories the world over—the usual mix of clattering robots, blowtorch-wielding welders, and, of course, assembly lines. But look a little closer and important differences emerge. The armies of workers who clog the aisles around Western assembly lines are missing. Almost everybody on Toyota's

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

车间正忙于增加价值。 缺少的还有西方常见的货架库存。 丰田的工人手头只有大约一个小时的库存，方便地存放在他们工作站旁边齐肩高的货架上。 川流不息的交通——自行车、小型卡车，甚至无人驾驶的手推车，播放高亢的电子音乐以警告他们的存在——为工人运送材料，这样他们就可以拿到他们需要的任何东西，而无需保留大量备件。

shop floor is busy adding value. Missing, too, are the shelf-loads of inventory that are common in the West. Toyota's workers have only about an hour's worth of inventory at hand, conveniently stored on shoulder-high shelves next to their workstations. A constant flow of traffic—bicycles, small trucks, and even unmanned carts, playing high-pitched electronic tunes to warn of their presence—deliver material to workers so that they can lay their hands on whatever they need without keeping huge supplies of spares.

然而，在所有这些匆忙中，每个工人都有权让装配线停止，如果他（看不到女性）发现故障，可以在他头顶上方拉一根电线。 故障消息立即在悬挂在天花板上的许多电子板之一上闪现，该板还告诉每个人已经制造了多少辆汽车以及距离目标有多远。 普遍的气氛是竞争性协作，每个团队都争相成为最有效率的。 一位年轻人展示了他几年前发明的一种工具，可以更轻松地将转向柱插入轴中。 该工具现已在世界各地的丰田工厂中使用。 第二名工人展示了另一项发明（这次是另一家工厂的发明）：一张移动椅，悬挂在天花板上， 让他可以在过往的汽车中快速进出，而不必爬满它们。 管理层异常重视员工的舒适度。 机器人做起重的繁重工作，而不是焊接的熟练工作。 汽车悬挂在地面之上，这样工人就可以在不弯腰的情况下插入零件。 出于同样的原因，备件存放在视线水平。

Yet, in all this haste, each worker has the power to bring the assembly line to a halt, pulling a wire above his head if he (there are no women to be seen) spots a fault. And the news of the fault is immediately flashed on one of the many electronic boards suspended from the ceiling that also tell everybody how many cars have been made and how near the line is to hitting its target. The general air is that of competitive collaboration, with each team vying to be the most efficient. One young man displays a tool he invented a couple of years ago to make it easier to insert the steering column into its shaft. The tool is now used in Toyota's factories around the world. A second worker shows off another invention (this time from another factory): a mobile chair, suspended from the ceiling, allows him to dart in and out of the passing cars without having to clamber all over them. The management puts an unusual amount of emphasis on the workers' comfort. Robots do the back-breaking work of lifting rather than the skilled work of welding. The cars are suspended above the ground so that the workers can insert parts without bending down. Spare parts are stored at eye level for the same reason.

听日本生意人郁郁寡欢的时候，值得一提的是丰田市。 在 1990 年代的大部分时间里，他们所能谈论的只是高日元对出口商的严重影响以及泡沫经济引发的衰退。 1995 年 11 月与日本主要雇主组织之一经济团体联合会主席的一次谈话相当典型，并产生了一长串抱怨：日本的公司太胖了，员工太娇生惯养了，人口太墨守成规了，它的利益团体太强大了，总统抱怨道。 为了重振日渐衰弱的财富，该国需要放松对行业的管制，摆脱终生雇佣制，并变得更加具有创业精神。

It is worth bearing Toyota City in mind when listening to Japan's gloomy business people. For most of the 1990s all they have been able to talk about is the high yen's crippling effect on exporters and the recession triggered by the bubble economy. A conversation in November 1995 with the president of the Keidanren, one of Japan's leading employers' organizations, was fairly typical, and produced a long list of complaints: Japan's companies are too fat, its employees too cosseted, its population too conformist, its interest groups too powerful, the president moaned. To revive its flagging fortunes, the country needs to deregulate its industries, get rid of lifetime employment, and become more entrepreneurial.

千真万确。 但不要忘记，日本经济依然强劲。 1995 年日本是世界第三大贸易国，仅次于

True enough. But do not forget that the Japanese economy is still strong. In 1995 Japan was the world's third biggest trader, after

238

238

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

美国和德国，并可能在本世纪末成为世界上最大的经济体。 按现行汇率计算，日本的国民生产总值 (GNP) 从 1989 年美国的 55% 上升到 1995 年的 80%。 日本在 1990 年代初期的经济衰退期间创造了 320 万个工作岗位，而 1995 年的官方失业率仍仅为 3.2%。它的成功很大程度上归功于丰田等公司超越竞争对手的方式。

America and Germany, and could become the world's biggest economy altogether by the end of the century. Japan's gross national product (GNP) rose from 55 percent of that of the United States in 1989 to 80 percent in 1995, in current exchange rates. Japan created 3.2 million jobs during the recession of the early 1990s and still had an official unemployment rate of only 3.2 percent in 1995. And it owes a lot of its success to the way that companies like Toyota have outmanaged their rivals.

品质的魅力

The Allure of Quality

认为日本战后的增长与管理理论有任何关系似乎有些牵强。 毕竟，在一天工作 10 小时后，普通工薪族在烤鸡肉串和清酒中放松一下，不会花时间谈论 Drucker-San 和 Peters-San。 如果你听之任之，管理理论的批评者会高兴地指出，日本只有几所商学院，没有一所很有声望，而且，在抵达日本 30 年后，那里的西方咨询公司仍在为维持生计而苦苦挣扎。 因为他们不必支付咨询公司虚高的费用，所以公司有更多的钱投入“真正的”投资； 由于他们没有追随最新的管理时尚，他们制定了连贯的长期战略。

It might seem far-fetched to think that Japan's postwar growth has anything to do with management theory. After all, the average salaryman, relaxing over yakitori and sake after a 10-hour day, does not spend his time talking about Drucker-San and Peters-San. If you let them, critics of management theory will happily point out that Japan has only a few business schools, none of them very prestigious, and that, 30 years after arriving, Western consultancies there are still struggling to make ends meet. Because they do not have to pay the consultancies inflated fees, the argument goes, companies have more money to devote to "real" investment; and because they are not following the latest management fashions, they develop coherent, long-term strategies.

怀疑论者在某一方面是对的。 迄今为止，日本只产生了一位自己的甲级联赛大师，大前健一（尽管正在涌现出一代年轻的竞争者）。 本章出现的许多“大师”是商界人士而非教授。 尽管如此，这些商人对管理的思考与德鲁克、彼得斯和其他人一样广泛； 他们的名字同样与经营企业的理论联系在一起。

The skeptics are right in one respect. Japan has so far produced only one first-division guru of its own, Kenichi Ohmae (though a generation of young pretenders is emerging). Many of the "gurus" who appear in this chapter are business people rather than professors. Nevertheless, those businessmen have thought about management just as broadly as Drucker, Peters, and others; and their names are no less associated with theories on how to run businesses.

此外，在他们的核心批评中，怀疑论者完全错了。 日本对管理理论欠了一大笔债——只是不是目前被标榜为最新和最伟大的准则。 他们欠一群美国理论家的债，他们的想法启发了日本人发明“精益生产”。 在对这场革命的最佳研究中，改变世界的机器（1990 年）中，丹尼尔·琼斯、詹姆斯·沃马克和丹尼尔·罗斯毫不含糊地得出了他们的结论：“精益生产是人类制造事物的最佳方式。它提供了以更低的成本提供更优质的产品。

Moreover, in their central criticism, the skeptics are plain wrong. Japan owes a huge debt to management theory—just not the precepts currently being flogged as the latest and greatest. They owe their debt to a group of American theorists whose ideas inspired the Japanese to invent "lean production." In the best study of that revolution, The Machine That Changed the World (1990), Daniel Jones, James Womack, and Daniel Roos present their conclusions on no uncertain terms: "Lean production is a superior way for humans to make things. It provides better products in wider variety at lower cost.

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

同样重要的是，它为从工厂到总部的各个层级的员工提供更具挑战性和成就感的工作。”1

Equally important, it provides more challenging and fulfilling work for employees at every level, from the factory to headquarters." 1

精益生产的灵感来自日本企业在战后美国占领期间首次发现的一套美国质量理论。 战后，日本人意识到他们的商品以国际标准来说是无可救药的劣质品； 他们也对美国经济的强大和美国产品的丰富性感到敬畏。 为了在国际市场上竞争，日本人抓住了一系列教导如何将质量融入工业产品的想法。 虽然从表面上看，这听起来太明显了，不值得一提（事实上，几十年来，在它的发明国美国，人们就是这样看待“质量”的），但实际上，它是工业革命背后的推动力。 简而言之， 这些想法侧重于第一次把事情做好的重要性，而不是在错误发生后花费大量时间来纠正错误——这一观念违背了当时标准公司模式的基本原则，后者认为质量就是一种质量部门在项目建成后进行检查。 在战后的日本，愿意访问并谈论质量的美国大师是天赐之物。

Lean production was inspired by a set of American theories about quality that Japanese businesses first discovered during the postwar American occupation. After the war, the Japanese realized that their goods were hopelessly shoddy by international standards; and they were also awe-struck by the might of the American economy and the sheer profusion of American products. Desperate to compete in international markets, the Japanese seized on a set of ideas that taught how to build quality into industrial products. While on the surface this sounds too obvious a concept to bear mentioning (indeed, this was how "quality" was regarded for decades in the land of its invention, the United States), in practice it was the impetus behind an industrial revolution. In a nutshell, these ideas focused on the importance of getting things right the first time rather than spending a lot of time fixing mistakes after they occurred—a notion that went against the grain of the standard corporate model of the time, which assumed that quality was something a quality department checked for after an item had been built. In postwar Japan, American gurus who were willing to visit and talk about quality were a godsend.

W. Edwards Deming 和他的朋友在 1950 年代初在美国或多或少被忽视，在日本受到了红地毯的待遇。 每当他们演讲时，大厅里挤满了工程师和生产经理。 他们写的任何东西都立即被翻译成日语，并被全国各地的经理们吞噬。 即使在今天，日本的经理们在谈论约瑟夫·朱兰、AV Feigenbaum，尤其是戴明时，仍然用人们通常对神灵保留的同样安静的语气。 自 1950 年以来，每年都会颁发戴明奖，其中包括一枚印有这位伟人头像的奖章，以表彰卓越的制造业，获奖者在日本电视上播出。

Having been more or less ignored in America in the early 1950s, W. Edwards Deming and his friends were given the red-carpet treatment in Japan. Whenever they lectured, the halls were packed to the ridgepole with engineers and production managers. Whatever they wrote was immediately translated into Japanese and devoured by managers the length and breadth of the country. Even today Japanese managers speak of Joseph Juran, A. V. Feigenbaum, and, particularly, Deming in the same hushed tones that people normally reserve for a deity. Since 1950 an annual Deming prize, including a medal bearing the face of the great man, has been awarded for excellence in manufacturing, and the prizewinners are featured on Japanese television.

除了需要快速开始制造优质产品之外，戴明的想法在日本看起来如此有吸引力还有其他具体原因。 在一个异常拥挤的国家，企业没有足够的空间将大量库存存放数月。 战后，日本无法承受将珍贵（进口）原材料浪费在一次性产品或破旧机器上的后果。 日本也缺少移民

Beyond the need to begin manufacturing quality products quickly, there were other specific reasons why Deming's ideas seemed so attractive in Japan. Businesses in a grotesquely overcrowded country do not have the space to keep large quantities of inventory hanging around for months. After the war, Japan could not afford to waste precious (imported) raw materials on throwaway products or crummy machinery. Japan also lacked the migrant

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

为亨利福特提供工厂饲料的工人； 工业动荡的激增清楚地表明，日本工人不再愿意仅仅被视为生产成本。 也许只有向世界提供寿司的国家才能如此直观地把握“准时制”交货。

workers who provided Henry Ford with his factory fodder; and a surge of industrial unrest made it clear that Japanese workers were no longer willing to be treated as mere costs of production. Perhaps only the nation that gave sushi to the world could have grasped "just-in-time" delivery so intuitively.

精益机器

The Lean, Mean Machine

最初的想法可能来自太平洋彼岸，但是是两个日本人，丰田公司的老板丰田喜一郎和他的得力助手大野耐一将它们转变为新的生产系统。 为此，他们将自己变成了管理理论家——在 1950 年代连续几个月访问美国工厂并研究大规模生产，看看是什么让它如此成功，以及如何改进它。 他们发现该系统充斥着 muda——一个日语术语，包含浪费的精力、浪费的材料和浪费的时间。 他们注意到，除了装配工人外，没有人能增加太多价值，而且强调始终保持生产线运行意味着错误无休止地成倍增加。 2个

The original ideas may have come from across the Pacific, but it was two Japanese, Kiichiro Toyoda, boss of Toyota, and Taiichi Ohno, his right-hand man, who transformed them into a new system of production. They did so by turning themselves into management theorists—visiting American factories for months on end during the 1950s and studying mass production, to see what made it so successful and how it could be bettered. They found the system rife with muda —a Japanese term that encompasses wasted effort, wasted material, and wasted time. Nobody except the assembly worker was adding much value, they noticed, and the emphasis on keeping the line running at all times meant that errors multiplied endlessly. 2

两人最终将所有部件组合在一起，形成了一个全新的生产系统——丰田公司将其称为丰田制造系统，几乎所有人都将其称为“精益生产”。 它的天才在于将制造业的重点从规模经济转移到“时间经济”。 它以三种方式做到了这一点。 首先，每个员工都成为质量检查员，负责发现错误并立即纠正。 丰田没有像其美国竞争对手那样设立质量部门，而是赋予工人在发现错误后立即停止生产线的权利——因此，所有这些电线都挂在生产线上。

The two eventually put all the pieces together for an entirely new system of production—dubbed the Toyota manufacturing system by Toyota and "lean production" by almost everybody else. Its genius was to shift the focus of manufacturing from economies of scale to "economies of time." It did this in three ways. First, every employee became a quality checker, responsible for spotting errors as they happen and correcting them immediately. Instead of installing a quality department like that of its American rivals, Toyota gave workers the right to stop the production line as soon as they saw errors—hence, all those cords hanging along the production line.

其次，日本人引入了“准时制”生产。 在世界其他地方，制造商制造他们的组件是为了“以防万一”需要它们。 他们用几天甚至几周的昂贵零件装满了垃圾箱、托盘和仓库，这些零件积满灰尘，直到最终需要它们为止。 日本人开始“及时”制造零部件，零件在生产线上需要时才送达。

Second, the Japanese introduced "just-in-time" production. In the rest of the world, manufacturers made their components "just in case" they were needed. They filled bins, pallets, and warehouses with days' or even weeks' worth of costly parts, which gathered dust until they were finally needed. The Japanese started making components "just in time," with parts arriving just as they were needed on the production line.

第三，遵循“需求拉动”原则也节省了时间。 西方工厂的零部件传统上是通过“供应推动”的方式交付的，货物一到就堆积起来

Third, time was also saved by following the "demand-pull" principle. Components in Western factories were traditionally delivered by "supply-push" arrangements, with goods piling up when they

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

不需要。 在需求拉动下，它们是按订单生产的。 在丰田，看板或卡片附在每个供应品盒上，描述其内容。 将卡退回供应商会自动重新订购进一步的发货。 需求拉动系统甚至延伸到客户。 丰田没有依靠客户走进当地的丰田经销店并表达对特定汽车的偏好，而是拥有一支挨家挨户的汽车推销员队伍。 从理论上讲，客户会告诉这些推销员他们想要什么样的汽车，然后工厂会按订单生产他们的汽车。

were not needed. With demand pull, they are made to order. At Toyota, a kanban, or card, is attached to every box of supplies describing its contents. Returning the card to the supplier automatically reorders a further shipment. The demand-pull system even extends to the customer. Instead of relying on customers to wander into their local Toyota dealership and express a preference for a particular car, Toyota has an army of door-to-door car salesmen. The theory is that customers will tell these salesman what sort of car they want and the factory will then make their car to order.

这个程序挑战了大规模生产的整个基础，这是（并且在世界许多地方仍然是）占主导地位的制造理念。 大规模生产取决于规模经济和专业化。 据推测，工人需要变得越来越专业，才能更有效地完成工作。 工厂需要变得越来越大才能实现规模经济。 然而，正如日本人所意识到的那样，该系统还需要付出两项严重的代价。

This procedure challenges the entire basis of mass production, which was (and in many parts of the world still is) the dominant manufacturing philosophy. Mass production depends on economies of scale and specialization. Workers, it is supposed, need to become more and more specialized in order to do their job more efficiently. And factories need to become bigger and bigger to achieve economies of scale. As the Japanese realized, however, this system also entails two serious costs.

首先，经典的大规模生产系统无法应对需求的快速变化。 大规模生产商往往更热衷于在生产中保持标准化设计，而不是试验新产品，部分原因是改变生产线的成本很高，部分原因是他们的专业工人对他们所知道的最满意。 随着时尚的变化，工厂可能不得不关闭数月，因为机器需要重新校准，工人需要重新培训。 生产商可能还不得不丢弃大量昂贵但现在已经过时的库存。 到工厂能够批量生产新产品时，需求可能会再次发生变化。

First, the classic mass-production system is unable to respond to rapid changes in demand. Mass producers tend to be much keener on keeping standardized designs in production than in experimenting with new products, partly because of the heavy costs of changing the production line and partly because their specialized workers are happiest with what they know. With a change in fashion, the factory may have to close down for months as machines are recalibrated and workers retrained. Producers may also have to throw away huge quantities of expensively stored but now obsolete inventory. By the time the factory is capable of mass-producing the new product, the demand may have changed once again.

其次，该系统的次品率高得令人无法接受。 大批量使得难以检测缺陷。 直到成品汽车最终发生故障，有缺陷的零件可能才会暴露出来。 日本人争辩说，装配线上的下一个人检查小批量更容易。 一个只生产小批量的工人更有可能感觉自己像个工匠，而大规模生产通常通过将工作减少为苦差事来实现规模经济。 相比之下，精益生产至少继续发挥工人的部分智力天赋。 他们可以看到他们的工艺（无论好坏）对公司制造过程的影响。 同事的表扬表示工作做得好，而皱眉则表示工作做得不够好。

Second, the system turns out an unacceptably high rate of faulty products. Large batches make it difficult to detect defects. A defective part may not reveal itself until the finished car finally breaks down. The Japanese argued that it is easier for the next person on the assembly line to check a small batch. And a worker making only a small batch is more likely to feel like a craftsman, whereas mass production usually achieves its economies of scale by reducing jobs to drudgery. By contrast, lean production continues to engage at least some of the intellectual gifts of the workers. They can see the impact of their workmanship—good or bad—on the company's manufacturing process. Pats on the back from one's colleagues are delivered for a job well done, scowls for a job skimped.

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

精益生产者通过让每个人不仅知道他们在做什么而且知道他们做得有多好来强调责任的概念。 这些信息在“质量圈”中传播——人们围坐在一起讨论他们的表现和他们所生产产品的质量的会议。 工人们还不断获得有关工作的信息：因此在丰田工厂的每个工作站都可以看到发光的电子显示屏。

Lean producers ram home this concept of responsibility by making everybody aware not only of what they are doing but how well they are doing it. This information is communicated in "quality circles"—sessions at which people sit around discussing their performance and the quality of what they have produced. Workers are also fed continuous information on the job: hence the lighted electronic displays that are visible at every workstation in Toyota's factories.

精益生产还意味着重新思考企业的界限——尤其是与供应商的关系。 在西方，这种关系有两种形式。 最初，制造商试图在为此目的设立的特殊部门中自己制造几乎所有零件。 当舆论反对这种“垂直整合”时，西方公司选择了围绕竞争供应商组织的系统。 在这种情况下，他们向大量供应商提供了他们想要的详细图纸，然后向能够提出最优惠价格的供应商提供为期一年的合同。

Lean production also means rethinking the boundaries of the firm—in particular its relationship with its suppliers. In the West, this relationship has taken two forms. Initially, manufacturers tried to make virtually all parts themselves, in special divisions set up for this purpose. When opinion turned against such "vertical integration," Western companies opted for a system organized around competing suppliers. In this case, they provided a large number of suppliers with a detailed drawing of what they wanted and then offered a one-year contract to the supplier who could come up with the best price.

再次由丰田开创的日本供应链管理的经典形式以不同的方式运作。 供应商可以是正式独立的公司，也可以是同一个 keiretsu（一组通过交叉持股联系起来的公司）的成员。 在任何一种情况下，母公司都将供应公司视为合作伙伴，而不是相互竞争。 供应商“及时”提供货物，以换取与主要制造商的长期合作关系。 制造商通过将处于职业生涯中期的经理派往供应商公司或 keiretsu 的其他成员的高级职位来巩固这些关系。 这意味着供应链的所有部分都可以集中资源并共享信息——从而再次减少时间浪费。

The classic form of Japanese supply-chain management, again pioneered by Toyota, works in a different way. The suppliers may be formally separate companies, or they can be members of the same keiretsu (a group of firms linked by cross-shareholdings). In either case, the parent company treats the supply firms as partners rather than playing them off against each other. The suppliers provide the goods "just in time" in return for long-term relationships with the main manufacturers. The manufacturers cement these relationships by sending mid-career managers to high-level positions in supplier companies or other members of a keiretsu. This means all parts of the supply chain can pool resources and also share information—thus once again cutting down on time-wasting. Even today Toyota can design and build a car twice as fast as an American-owned factory in Detroit.

Kenichi Ohmae、Kaizen 和共识

Kenichi Ohmae, Kaizen, and Consensus

如果精益生产代表了“日本奇迹”的核心，那么直到最近，另外两个成分也是不可或缺的部分：持续改进或改善的原则； 和共识，尤其是在应用于长期战略思考时。 Kenichi Ohmae 的工作提供了对这两个概念的洞察。

If lean production represents the core of "the Japanese miracle," two other ingredients were, until recently, also indispensable parts of it: the doctrine of continuous improvement, or kaizen; and consensus, especially when applied to long-term strategic thinking. The work of Kenichi Ohmae provides insight into both these concepts.

Ohmae 现在在日本国内最著名的是他试图建立一个新政党。 但他在世界其他地方成名

Ohmae is now best known inside Japan for his attempt to set up a new political party. But he made his name in the rest of the world

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

通过他在麦肯锡担任顾问期间所写的书籍。 与大多数大师一样，Ohmae 乐于在政治和经济领域的几乎所有主题上发表言论。 （在接受其中一位作者的采访时，他反复将自己与玛格丽特·撒切尔 (Margaret Thatcher) 进行比较。）在某些方面，这种多样性适合会说两种语言、骑着哈雷戴维森摩托车的博学者，他可能是一名核工程师。 Ohmae 对管理理论的主要贡献集中在他对全球化的看法（在第 10 章中讨论）和他对日本的了解。

through books he wrote while working as a consultant for McKinsey. Like most gurus, Ohmae is happy to pontificate on almost any subject within the realms of politics and economics. (In an interview with one of the authors, he repeatedly compared himself with Margaret Thatcher.) In some ways, this diversity fits a bilingual, Harley-Davidson-riding polymath, who could have been, among other things, a nuclear engineer. Ohmae's main contribution to management theory centers on his vision of globalization (discussed in Chapter 10) and his knowledge of Japan.

在这两者中，正是他对日本的了解奠定了他的声誉。 在过去的四分之一个世纪里，局外人，尤其是美国商界人士，对日本既着迷又害怕。 Ohmae 已经向他们解释了这一点——在他的书中充斥着日本公司如何运作的很好的内部例子，并且通常会在此过程中批评美国公司。 即使在他后来的“全球”书籍中，几乎所有令人难忘的例子，例如带有电控坐浴盆的加热马桶座圈的发明，都来自日本。 最好的章节往往涉及日本特色的概念，例如商业联盟。

Of the two, it is his knowledge of Japan that established his reputation. For the past quarter century, outsiders, particularly American business people, have been fascinated and frightened by Japan. Ohmae has explained it to them—showering his books with good insider examples of how Japanese companies work and usually criticizing American firms in the process. Even in his later "global" books, nearly all the memorable examples, such as the invention of a heated toilet seat with an electronically controlled bidet, come from Japan. And the best chapters tend to deal with characteristically Japanese concepts such as the business alliance.

Ohmae 将创新写得特别好。 以日本人的标准，他对特立独行有很高的欣赏度。 他赞成将研究预算分成三份：一份用于常规研究（赶上竞争对手或试图让自己的产品更便宜），一份用于长期战略研究，一份用于外卡项目。 总的来说，Ohmae 推崇日本人通过持续改进生产新产品的方式。

Ohmae writes about innovation particularly well. By Japanese standards, he has a high appreciation of the maverick. He favors splitting a research budget into thirds: one for routine research (to catch up with competitors or try to make your own products cheaper), one for long-range strategic research, and one for wild-card projects. In general, Ohmae exalts the Japanese way of producing new products through continuous improvement.

Ohmae 认为，如果创新要有任何用处，就必须为消费者增加价值。 他倾向于蔑视高清电视等大型研发项目，并乐于逐步应对挑战，尤其是在世俗世界中。 你能制造出更好的咖啡机吗——不仅仅是一台有很多花哨的小玩意，而是一台能真正煮出更好的咖啡的咖啡机？ 是的，我们发现，如果你添加一个净水器，因为咖啡的味道取决于水的质量，就像它取决于你如何过滤咖啡豆一样。 你能做出更好的相机吗？ 是的，如果你让它为你对焦（即消除破坏大多数照片的人为错误）并包括自动闪光灯。

Innovation, argues Ohmae, must add value for consumers if it is to be of any use. He tends to pour scorn on big R&D projects, such as high-definition television, and revels in meeting challenges incrementally, particularly in the mundane world. Can you make a better coffee machine—not just one with lots of fancy gadgets but one that actually makes better coffee? Yes, we discover, if you add a water purifier, because the taste of coffee depends as much on the quality of the water as it does on how you percolate the beans. Can you make a better camera? Yes, if you get it to do the focusing for you (i.e., eliminate the human error that ruins most pictures) and include an automatic flash.

大量生产具有大量微小改进的产品的策略非常适合精益生产。 毕竟一个

A strategy of churning out products with lots of minuscule improvements fits in quite nicely with lean production. After all, one

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

灵活的装配线的优势在于它可以很容易地进行更改以纳入新的见解并包括最近的创新。 这也意味着你可以用同样旧东西的新版本来扼杀你的市场。 这一过程的一个典型例子是索尼随身听，它有数百种形状和尺寸。 夏普和佳能等日本公司经常通过混合摄影和办公设备等不同种类的技术来抢占先机。 松下在东京的一个低档购物区测试其最新的便携式摄像机，以了解大众对它们的看法。 如果销售不景气，产品就会被撤回。 这种对改进的重视——通过快速更新车型和巧妙的添加，如化妆镜和间歇式挡风玻璃雨刷——帮助日本汽车制造商击败了他们的竞争对手。

advantage of a flexible assembly line is that it can be easily altered to incorporate a new insight and include a recent innovation. It also means that you can smother your market with new versions of the same old thing. One classic example of this process was the Sony Walkman, which came in hundreds of shapes and sizes. Japanese firms such as Sharp and Canon have often jumped ahead by mixing different sorts of technology, such as photography and office machines. Matsushita tests its latest camcorders in one of Tokyo's more downmarket shopping districts to see what the masses make of them. If sales are sluggish, the products are withdrawn. This emphasis on improvement—with its rapid updating of models and clever additions, such as vanity mirrors and intermittent windscreen wipers— has helped Japanese car makers outfox their rivals. By contrast, American and European manufacturers have seemed obsessed with finding "one big solution" in their research projects—the legacy, some argue, of the Apollo project.

日本管理的诀窍是将产品开发中的这种无休止的渐进主义与在参与开发的人员之间寻求共识的长期战略结合起来。 正如 Ohmae 指出的那样，西方公司以军队为蓝本，指挥清晰，军官（负责思考）与其他人严格区分，而日本公司则扎根于乡村公社。 3 “过于简单化了，”Ohmae 写道，“可以说在日本，村里的每个成员都是平等的，都是多面手。” 与其从上而下发号施令，日本公司更愿意将重点放在 nemawashi（建立共识）和 ringi（共同决策）上。 希望每一个决定都源于不懈的讨论，

The trick of Japanese management is to marry this relentless in-crementalism in the development of products to a long-term strategy of seeking a consensus among those involved in that development. As Ohmae points out, whereas Western firms modeled themselves on the military, with its clear lines of command and rigid distinction between the officers (who do the thinking) and the rest, Japanese firms are rooted in village communes. 3 "Grossly oversimplifying," Ohmae writes, "one could say that in Japan every member of the village is equal and a generalist." Rather than issuing orders from on high, Japanese companies prefer to put their emphasis on nemawashi (consensus building) and ringi (shared decision making). The hope is that every decision will spring from tireless discussion, since managers will be obliged to gain the enthusiastic support of their workers.

集体决策也影响日本的领导方式。 在美国老板傲慢和霸道的地方，他们的日本老板谦虚而退休； 在美国人居住的地方做决定，日本人更喜欢让自己做决定。 他们将领导力比作空气——它是生活所必需的，但却是无形的和无形的。 他们通过超越同事、虔诚地将团队置于个人之上来提升公司的地位。 一旦登上顶峰，他们就会通过共识而不是命令来领导。 领导者在会议的大部分时间里保持沉默的情况并不少见，而他们的下属则在争论利弊

Communal decision making also affects Japan's approach to leadership. Where American bosses are brash and bullying, their Japanese counterparts are modest and retiring; and where Americans live to make decisions, the Japanese prefer to let decisions make themselves. They compare leadership to air—it is necessary for life but invisible and insubstantial. They rise up the corporate ranks by outconforming their colleagues, religiously putting the group before the individual. Once at the top, they lead by consensus rather than command. It is not unusual for leaders to sit in silence throughout much of a meeting, while their underlings debate the pros and cons

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

的政策。 领导的艺术是预测团队的意志，而不是用个人魅力来激励组织。

of policy. The art of leadership is to divine the will of the group, not to electrify the organization with one's charisma.

日本的长期战略方法也不同。 在西方，专业的战略家帮助制定清晰明确的目标及其实施手段，一切都写在正式的计划中。 在日本，战略由整个组织松散地制定，并以愿景和使命的形式表达，而不是精确的计划。 在西方人看来，这是灾难的根源。 但是，根据 Ohmae 的说法，日本人可以这样做，因为这符合他们的终身雇佣制度。 因此，核心员工认同公司的长远未来。 日本人在不同部门之间轮换人员的习惯迫使他们像战略家一样思考。 由于每个人都必须从车间开始，因此高级管理人员非常了解其组织核心正在发生的事情。

The Japanese approach to long-term strategy is also different. In the West, professional strategists help formulate clear and definite goals and their means of implementation, and everything is written down in formal plans. In Japan, the strategy is loosely generated by the whole organization and expressed in terms of visions and missions rather than precise plans. To the Western mind, this is a recipe for disaster. But, according to Ohmae, the Japanese can do it because it fits in with their general system of lifetime employment. Thus core workers identify with the long-term future of the company. The Japanese habit of rotating people between different departments forces them to think like strategists. And since everybody must start on the shop floor, senior managers are well versed in what is going on in the heart of their organizations.

太阳照常落山

The Sun Also Sets

精益生产、共识和改善取得了非凡的成功。 到 20 世纪 80 年代初期，日本公司在从价格到质量的各个方面都将美国人打得落花流水，太平洋的天空一片漆黑，飞机载着管理人员前往日本研究索尼和丰田等公司。 书店的书架上摆满了《日本管理艺术》和《聪明人的改善指南》等书籍。 80年代后期，美国人眼睁睁地看着日本公司买下洛克菲勒广场、哥伦比亚影业、圆石滩高尔夫球场等美国图腾。 在《旭日东升》（1992 年）中，一部关于洛杉矶企业诈骗的惊悚片，迈克尔·克莱顿甚至对日本经理人进行了妖魔化的终极恭维。 美国人似乎对日本人的两种种族主义刻板印象很着迷： 他们要么是聪明的小亚洲人，生产出越来越聪明的小玩意儿，要么是狡猾的战略家，为了同一个未说明的目标而共同努力。 管理书籍——甚至是 Ohmae 的那些——只是强化了这些神话。

Lean production, consensus, and kaizen experienced extraordinary success. By the early 1980s Japanese firms were beating the Americans to a pulp in everything from price to quality, and the skies of the Pacific were black with aircraft carrying managers to Japan to study companies like Sony and Toyota. Bookshops filled their shelves with titles such as The Art of Japanese Management and The Intelligent Person's Guide to Kaizen. In the late 1980s, Americans watched helplessly as Japanese companies bought Rockefeller Plaza, Columbia Pictures, Pebble Beach golf course, and other American totems. In Rising Sun (1992), a thriller about corporate skulduggery in Los Angeles, Michael Crichton even played Japanese managers the ultimate compliment of demonizing them. Americans seemed obsessed by two racist stereotypes of the Japanese: they were either clever little Asians producing ever smarter gadgets, or fiendish strategists cunningly working together toward the same unstated goal. Management books—even those of Ohmae—only reinforced these myths.

到 20 世纪 90 年代中期，所有关于日本管理秘密的书籍都在二手书店里出售； 大前越来越多地以日本的批评者而不是日本的辩护者而闻名。 随着日本公司努力摆脱长期衰退和昂贵货币的负担，他们看到西方公司

By the mid-1990s all those books on the secrets of Japanese management were in second-hand bookshops; and Ohmae was becoming better known as a critic of Japan rather than as an apologist for it. As Japan's firms struggled to emerge from a prolonged recession and the burden of an expensive currency, they saw that Western companies

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

扭转了他们的局面，将他们需要了解的有关日本管理的一切知识都纳入了他们的系统； 现在是日本人必须向西方学习了。

had turned the tables on them, incorporating everything they needed to know about Japanese management into their system; now it was the Japanese who would have to learn from the West.

毫无疑问，西方——尤其是美国——已经迅速迎头赶上。 1980 年 6 月，戴明在自己的国家遭到唾弃 30 年后，由于 NBC 电视纪录片“如果日本能，我们为什么不能？”而被重新发现。 节目播出后的第二天，戴明的电话就响了，他的余生都在举办研讨会和受到美国老板和政客的宴请中度过，直到 1993 年去世。 在美国，全面质量管理是 20 世纪 80 年代最有影响力的时尚。 1987 年，政府设立了相当于日本戴明奖的鲍德里奇奖。 摩托罗拉是 TQM 最成功的采用者之一，它声称在 1987-92 年，公司的利润增加了 32 亿美元。 4 1989年，日本人甚至承认美国的

There is no doubt that the West—and America in particular— has caught up quickly. Three decades after he had been spurned in his own country, Deming was rediscovered in June 1980, thanks to an NBC television documentary, "If Japan Can, Why Can't We?" The day after the program was shown, Deming's phone started ringing, and he spent the rest of his life until he died in 1993 giving seminars and being feted by American bosses and politicians. In the United States, total-quality management was the most influential fad of the 1980s. In 1987 the government created an equivalent of Japan's Deming prize, the Baldridge. Motorola, one of the most successful adopters of TQM, claimed that in 1987-92 it had added $3.2 billion to the company's bottom line. 4 In 1989, the Japanese even acknowledged America's conversion to quality by giving an American company, Florida Light and Power, the Deming prize.

西方制造商也学会了“精益生产”的秘诀，主要是通过与日本公司组建合资企业。 随着福特于 1979 年收购马自达 24% 的股份，其高级管理人员获得了对马自达在广岛的主要生产基地的完全访问权。 5（福特现在拥有 33% 的控股权。）通用汽车公司与丰田公司在加利福尼亚成立了一家合资企业，将其生产率最低、罢工频发的工厂之一转变为生产力的典范。 日本“移植”在北美和英国扎根的轻而易举证明了精益生产并不仅仅在日本的土地上能够蓬勃发展。

Western manufacturers have also learned the secrets of "lean production," largely by forming joint ventures with Japanese companies. With Ford's purchase of 24 percent of Mazda in 1979, its senior managers gained full access to Mazda's main production complex in Hiroshima. 5 (Ford now owns a controlling 33 percent stake.) General Motors formed a joint venture with Toyota in California, transforming one of its most unproductive, strike-ridden plants into a model of productivity. The ease with which Japanese "transplants" put down roots in North America and Britain proved that lean production was not something that could flourish only on Japanese soil.

一些西方人改进了他们所学的知识。 摩托罗拉、克莱斯勒和玛莎百货等公司与其供应商建立了密切的联系，而没有使自己受制于经常困扰日本经连会系统的僵化。 “传统的经连会不再是最佳实践的典范，”生产商-供应商联系专家乔丹·刘易斯说。 “为此，必须向西方看齐。” 6 在某种程度上，师徒的角色已经颠倒了：即使是丰田也不得不求助于福特以探索如何改善其工程师与车间工人之间的关系，以及求助于克莱斯勒以了解“价值工程” —一种通过在不同型号中使用更多可互换组件来加快汽车生产的新方法。

And some Westerners improved on what they learned. Companies such as Motorola, Chrysler, and Marks and Spencer have formed close links with their suppliers without subjecting themselves to the rigidities that have often bedeviled Japan's keiretsu system. "The traditional keiretsu are no longer the model of best practice," says Jordan Lewis, an expert on producer-supplier links. "For this, one has to look to the West." 6 To some extent, the role of master and apprentice has been reversed: even Toyota has had to turn to Ford to discover how to improve the relations between its engineers and its shop-floor workers, and to Chrysler to learn about "value engineering"—a new way to speed up car production by using more interchangeable components in different models.

他们手中的世界太日本化了

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS All Too Japanese

许多人争辩说，在泄露了它的秘密之后，日本只保留对那些没有人想要的东西的专有权。 终生雇佣制度让日本公司过于肥大，而股东的软弱让一些公司无法集中注意力。 该国白领部门的效率仅为欧美同类部门的三分之二。 日本过度监管的经济阻碍了创新，并给企业带来了高昂的成本，例如过高的燃料和电信费用。 在西方蓬勃发展的软件和多媒体等“创意”产业中，日本远远落后，受到语言的孤立，并受到循规蹈矩的教育体系的阻碍。 日本的大学是昏昏欲睡的精修学校，不是创新的重要源泉； 和日本'

Having given away its secrets, many argue, Japan retains exclusive rights only to those things that nobody else wants. The system of lifetime employment has kept Japanese companies far too fat, while the weakness of shareholders has allowed some firms to remain hopelessly unfocused. The country's white-collar sector is only two-thirds as efficient as its equivalent in Europe and America. Japan's overreg-ulated economy discourages innovation and imposes high costs on businesses, such as exorbitant fuel and telecommunications charges. In "creative" industries, such as software and multimedia, which are booming in the West, Japan is way behind, isolated by language and hampered by a conformist educational system. Japan's universities are sleepy finishing schools, not vital sources of innovation; and Japan's banks are reluctant to invest in unproved companies.

让这些批评更具说服力的是，日本人和美国人都提出了这些批评。 如果日本要在计算机业务中生存，Mochio Umeda 认为，他是 Arthur D. Little 的顾问和主队的日本抨击者，管理层将不得不放弃“它的狭隘主义，它不正当的平等主义，它的内部导向，以及它压制个性和创造力的倾向。” 更老练的日本经理人在他们的图书馆里堆满了西方管理书籍，并在他们的谈话中充斥着诸如“裁员”和“再造”之类的词。

What gives these criticisms added bite is that they are being made by Japanese as well as Americans. If Japan is to survive in the computer business, argues Mochio Umeda, a consultant with Arthur D. Little and a Japan-basher for the home team, management will have to give up "its parochialism, its perverse egalitarianism, its in-group orientation, and its tendency to suppress individuality and creativity." The more sophisticated Japanese managers are stocking their libraries with Western management books and littering their conversations with words like "downsizing" and "reengineering."

日本人也开始质疑他们的两个著名优势：改善和共识。 在日本公司不断生产出同一产品的更智能版本的同时，美国公司一直在消费电子产品方面取得真正的突破，例如个人电脑和移动电话。 到 20 世纪 90 年代中期，尽管日本汽车拥有所有额外的小部件，但它们开始看起来都一样了。 事实上，额外的小部件使生产变得混乱。 他们需要的是更简单、更大胆的设计。

The Japanese are also beginning to question two of their famed strengths: kaizen and consensus. While Japanese companies have continued churning out ever smarter versions of the same product, American firms have been making the real breakthroughs in consumer electronics, such as the personal computer and the cellular telephone. By the mid-1990s, for all their extra widgets, Japanese cars were beginning to look the same. Indeed, the extra widgets were cluttering up production. What they needed were simpler, bolder designs.

同时，强调共识使管理外国人变得困难。 日本的跨国公司传统上专注于出口而不是海外投资，部分原因是他们觉得自己的制造系统太日本化了，无法在外国土地上生存。 现在，由于日元升值、对国外保护主义的担忧以及全球化，他们别无选择。 野村综合研究所预测，到 1998 年，将近 40% 的

Meanwhile, the emphasis on consensus has made managing foreigners difficult. Japan's multinationals traditionally concentrated on exporting rather than investing abroad, partly because they felt that their manufacturing system was so Japanese that it could not survive on foreign soil. Now, thanks to the high yen, fears of protectionism abroad, and globalization, they have no choice. The Nomura Research Institute has predicted that by 1998 almost 40 percent of

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

日本五个最大的电子集团的生产将在海外进行。 1994 年，丰田 48% 的汽车在海外生产； 到 1998 年，该部分将达到 65% 左右。

the production of Japan's five biggest electronics groups will be offshore. In 1994 Toyota produced 48 percent of its cars overseas; by 1998 that portion will be about 65 percent.

虽然基本的精益生产系统实际上已经相对容易输出，但仅仅让人们高效地制造东西往往是不够的。 许多日本经理人的文化不敏感有时会导致生产工人难以管理。 三洋电机以安全为由拒绝让 33 名流水线女工穿传统的穆斯林服装，在印度尼西亚激起了愤怒的罢工。 7 日本工薪族发现无法驾驭毛茸茸的艺术类型：见证索尼和松下在好莱坞的噩梦。

Although the basic lean-production system has actually been relatively easy to export, merely getting people to manufacture things efficiently is often not enough. The cultural insensitivity of many Japanese managers at times makes it difficult to manage production workers. Sanyo Electric provoked an angry strike in Indonesia when it refused to allow 33 female assembly-line workers to wear traditional Muslim dress, citing safety reasons. 7 And Japanese salarymen have found it impossible to manage hairy artistic types: witness Sony's and Matsushita's nightmare in Hollywood.

西方员工很难适应日本银行的两级管理系统：东道国的虚拟管理系统和日本管理层与其在东京的老板之间的真实管理系统。 他们总是在做决定，他们喃喃自语，结果却被来自东京的电传撤销。 1991 年，众议院兰托斯委员会关于在美日资企业的雇佣做法听取了一连串的抱怨：少数日本人与总部勾结，做出了所有最重要的决定； “宣纸天花板”横亘在非日本人和严肃的推广之间； 日本人以种族和性别为由进行歧视； 日本人不愿意听取外国人的意见。 共识，似乎，

Western employees have difficulty adjusting to the two-tier management system in Japanese banks: a dummy one in the host country and a real one between the Japanese management and their bosses in Tokyo. They are forever making decisions, they murmur, only to have them countermanded by a telex from Tokyo. In 1991 the Lantos Committee of the House of Representatives on the employment practices of Japanese-owned companies in the United States listened to a litany of complaints: that a handful of Japanese made all the most important decisions, in collusion with head office; that a "rice-paper ceiling" stood between the non-Japanese and serious promotion; that the Japanese discriminated on the grounds of race and sex; and that the Japanese were unwilling to listen to ideas from foreigners. Consensus, it seems, is only consensual if you are Japanese.

虽然宣纸上限阻止了外国人为日本公司工作，但仇外心理也阻止了有能力的日本人在国外工作。 由于担心离开总部一段时间可能会阻碍他们在晋升竞赛中的表现，许多工薪族将海外派遣称为“放逐”。 母亲们经常呆在家里，这样孩子们就可以继续在日本的学校上学，这种安排给家庭带来了巨大的压力。 那些在国外度过任何时间的孩子都面临着在学校被排斥和被指责为“有黄油味”的风险。

While the rice-paper ceiling has deterred foreigners from working for Japanese firms, xenophobia has also discouraged able Japanese from working abroad. Fearing that a spell away from headquarters may handicap them in the promotion race, many salarymen refer to overseas postings as "banishment." Mothers often stay at home so that children can continue in Japanese schools, an arrangement that imposes huge strains on families. Those children who spend any length of time abroad run the risk of being ostracized at school and accused of "smelling of butter."

日本在创新和国际化问题上的犹豫不决似乎反映出失败，不仅是特定商业领袖的失败，也是日本整个领导方式的失败。 当日本经济以每年 10% 的速度增长时，崇拜共识是件好事。 但经济不景气正在考验老板们做出艰难选择的能力。

Japan's dithering over innovation and internationalization seems to reflect a failure, not just of particular business leaders, but of Japan's whole approach to leadership. Worshiping consensus was all very well when Japan's economy was growing by 10 percent a year. But a flat economy is testing bosses' ability to make hard choices.

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

他们必须摆脱多余的工人（或至少让他们提前退休）并决定将重点放在哪条业务线上。 来自管理严密的西方公司的竞争意味着日本公司需要能够快速做出决策。 现在，日本越来越多地通过合资企业和海外业务与世界其他地区打交道，日本经理人不能再依赖只有日本同胞才能理解的决策过程。

They have to get rid of surplus workers (or at least retire them early) and decide which line of business to focus on. Competition from tightly managed Western companies means that Japanese companies need to be able to make decisions quickly. Now that Japan is becoming increasingly involved with the rest of the world, through joint ventures and overseas operations, Japanese managers can no longer rely on a decision-making process that is only comprehensible to their fellow Japanese.

东方遇见西方：混音

East Meets West: The Remix

日本的管理方式显然既有优点也有缺点。 但至少可以说，将日本排除在外还为时过早。 该国仍然是世界领先的卓越制造中心。 日本企业有化逆境为优势的天才。 由于日本缺乏自然资源，政府大力投资于教育。 两次石油危机和日元的几次急剧升值对工业和管理创新起到了强大的推动作用。 此前数次，随着日元大幅升值，日本对美国的汽车进口量下降； 每一次，丰田市都找到了使精益生产更加精简的新方法，并再次回到不起眼的底特律。

The Japanese approach to management is clearly endowed with both advantages and shortcomings. But writing off Japan would be, to say the least, premature. The country is still the world's leading center of manufacturing excellence. And Japanese businesses have a genius for turning adversity into advantage. Because Japan lacks natural resources, the government invests heavily in education. Two oil shocks and several steep rises in the yen have acted as powerful spurs to industrial and managerial innovation. Several times before, Japanese car imports to the United States have dropped following steep rises in the yen; each time, Toyota City has found new ways to make lean production even leaner and to come back to humble Detroit again.

这一次，日本的反弹不会是其战后显着转型的重演，因为 30 年来，日本人第一次走出国门寻求解决方案。 他们不仅要改进自己的管理模式，还要将其与西方的相结合。 在这方面的一位重要思想家是富士施乐公司的老板小林洋太郎，他在日本年轻一代经理人眼中堪称英雄，在过去十年的大部分时间里，他一直向同行坚持认为，他的国家需要协商一致的领导理念改变。

This time, Japan's bounce-back will not be a reprise of its remarkable postwar transformations because, for the first time in 30 years, the Japanese are looking beyond their own borders for solutions. They are not just trying to improve their own management models, but to merge them with Western ones. One important thinker in this respect is Yotaro Kobayashi, the boss of Fuji Xerox, who is something of a hero to the younger generation of Japanese managers and who has spent much of the past decade insisting to his peers that his country's idea of consensual leadership needs to change.

小林毕业于沃顿商学院，多年来一直担任一家美国公司合资企业的负责人，他认为日本老板必须学会如何做出艰难的决定，以及如何在公司内部和市场上“推销”这些决定。整个世界，以便员工和局外人都能看到令人不快的决定的逻辑。 他还认为，日本经理人需要一定程度的西方式专业精神。 领导者应该受到精心培训，而不仅仅是被允许从中脱颖而出

Kobayashi, who graduated from the Wharton Business School and has spent years as head of a joint venture with an American company, argues that Japanese bosses must learn how to make tough decisions and how to "market" them, both within their firms and in the world at large, so that employees and outsiders can see the logic of unpalatable decisions. He also believes that Japanese managers need a dose of Western-style professionalism. Leaders should be carefully trained, not just allowed to emerge from the

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

行列。 他鼓励富士施乐正在崛起的中层管理人员对战略决策负责。 他还喜欢派一些人参加美国 MBA 课程——尽管他小心翼翼地不给人留下公司正在变成美国殖民地的印象。

ranks. He encourages Fuji Xerox's rising middle managers to take responsibility for strategic decisions. He also likes to send a few on American MBA courses—though he is careful not to give the impression that the firm is being turned into an American colony.

小林希望在工薪族的灵魂中引入一种叛逆：日本的管理者应该挑战他们的商业模式，而不是无休止地改进它们。 小林本人的职业生涯受到访问美国阿斯彭研究所的极大影响，该研究所为商界领袖举办开阔视野的研讨会。 他现在在日本有自己的版本，商界人士坐下来聆听哲学家以及彼得·德鲁克等人的演讲，讨论从环境保护到管理方法的各种问题。

Kobayashi wants to introduce a streak of rebelliousness into the salaryman's soul: Japanese managers ought to challenge their business models rather than just endlessly improve them. Kobayashi's own career was greatly influenced by a visit to the Aspen Institute in the United States, which puts on mind-broadening seminars for business leaders. He now has his own version in Japan where business people sit and listen to philosophers, as well as people like Peter Drucker, and debate issues ranging from environmental protection to methods of management.

有尊严的撤退

A Dignified Retreat

难道小林只是荒野中哭泣的声音？ 考虑日本管理变革缓慢的两个领域：终身雇佣和多元文化管理。

Is Kobayashi just a voice crying in the wilderness? Consider two areas in which Japanese management has been slow to change: lifetime employment and multicultural management.

乍一看，日本企业极力坚持“终生工作”的理念，不惜一切代价为冗余人员寻找新工作。 在本田，甚至可以找到男性经理来代替传统的办公室女士提供咖啡。 为了避免不得不解雇员工，公司正在削减奖金、阻止员工加班并停止招聘。 过去，日产每年招聘 1,500 至 2,000 名新员工； 它在 1995 年只雇用了 55 名员工。如今，日本的毕业生焦急地研究着每年公布的公司年龄概况，看看他们是否有任何职业机会。

At first sight, Japanese companies have tried hard to hang on to the idea of a "job for life," doing anything to find new jobs for redundant personnel. In Honda it is even possible to find male managers serving coffee in place of the traditional office ladies. To avoid having to fire people, companies are cutting back on bonuses, preventing workers from working overtime, and freezing recruitment. Nissan used to recruit between 1,500 and 2,000 new workers a year; it hired only 55 in 1995. Nowadays, Japanese graduates anxiously study the age profiles of companies, which are published annually, to see if they have any chance of a career.

然而有运动。 西方式的评估程序正悄悄进入日本的大公司，工作也不像过去那么安全了。 尽管他们忠于终身雇佣的概念，但公司正在重新定义这个词，认为它只适用于一部分工人，并尽可能减少这一比例。 日本银行引入了一种“不升不降”的制度：那些在 40 岁之前没有达到等级的人会被送走，去经营当地的银行。 丰田已经开始将 50 岁的经理从监督工作转移到“个人工作”。 还有一些公司正在为其终身雇员引入“自愿”提前退休。 日产削减其

Yet there is movement. Western-style assessment procedures are creeping into big Japanese firms, and jobs are not as safe as they used to be. Despite their loyalty to the concept of lifetime employment, firms are redefining the phrase, arguing that it applied only to a proportion of workers and whittling down that proportion as far as they can. Japanese banks have introduced a system of "up or out": those who do not make the grade by the age of 40 are sent away to run local banks. Toyota has taken to moving 50-year-old managers from supervisory jobs to "individual work." And a few are introducing "voluntary" early retirement for their lifetime employees. Nissan cut its

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

1993-95 年劳动力减少 5,000 人，其中大部分损失落在白领工人身上。 电子公司东芝将在 1992 年至 1997 年间将其总部员工人数减少 30%，同时将更多权力下放给一线员工。 （“小、简单、快速、战略”是其最新的座右铭。）丰田声称将其白领劳动力减少 20%，尽管这种减少的秘诀似乎是在部门之间调整人员。

workforce by 5,000 in 1993-95, with the majority of the losses falling on white-collar workers. Toshiba, an electronics company, will have reduced the size of its headquarters staff by 30 percent between 1992 and 1997, delegating more power to front-line workers as it does so. ("Small, simple, speedy, strategic" is its latest motto.) Toyota claims to be reducing its white-collar workforce by 20 percent, though the secret of this reduction seems to be shuffling people between departments.

至于与外籍员工打交道的问题，最好的日本企业当然已经开始用“多元文化跨国公司”的口号说话了。 NEC 正将其所有产品“置于全球视野中，以确定最合适的设计、制造和销售地点”。 8 Matsushita 曾经是其大本营最热心的捍卫者之一，现在已经决定自己是一家“多本地化公司”，并谈到要成为“全球网络管理者”。 9 日产热衷于营造“全球团队精神”，并谈到将整个世界作为“知识库”。

As for the problem of dealing with foreign staff, the best Japanese companies have certainly begun to talk like "multicultural multinationals." NEC is putting all its products "into a global perspective in order to determine the most appropriate locations for design, manufacturing and sales." 8 Matsushita, once one of the keenest defenders of its home base, has now decided that it is a "multilocal" and talks about being a "global network manager." 9 Nissan is keen on creating a "global team spirit" and talks about using the entire world as a "knowledge base."

有迹象表明这不仅仅是空谈。 越来越多的日本蓝筹公司将外国经理人带到日本。 丰田现在在日本境外举行股东大会。 东芝正在全球范围内重组从会计到技术管理的每一点工作，部分原因是为了消除重复，部分原因是不再存在任何纯粹的日本业务问题。 日本人也在建立全球网络，其中来自“第三国”的人充当日本管理的传教士。 东芝派遣泰国人到已经运营了 20 年的马来西亚工厂，向他们介绍日本的生产技术。

There are signs that this is more than just talk. More blue-chip Japanese companies are bringing foreign managers to Japan. Toyota now holds shareholder meetings outside Japan. Toshiba is reorganizing every bit of its work, from accounting to technology management, on a worldwide basis, partly to get rid of duplication but also partly because there is no longer any such thing as a purely Japanese business problem. The Japanese are also establishing global networks, in which people from "third countries" act as missionaries for Japanese management. Toshiba sends Thais to its plant in Malaysia, which has been operating for 20 years, in order to introduce them to Japanese production techniques.

思想的双向流动已经产生了结果。 例如，佳能和东芝都在英国设立了实验室，从而在音频技术方面取得了突破。 本田凭借本田雅阁从 1980 年代末的糟糕时期中恢复过来，这款车的设计部分是通过组织日本、美国和欧洲的工作室之间的竞赛来设计的。 10 该公司还将 60 名美国生产工程师及其家属迁往日本两年。

The two-way flow of ideas is already producing results. Both Canon and Toshiba, for example, have made breakthroughs in audio technology by setting up laboratories in Britain. Honda rebounded from a bad stretch in the late 1980s with the Honda Accord, a car that it designed in part by organizing a contest between studios in Japan, the United States, and Europe. 10 The company also moved 60 American production engineers and their families to Japan for two years.

多元文化方法的领导者之一（也是小林和 Ohmae 的另一个盟友）是 Minoru Makihara。 槙原出生于伦敦，就读于哈佛大学，曾在国外服役 22 年，英语流利。 他在家里很自在

One of the leaders of the multicultural approach (and another ally of Kobayashi and Ohmae) has been Minoru Makihara. Makihara was born in London, educated at Harvard University, spent 22 years serving abroad, and speaks perfect English. He is so at home in the

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

美国，他的两个孩子在美国公司工作，他的昵称是 Ben。 1992 年，他从国外应征入伍（这在一家日本公司是不寻常的举动），成为三菱商事公司的总裁，这是日本十几家贸易公司中最大的一家——或称 soga sosha。

United States that his two children work for American companies and he is known hy the nickname Ben. In 1992 he was drafted from abroad (an unusual move in a Japanese company) to become president of Mitsubishi Corporation, the biggest of Japan's dozen or so trading companies—or soga sosha.

过去，贸易公司可以作为进出口商生存，为在日本的外国人和在国外的日本公司提供代理。 然而，随着市场的开放，这一角色正在消亡。 三菱的未来，如果有的话，是作为一个更积极主动的全球交易撮合者，利用其人脉和人才在世界各地建立发电站和有线电视网络等项目。 自从 Maki-hara 出人意料地被任命以来，他一直试图强迫他的同事——但并不总是成功——以与他相同的方式思考。 他的第一个举措是要求他所有的高级经理给他写辞职信（以便他在必要时可以使用）； 如果他们称呼他为总统，他也会对他们处以罚款。

In the past, a trading house could survive as an importer-exporter, acting as an agent for foreigners in Japan and for Japanese firms abroad. As markets open up, however, this role is dying. Mitsubishi's future, if it has one, is as a more proactive global deal maker, using its contacts and its people to set up things like power stations and cable television networks around the world. Ever since Maki-hara's surprise appointment, he has tried to force his colleagues— not always successfully—to think in the same way that he does. One of his first moves was to ask all his senior managers to write him letters of resignation (so that he could use them if necessary); he also fines them if they address him as president.

牧原试图在公司提拔非日本人。 和小林一样，他是让西方思想家进入公司的热心支持者。 但这是一项艰巨的任务。 三菱的西方员工抱怨说他们签的是短期合同，而他们的日本同事则是终身工作。

Makihara has tried to promote non-Japanese in the company. And like Kobayashi, he is a keen supporter of letting Western thinkers into the company. But it is a hard slog. Western employees in Mitsubishi complain that they are on short-term contracts, while their Japanese colleagues have a job for life.

目前，像小林、牧原和大前这样的人仍然是例外，而不是常规。 但他们有三件事要做。 首先，日本经济正变得越来越全球化。 其次，他们最坚定的支持者是更年轻、更灵活的一代日本经理人，他们是在迪士尼和任天堂长大的，现在正步入成年。 最后，他们提供了一些新东西。 日本的管理可以改变，而不仅仅是西化。

For the moment, people like Kobayashi, Makihara, and Ohmae remain the exceptions rather than the rule. But they have three things going for them. First, Japan's economy is becoming ever more global. Second, their strongest supporters are among the younger more flexible generation of Japanese managers, who were bred on Disney and Nintendo and are now coming of age. And, finally, they are offering something new. Japanese management can change without merely becoming Western.

日本还能教给西方什么

What Japan Can Still Teach the West

世界各地的管理者面临的两个最大问题是迫切需要削减成本和更有效地管理知识。 尽管西方公司在这些领域取得了大部分进展，但日本经理人仍然可以教西方一两招。

Two of the greatest problems facing managers everywhere are the dire need to cut costs and manage knowledge more effectively. Although Western firms have been making most of the progress in these fields, Japanese managers can still teach the West a trick or two.

在削减成本方面，西方公司厌倦了再造、缩小规模和去层次化等粗野主义管理时尚。 迄今为止，日本企业明显更

On the cost-cutting side, Western companies are wearying of bru-talist management fads such as reengineering, downsizing, and de-layering. So far, Japanese companies have been noticeably more

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

在不破坏公司创新核心的情况下，他们比西方同行更成功地控制了成本。 这不仅仅是解雇更少人的问题。 日本公司鼓励全体员工帮助实现成本削减目标。 在许多公司的墙上都贴满了成本控制进展情况的海报。 在光学公司 Topcon，口号是“预算就是上帝”。

successful than their Western peers at controlling costs without tearing out the innovative heart of a company. This is not just a matter of having sacked fewer people. Japanese firms have encouraged the entire workforce to help in reaching cost-reduction targets. In many companies the walls are decorated with posters showing progress in cost control. At Topcon, an optical company, the slogan is "The budget is God."

这种集体精神显然得益于日本高级管理人员的自我牺牲态度。 相比之下，西方的高管薪酬近年来一直在无情地上涨，无论公司业绩或业务风险如何。 公众对这种做法的愤怒可能会为整个企业创造一个不太友好的政治氛围。 在日本，公司认为，当形势变得艰难时，老板应该是第一个牺牲奖金和薪水的人，然后再开始重组公司的其他部门。

This communal spirit has clearly benefited from the self-sacrificing attitude of senior managers in Japan. By contrast, executive salaries in the West have risen relentlessly in recent years, regardless of the performance of the company or the riskiness of the business. The public furor over this practice threatens to create a less friendly political climate for business in general. In Japan, companies believe that when the going gets tough bosses should be the first people to sacrifice their bonuses and salaries, before they start restructuring the rest of the company.

同样，日本人不愿任由解雇中层管理人员的意愿也可能对他们有利。 是的，日本公司往往迟迟不能区分小麦和谷壳。 但在日本人眼中，中层管理人员不仅是指挥系统中可牺牲的一环，而且对公司业务具有宝贵的见解。 特别是，中层管理人员将两种愿景结合在一起——高级管理人员的战略观点和一线员工的详细运营观点。

Similarly, the Japanese reluctance to sack middle managers willy-nilly may also rebound in their favor. Yes, Japanese firms have often been slow to separate the wheat from the chaff. But in Japanese eyes, the middle manager is not just an expendable link in the chain of command but a possessor of a valuable perspective on a company's business. In particular, the middle manager knits together two visions—the strategic view of senior managers and the detailed operational view of front-line workers.

至于供应商，毫无疑问，日本大公司对待他们的方式比以往更加粗暴（而且比他们自己的员工更加粗暴）。 这种新趋势甚至还有一个名称——shitauke ijirne，即“分包商欺凌”。 1989-94 年中小型企业裁员近 200 万，许多企业倒闭。 Otaku 位于东京东部，曾经是一个由小作坊组成的繁华地区，现在已经成为昔日的影子，一个接一个的生意都被挤死了。 1995 年 7 月 25 日，松下的一位分包商告诉《华尔街日报》：“我们只是汗流浃背，直到皮包骨。” 另一方面，《华尔街日报》的非凡之处在于 s story 是一个故事。 在欧洲或美国，供应商已经习惯了挨打。 在日本，它们直到最近才受到保护。

As for suppliers, there seems little doubt that big Japanese companies treat them more roughly than they used to (and much more roughly than their own employees). There is even a name for the new trend— shitauke ijirne, or "subcontractor bullying." Small and midsize businesses shed nearly two million jobs in 1989-94, with many businesses going under. Otaku, in the east of Tokyo, once a bustling area of tiny workshops, is now a shadow of its former self, as business after business has been squeezed to death. "We just sweat and sweat until we're all skin and bones," one of Matsushita's subcontractors told The Wall Street Journal on July 25, 1995. "Subcontractors like us are becoming weaker, while assemblers like Matsushita are amassing strength." On the other hand, what was remarkable about the Journal's story was that it was a story. In Europe or America, suppliers are used to being battered. In Japan, they have until recently been protected.

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

鉴于美国人一直是从软件到娱乐等众多知识密集型行业的领导者，建议日本人可以帮助西方公司管理知识似乎有些奇怪。 尽管如此，日本新一代的管理思想家，尤其是日都桥大学的野中郁次郎和竹内博孝认为，日本人仍然具有一定的优势。 他们承认，西方公司在管理可以通过传真或电子邮件发送的正式、明确的知识方面远远领先于日本公司。 （在微软，一线员工平均每天收到 50 封电子邮件，而比尔盖茨收到 200 封；在许多最好的日本公司，电子邮件仍未安装。）但是，他们补充说，

It may seem strange to suggest the Japanese can help Western firms manage knowledge, given that Americans have been the leaders in so many knowledge-intensive industries, from software to entertainment. Nevertheless, a new generation of Japanese management thinkers, particularly Ikujiro Nonaka and Hirotaka Takeuchi of Hi-totsubashi University, argue that the Japanese still have certain advantages. Western companies, they admit, are well ahead of the Japanese in managing the sort of formal, explicit knowledge that can be faxed or E-mailed. (At Microsoft, front-line employees receive an average of 50 E-mail messages a day and Bill Gates receives 200; at many of the best Japanese companies E-mail has still not been installed.) But, they add, the Japanese are better at managing tacit knowledge—the informal occupational lore generated by workers grappling with everyday problems and passed on in cafeterias.

这种技能使公司能够利用大部分员工的洞察力，并确保一个人的直觉可以成为整个公司的竞争优势。 最重要的技巧是鼓励员工尽可能多地在一起，无论是非正式的还是正式的。 公司通常将员工分成几个小组，通常希望他们能连续多年与同一位同事共事。 新员工与“导师”或“团队领导”密切合作，从他们那里学到的东西远远超过从正规培训课程中学到的东西。 下班后的饮酒会和乡村静修会在促进非正式理解方面发挥着重要作用。 一些公司谈论“nommunication”，这个词由日语中的饮酒 (nomu) 和交流词组成。

This skill allows companies to tap into the insights of the bulk of their employees and ensures that one man's hunch can become an entire firm's competitive advantage. The most important trick is to encourage workers to spend as much time as possible together, informally as well as formally. Companies routinely divide workers into teams, often expecting them to stick with the same colleagues for years on end. New recruits work closely with "mentors" or "team leaders," learning far more from them than they do from formal training courses. After-work drinking sessions and country retreats play an important part in promoting informal understanding. Some companies talk of "nommunication," a word that is made up of the Japanese word for drinking (nomu) and communication. 11 Honda and Canon both make frequent use of "brainstorming camps"—informal meetings in country inns in which project-development teams (and anybody else who wants to contribute) work intensively on a project, but also drink sake, share meals, and even bathe together in hot springs.

这些会议不仅有助于促进员工之间的信任，而且有助于激发聪明的想法。 正是在其中一次会议上，来自佳能的一个团队试图制造一台微型复印机，他们想出了解决困扰他们几个月的问题的方法：如何处理鼓的维修费用。 为这个问题琢磨了一个上午，组长派人去喝啤酒。 当大家喝啤酒时，话题转向了制作一个一次性罐头要花多少钱的问题。 这

These sessions are useful not only for promoting trust between workers but also for sparking bright ideas. It was at one of these sessions that a team from Canon, trying to make a mini-photocopier, hit upon the solution to a problem that had been troubling them for months: what to do about the expense of repairing the drum. After a morning puzzling over this problem, the team leader sent out for some beer. As the group drank the beer, the conversation turned to the question of how much it costs to make a disposable can. This

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

灵机一动：为什么不给复印机配备一个一次性的罐形鼓。 12

sparked off an idea: why not equip the photocopier with a disposable can-shaped drum. 12

非正式知识的来源也存在于公司外部。 试图开发自动面包机的松下团队负责人决定，最好的面包来自大阪国际酒店。 于是她拜师于面包师傅，观察他的工作方式。 经过数周的学习，她意识到制作完美面包的秘诀不仅在于揉面团，还在于扭转面团。 她确定她的机器可以模仿这种动作组合。

Sources of informal knowledge exist outside the company too. The head of a team at Matsushita trying to develop an automatic breadmaker decided that the best bread came from the Osaka International Hotel. So she apprenticed herself to the head baker and watched the way he worked. After weeks of study, she realized that the secret of making perfect bread was not just kneading the dough, but also twisting it. She made certain that her machine could imitate this combination of movements.

隐性知识的要点在于它始终存在：公司不必创造它，而是消除阻碍它在当地流动的障碍。 花王是一家化学品和化妆品公司，所有会议都公开举行，任何人都可以随意参加。 行政楼层的一半面积被分配给“决策室”。 花王的季度研发会议定期吸引约 1,800 人（在 7,000 名员工中）。 公司还鼓励客户打电话提出建议和投诉：公司每年接到大约 50,000 个电话。 它还建立了一个计算机网络，让所有员工，无论多么低级，都可以访问除了最敏感的个人信息之外的所有信息。 就连总统的开支账目也是公开的。

The point about tacit knowledge is that it is always there: a company does not have to create it but rather remove barriers that prevent it from flowing around the place. Kao, a chemicals and cosmetics company, holds all its meetings in the open, allowing anybody to drop in if they feel like it. Half the floor space on the executive floor is given over to a "decision-making room." Kao's quarterly R&D conference regularly attracts some 1,800 people (out of a workforce of 7,000). The company also encourages customers to phone in with suggestions and complaints: it receives some 50,000 calls a year. It also set up a computer network that gives all employees, however lowly, access to all but the most sensitive personal information. Even the president's expense account is on public view.

隐性知识的一个问题是，即使人们使用同一种语言，也很难跨境转移。 （正如任何住在加利福尼亚的英国人都会告诉你的那样，讽刺几乎不会跨越大西洋，也从未跨越过落基山脉。）尽管日本公司在从其外国子公司汲取创意方面相当薄弱，但事实证明它们是相当有能力的老师——特别是关于制造业的隐性知识。 在远至德比郡和田纳西州的地方，当地工人正在使用“日本”方法为国内市场生产丰田和日产汽车，并且在质量和效率方面经常与日本工厂竞争。

One problem with implicit knowledge is that it is difficult to transfer across borders even when people share the same language. (As any Englishman who has lived in California will tell you, irony barely travels across the Atlantic and has never crossed the Rockies.) Although Japanese companies have been fairly weak at extracting ideas from their foreign subsidiaries, they have proved to be fairly capable teachers—particularly of tacit knowledge about manufacturing. In places as far apart as Derbyshire and Tennessee, local workers are using "Japanese" methods to produce Toyotas and Nissans for their domestic markets and often give plants in Japan a run for their money when it comes to quality and efficiency.

转向日本人

Turning Japanese

虽然像隐性知识这样的概念目前听起来可能很模糊和陌生，但西方的管理者如果忽视它们就太愚蠢了。 在某些方面，世界正变得越来越像日本，而不是

Although ideas like tacit knowledge might sound vague and unfamiliar at the moment, Western managers would be foolish to ignore them. In some ways, the world is becoming more like Japan, not

日本管理的艺术

The Art of Japanese Management

不那么。 即使是最成功的西方公司也无法再像通用汽车或 IBM 曾经那样主宰整个市场。 他们还发现，他们从新产品中赚钱的时间越来越少。 相比之下，最好的日本公司习惯于过度拥挤的市场和即时模仿。 日本有 9 家汽车公司，而美国只有 3 家。 在日本，没有什么是长久的秘密：消息在学校聚会和与供应商的会议上泄露。 日本公司一直生活在一些管理思想家称之为“超级竞争”的世界中。

less so. Even the most successful Western companies can no longer dominate entire markets in the way that General Motors or IBM once did. They are also finding that they have less and less time to make money out of a new product. By contrast, the best Japanese firms are used to overcrowded markets and instant imitation. Japan has nine car companies whereas the United States has only three. Nothing remains secret in Japan for long: word leaks out at school reunions and through meetings with suppliers. Japanese firms have always lived in a world of what some management thinkers call "hypercompetition."

但是，现在没有时间回到 1980 年代初期对日本的原始崇拜，他们的“质量圈”、晨间健美操和每年三次到丰田市的朝圣。 日本公司在美国最具创造力的公司中似乎存在的“离奇”思维方面过于臃肿和无能。 但在小林和大前等人的指导下，他们显然学得很快； 在某些事情上，他们比西方的竞争对手做得更好。 正如西方人过去所了解的那样，始终值得至少关注东方。

But this is no time to go back to the crude Japan worship of the early 1980s, with their "quality circles," morning calisthenics, and thrice-yearly pilgrimages to Toyota City. Japanese companies are too bloated and too inept at the "off-the-wall" thinking that seems to go on in America's most inventive companies. But they are clearly learning fast, under the tutelage of men like Kobayashi and Ohmae; and there are some things that they do much better than their rivals in the West. As Westerners have learned in the past, it is always worth keeping at least one eye on the East.

第十二章

CHAPTER 12

o

o

任何怀疑中国变化有多大的人都应该花一个下午的时间偷听中欧国际工商学院 (CEIBS) 为期 20 个月的 MBA 课程的面试。 1 这所学校隐藏在上海广阔的工业郊区，号称是世界上发展最快的学校。 尽管该课程的费用为 4,000 美元（几乎是中国平均年收入的两倍），但它的 65 个名额吸引了 4,000 名申请者。 大多数受访者都在 20 多岁，他们表现出的干劲会让普通的哈佛 MBA 都脸红。 问“你的弱点是什么？” 一个回答“我太成功了”。 有几位年轻的创业者曾申请过中欧，但因英语不好而被拒绝； 尽管显然是从黎明工作到黄昏，但他们仍然找到了在夜间语言课程中补习的精力。

Anybody who doubts how much China has changed should spend an afternoon eavesdropping on interviews for the 20-month MBA course at the China Europe International Business School (CEIBS). 1 The school, hidden away in Shanghai's sprawling industrial suburbs, claims to be the fastest growing in the world. Although the course costs $4,000 (or nearly twice the average annual income in China), its 65 places attract 4,000 applicants. Most of the interviewees are in their mid-20s and exhibit a drive that would make the average Harvard MBA blush. Asked "What are your weaknesses?" one replies "I am too successful." Several of the young entrepreneurs have applied to CEIBS before and been rejected for poor English; despite apparently working from dawn to dusk, they have still found the energy to cram in nighttime language courses. Many of the best candidates are women: one, a tiny birdlike figure who works for a local textiles company, bosses around the panel of professors in a way that Margaret Thatcher's cabinet ministers would have found familiar.

然而，最令人难忘的候选人是一个身材高大的年轻人——就叫他​​“邓”吧。 他解释说，他的职业生涯被仔细地分为三个阶段，每个阶段都适合充分利用现代中国。 第一个是大学，邓以全班第一名的成绩毕业。 下一阶段是外贸机构的一份珍贵工作，因为它的“复杂”工作而被选中； 被迫解释他的意思，

However, the most memorable candidate is a tall young man— call him "Deng." He explains that his career has been carefully divided into three stages, each suited to make the most out of modern China. The first was university, where Deng finished at the top of his class. The next stage was a prized job at a foreign-trade organization, chosen for its "complicated" work; pushed to explain what he means,

亚洲新模式？

A New Model in Asia?

邓说有很多腐败（在这里他指着一块昂贵的手表时表现出短暂的自我怀疑）显然与邓无关。 现在他想去一所教授西方思想的商学院：“中国比什么都需要管理者。”

Deng says that there is a lot of corruption, though (here he shows a momentary sign of self-doubt as he fingers an expensive watch) obviously nothing that involved Deng. Now he wants to go to a business school that teaches Western ideas: "China needs managers more than anything else."

邓是有把握的。 到 1996 年，中国约有 80,000 家外国合资企业。 如果每个都需要四名管理人员，那么即使是中国经济的这个小部门也需要近 25 万名管理人员，但中国目前每年只培养 300 名 MBA。 即使加上那些在海外留学的中国学生和一些西方公司试图进口但通常不成功的在美国出生的华人，供求之间仍存在巨大的鸿沟。 1992 年至 1996 年间，上海管理人员的工资增长了 10 倍； 一些外国合资企业的管理职位的流动率约为每年 30%。

Deng is on to a sure thing. By 1996 there were some 80,000 foreign joint ventures in China. If each requires four managers, then even this small sector of the Chinese economy needs nearly a quarter of a million managers, but China currently produces a mere 300 MBAs a year. Even adding in those Chinese students who study overseas and the American-born Chinese that some Western firms have tried, usually unsuccessfully, to import, there is a dramatic gulf between demand and supply. Salaries for managers in Shanghai rose 10 times between 1992 and 1996; the turnover rate for managerial jobs at some foreign joint ventures is about 30 percent a year.

乱世对管理的渴求或许是一个极端的例子。 然而，即使在高度组织化的新加坡，南洋理工大学在其 MBA 课程中只能提供 125 个名额，它已经开始以每本 25 美元的价格出售招股说明书以阻止学生：它仍然收到 900 份申请。 麦肯锡增长最快的业务在印度。 在其他地方，麦肯锡的大多数客户喜欢对他们聘请顾问的事实保持沉默； 在印度，麦肯锡不得不恳求其客户不要购买广告空间来宣告他们已获得其服务的事实。 打开一份亚洲报纸，你本以为会有整版广告预告滚石乐队即将到来，但你会发现类似的广告宣传“世界上最具竞争力的人”迈克尔·波特， 正在路上。 另一方面，在一个报刊经销商实际上将诸如供应链管理新闻之类的出版物放在时代和花花公子之上的大陆上，与波特共度一个晚上似乎是一件大事。

Chaotic China's thirst for management may be an extreme example. However, even in hyperorganized Singapore, Nanyang Technological University, which can offer only 125 places in its MBA course, has taken to selling prospectuses at $25 each to hold students at bay: it still gets 900 applications. McKinsey's fastest-growing practice is in India. Elsewhere, most of McKinsey's clients like to keep quiet about the fact that they have called in consultants; in India McKinsey has to plead with its clients not to buy advertising space to proclaim the fact that they have secured its services. Open an Asian newspaper and, where you might have expected a full-page advertisement foretelling the imminent arrival of the Rolling Stones, you find instead a similar spread announcing that "the world's most competitive man," Michael Porter, is on his way. On the other hand, on a continent where newsagents actually put publications with names like Supply Chain Management News on top of Time and Playboy, an evening with Porter seems quite an event.

为什么亚洲很重要

Why Asia Matters

从西方管理理论家的角度来看，这一切都意味着非日本亚洲不过是另一个稍显热情的待教学生。 事实上，发展中的亚洲有自己的管理思想，在未来十年，这些思想将对管理理论产生巨大的影响。 比较

From the perspective of Western management theorists, all this implies that non-Japanese Asia is simply another slightly overenthusi-astic pupil waiting to be taught. In fact, developing Asia has management ideas of its own, and, over the next decade, these ideas will have an enormously powerful effect on management theory. The comparison

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

要记住（即使它最终看起来不太可能完全实现）与日本有关。 当日本汽车和收音机首次出现在美国时，美国经理人认为丰田和索尼打败他们只是因为他们有更便宜的劳动力或因为他们工作更努力。 正如第 11 章所指出的那样，现实是他们在管理上处于劣势，而美国人很快发现自己在模仿精益生产之类的东西。

to bear in mind (even if it is one that, in the end, looks unlikely to be fully realized) is with Japan. When Japanese cars and radios first began to appear in America, American managers presumed that Toyota and Sony were beating them just because they had cheaper labor or because they worked harder. The reality, as pointed out in Chapter 11, was that they were being outmanaged, and the Americans soon found themselves copying things like lean production.

如今，美国老板们抱怨从泰国、中国、印度和韩国等国进口的廉价商品。 他们是为了另一个惊喜吗？ 油嘴滑舌的回答是“规模不同”。 总的来说，发展中的亚洲要向既定的西方管理理论学习的地方要多于相反的方向。 即使亚洲公司确实在他们面前全力以赴，也不会是因为他们坚持一些容易模仿的固定文本，比如丰田的手册。 在非日本亚洲出现的新管理“理论”是本能的而不是智力的。

Nowadays, American bosses are grumbling about cheap imports from the likes of Thailand, China, India, and South Korea. Are they in for another surprise? The glib answer is "not of the same scale." On the whole, developing Asia still has more to learn from established Western management theory than the other way around. And even if Asian companies do push all before them, it will not be because they were sticking to some easily imitable set text, such as Toyota's manuals. The new management "theories" that are emerging in non-Japanese Asia are instinctive rather than intellectual.

然而，该地区至少需要关注两个方面。 第一个（一般）原因是其经济的绝对力量及其带来的机会。 根据世界银行的数据，1985-94 年世界上增长最快的国家是泰国（年增长率为 8.6%），其次是韩国和中国（均为 7.8%），然后是新加坡（6.1%）。 发展中的亚洲现在既在放慢速度，又在开放其国内市场，这使它成为竞争资本主义的驾驶舱，十几个不同类型的公司相互竞争。 其中不仅包括西方和日本跨国公司等容易辨认的野兽，还包括从中国国有企业到韩国财阀等鲜为人知的本地生物

Yet the region demands attention on at least two scores. The first (general) reason is the sheer power of its economies and the opportunities that they are throwing up. According to the World Bank, the world's fastest-growing country in 1985-94 was Thailand (which sped along at an annual rate of 8.6 percent), followed by South Korea and China (both 7.8 percent) and then Singapore (6.1 percent). Developing Asia is now both slowing down a little and opening up its domestic markets, which makes it something of a cockpit of competing capitalisms, with a dozen or so different sorts of companies battling away. These include not only readily recognizable beasts, such as Western and Japanese multinationals, but also less familiar local creatures, ranging from China's state-owned companies to South Korea's chaebol

这就引出了亚洲发展需要关注的第二个（特别）原因：海外华人创建的商业网络。 尽管这些与西方的管理理念几乎没有关系，但迄今为止，它们在世界上许多最具活力的市场中都力压群雄。 我们将会看到，华侨帝国的强弱与历史和人脉有很大关系。 然而，在其他方面，例如他们建立创业网络的能力，他们与地球上任何其他人一样“现代”。 从某些角度来看，他们中的佼佼者让我们得以一窥西方管理大师如此钟爱的松散“虚拟”公司可能会如何发展。

This brings us to the second (particular) reason why developing Asia demands attention: the business networks created by the overseas Chinese. Although these owe little to Western management ideas, they have so far managed to trounce all comers in many of the world's most vibrant markets. As we shall see, the strength of the overseas-Chinese empires has a lot to do with history and connections. In other respects, however, such as their ability to build entrepreneurial networks, they are as "modern" as any other on the planet. From some angles, the best of them offer a glimpse of how the loose "virtual" companies so beloved of Western management gurus might turn out.

亚洲新模式？

A New Model in Asia?

为什么要关注海外的中国公司而不是韩国的财阀？ 毕竟，听说过三星、现代和大宇的西方人比听说过郭鹤年或李嘉诚的西方人多得多。 还有更多的案例研究。 答案——这又是一个概括——是发展中亚洲的其他管理结构看起来像本书已经讨论过的管理结构的苍白（或精致）版本。 例如，财阀已经足够了不起，但在结构上它们类似于日本的经连会。 韩国人甚至跟随日本人进入相同的行业：汽车和电子产品。 同样，印度的大企业，现在从几十年的受保护市场中脱颖而出，遵循一种西方管理理论的官僚版本。

Why focus on the overseas-Chinese companies and not on, say, South Korea's chaebol? After all, many more Westerners have heard of Samsung, Hyundai, and Daewoo than they have of Robert Kuok or Li Ka-shing. There are also many more case studies. The answer— and this, once again, is a generalization—is that the other management structures in developing Asia look like pale (or refined) versions of ones already discussed in this book. For instance, the chaebol are impressive enough, but structurally they resemble Japan's keiretsu. The South Koreans are even following the Japanese into the same industries: cars and electronics. Similarly, the big Indian businesses, now emerging from several decades of protected markets, follow a sort of bureaucratic version of Western management theory. This may change—India is the one country in Asia that is stocked full of managers, and it has a particularly sparkling set of middle-sized companies—but as yet nobody is looking to India for ideas.

相比之下，海外华人创建的家族企业创业“竹网”不仅是另一种有趣的变体，而且是一种成熟的替代模式——而且看起来非常强大。 大多数西方人已经知道，台湾、香港和新加坡都聚集了大量有创业精神的华人。 现在他们开始意识到这些企业家已经变得多么强大。 在菲律宾，华侨只占该国人口的百分之一，却控制着一半以上的股市。 在印度尼西亚，同等比例分别为 4% 和 75%，在马来西亚则为 32% 和 60%。 欧洲工商管理学院欧亚中心管理学教授赫尔穆特·希特 (Hellmut Schiitte) 估计，到 1996 年，5100 万海外华人控制着价值 7 万亿美元的经济，

By contrast the entrepreneurial "bamboo network" of family businesses created by the overseas Chinese is not just another interesting variant, but a full fledged alternative model—and one that looks intriguingly powerful. Most Westerners already know that Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore are all heavily populated with entrepreneurial Chinese. Now they are beginning to realize just how powerful those entrepreneurs have become. In the Philippines the overseas Chinese make up only 1 percent of the country's population but control over half the stock market. In Indonesia the equivalent proportions are 4 percent and 75 percent, in Malaysia 32 percent and 60 percent. Hellmut Schiitte, a management professor at Insead's Euro-Asia Centre, reckons that by 1996 the 51 million overseas Chinese controlled an economy worth $7 trillion, roughly the same size as that of the 1.2 billion mainlanders.

这些资本主义的典范极难确定。 没有一家中国家族企业出现在全球市值最大的 100 强中； 然而，这些家族中可能至少有 20 个价值 50 亿美元或更多（相比之下，美国只能召集 10 个）。 就像商业冰山一样，大多数中国家庭只向外界展示了自己的一小部分。 1996 年初，可能是其中最有权势的马来西亚华人郭鹤年控制了香格里拉连锁酒店（市值：30 亿美元）和南华早报（11 亿美元），但他的大部分资产在中国、香港和环太平洋地区

These paragons of capitalism are desperately hard to pin down. No single Chinese family firm appears in the world's 100 biggest by market capitalization; yet probably at least 20 of these families are worth $5 billion or more (America, by contrast, can muster only 10). Like commercial icebergs, most Chinese families exhibit only a small portion of themselves to the outside world. In early 1996 Robert Kuok, a Malaysian Chinese who may well be the most powerful of them all, controlled the Shangri-La hotel chain (market capitalization: $3 billion) and the South China Morning Post ($1.1 billion), but most of his assets in China, Hong Kong, and around the Pacific Rim were

他们手中的世界

THE WORLD IN THEIR HANDS

隐藏在私人公司网络中。 1995年11月，新加坡商业时报计算出吉隆坡证券交易所的七大投资者都是华人。 其中最富有的是一位名叫林梧桐的赌博大亨，仅在吉隆坡就拥有价值 52 亿美元的股票。 《福布斯》、《亚洲周刊》和其他媒体此前对他财富的估计显示，他的总财富还不到这个数字的一​​半。

squirreled away in a network of private companies. In November 1995 the Singapore Business Times calculated that the seven biggest investors on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange were all ethnic Chinese. The richest of them, a gambling magnate called Lim Goh Tong, owned $5.2 billion worth of shares in Kuala Lumpur alone. Previous estimates of his wealth by Forbes, Asiaweek, and others had put his total wealth at barely half that figure.

这种信息的缺乏延伸到管理理论家。 到目前为止，只有少数思想家对中国的家庭资本主义非常了解：香港大学的戈登·雷丁是其中的佼佼者； Henri-Claude de Bettignies 在斯坦福大学和欧洲工商管理学院教授亚洲商业课程是另一个经常被提及的名字。 迄今为止，最全面的华侨书籍是由澳大利亚外交部东亚分析部编写的。 2 哈佛商学院的研究团队已经在努力迎头赶上。 大多数现有工作鼓励这样一种想法，即海外华人展示了西方公司所缺乏的所有网络和创业技能，例如“信任”和“灵活性”：他们可以根据需要或大或小，本地或区域， 利用他们现成的盟友网络进出市场。 最近出版的一本关于海外华人的书，Sterling Sea-grave 的 Lords of the Rim (1995)，开头引用了孙子的话：“Be so subtle to you are invisible. Be so mystery to you are intangible. Then你将控制对手的命运。”

This lack of information extends to management theorists. So far there are only a handful of thinkers who know much at all about Chinese family capitalism: Gordon Redding at Hong Kong University is the leader; Henri-Claude de Bettignies who teaches a course in Asian business at both Stanford and Insead is another much mentioned name. The most comprehensive book on the overseas Chinese so far was put together by the East Asia Analytical Unit of Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs. 2 Already research teams from the Harvard Business School are working hard to catch up. Most of the existing work encourages the idea that the overseas Chinese exhibit all the networking and entrepreneurial skills that Western companies lack, such as "trust" and "flexibility": they can be big or small, local or regional according to need, using their ready-made network of allies to dart in and out of markets. One of the more recent books about the overseas Chinese, Lords of the Rim (1995) by Sterling Sea-grave, begins with a quotation from Sun Tzu: "Be so subtle that you are invisible. Be so mysterious that you are intangible. Then you will control your rival's fate."

海外华人真的那么好吗？

Are the overseas Chinese really that good?

全家福

All in the Family

考虑一个典型的中国家庭资本主义的故事。 1994 年，新加坡商人理查德·萨维奇 (Richard Savage) 会见了一些朝鲜官员。 他将这些人脉传给了他的兄弟罗纳德，罗纳德在 Loxley 工作，这是一家由 Lamsam 家族控制的泰国公司。 Lox-ley 的业务范围包括环境工程、酿造、电器、发电厂、保健食品、化学品、移动电话、娱乐、房地产和六家计算机公司。 朝鲜被分配给家族中一位受过西方教育的年轻成员 Boonyakit Tansakul。 1995 年 10 月，在一次成功的晚宴之后，Lamsam 的高级成员

Consider a typical tale of Chinese family capitalism. In 1994 Richard Savage, a Singaporean businessman, met some officials from North Korea. He passed on these contacts to his brother, Ronald, who works at Loxley, a Thai firm controlled by the Lamsam family. Lox-ley's business lines include, among other things, environmental engineering, brewing, electrical appliances, power plants, health food, chemicals, cellular telephones, entertainment, property, and six computer companies. North Korea was assigned to Boonyakit Tansakul, a younger Western-educated member of the family. In October 1995, following a successful dinner where senior members of the Lamsam

亚洲新模式？

A New Model in Asia?

一家人会见了多位朝鲜政客，洛克斯利赢得了一份有争议的合同，为朝鲜新的罗津崇邦自由贸易区建设国际电话系统。 到 1996 年初，虽然拉姆森还没有看到这个隐士王国出一分钱，但文雅吉坚信，在十年内，拉金颂邦将成为“北方的新加坡”。

family met various North Korean politicians, Loxley won a controversial contract to build an international telephone system for North Korea's new Rajin Sombong free-trade zone. By early 1996, although Lamsam had yet to see a dollar out of the hermit kingdom, Boonyakit was convinced that within a decade Rajin Sombong would become the "Singapore of the North."
